contents:-     /**&#010;     * This plugin's descriptor&#010;     */&#010;    @Parameter(property = "plugin")&#010;    private PluginDescriptor pluginDescriptor;&#010;&#010;&gt;From there you use&#010;http://maven.apache.org/ref/3.2.3/maven-plugin-api/apidocs/org/apache/maven/plugin/descriptor/PluginDescriptor.html#getVersion()&#010;&#010;On 1 December 2014 at 07:35, Thomas Scheffler &lt;thomas.scheffler@uni-jena.de&gt;&#010;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi there,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I try to write a simple plugin. I want to have access to the version of&#010;&gt; this plugin. As maven already knows it, I wondered, if I can get access to&#010;&gt; this version string somehow without hardcoding it in properties or java&#010;&gt; code.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; kind regards,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thomas&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Martin Hoeller &lt;mar...@xss.co.at&gt;
Subject  :-versions-maven-plugin not updating properties any more
contents:- Hi all!&#010;&#010;I have two multi-module projects where the first one is a dependency of&#010;the second one. Usually before a release of the second one also the first&#010;one is released and the second one has to update the dependency-version&#010;which is set via a property.&#010;&#010;For this update I use versions-maven-plugin (v2.1) to do the update:&#010;&#010;  mvn -DincludeProperties=mylib.version versions:update-properties&#010;&#010;This used to work, when the released version was for example 1.0-beta-13&#010;and the new development version was 1.0-beta-14-SNAPSHOT.&#010;&#010;After I changed the new development version to always be 1.0-SNAPSHOT the&#010;update via versions-maven-plugin stopped working. I get debugging output&#010;like state from somebody else on StackOverflow:&#010;http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25034556/how-can-i-update-a-property-in-a-maven-pom&#010;&#010;For me this means version 1.0-beta-13/14 are found but than it says&#010;"current winner is: null" and leaves the version unchanged.&#010;&#010;Could this be a bug or am I doing something wrong?&#010;&#010;- martin&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Uber jar considered harmful?
contents:- I wrote this in 2011&#010;http://blog.artifact-software.com/tech/?p=121&#010;which describe our use of aggregation jars.&#010;It is, of course, focused on the wonderful advantages that these offer.&#010;&#010;It may have prompted the discussion that you recall so this might give &#010;you a time-frame to narrow your search.&#010;&#010;I may be wrong but I think that Stephen Connolly and Wayne Fay raised &#010;some issues with the approach. The word "anti-pattern" may have come up.:-)&#010;&#010;Perhaps this will jog some memories.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;&#010;On 01/12/2014 10:59 AM, Jeffrey E Care wrote:&#010;&gt; I seem to recall a post in the not too distant past where is was at &#010;&gt; least implied (if not outwardly stated) that the use of uber jars was &#010;&gt; an anti-practice. Name  :- Benson Margulies &lt;bimargul...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Uber jar considered harmful?
contents:- I don't know about 'harmful', but there are certainly some good ways to&#010;shoot your toes off.&#010;&#010;My convention is that I only use shaded jars as exports to the non-Maven&#010;world, I discourage using shaded jars as part of a larger dependency graph.&#010;I could detail some mishaps which motivated that convention if anyone cares.&#010;&#010;On Mon, Dec 1, 2014 at 11:36 AM, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I wrote this in 2011&#010;&gt; http://blog.artifact-software.com/tech/?p=121&#010;&gt; which describe our use of aggregation jars.&#010;&gt; It is, of course, focused on the wonderful advantages that these offer.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; It may have prompted the discussion that you recall so this might give you&#010;&gt; a time-frame to narrow your search.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I may be wrong but I think that Stephen Connolly and Wayne Fay raised some&#010;&gt; issues with the approach. The word "anti-pattern" may have come up.:-)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Perhaps this will jog some memories.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 01/12/2014 10:59 AM, Jeffrey E Care wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I seem to recall a post in the not too distant past where is was at least&#010;&gt;&gt; implied (if not outwardly stated) that the use of uber jars was an&#010;&gt;&gt; anti-practice. Unfortunately I can't find it now and my google-fu is&#010;&gt;&gt; failing me.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Am I making this up? Can anyone confirm my recollection?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Is there a best-practice recommendation re. uber jars that is generally&#010;&gt;&gt; recognized in the Maven community?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; *Jeffrey E. (Jeff) Care*&#010;&gt;&gt; Advisory Software Engineer | IBM Watson Implementations Release&#010;&gt;&gt; Engineering&#010;&gt;&gt; carej@us.ibm.com &lt;mailto:carej@us.ibm.com&gt;| External: 919-543-4907 | Tie&#010;&gt;&gt; line: 441-4907&#010;&gt;&gt;         &lt;http://www.facebook.com/ibmwatson&gt;&lt;https://twitter.&#010;&gt;&gt; com/@ibmwatson&gt;&lt;http://www.youtube.com/user/IBMWatsonSolutions/videos&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; President&#010;&gt; Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt; email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt; phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Uber jar considered harmful?
contents:- It all depends how you use them.&#010;&#010;There are some use cases where they make sense.&#010;&#010;Usually these use cases include aggressive shading of the dependencies you&#010;are bundling.&#010;&#010;Some cases where it can be useful:&#010;&#010;* If you are interfacing with a non-maven aware build tool chain - here the&#010;uberjar makes life easier for that toolchain as they only have one&#010;dependency to specify... the gotcha is if you make this the only way for&#010;people to consume then the POM aware build toolchains will end up with&#010;duplicate class hell&#010;&#010;* If you are creating an "App" or CLI utility jar file where people just&#010;run the file directly then it can be easier to give them a single jar&#010;file... but anyone else embedding your "app" will curse you if you only&#010;provide the uberjar&#010;&#010;On 1 December 2014 at 16:59, Benson Margulies &lt;bimargulies@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I don't know about 'harmful', but there are certainly some good ways to&#010;&gt; shoot your toes off.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My convention is that I only use shaded jars as exports to the non-Maven&#010;&gt; world, I discourage using shaded jars as part of a larger dependency graph.&#010;&gt; I could detail some mishaps which motivated that convention if anyone&#010;&gt; cares.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Mon, Dec 1, 2014 at 11:36 AM, Ron Wheeler &lt;&#010;&gt; rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; &gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I wrote this in 2011&#010;&gt; &gt; http://blog.artifact-software.com/tech/?p=121&#010;&gt; &gt; which describe our use of aggregation jars.&#010;&gt; &gt; It is, of course, focused on the wonderful advantages that these offer.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; It may have prompted the discussion that you recall so this might give&#010;&gt; you&#010;&gt; &gt; a time-frame to narrow your search.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I may be wrong but I think that Stephen Connolly and Wayne Fay raised&#010;&gt; some&#010;&gt; &gt; issues with the approach. The word "anti-pattern" may have come up.:-)&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Perhaps this will jog some memories.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Ron&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; On 01/12/2014 10:59 AM, Jeffrey E Care wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; I seem to recall a post in the not too distant past where is was at&#010;&gt; least&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; implied (if not outwardly stated) that the use of uber jars was an&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; anti-practice. Unfortunately I can't find it now and my google-fu is&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; failing me.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; Am I making this up? Can anyone confirm my recollection?&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; Is there a best-practice recommendation re. uber jars that is generally&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; recognized in the Maven community?&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; *Jeffrey E. (Jeff) Care*&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; Advisory Software Engineer | IBM Watson Implementations Release&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; Engineering&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; carej@us.ibm.com &lt;mailto:carej@us.ibm.com&gt;| External: 919-543-4907 |&#010;&gt; Tie&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; line: 441-4907&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         &lt;http://www.facebook.com/ibmwatson&gt;&lt;https://twitter.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; com/@ibmwatson&gt;&lt;http://www.youtube.com/user/IBMWatsonSolutions/videos&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; --&#010;&gt; &gt; Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; &gt; President&#010;&gt; &gt; Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt; &gt; email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; &gt; skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt; &gt; phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Jeffrey E Care &lt;ca...@us.ibm.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Uber jar considered harmful?
contents:- Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt; wrote on 12/01/2014 &#010;12:14:23 PM:&#010;&#010;&gt; It all depends how you use them.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; There are some use cases where they make sense.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Usually these use cases include aggressive shading of the dependencies &#010;you&#010;&gt; are bundling.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Some cases where it can be useful:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; * If you are interfacing with a non-maven aware build tool chain - here &#010;the&#010;&gt; uberjar makes life easier for that toolchain as they only have one&#010;&gt; dependency to specify... the gotcha is if you make this the only way for&#010;&gt; people to consume then the POM aware build toolchains will end up with&#010;&gt; duplicate class hell&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; * If you are creating an "App" or CLI utility jar file where people just&#010;&gt; run the file directly then it can be easier to give them a single jar&#010;&gt; file... but anyone else embedding your "app" will curse you if you only&#010;&gt; provide the uberjar&#010;&#010;Thanks to all who replied; this was the information I was looking for.&#010;

================

Name  :- &quot;Robert Scholte&quot; &lt;rfscho...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: AW: Problems with the release plugin
contents:- Just to be sure that we are on the same page:&#010;Your request is if the maven-release-plugin could be changed, so you can  &#010;specify versions for external (i.e. non reactor/multimodule) dependencies.&#010;I won't allow this unless it can be automated, hence the introduction of  &#010;the VersionPolicy. This is a first step towards a solution as asked by the  &#010;community, which asked for a better way to predict the next version(s).&#010;&#010;Robert&#010;&#010;Op Mon, 01 Dec 2014 00:11:46 +0100 schreef Christofer Dutz  &#010;&lt;christofer.dutz@c-ware.de&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; Oh well ... I give up ... so yet another plugin it will be.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I wasn't talking about changing anything at the workflow, just to have  &#010;&gt; one enforced constraint loosended a little if required, but I guess this  &#010;&gt; will never happen.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Chris&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -----Ursprüngliche Nachricht-----&#010;&gt; Von: Benson Margulies [mailto:bimargulies@gmail.com]&#010;&gt; Gesendet: Sonntag, 30. November 2014 22:22&#010;&gt; An: Maven Users List&#010;&gt; Betreff: Re: Problems with the release plugin&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The release plugin is a tool that does a specified set of steps. It's  &#010;&gt; built out of reusable components. Turning it into MS Word with&#010;&gt; 10,000,000 options is not, in my view, a good plan.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; If you can write down a clear spec for an alternative workflow, you can  &#010;&gt; study the source and make a plugin. That's what the owners of the  &#010;&gt; gitflow-maven-plugin did. It's an alternative release plugin with a  &#010;&gt; different workflow.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Sun, Nov 30, 2014 at 11:44 AM, Christofer Dutz  &#010;&gt; &lt;christofer.dutz@c-ware.de&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; Unfortunately the world isn't as ideal as I would like it to be. There  &#010;&gt;&gt; are sometimes constraints that lie outside of the reach of the  &#010;&gt;&gt; developer(s) working on the projects build.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; In one case the company I worked for desperately needed to release  &#010;&gt;&gt; parts of a multi module build separately. I know that this comes with  &#010;&gt;&gt; problems, but as long as no other option comes up to reduce the amount  &#010;&gt;&gt; of binary data of a new release having to be transfered over an Edge  &#010;&gt;&gt; mobile connection, they will have to do partial releases.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; In my current case the entire company is being switched from Ant to  &#010;&gt;&gt; Maven. Switching everything in one big step is completely out of the  &#010;&gt;&gt; question. The amount of simultaneous training needed for this is simply  &#010;&gt;&gt; not possible. So we have to go a migration path which brings us closer  &#010;&gt;&gt; and closer to the final goal of having everything in Maven and be able  &#010;&gt;&gt; to use the default maven-release-plugin. But till we are there it feels  &#010;&gt;&gt; like there is no way without patching this plugin in order to have an  &#010;&gt;&gt; easy transition path.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; What about some "legacy" or "quirks" mode for the plugin that allows  &#010;&gt;&gt; such a thing ... it might even output warnings and pages of text  &#010;&gt;&gt; explaining why this mode sucks and should be avoided. All I am asking  &#010;&gt;&gt; for is a way to use the plugin without having to hack it which  &#010;&gt;&gt; acknowledging that I know this is not ideal, but I am willing to accept  &#010;&gt;&gt; the consequences.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Chris&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; -----Ursprüngliche Nachricht-----&#010;&gt;&gt; Von: Benson Margulies [mailto:bimargulies@gmail.com]&#010;&gt;&gt; Gesendet: Sonntag, 30. November 2014 13:52&#010;&gt;&gt; An: Maven Users List&#010;&gt;&gt; Betreff: Re: Problems with the release plugin&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I'm going to attempt a summary here.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The release plugin has a requirement. It must be true that you can go  &#010;&gt;&gt; to the SCM, checkout a brand new copy of the tree rooted at the &lt;scm/&gt;  &#010;&gt;&gt; element, _change the versions_ in the pom(s), and run a build as  &#010;&gt;&gt; configured by the profiles and goals. If that's not true, the release  &#010;&gt;&gt; process will fail, and possibly leave you with a manual cleanup in the  &#010;&gt;&gt; SCM. There are many ways to set up a build that seems just fine but  &#010;&gt;&gt; fails this test.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The top of this thread is a plea for a 'dry run' that is a perfect  &#010;&gt;&gt; simulation of this, so that users can flush this out before it bites  &#010;&gt;&gt; them, and that it should not be hard to ask for this.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; It seems to me that it should not be hard, in a typical automated build  &#010;&gt;&gt; system (Jenkins, etc.) to set up a build that does exactly this.&#010;&gt;&gt; Checkout a clean tree, run the maven-versions-plugin to set a dummy  &#010;&gt;&gt; version, and run a build, with profiles and goals to match the eventual  &#010;&gt;&gt; release. Eat one of these apples every day, and you won't be visiting  &#010;&gt;&gt; the maven doctor so often.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; It seems to me that it should also not be terribly hard to make this a  &#010;&gt;&gt; feature of the maven-release-plugin.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; As a further wrinkle, there's the question of tag management, which  &#010;&gt;&gt; might be seen as interrelated to the lengthy threads here and elsewhere  &#010;&gt;&gt; about never, ever, deleting a tag. I wonder about yet another m-r-p  &#010;&gt;&gt; parameter: a staging SCM URL, distinct from the &lt;scm/&gt; stock  &#010;&gt;&gt; identifiers. m-r-p would pull from &lt;scm/&gt; but push to this other place.  &#010;&gt;&gt; Then, a human could decide if the release is real, and, if so, push the  &#010;&gt;&gt; commits and tag to the real, immutable, repo. I'm not qualifier to  &#010;&gt;&gt; judge whether this can work for anything other than git, but git sure  &#010;&gt;&gt; is popular.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- &quot;Robert Scholte&quot; &lt;rfscho...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: AW: Problems with the release plugin
contents:- Just to be sure that we are on the same page:&#010;Your request is if the maven-release-plugin could be changed, so you can  &#010;specify versions for external (i.e. non reactor/multimodule) dependencies.&#010;I won't allow this unless it can be automated, hence the introduction of  &#010;the VersionPolicy. This is a first step towards a solution as asked by the  &#010;community, which asked for a better way to predict the next version(s).&#010;&#010;Robert&#010;&#010;Op Mon, 01 Dec 2014 00:11:46 +0100 schreef Christofer Dutz  &#010;&lt;christofer.dutz@c-ware.de&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; Oh well ... I give up ... so yet another plugin it will be.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I wasn't talking about changing anything at the workflow, just to have  &#010;&gt; one enforced constraint loosended a little if required, but I guess this  &#010;&gt; will never happen.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Chris&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -----Ursprüngliche Nachricht-----&#010;&gt; Von: Benson Margulies [mailto:bimargulies@gmail.com]&#010;&gt; Gesendet: Sonntag, 30. November 2014 22:22&#010;&gt; An: Maven Users List&#010;&gt; Betreff: Re: Problems with the release plugin&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The release plugin is a tool that does a specified set of steps. It's  &#010;&gt; built out of reusable components. Turning it into MS Word with&#010;&gt; 10,000,000 options is not, in my view, a good plan.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; If you can write down a clear spec for an alternative workflow, you can  &#010;&gt; study the source and make a plugin. That's what the owners of the  &#010;&gt; gitflow-maven-plugin did. It's an alternative release plugin with a  &#010;&gt; different workflow.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Sun, Nov 30, 2014 at 11:44 AM, Christofer Dutz  &#010;&gt; &lt;christofer.dutz@c-ware.de&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; Unfortunately the world isn't as ideal as I would like it to be. There  &#010;&gt;&gt; are sometimes constraints that lie outside of the reach of the  &#010;&gt;&gt; developer(s) working on the projects build.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; In one case the company I worked for desperately needed to release  &#010;&gt;&gt; parts of a multi module build separately. I know that this comes with  &#010;&gt;&gt; problems, but as long as no other option comes up to reduce the amount  &#010;&gt;&gt; of binary data of a new release having to be transfered over an Edge  &#010;&gt;&gt; mobile connection, they will have to do partial releases.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; In my current case the entire company is being switched from Ant to  &#010;&gt;&gt; Maven. Switching everything in one big step is completely out of the  &#010;&gt;&gt; question. The amount of simultaneous training needed for this is simply  &#010;&gt;&gt; not possible. So we have to go a migration path which brings us closer  &#010;&gt;&gt; and closer to the final goal of having everything in Maven and be able  &#010;&gt;&gt; to use the default maven-release-plugin. But till we are there it feels  &#010;&gt;&gt; like there is no way without patching this plugin in order to have an  &#010;&gt;&gt; easy transition path.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; What about some "legacy" or "quirks" mode for the plugin that allows  &#010;&gt;&gt; such a thing ... it might even output warnings and pages of text  &#010;&gt;&gt; explaining why this mode sucks and should be avoided. All I am asking  &#010;&gt;&gt; for is a way to use the plugin without having to hack it which  &#010;&gt;&gt; acknowledging that I know this is not ideal, but I am willing to accept  &#010;&gt;&gt; the consequences.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Chris&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; -----Ursprüngliche Nachricht-----&#010;&gt;&gt; Von: Benson Margulies [mailto:bimargulies@gmail.com]&#010;&gt;&gt; Gesendet: Sonntag, 30. November 2014 13:52&#010;&gt;&gt; An: Maven Users List&#010;&gt;&gt; Betreff: Re: Problems with the release plugin&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I'm going to attempt a summary here.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The release plugin has a requirement. It must be true that you can go  &#010;&gt;&gt; to the SCM, checkout a brand new copy of the tree rooted at the &lt;scm/&gt;  &#010;&gt;&gt; element, _change the versions_ in the pom(s), and run a build as  &#010;&gt;&gt; configured by the profiles and goals. If that's not true, the release  &#010;&gt;&gt; process will fail, and possibly leave you with a manual cleanup in the  &#010;&gt;&gt; SCM. There are many ways to set up a build that seems just fine but  &#010;&gt;&gt; fails this test.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The top of this thread is a plea for a 'dry run' that is a perfect  &#010;&gt;&gt; simulation of this, so that users can flush this out before it bites  &#010;&gt;&gt; them, and that it should not be hard to ask for this.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; It seems to me that it should not be hard, in a typical automated build  &#010;&gt;&gt; system (Jenkins, etc.) to set up a build that does exactly this.&#010;&gt;&gt; Checkout a clean tree, run the maven-versions-plugin to set a dummy  &#010;&gt;&gt; version, and run a build, with profiles and goals to match the eventual  &#010;&gt;&gt; release. Eat one of these apples every day, and you won't be visiting  &#010;&gt;&gt; the maven doctor so often.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; It seems to me that it should also not be terribly hard to make this a  &#010;&gt;&gt; feature of the maven-release-plugin.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; As a further wrinkle, there's the question of tag management, which  &#010;&gt;&gt; might be seen as interrelated to the lengthy threads here and elsewhere  &#010;&gt;&gt; about never, ever, deleting a tag. I wonder about yet another m-r-p  &#010;&gt;&gt; parameter: a staging SCM URL, distinct from the &lt;scm/&gt; stock  &#010;&gt;&gt; identifiers. m-r-p would pull from &lt;scm/&gt; but push to this other place.  &#010;&gt;&gt; Then, a human could decide if the release is real, and, if so, push the  &#010;&gt;&gt; commits and tag to the real, immutable, repo. I'm not qualifier to  &#010;&gt;&gt; judge whether this can work for anything other than git, but git sure  &#010;&gt;&gt; is popular.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- &quot;Dutz, Christofer&quot; &lt;C.D...@ing-diba.de&gt;
Subject  :-AW: AW: Problems with the release plugin
contents:- Yeah well ... as I said, as the projects I had to work on fort he last few years, during the&#010;transition to maven there is no way to have all under controll of maven. So I will probably&#010;just create my own set of "multi-version" plugin for Maven and Ant and start using this completely&#010;dropping usage oft he release plugin.&#010;&#010;Chris&#010;&#010;-----Ursprüngliche Nachricht-----&#010;Von: Robert Scholte [mailto:rfscholte@apache.org] &#010;Gesendet: Montag, 1. Dezember 2014 20:00&#010;An: Maven Users List&#010;Betreff: Re: AW: Problems with the release plugin&#010;&#010;Just to be sure that we are on the same page:&#010;Your request is if the maven-release-plugin could be changed, so you can specify versions&#010;for external (i.e. non reactor/multimodule) dependencies.&#010;I won't allow this unless it can be automated, hence the introduction of the VersionPolicy.&#010;This is a first step towards a solution as asked by the community, which asked for a better&#010;way to predict the next version(s).&#010;&#010;Robert&#010;&#010;Op Mon, 01 Dec 2014 00:11:46 +0100 schreef Christofer Dutz&#010;&lt;christofer.dutz@c-ware.de&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; Oh well ... I give up ... so yet another plugin it will be.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I wasn't talking about changing anything at the workflow, just to have &#010;&gt; one enforced constraint loosended a little if required, but I guess &#010;&gt; this will never happen.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Chris&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -----Ursprüngliche Nachricht-----&#010;&gt; Von: Benson Margulies [mailto:bimargulies@gmail.com]&#010;&gt; Gesendet: Sonntag, 30. November 2014 22:22&#010;&gt; An: Maven Users List&#010;&gt; Betreff: Re: Problems with the release plugin&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The release plugin is a tool that does a specified set of steps. It's &#010;&gt; built out of reusable components. Turning it into MS Word with&#010;&gt; 10,000,000 options is not, in my view, a good plan.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; If you can write down a clear spec for an alternative workflow, you &#010;&gt; can study the source and make a plugin. That's what the owners of the &#010;&gt; gitflow-maven-plugin did. It's an alternative release plugin with a &#010;&gt; different workflow.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Sun, Nov 30, 2014 at 11:44 AM, Christofer Dutz &#010;&gt; &lt;christofer.dutz@c-ware.de&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; Unfortunately the world isn't as ideal as I would like it to be. &#010;&gt;&gt; There are sometimes constraints that lie outside of the reach of the&#010;&gt;&gt; developer(s) working on the projects build.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; In one case the company I worked for desperately needed to release &#010;&gt;&gt; parts of a multi module build separately. I know that this comes with &#010;&gt;&gt; problems, but as long as no other option comes up to reduce the &#010;&gt;&gt; amount of binary data of a new release having to be transfered over &#010;&gt;&gt; an Edge mobile connection, they will have to do partial releases.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; In my current case the entire company is being switched from Ant to &#010;&gt;&gt; Maven. Switching everything in one big step is completely out of the &#010;&gt;&gt; question. The amount of simultaneous training needed for this is &#010;&gt;&gt; simply not possible. So we have to go a migration path which brings &#010;&gt;&gt; us closer and closer to the final goal of having everything in Maven &#010;&gt;&gt; and be able to use the default maven-release-plugin. But till we are &#010;&gt;&gt; there it feels like there is no way without patching this plugin in &#010;&gt;&gt; order to have an easy transition path.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; What about some "legacy" or "quirks" mode for the plugin that allows &#010;&gt;&gt; such a thing ... it might even output warnings and pages of text &#010;&gt;&gt; explaining why this mode sucks and should be avoided. All I am asking &#010;&gt;&gt; for is a way to use the plugin without having to hack it which &#010;&gt;&gt; acknowledging that I know this is not ideal, but I am willing to &#010;&gt;&gt; accept the consequences.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Chris&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; -----Ursprüngliche Nachricht-----&#010;&gt;&gt; Von: Benson Margulies [mailto:bimargulies@gmail.com]&#010;&gt;&gt; Gesendet: Sonntag, 30. November 2014 13:52&#010;&gt;&gt; An: Maven Users List&#010;&gt;&gt; Betreff: Re: Problems with the release plugin&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I'm going to attempt a summary here.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The release plugin has a requirement. It must be true that you can go &#010;&gt;&gt; to the SCM, checkout a brand new copy of the tree rooted at the &#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;scm/&gt; element, _change the versions_ in the pom(s), and run a build &#010;&gt;&gt; as configured by the profiles and goals. If that's not true, the &#010;&gt;&gt; release process will fail, and possibly leave you with a manual &#010;&gt;&gt; cleanup in the SCM. There are many ways to set up a build that seems &#010;&gt;&gt; just fine but fails this test.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The top of this thread is a plea for a 'dry run' that is a perfect &#010;&gt;&gt; simulation of this, so that users can flush this out before it bites &#010;&gt;&gt; them, and that it should not be hard to ask for this.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; It seems to me that it should not be hard, in a typical automated &#010;&gt;&gt; build system (Jenkins, etc.) to set up a build that does exactly this.&#010;&gt;&gt; Checkout a clean tree, run the maven-versions-plugin to set a dummy &#010;&gt;&gt; version, and run a build, with profiles and goals to match the &#010;&gt;&gt; eventual release. Eat one of these apples every day, and you won't be &#010;&gt;&gt; visiting the maven doctor so often.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; It seems to me that it should also not be terribly hard to make this &#010;&gt;&gt; a feature of the maven-release-plugin.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; As a further wrinkle, there's the question of tag management, which &#010;&gt;&gt; might be seen as interrelated to the lengthy threads here and &#010;&gt;&gt; elsewhere about never, ever, deleting a tag. I wonder about yet &#010;&gt;&gt; another m-r-p&#010;&gt;&gt; parameter: a staging SCM URL, distinct from the &lt;scm/&gt; stock &#010;&gt;&gt; identifiers. m-r-p would pull from &lt;scm/&gt; but push to this other place.&#010;&gt;&gt; Then, a human could decide if the release is real, and, if so, push &#010;&gt;&gt; the commits and tag to the real, immutable, repo. I'm not qualifier &#010;&gt;&gt; to judge whether this can work for anything other than git, but git &#010;&gt;&gt; sure is popular.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;ING-DiBa AG, Frankfurt am Main. Subject  :-Re: AW: Problems with the release plugin
contents:- On Tue, Dec 2, 2014 at 3:08 AM, Dutz, Christofer &lt;C.Dutz@ing-diba.de&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Yeah well ... as I said, as the projects I had to work on fort he last few years, during&#010;the transition to maven there is no way to have all under controll of maven. I think you will discover that it is not so easy to change&#010;the release plugin to 'just relax a constraint' and still get a&#010;coherent result.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Chris&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -----Ursprüngliche Nachricht-----&#010;&gt; Von: Robert Scholte [mailto:rfscholte@apache.org]&#010;&gt; Gesendet: Montag, 1. Name  :- Deme Carv &lt;demec...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: What dos it mean: [WARNING ] Skipping because it does not denote a directory

Subject  :-Re: What dos it mean: [WARNING ] Skipping because it does not denote a directory
contents:- It looks more like a Spring problem with a bean definition.&#010;&#010;It looks like you have configured something that is looking for a &#010;resource bundle that you have not provided.&#010;&#010;In your build section you do not mention any resources that you want &#010;included in your war.&#010;&#010;When you look  at the deployed war, do you see the resource bundles?&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;On 01/12/2014 2:52 PM, Deme Carv wrote:&#010;&gt; contents:- Any last votes?&#010;&#010;You have 17 minutes!!!&#010;&#010;On 1 December 2014 at 22:55, Hervé BOUTEMY &lt;herve.boutemy@free.fr&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; +1&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Regards,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Hervé&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Le lundi 1 décembre 2014 07:54:56 Baptiste Mathus a écrit :&#010;&gt; &gt; +1.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Though I quite also like the comment about having some form of M on the&#010;&gt; &gt; chest (say like a superman S), but I'm late to the train here.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Le 28 nov. 2014 10:38, "Dennis Lundberg" &lt;dennisl@apache.org&gt; a écrit :&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; +1&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; On Tue, Nov 25, 2014 at 11:57 AM, Stephen Connolly&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; For anyone who has been living under a rock, here is the background&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Background&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; =========&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I think everyone can agree that the site needs a reorganisation and a&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; rewrite. Users cannot find what they need, and the end result is that&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; people keep on abusing maven rather than having maven help them.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Try as I might, I have been unable to motivate myself to do the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; reorganisation with the current dated look and feel of the site... I&#010;&gt; am&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; not&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; saying that picking a new logo and selecting a mascot will result in&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; making&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; progress, but it can't hurt and I believe it will help&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Proposed changes&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ===============&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; 1. Change the logo font to Alte Haas Grotesk Bold with italics&#010;&gt; applied&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; by&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Inkscape&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; 2. Change the highlighted letter from 'a' to 'v' and replace the v&#010;&gt; with&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; two&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Apache Feathers&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; 3. Adopt the (currently unnamed) owl as our mascot&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Here is a link to the font:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; http://www.dafont.com/alte-haas-grotesk.font&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Here is a large version of the owl and the logo:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; http://people.apache.org/~stephenc/maven-logo-contest/maven-owl-final-larg&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; e.png&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; A regular version of the own and the logo, e.g. a size suitable for&#010;&gt; use&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; in&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the top of the standard maven sites:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; http://people.apache.org/~stephenc/maven-logo-contest/maven-owl-final.png&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; (Note that in all likelihood, the mascot would probably end up on the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; other&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; side of the title bar from the logo... and that is IF the mascot&#010;&gt; ends up&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; on&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the title bar)&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Here is both of those rendered in a site (as it can be helpful to see&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; graphics adjacent to text)&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; http://people.apache.org/~stephenc/maven-logo-contest/maven-owl-final-cont&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; ext.png&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Logo Rational&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ===========&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; If we do some searches for the Maven logo:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; https://www.google.com/search?site=imghp&amp;tbm=isch&amp;q=maven+logo&amp;oq=maven+lo&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; go&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; http://www.bing.com/images/search?q=maven+logo&amp;go=Submit&amp;qs=n&amp;form=QBLH&amp;sc&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; ope=images&amp;pq=maven+logo&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Our current logo, with a single highlighted letter stands out quite&#010;&gt; well&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; from the other "maven" logos, so keeping a highlighted letter and an&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; italic&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; rendered font maintains continuity with our current logo.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; By changing the highlighted letter to the `v` and by using two Apache&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; feathers to create the `v`, we connect our logo back to Apache... we&#010;&gt; are&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Apache Maven after all.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The `v` is also the common short term for version (e.g.v3 is short&#010;&gt; for&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; version 3). Apache Maven puts a lot of emphasis on versions of&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; dependencies&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; and plugins... you could say that versions are very important to&#010;&gt; Maven.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The colours of the feather were changed to solid colours to match the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; owl&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; mascot's scarf, beak and eyebrows&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Voting rules&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; =========&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Anyone who is subscribed to the dev or users list is eligible to&#010;&gt; vote.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; If you vote multiple times, only your final vote will be counted.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The vote will be open until 1:00pm GMT on Wed 3rd Dec 2014&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The vote is for all three changes as one single change. Partial votes&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; (e.g.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; for the logo but not the mascot, or vice-versa) will not be counted.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I, as the caller of the vote, reserve the right to cancel the vote if&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; this&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; vote is putting the harmony of the community at risk.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; If a majority of the PMC believe that this vote is putting the&#010;&gt; harmony&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; of&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the community at risk, then the PMC may cancel this vote (though if&#010;&gt; even&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; a&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; small minority of the PMC were of that belief, I will more than&#010;&gt; likely&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; have&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; cancelled the vote before the PMC would need to decide... I'm just&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; stating&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; this FTR)&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The decision will be a simple majority, there will be no special veto&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; powers.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; +1: [ ] Change the logo to the proposed logo and adopt the owl as&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; project&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; mascot&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; 0: [ ] No opinion&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; -1: [ ] No change&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Please only respond with +1, 0 or -1. If you want to discuss the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; proposed&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; changes please use a different thread. This thread is for voting&#010;&gt; only.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; -Stephen&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; --&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Dennis Lundberg&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: dev-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; For additional commands, e-mail: dev-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: dev-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: dev-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Users cannot find what they need, and the end result is that&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; people keep on abusing maven rather than having maven help them.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Try as I might, I have been unable to motivate myself to do the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; reorganisation with the current dated look and feel of the site... I&#010;&gt; am&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; not&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; saying that picking a new logo and selecting a mascot will result in&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; making&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; progress, but it can't hurt and I believe it will help&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Proposed changes&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ===============&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; 1. Change the logo font to Alte Haas Grotesk Bold with italics&#010;&gt; applied&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; by&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Inkscape&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; 2. Change the highlighted letter from 'a' to 'v' and replace the v&#010;&gt; with&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; two&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Apache Feathers&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; 3. Adopt the (currently unnamed) owl as our mascot&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Here is a link to the font:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; http://www.dafont.com/alte-haas-grotesk.font&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Here is a large version of the owl and the logo:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; http://people.apache.org/~stephenc/maven-logo-contest/maven-owl-final-larg&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; e.png&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; A regular version of the own and the logo, e.g. a size suitable for&#010;&gt; use&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; in&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the top of the standard maven sites:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; http://people.apache.org/~stephenc/maven-logo-contest/maven-owl-final.png&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; (Note that in all likelihood, the mascot would probably end up on the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; other&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; side of the title bar from the logo... and that is IF the mascot&#010;&gt; ends up&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; on&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the title bar)&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Here is both of those rendered in a site (as it can be helpful to see&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; graphics adjacent to text)&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; http://people.apache.org/~stephenc/maven-logo-contest/maven-owl-final-cont&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; ext.png&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Logo Rational&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ===========&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; If we do some searches for the Maven logo:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; https://www.google.com/search?site=imghp&amp;tbm=isch&amp;q=maven+logo&amp;oq=maven+lo&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; go&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; http://www.bing.com/images/search?q=maven+logo&amp;go=Submit&amp;qs=n&amp;form=QBLH&amp;sc&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; ope=images&amp;pq=maven+logo&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Our current logo, with a single highlighted letter stands out quite&#010;&gt; well&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; from the other "maven" logos, so keeping a highlighted letter and an&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; italic&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; rendered font maintains continuity with our current logo.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; By changing the highlighted letter to the `v` and by using two Apache&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; feathers to create the `v`, we connect our logo back to Apache... we&#010;&gt; are&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Apache Maven after all.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The `v` is also the common short term for version (e.g.v3 is short&#010;&gt; for&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; version 3). Apache Maven puts a lot of emphasis on versions of&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; dependencies&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; and plugins... you could say that versions are very important to&#010;&gt; Maven.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The colours of the feather were changed to solid colours to match the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; owl&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; mascot's scarf, beak and eyebrows&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Voting rules&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; =========&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Anyone who is subscribed to the dev or users list is eligible to&#010;&gt; vote.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; If you vote multiple times, only your final vote will be counted.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The vote will be open until 1:00pm GMT on Wed 3rd Dec 2014&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The vote is for all three changes as one single change. Partial votes&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; (e.g.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; for the logo but not the mascot, or vice-versa) will not be counted.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I, as the caller of the vote, reserve the right to cancel the vote if&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; this&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; vote is putting the harmony of the community at risk.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; If a majority of the PMC believe that this vote is putting the&#010;&gt; harmony&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; of&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the community at risk, then the PMC may cancel this vote (though if&#010;&gt; even&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; a&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; small minority of the PMC were of that belief, I will more than&#010;&gt; likely&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; have&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; cancelled the vote before the PMC would need to decide... I'm just&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; stating&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; this FTR)&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The decision will be a simple majority, there will be no special veto&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; powers.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; +1: [ ] Change the logo to the proposed logo and adopt the owl as&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; project&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; mascot&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; 0: [ ] No opinion&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; -1: [ ] No change&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Please only respond with +1, 0 or -1. If you want to discuss the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; proposed&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; changes please use a different thread. This thread is for voting&#010;&gt; only.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; -Stephen&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; --&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Dennis Lundberg&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: dev-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; For additional commands, e-mail: dev-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: dev-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: dev-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

&gt; &gt; &gt; short&#010;&gt; for&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; version 3). Apache Maven puts a lot of emphasis on versions of&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; dependencies&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; and plugins... you could say that versions are very important to&#010;&gt; Maven.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The colours of the feather were changed to solid colours to &#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; match the owl mascot's scarf, beak and eyebrows&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Voting rules&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; =========&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Anyone who is subscribed to the dev or users list is eligible to&#010;&gt; vote.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; If you vote multiple times, only your final vote will be counted.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The vote will be open until 1:00pm GMT on Wed 3rd Dec 2014&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The vote is for all three changes as one single change. Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: [RESULT] [VOTE] Change project logo and adopt owl as mascot
contents:- Some nicknames&#010;Boo - since we started with a muti-cultural theme "hibou" is French for &#010;owl (Couche Tard is a chain that owns or operates 11,000 convenience &#010;stores that has an owl as its symbolso we had better not mess with their &#010;names)&#010;Ty (short for Tyton)- the family name for barn owls is Tytonidae - &#010;sounds like Titan (second order of divine beings noted for size and &#010;strength but got overthrown by their own children - the Olymians)&#010;Rap - the owl is a nocturnal raptor - "Maven Rapper"&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;On 03/12/2014 10:53 AM, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt; Vote threads:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/maven-users/201411.mbox/%3CCA%2BnPnMw%2Bn6KLx2Zg0R-d2_iWCyVYfKVYfGEzk7XGt08fU%3D0tMg%40mail.gmail.com%3E&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; and&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/maven-dev/201411.mbox/%3CCA+nPnMw+n6KLx2Zg0R-d2_iWCyVYfKVYfGEzk7XGt08fU=0tMg@mail.gmail.com%3E&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Results:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; +1: Stephen Connolly (pmc), Arnaud Héritier (pmc), James Green, Thorsten&#010;&gt; Heit, Raphael Ackermann, Dominik Bartholdi (committer), Maxim Solodovnik,&#010;&gt; Andreas Gudian (committer), Paul Benedict, Alexandre Bretet, Mark Struberg&#010;&gt; (pmc), Dan Rollo, Kristian Rosenvold (pmc), Karl Heinz Marbaise (pmc), Tony&#010;&gt; Jewell, Emilio Lopez, Hilton Wichwski Silva, Daniel Kulp (pmc), Anders&#010;&gt; Hammar (committer), Mirko Friedenhagen (committer), Olivier Lamy (pmc),&#010;&gt; Stephane Nicoll (pmc), David Hoffer, Dennis Lundberg (pmc), Baptiste&#010;&gt; Mathus, Hervé Boutemy (pmc), Eric Barboni&#010;&gt; -1: Stephan Krull, Ralph Goers(pmc), Michale Osipov (committer)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Total poll: 30 votes&#010;&gt; +1: 27 votes&#010;&gt; -1: 3 votes&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On the basis of a simple majority this proposal passes&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thank you everyone for contributing your opinion. The next thing is to&#010;&gt; decide if we want to give our mascot a nickname and if so what would that&#010;&gt; nickname be.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I will commit the artwork to source control later today.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -Stephen&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; P.S. if you voted and I mis-spelled your name or provided an incorrect&#010;&gt; association with the project, please accept my sincere apologies.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

And it underlines the power,&#010;&gt;&gt; yet the danger that comes from improper handling ;-).&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; And let's face it - the name just sticks. It already has, for some of us.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; "I call shotgun!"&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Am Donnerstag, 4. Dezember 2014 schrieb Manfred Moser :&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Shotgun ... we dont need a reason for a name and it is funny to use the&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; name that came up in the design discussion due to a visual hole in the&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; owl's belly ;-)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Ron Wheeler wrote on 03.12.2014 09:01:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; Some nicknames&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; Boo - since we started with a muti-cultural theme "hibou" is French for&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; owl (Couche Tard is a chain that owns or operates 11,000 convenience&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; stores that has an owl as its symbolso we had better not mess with their&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; names)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; Ty (short for Tyton)- the family name for barn owls is Tytonidae -&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; sounds like Titan (second order of divine beings noted for size and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; strength but got overthrown by their own children - the Olymians)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; Rap - the owl is a nocturnal raptor - "Maven Rapper"&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; On 03/12/2014 10:53 AM, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Name  :- Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.koloty...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-org.apache.maven.plugins.shade.resource.AppendingTransformer
contents:- Here is part of my POM&#010;&#010;           &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;             &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;             &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-shade-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;             &lt;executions&gt;&#010;               &lt;execution&gt;&#010;                 &lt;phase&gt;package&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;                 &lt;goals&gt;&#010;                   &lt;goal&gt;shade&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;                 &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;                 &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&lt;shadedArtifactAttached&gt;true&lt;/shadedArtifactAttached&gt;&#010;&lt;shadedClassifierName&gt;allinone&lt;/shadedClassifierName&gt;&#010;                    &lt;artifactSet&gt;&#010;                      &lt;includes&gt;&#010;                        &lt;include&gt;*:*&lt;/include&gt;&#010;                      &lt;/includes&gt;&#010;                    &lt;/artifactSet&gt;&#010;                  &lt;transformer &#010;implementation="org.apache.maven.plugins.shade.resource.AppendingTransformer"&gt;&#010;                    &lt;resource&gt;application.conf&lt;/resource&gt;&#010;                  &lt;/transformer&gt;&#010;                  &lt;transformer &#010;implementation="org.apache.maven.plugins.shade.resource.AppendingTransformer"&gt;&#010;                    &lt;resource&gt;reference.conf&lt;/resource&gt;&#010;                  &lt;/transformer&gt;&#010;                   &lt;transformers&gt;&#010;                     &lt;transformer &#010;implementation="org.apache.maven.plugins.shade.resource.ManifestResourceTransformer"&gt;&#010;                       &lt;manifestEntries&gt;&#010;                         &lt;!-- &#010;&lt;Main-Class&gt;platform3.AccountService.ServiceKernel&lt;/Main-Class&gt; --&gt;&#010;&lt;Main-Class&gt;akka.Main&lt;/Main-Class&gt;&#010;                       &lt;/manifestEntries&gt;&#010;                     &lt;/transformer&gt;&#010;                   &lt;/transformers&gt;&#010;                 &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;               &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;             &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;           &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;But when I look at application.conf and reference.conf in the JAR file, &#010;there is nothing appended to them. Clearly the AppendingTransformer is &#010;not working because I can see other application.conf and reference.conf &#010;files in the included jars.&#010;&#010;The ManifestResourceTransformer is working correctly, so I am not sure &#010;what is wrong with AppendingTransformer?&#010;&#010;Does anyone have any idea on what the problem may be?&#010;&#010;Cheers, Eric&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.koloty...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: org.apache.maven.plugins.shade.resource.AppendingTransformer
contents:- Never mind, I should have put the &lt;transformer&gt; elements inside the &#010;&lt;transformers&gt; element..&#010;&#010;Cheers, Eric&#010;&#010;On 12/3/2014 10:28 AM, Eric Kolotyluk wrote:&#010;&gt; Here is part of my POM&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-shade-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;executions&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;execution&gt;&#010;&gt;                 &lt;phase&gt;package&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;&gt;                 &lt;goals&gt;&#010;&gt;                   &lt;goal&gt;shade&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;&gt;                 &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;&gt;                 &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;shadedArtifactAttached&gt;true&lt;/shadedArtifactAttached&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;shadedClassifierName&gt;allinone&lt;/shadedClassifierName&gt;&#010;&gt;                    &lt;artifactSet&gt;&#010;&gt;                      &lt;includes&gt;&#010;&gt;                        &lt;include&gt;*:*&lt;/include&gt;&#010;&gt;                      &lt;/includes&gt;&#010;&gt;                    &lt;/artifactSet&gt;&#010;&gt;                  &lt;transformer &#010;&gt; implementation="org.apache.maven.plugins.shade.resource.AppendingTransformer"&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;resource&gt;application.conf&lt;/resource&gt;&#010;&gt;                  &lt;/transformer&gt;&#010;&gt;                  &lt;transformer &#010;&gt; implementation="org.apache.maven.plugins.shade.resource.AppendingTransformer"&gt;&#010;&gt;                    &lt;resource&gt;reference.conf&lt;/resource&gt;&#010;&gt;                  &lt;/transformer&gt;&#010;&gt;                   &lt;transformers&gt;&#010;&gt;                     &lt;transformer &#010;&gt; implementation="org.apache.maven.plugins.shade.resource.ManifestResourceTransformer"&gt;&#010;&gt;                       &lt;manifestEntries&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;!-- &#010;&gt; &lt;Main-Class&gt;platform3.AccountService.ServiceKernel&lt;/Main-Class&gt; --&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;Main-Class&gt;akka.Main&lt;/Main-Class&gt;&#010;&gt;                       &lt;/manifestEntries&gt;&#010;&gt;                     &lt;/transformer&gt;&#010;&gt;                   &lt;/transformers&gt;&#010;&gt;                 &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; But when I look at application.conf and reference.conf in the JAR &#010;&gt; file, there is nothing appended to them. Clearly the &#010;&gt; AppendingTransformer is not working because I can see other &#010;&gt; application.conf and reference.conf files in the included jars.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The ManifestResourceTransformer is working correctly, so I am not sure &#010;&gt; what is wrong with AppendingTransformer?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Does anyone have any idea on what the problem may be?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Cheers, Eric&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.koloty...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Emotional Support Group for Typesafe Maven Users
contents:- Does anyone know of a good emotional support group for people trying to &#010;use Maven with Typesafe projects such as Akka and Play?&#010;&#010;I was thinking maybe there could a buddy/sponsor system, such as used in &#010;AA and other self help groups. Maybe there might be group sessions where &#010;people can talk about their trauma, especially by being constantly &#010;invalidated by comments such as "you should use the simple build tool &#010;SBT, cause, well you know, it's simple and easy to use."&#010;&#010;Seriously though, is there a community of people who are successfully &#010;using Maven with Akka an Play projects? I would love to meet you.&#010;&#010;I can see why people who have tried Maven naturally think "oh, its' too &#010;complicated, anyone can write a simple build tool that does what Maven &#010;does." Clearly they do not appreciate what Maven is or what it does. SBT &#010;and Gradle are two great examples of projects that attempted to do &#010;something more simple, but in the end, really don't measure up.&#010;&#010;I personally think the Scala community would be been better served if &#010;more investment was made in developing better Scala build tools within &#010;the Maven framework. More and better plugins for Scala, Akka, Play, &#010;etc.  Better use of&#010;&#010;http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/sect-scala-script-inline.html&#010;http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/ch03s03.html&#010;&#010;I don't know if there is a Scala template for writing Maven plugins (or &#010;mojos), but there should be.&#010;&#010;The more I use SBT, the less I like it. It is not what I consider a &#010;serious build tool for build engineers, it is a toy or playground for &#010;Scala hackers who thrive on the abstruse. Don't get me wrong, I love &#010;Scala, but creating a build tool around .scala files just invites the &#010;use of chicken tracks and obscure overly concise cleverness that leads &#010;to one WTF experience after another. /It is actually possible to write &#010;Scala code that you can reason about,/ but it just as easy to write &#010;Scala code that resembles APL, and reasoning about build engineering was &#010;clearly not a priority with the designers of SBT.&#010;&#010;The Scala-IDE was a really great approach because it leveraged off of an &#010;existing IDE infrastructure such as Eclipse, rather than trying to write &#010;an IDE from scratch the way SBT does. I wish the Scala/Typesafe &#010;community had taken the same approach with build-tools.&#010;&#010;- Eric&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Jon Pretty &lt;propens...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: [scala-debate] Emotional Support Group for Typesafe Maven Users
contents:- I can offer you this:&#010;&#010;  http://play.textadventures.co.uk/Play.aspx?id=zv-wer8keey6rnhk4am25q&#010;&#010;It's a create-your-own-adventure about my experience of trying to publish a&#010;library to Maven Central. It's a couple of years old now, so the landscape&#010;might have improved a little in patches.&#010;&#010;Jon&#010;&#010;On 3 December 2014 at 19:11, Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com&gt;&#010;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt;  Does anyone know of a good emotional support group for people trying to&#010;&gt; use Maven with Typesafe projects such as Akka and Play?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I was thinking maybe there could a buddy/sponsor system, such as used in&#010;&gt; AA and other self help groups. Maybe there might be group sessions where&#010;&gt; people can talk about their trauma, especially by being constantly&#010;&gt; invalidated by comments such as "you should use the simple build tool SBT,&#010;&gt; cause, well you know, it's simple and easy to use."&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Seriously though, is there a community of people who are successfully&#010;&gt; using Maven with Akka an Play projects? I would love to meet you.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I can see why people who have tried Maven naturally think "oh, its' too&#010;&gt; complicated, anyone can write a simple build tool that does what Maven&#010;&gt; does." Clearly they do not appreciate what Maven is or what it does. SBT&#010;&gt; and Gradle are two great examples of projects that attempted to do&#010;&gt; something more simple, but in the end, really don't measure up.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I personally think the Scala community would be been better served if more&#010;&gt; investment was made in developing better Scala build tools within the Maven&#010;&gt; framework. More and better plugins for Scala, Akka, Play, etc.  Better use&#010;&gt; of&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/sect-scala-script-inline.html&#010;&gt; http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/ch03s03.html&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I don't know if there is a Scala template for writing Maven plugins (or&#010;&gt; mojos), but there should be.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The more I use SBT, the less I like it. It is not what I consider a&#010;&gt; serious build tool for build engineers, it is a toy or playground for Scala&#010;&gt; hackers who thrive on the abstruse. Don't get me wrong, I love Scala, but&#010;&gt; creating a build tool around .scala files just invites the use of chicken&#010;&gt; tracks and obscure overly concise cleverness that leads to one WTF&#010;&gt; experience after another. *It is actually possible to write Scala code&#010;&gt; that you can reason about,* but it just as easy to write Scala code that&#010;&gt; resembles APL, and reasoning about build engineering was clearly not a&#010;&gt; priority with the designers of SBT.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The Scala-IDE was a really great approach because it leveraged off of an&#010;&gt; existing IDE infrastructure such as Eclipse, rather than trying to write an&#010;&gt; IDE from scratch the way SBT does. I wish the Scala/Typesafe community had&#010;&gt; taken the same approach with build-tools.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - Eric&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups&#010;&gt; "scala-debate" group.&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an&#010;&gt; email to scala-debate+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.&#010;&gt; For more options, visit https://groups.google.com/d/optout.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Jon Pretty | @propensive&#010;&#010;

It's a couple of years old now, so &#010;&gt; the landscape might have improved a little in patches.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Jon&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 3 December 2014 at 19:11, Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com &#010;&gt; &lt;mailto:eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     Does anyone know of a good emotional support group for people&#010;&gt;     trying to use Maven with Typesafe projects such as Akka and Play?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     I was thinking maybe there could a buddy/sponsor system, such as&#010;&gt;     used in AA and other self help groups. SBT and Gradle are two great examples of&#010;&gt;     projects that attempted to do something more simple, but in the&#010;&gt;     end, really don't measure up.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     I personally think the Scala community would be been better served&#010;&gt;     if more investment was made in developing better Scala build tools&#010;&gt;     within the Maven framework. It is not what I consider&#010;&gt;     a serious build tool for build engineers, it is a toy or&#010;&gt;     playground for Scala hackers who thrive on the abstruse. Don't get&#010;&gt;     me wrong, I love Scala, but creating a build tool around .scala&#010;&gt;     files just invites the use of chicken tracks and obscure overly&#010;&gt;     concise cleverness that leads to one WTF experience after another.&#010;&gt;     /It is actually possible to write Scala code that you can reason&#010;&gt;     about,/ but it just as easy to write Scala code that resembles&#010;&gt;     APL, and reasoning about build engineering was clearly not a&#010;&gt;     priority with the designers of SBT.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     The Scala-IDE was a really great approach because it leveraged off&#010;&gt;     of an existing IDE infrastructure such as Eclipse, rather than&#010;&gt;     trying to write an IDE from scratch the way SBT does. I would love to meet you.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I can see why people who have tried Maven naturally think "oh, its' too&#010;&gt;&gt; complicated, anyone can write a simple build tool that does what Maven&#010;&gt;&gt; does." Clearly they do not appreciate what Maven is or what it does. SBT&#010;&gt;&gt; and Gradle are two great examples of projects that attempted to do&#010;&gt;&gt; something more simple, but in the end, really don't measure up.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I personally think the Scala community would be been better served if&#010;&gt;&gt; more investment was made in developing better Scala build tools within the&#010;&gt;&gt; Maven framework. More and better plugins for Scala, Akka, Play, etc.&#010;&gt;&gt; Better use of&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/sect-scala-script-inline.html&#010;&gt;&gt; http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/ch03s03.html&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I don't know if there is a Scala template for writing Maven plugins (or&#010;&gt;&gt; mojos), but there should be.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The more I use SBT, the less I like it. It is not what I consider a&#010;&gt;&gt; serious build tool for build engineers, it is a toy or playground for Scala&#010;&gt;&gt; hackers who thrive on the abstruse. Don't get me wrong, I love Scala, but&#010;&gt;&gt; creating a build tool around .scala files just invites the use of chicken&#010;&gt;&gt; tracks and obscure overly concise cleverness that leads to one WTF&#010;&gt;&gt; experience after another. *It is actually possible to write Scala code&#010;&gt;&gt; that you can reason about,* but it just as easy to write Scala code that&#010;&gt;&gt; resembles APL, and reasoning about build engineering was clearly not a&#010;&gt;&gt; priority with the designers of SBT.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The Scala-IDE was a really great approach because it leveraged off of an&#010;&gt;&gt; existing IDE infrastructure such as Eclipse, rather than trying to write an&#010;&gt;&gt; IDE from scratch the way SBT does. I wish the Scala/Typesafe community had&#010;&gt;&gt; taken the same approach with build-tools.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; - Eric&#010;&gt;&gt;  --&#010;&gt;&gt; You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups&#010;&gt;&gt; "scala-debate" group.&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an&#010;&gt;&gt; email to scala-debate+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.&#010;&gt;&gt; For more options, visit https://groups.google.com/d/optout.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt;  Jon Pretty | @propensive&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Jon Pretty | @propensive&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-Re: [scala-debate] Emotional Support Group for Typesafe Maven Users
contents:- &gt; If you want to publish to Maven Central I recommend&#010;https://www.packtpub.com/application-development/&#010;getting-started-apache-maven-video&#010;&#010;In case it helps, I've helped a few deploy to Central and recommend this&#010;(and the other pages on the "Producers" menu); makes it very easy:&#010;http://central.sonatype.org/pages/ossrh-guide.html&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Dec 3, 2014 at 3:53 PM, Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com&gt;&#010;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Ha ha ha. It's a couple of years old now, so the&#010;&gt;&gt; landscape might have improved a little in patches.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Jon&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 3 December 2014 at 19:11, Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;mailto:eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     Does anyone know of a good emotional support group for people&#010;&gt;&gt;     trying to use Maven with Typesafe projects such as Akka and Play?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     I was thinking maybe there could a buddy/sponsor system, such as&#010;&gt;&gt;     used in AA and other self help groups. More and better plugins for Scala,&#010;&gt;&gt;     Akka, Play, etc.  Better use of&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/sect-&#010;&gt;&gt; scala-script-inline.html&#010;&gt;&gt;     http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/ch03s03.html&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     I don't know if there is a Scala template for writing Maven&#010;&gt;&gt;     plugins (or mojos), but there should be.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     The more I use SBT, the less I like it. Name  :- Martijn Verburg &lt;martijnverb...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: [scala-debate] Emotional Support Group for Typesafe Maven Users
contents:- Play *very* firmly wants you to use the activator framework to control your&#010;build and deploy - I'd seriously not try and fight against it.  It's one of&#010;the reasons we dropped the Play framework for a community project we're&#010;working on, that and the constant breaking of APIs etc :-).&#010;&#010;Cheers,&#010;Martijn&#010;&#010;On 4 December 2014 at 12:58, Jeff Jensen &lt;jeffjensen@upstairstechnology.com&gt;&#010;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; &gt; If you want to publish to Maven Central I recommend&#010;&gt; https://www.packtpub.com/application-development/&#010;&gt; getting-started-apache-maven-video&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; In case it helps, I've helped a few deploy to Central and recommend this&#010;&gt; (and the other pages on the "Producers" menu); makes it very easy:&#010;&gt; http://central.sonatype.org/pages/ossrh-guide.html&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Wed, Dec 3, 2014 at 3:53 PM, Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com&gt;&#010;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Ha ha ha.
