Name  :- Curtis Rueden &lt;ctrue...@wisc.edu&gt;
Subject  :-Re: [scala-debate] Emotional Support Group for Typesafe Maven Users
contents:- Hi Eric,&#010;&#010;&gt; Is there some alternative to Play, such that we can migrate existing&#010;&gt; Play projects to something that is Maven friendly?&#010;&#010;Grails?&#010;&#010;http://grails.org/doc/latest/guide/commandLine.html#antAndMaven&#010;http://raibledesigns.com/rd/entry/play_vs_grails_smackdown_at&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;Curtis&#010;&#010;On Tue, Dec 9, 2014 at 3:12 PM, Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com&gt;&#010;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Ouch, I was afraid someone would say something like that.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is there some alternative to Play, such that we can migrate existing Play&#010;&gt; projects to something that is Maven friendly?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Cheers, Eric&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 2014-12-04 5:31 AM, Martijn Verburg wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Play *very* firmly wants you to use the activator framework to control&#010;&gt;&gt; your&#010;&gt;&gt; build and deploy - I'd seriously not try and fight against it.  It's one&#010;&gt;&gt; of&#010;&gt;&gt; the reasons we dropped the Play framework for a community project we're&#010;&gt;&gt; working on, that and the constant breaking of APIs etc :-).&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Cheers,&#010;&gt;&gt; Martijn&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 4 December 2014 at 12:58, Jeff Jensen &lt;jeffjensen@&#010;&gt;&gt; upstairstechnology.com&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  If you want to publish to Maven Central I recommend&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; https://www.packtpub.com/application-development/&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; getting-started-apache-maven-video&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; In case it helps, I've helped a few deploy to Central and recommend this&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; (and the other pages on the "Producers" menu); makes it very easy:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; http://central.sonatype.org/pages/ossrh-guide.html&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On Wed, Dec 3, 2014 at 3:53 PM, Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;  Ha ha ha. Very good :-)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I have published to Maven Central, so I know how daunting this can be at&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; first.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; If you want to publish to Maven Central I recommend&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; https://www.packtpub.com/application-development/&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; getting-started-apache-maven-video&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Cheers, Eric&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 12/3/2014 11:27 AM, Jon Pretty wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;  I can offer you this:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; http://play.textadventures.co.uk/Play.aspx?id=zv-wer8keey6rnhk4am25q&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; It's a create-your-own-adventure about my experience of trying to&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; publish&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; a library to Maven Central. It's a couple of years old now, so the&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; landscape might have improved a little in patches.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Jon&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 3 December 2014 at 19:11, Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;mailto:eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      Does anyone know of a good emotional support group for people&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      trying to use Maven with Typesafe projects such as Akka and Play?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      I was thinking maybe there could a buddy/sponsor system, such as&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      used in AA and other self help groups. Maybe there might be group&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      sessions where people can talk about their trauma, especially by&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      being constantly invalidated by comments such as "you should use&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      the simple build tool SBT, cause, well you know, it's simple and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      easy to use."&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      Seriously though, is there a community of people who are&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      successfully using Maven with Akka an Play projects? I would love&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      to meet you.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      I can see why people who have tried Maven naturally think "oh,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      its' too complicated, anyone can write a simple build tool that&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      does what Maven does." Clearly they do not appreciate what Maven&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      is or what it does. SBT and Gradle are two great examples of&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      projects that attempted to do something more simple, but in the&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      end, really don't measure up.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      I personally think the Scala community would be been better served&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      if more investment was made in developing better Scala build tools&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      within the Maven framework. More and better plugins for Scala,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      Akka, Play, etc.  Better use of&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/sect-&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; scala-script-inline.html&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/ch03s03.html&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      I don't know if there is a Scala template for writing Maven&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      plugins (or mojos), but there should be.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      The more I use SBT, the less I like it. It is not what I consider&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      a serious build tool for build engineers, it is a toy or&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      playground for Scala hackers who thrive on the abstruse. Don't get&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      me wrong, I love Scala, but creating a build tool around .scala&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      files just invites the use of chicken tracks and obscure overly&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      concise cleverness that leads to one WTF experience after another.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      /It is actually possible to write Scala code that you can reason&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      about,/ but it just as easy to write Scala code that resembles&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      APL, and reasoning about build engineering was clearly not a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      priority with the designers of SBT.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      The Scala-IDE was a really great approach because it leveraged off&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      of an existing IDE infrastructure such as Eclipse, rather than&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      trying to write an IDE from scratch the way SBT does. I wish the&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      Scala/Typesafe community had taken the same approach with&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; build-tools.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      - Eric&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      --     You received this message because you are subscribed to the&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Google&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      Groups "scala-debate" group.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      send an email to scala-debate+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      &lt;mailto:scala-debate+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com&gt;.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;      For more options, visit https://groups.google.com/d/optout.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; --&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Jon Pretty | @propensive&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- &quot;Manfred Moser&quot; &lt;manf...@mosabuam.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: [scala-debate] Emotional Support Group for Typesafe Maven Users
contents:- I sure hope things have changed with all the documentation and help we put into the central&#010;landing website and the free staging training course and examples that cover staging to Nexus&#010;(and therefore OSSRH and Central) with all sorts of tools. &#010;&#010;http://central.sonatype.org/&#010;http://books.sonatype.com/nexus-book/reference/staging.html&#010;https://github.com/sonatype/nexus-book-examples&#010;http://www.sonatype.org/nexus/members-only/video-gallery-2/free-training/&#010;&#010;If not.. let me know!&#010;&#010;Manfred&#010;&#010;&#010;Jon Pretty wrote on 03.12.2014 11:27:&#010;&#010;&gt; I can offer you this:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;  http://play.textadventures.co.uk/Play.aspx?id=zv-wer8keey6rnhk4am25q&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; It's a create-your-own-adventure about my experience of trying to publish a&#010;&gt; library to Maven Central. It's a couple of years old now, so the landscape&#010;&gt; might have improved a little in patches.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Jon&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; On 3 December 2014 at 19:11, Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com&gt;&#010;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;  Does anyone know of a good emotional support group for people trying to&#010;&gt;&gt; use Maven with Typesafe projects such as Akka and Play?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I was thinking maybe there could a buddy/sponsor system, such as used in&#010;&gt;&gt; AA and other self help groups. Maybe there might be group sessions where&#010;&gt;&gt; people can talk about their trauma, especially by being constantly&#010;&gt;&gt; invalidated by comments such as "you should use the simple build tool SBT,&#010;&gt;&gt; cause, well you know, it's simple and easy to use."&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Seriously though, is there a community of people who are successfully&#010;&gt;&gt; using Maven with Akka an Play projects? I would love to meet you.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I can see why people who have tried Maven naturally think "oh, its' too&#010;&gt;&gt; complicated, anyone can write a simple build tool that does what Maven&#010;&gt;&gt; does." Clearly they do not appreciate what Maven is or what it does. SBT&#010;&gt;&gt; and Gradle are two great examples of projects that attempted to do&#010;&gt;&gt; something more simple, but in the end, really don't measure up.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I personally think the Scala community would be been better served if more&#010;&gt;&gt; investment was made in developing better Scala build tools within the Maven&#010;&gt;&gt; framework. More and better plugins for Scala, Akka, Play, etc.  Better use&#010;&gt;&gt; of&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/sect-scala-script-inline.html&#010;&gt;&gt; http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/ch03s03.html&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I don't know if there is a Scala template for writing Maven plugins (or&#010;&gt;&gt; mojos), but there should be.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The more I use SBT, the less I like it. It is not what I consider a&#010;&gt;&gt; serious build tool for build engineers, it is a toy or playground for Scala&#010;&gt;&gt; hackers who thrive on the abstruse. Don't get me wrong, I love Scala, but&#010;&gt;&gt; creating a build tool around .scala files just invites the use of chicken&#010;&gt;&gt; tracks and obscure overly concise cleverness that leads to one WTF&#010;&gt;&gt; experience after another. *It is actually possible to write Scala code&#010;&gt;&gt; that you can reason about,* but it just as easy to write Scala code that&#010;&gt;&gt; resembles APL, and reasoning about build engineering was clearly not a&#010;&gt;&gt; priority with the designers of SBT.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The Scala-IDE was a really great approach because it leveraged off of an&#010;&gt;&gt; existing IDE infrastructure such as Eclipse, rather than trying to write an&#010;&gt;&gt; IDE from scratch the way SBT does. I wish the Scala/Typesafe community had&#010;&gt;&gt; taken the same approach with build-tools.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; - Eric&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; --&#010;&gt;&gt; You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups&#010;&gt;&gt; "scala-debate" group.&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an&#010;&gt;&gt; email to scala-debate+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.&#010;&gt;&gt; For more options, visit https://groups.google.com/d/optout.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; -- &#010;&gt; Jon Pretty | @propensive&#010;&gt; &#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Rodrigo Cano &lt;ioniv...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: [scala-debate] Emotional Support Group for Typesafe Maven Users
contents:- I just want to say that maven is not at all flowers, their phase model is&#010;too primitive, to the point where something such as wsimport (pretty basic&#010;stuff for good ol' java) did not work properly: I had a configuration for&#010;the java version wanted in the pom.xml, but because of the way phases work&#010;and the very restricted compile order, wsimport would always pick my&#010;OS-globally configured wsimport instead of the one configured in the&#010;pom.xml, leading to incorrect defintions of the ws and a VERY ugly hack&#010;where I had to basically compile the thing twice to get it right. Also, my&#010;os installed java was java7, the pom.xml stated that I wanted java6, guess&#010;what version would the .class generated by wsimport be..&#010;&#010;My point is, build tools are no easy task, and I know no system that does&#010;it right. While my experience with sbt has certainly not been yours (and&#010;I've done quite a bit with it, same with maven, where I had written several&#010;plugins for our own dev environment), I do have to say that I find it an&#010;improvement over maven.&#010;&#010;I still love maven for what it accomplished though.&#010;&#010;Cheers.&#010;&#010;On Wed, Dec 3, 2014 at 5:11 PM, Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com&gt;&#010;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt;  Does anyone know of a good emotional support group for people trying to&#010;&gt; use Maven with Typesafe projects such as Akka and Play?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I was thinking maybe there could a buddy/sponsor system, such as used in&#010;&gt; AA and other self help groups. Maybe there might be group sessions where&#010;&gt; people can talk about their trauma, especially by being constantly&#010;&gt; invalidated by comments such as "you should use the simple build tool SBT,&#010;&gt; cause, well you know, it's simple and easy to use."&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Seriously though, is there a community of people who are successfully&#010;&gt; using Maven with Akka an Play projects? I would love to meet you.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I can see why people who have tried Maven naturally think "oh, its' too&#010;&gt; complicated, anyone can write a simple build tool that does what Maven&#010;&gt; does." Clearly they do not appreciate what Maven is or what it does. SBT&#010;&gt; and Gradle are two great examples of projects that attempted to do&#010;&gt; something more simple, but in the end, really don't measure up.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I personally think the Scala community would be been better served if more&#010;&gt; investment was made in developing better Scala build tools within the Maven&#010;&gt; framework. More and better plugins for Scala, Akka, Play, etc.  Better use&#010;&gt; of&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/sect-scala-script-inline.html&#010;&gt; http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/ch03s03.html&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I don't know if there is a Scala template for writing Maven plugins (or&#010;&gt; mojos), but there should be.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The more I use SBT, the less I like it. It is not what I consider a&#010;&gt; serious build tool for build engineers, it is a toy or playground for Scala&#010;&gt; hackers who thrive on the abstruse. Don't get me wrong, I love Scala, but&#010;&gt; creating a build tool around .scala files just invites the use of chicken&#010;&gt; tracks and obscure overly concise cleverness that leads to one WTF&#010;&gt; experience after another. *It is actually possible to write Scala code&#010;&gt; that you can reason about,* but it just as easy to write Scala code that&#010;&gt; resembles APL, and reasoning about build engineering was clearly not a&#010;&gt; priority with the designers of SBT.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The Scala-IDE was a really great approach because it leveraged off of an&#010;&gt; existing IDE infrastructure such as Eclipse, rather than trying to write an&#010;&gt; IDE from scratch the way SBT does. I wish the Scala/Typesafe community had&#010;&gt; taken the same approach with build-tools.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - Eric&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups&#010;&gt; "scala-debate" group.&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an&#010;&gt; email to scala-debate+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.&#010;&gt; For more options, visit https://groups.google.com/d/optout.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Hervé BOUTEMY &lt;herve.bout...@free.fr&gt;
Subject  :-Re: [scala-debate] Emotional Support Group for Typesafe Maven Users
contents:- Le mercredi 3 décembre 2014 17:32:47 Rodrigo Cano a écrit :&#010;&gt; I just want to say that maven is not at all flowers, their phase model is&#010;&gt; too primitive, to the point where something such as wsimport (pretty basic&#010;&gt; stuff for good ol' java) did not work properly: I had a configuration for&#010;&gt; the java version wanted in the pom.xml, but because of the way phases work&#010;&gt; and the very restricted compile order, wsimport would always pick my&#010;&gt; OS-globally configured wsimport instead of the one configured in the&#010;&gt; pom.xml, leading to incorrect defintions of the ws and a VERY ugly hack&#010;&gt; where I had to basically compile the thing twice to get it right. Also, my&#010;&gt; os installed java was java7, the pom.xml stated that I wanted java6, guess&#010;&gt; what version would the .class generated by wsimport be..&#010;I'm interested to understand the problem and try to improve.&#010;What is the Maven plugin you're using for wsimport, with which version?&#010;&#010;The general solution to such problem is to use Toolchains: toolchains support &#010;has to be implemented in the plugin.&#010;Here is a list of know plugins supporting toolchains:&#010;http://maven.apache.org/guides/mini/guide-using-toolchains.html&#010;&#010;Adding jax-ws plugin to the list would be an interesting improvement&#010;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; My point is, build tools are no easy task, and I know no system that does&#010;&gt; it right. While my experience with sbt has certainly not been yours (and&#010;&gt; I've done quite a bit with it, same with maven, where I had written several&#010;&gt; plugins for our own dev environment), I do have to say that I find it an&#010;&gt; improvement over maven.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I still love maven for what it accomplished though.&#010;+1 peace: just let everyone choose the best tool for his own use case&#010;&#010;And let us know when Maven can be improved.&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;&#010;Hervé&#010;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Cheers.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; On Wed, Dec 3, 2014 at 5:11 PM, Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com&gt;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt;  Does anyone know of a good emotional support group for people trying to&#010;&gt; &gt; &#010;&gt; &gt; use Maven with Typesafe projects such as Akka and Play?&#010;&gt; &gt; &#010;&gt; &gt; I was thinking maybe there could a buddy/sponsor system, such as used in&#010;&gt; &gt; AA and other self help groups. Maybe there might be group sessions where&#010;&gt; &gt; people can talk about their trauma, especially by being constantly&#010;&gt; &gt; invalidated by comments such as "you should use the simple build tool SBT,&#010;&gt; &gt; cause, well you know, it's simple and easy to use."&#010;&gt; &gt; &#010;&gt; &gt; Seriously though, is there a community of people who are successfully&#010;&gt; &gt; using Maven with Akka an Play projects? I would love to meet you.&#010;&gt; &gt; &#010;&gt; &gt; I can see why people who have tried Maven naturally think "oh, its' too&#010;&gt; &gt; complicated, anyone can write a simple build tool that does what Maven&#010;&gt; &gt; does." Clearly they do not appreciate what Maven is or what it does. SBT&#010;&gt; &gt; and Gradle are two great examples of projects that attempted to do&#010;&gt; &gt; something more simple, but in the end, really don't measure up.&#010;&gt; &gt; &#010;&gt; &gt; I personally think the Scala community would be been better served if more&#010;&gt; &gt; investment was made in developing better Scala build tools within the&#010;&gt; &gt; Maven&#010;&gt; &gt; framework. More and better plugins for Scala, Akka, Play, etc.  Better use&#010;&gt; &gt; of&#010;&gt; &gt; &#010;&gt; &gt; http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/sect-scala-script-inline.htm&#010;&gt; &gt; l&#010;&gt; &gt; http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/ch03s03.html&#010;&gt; &gt; &#010;&gt; &gt; I don't know if there is a Scala template for writing Maven plugins (or&#010;&gt; &gt; mojos), but there should be.&#010;&gt; &gt; &#010;&gt; &gt; The more I use SBT, the less I like it. It is not what I consider a&#010;&gt; &gt; serious build tool for build engineers, it is a toy or playground for&#010;&gt; &gt; Scala&#010;&gt; &gt; hackers who thrive on the abstruse. Don't get me wrong, I love Scala, but&#010;&gt; &gt; creating a build tool around .scala files just invites the use of chicken&#010;&gt; &gt; tracks and obscure overly concise cleverness that leads to one WTF&#010;&gt; &gt; experience after another. *It is actually possible to write Scala code&#010;&gt; &gt; that you can reason about,* but it just as easy to write Scala code that&#010;&gt; &gt; resembles APL, and reasoning about build engineering was clearly not a&#010;&gt; &gt; priority with the designers of SBT.&#010;&gt; &gt; &#010;&gt; &gt; The Scala-IDE was a really great approach because it leveraged off of an&#010;&gt; &gt; existing IDE infrastructure such as Eclipse, rather than trying to write&#010;&gt; &gt; an&#010;&gt; &gt; IDE from scratch the way SBT does. I wish the Scala/Typesafe community had&#010;&gt; &gt; taken the same approach with build-tools.&#010;&gt; &gt; &#010;&gt; &gt; - Eric&#010;&gt; &gt; &#010;&gt; &gt; --&#010;&gt; &gt; You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups&#010;&gt; &gt; "scala-debate" group.&#010;&gt; &gt; To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an&#010;&gt; &gt; email to scala-debate+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.&#010;&gt; &gt; For more options, visit https://groups.google.com/d/optout.&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Adam Retter &lt;adam.ret...@googlemail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Emotional Support Group for Typesafe Maven Users
contents:- I have used Maven for plenty of Scala and Akka projects, but never for&#010;a Play project as Play seems to have its own idea of application&#010;structure and layout and it is easier to just stick with it for Play.&#010;&#010;On 3 December 2014 at 19:11, Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Does anyone know of a good emotional support group for people trying to use&#010;&gt; Maven with Typesafe projects such as Akka and Play?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I was thinking maybe there could a buddy/sponsor system, such as used in AA&#010;&gt; and other self help groups. Maybe there might be group sessions where people&#010;&gt; can talk about their trauma, especially by being constantly invalidated by&#010;&gt; comments such as "you should use the simple build tool SBT, cause, well you&#010;&gt; know, it's simple and easy to use."&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Seriously though, is there a community of people who are successfully using&#010;&gt; Maven with Akka an Play projects? I would love to meet you.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I can see why people who have tried Maven naturally think "oh, its' too&#010;&gt; complicated, anyone can write a simple build tool that does what Maven&#010;&gt; does." Clearly they do not appreciate what Maven is or what it does. SBT and&#010;&gt; Gradle are two great examples of projects that attempted to do something&#010;&gt; more simple, but in the end, really don't measure up.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I personally think the Scala community would be been better served if more&#010;&gt; investment was made in developing better Scala build tools within the Maven&#010;&gt; framework. More and better plugins for Scala, Akka, Play, etc.  Better use&#010;&gt; of&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/sect-scala-script-inline.html&#010;&gt; http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/ch03s03.html&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I don't know if there is a Scala template for writing Maven plugins (or&#010;&gt; mojos), but there should be.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The more I use SBT, the less I like it. It is not what I consider a serious&#010;&gt; build tool for build engineers, it is a toy or playground for Scala hackers&#010;&gt; who thrive on the abstruse. Don't get me wrong, I love Scala, but creating a&#010;&gt; build tool around .scala files just invites the use of chicken tracks and&#010;&gt; obscure overly concise cleverness that leads to one WTF experience after&#010;&gt; another. /It is actually possible to write Scala code that you can reason&#010;&gt; about,/ but it just as easy to write Scala code that resembles APL, and&#010;&gt; reasoning about build engineering was clearly not a priority with the&#010;&gt; designers of SBT.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The Scala-IDE was a really great approach because it leveraged off of an&#010;&gt; existing IDE infrastructure such as Eclipse, rather than trying to write an&#010;&gt; IDE from scratch the way SBT does. I wish the Scala/Typesafe community had&#010;&gt; taken the same approach with build-tools.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - Eric&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Adam Retter&#010;&#010;skype: adam.retter&#010;tweet: adamretter&#010;http://www.adamretter.org.uk&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Subject  :-Re: Emotional Support Group for Typesafe Maven Users
contents:- I believe this is an (fair) excuse to get a hug.&#010;&#010;--&#010;-- Aldrin Leal, &lt;aldrin@leal.eng.br&gt;&#010;Master your EC2-fu! Get the latest ekaterminal public beta&#010;http://www.ingenieux.com.br/products/ekaterminal/&#010;&#010;On Wed, Dec 3, 2014 at 4:11 PM, Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.kolotyluk@gmail.com&gt;&#010;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Does anyone know of a good emotional support group for people trying to&#010;&gt; use Maven with Typesafe projects such as Akka and Play?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I was thinking maybe there could a buddy/sponsor system, such as used in&#010;&gt; AA and other self help groups. Maybe there might be group sessions where&#010;&gt; people can talk about their trauma, especially by being constantly&#010;&gt; invalidated by comments such as "you should use the simple build tool SBT,&#010;&gt; cause, well you know, it's simple and easy to use."&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Seriously though, is there a community of people who are successfully&#010;&gt; using Maven with Akka an Play projects? I would love to meet you.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I can see why people who have tried Maven naturally think "oh, its' too&#010;&gt; complicated, anyone can write a simple build tool that does what Maven&#010;&gt; does." Clearly they do not appreciate what Maven is or what it does. SBT&#010;&gt; and Gradle are two great examples of projects that attempted to do&#010;&gt; something more simple, but in the end, really don't measure up.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I personally think the Scala community would be been better served if more&#010;&gt; investment was made in developing better Scala build tools within the Maven&#010;&gt; framework. More and better plugins for Scala, Akka, Play, etc.  Better use&#010;&gt; of&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/sect-&#010;&gt; scala-script-inline.html&#010;&gt; http://books.sonatype.com/mcookbook/reference/ch03s03.html&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I don't know if there is a Scala template for writing Maven plugins (or&#010;&gt; mojos), but there should be.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The more I use SBT, the less I like it. It is not what I consider a&#010;&gt; serious build tool for build engineers, it is a toy or playground for Scala&#010;&gt; hackers who thrive on the abstruse. Don't get me wrong, I love Scala, but&#010;&gt; creating a build tool around .scala files just invites the use of chicken&#010;&gt; tracks and obscure overly concise cleverness that leads to one WTF&#010;&gt; experience after another. /It is actually possible to write Scala code that&#010;&gt; you can reason about,/ but it just as easy to write Scala code that&#010;&gt; resembles APL, and reasoning about build engineering was clearly not a&#010;&gt; priority with the designers of SBT.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The Scala-IDE was a really great approach because it leveraged off of an&#010;&gt; existing IDE infrastructure such as Eclipse, rather than trying to write an&#010;&gt; IDE from scratch the way SBT does. I wish the Scala/Typesafe community had&#010;&gt; taken the same approach with build-tools.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - Eric&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Mark Eggers &lt;its_toas...@yahoo.com.INVALID&gt;
Subject  :-Using shaded JAR as a dependency in a WAR module
contents:- -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----&#010;Hash: SHA1&#010;&#010;Folks,&#010;&#010;I admit it, I'm a bit confused (and relatively new to maven).&#010;&#010;Goal:&#010;&#010;To release a WAR file with a minimal number of JAR files in WEB-INF/lib.&#010;&#010;Thought:&#010;&#010;1. Break up the WAR project into a WAR module and a JAR module&#010;2. Make the WAR module be dependent on the JAR module&#010;3. Use the Maven shade plugin in the JAR module to create a shaded JAR&#010;4. Drive the entire project with an agregator pom.xml&#010;&#010;The JAR module does shade properly, creating a single JAR with all of&#010;the dependencies bundled into a single JAR. It uses a pom dependency&#010;to gather in most of its requirements. None of the JAR or pom&#010;dependencies have further dependencies, so the resulting JAR is&#010;self-contained.&#010;&#010;However, when I build the WAR file and reference the shaded JAR file&#010;as a dependency, I do not get the shaded JAR file in WEB-INF/lib.&#010;Instead, I get all of the dependencies as individual JAR files in&#010;WEB-INF/lib.&#010;&#010;I'm using the following environment (can post my complete pom.xml&#010;files if needed).&#010;&#010;OS:    Fedora Linux 64 bit - latest updates&#010;JDK:   1.7.0_72 64 bit&#010;Maven: 3.2.3&#010;&#010;maven-shade-plugin: 2.3&#010;maven-war-plugin:   2.4&#010;&#010;shade configuration and dependencies for&#010;org.mdeggers:IFCResources:1.0-SNAPSHOT&#010;&#010;&lt;properties&gt;&#010;    &lt;calhost.version&gt;1.0-SNAPSHOT&lt;/calhost.version&gt;&#010;    &lt;ihomeresources.version&gt;1.0-SNAPSHOT&lt;/ihomeresources.version&gt;&#010;&lt;/properties&gt;&#010;&#010;&lt;dependencies&gt;&#010;    &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;        &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;        &lt;artifactId&gt;Calhost&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;        &lt;version&gt;${calhost.version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;    &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;    &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;        &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;        &lt;artifactId&gt;IHomeResources&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;        &lt;version&gt;${ihomeresources.version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;        &lt;type&gt;pom&lt;/type&gt;&#010;    &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&#010;&lt;plugin&gt;&#010;    &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;    &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-shade-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;    &lt;version&gt;2.3&lt;/version&gt;&#010;    &lt;executions&gt;&#010;        &lt;execution&gt;&#010;            &lt;id&gt;combine&lt;/id&gt;&#010;            &lt;phase&gt;package&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;            &lt;goals&gt;&#010;                &lt;goal&gt;shade&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;            &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;            &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;                &lt;artifactSet&gt;&#010;                    &lt;includes&gt;&#010;                        &lt;include&gt;org.mdeggers:*&lt;/include&gt;&#010;                    &lt;/includes&gt;&#010;                &lt;/artifactSet&gt;&#010;            &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;         &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;    &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;&lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;Partial dependencies for org.mdeggers:iforeclosure:1.0-SNAPSHOT:war&#010;&#010;&lt;dependencies&gt;&#010;    &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;        &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;        &lt;artifactId&gt;IFCResources&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;        &lt;version&gt;1.0-SNAPSHOT&lt;/version&gt;&#010;    &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&#010;Parent pom modules section:&#010;&#010;&lt;modules&gt;&#010;    &lt;module&gt;IFCResources&lt;/module&gt;&#010;    &lt;module&gt;iforeclosure&lt;/module&gt;&#010;&lt;/modules&gt;&#010;&#010;I'm obviously missing something here. Thoughts, corrections, pointers&#010;are all appreciated.&#010;&#010;I know, using a shaded JAR as a dependency is probably not best&#010;practice. However, the resulting WAR file is an end product and the&#010;shaded JAR only contains internal components from other web overlays&#010;used to build the final war.&#010;&#010;. . . just my (confused) 2 cents&#010;/mde/&#010;-----BEGIN PGP SIGNATURE-----&#010;Version: GnuPG v2&#010;&#010;iQEcBAEBAgAGBQJUgO5LAAoJEEFGbsYNeTwt9YgIAKLuOll7rpDRI4Ea3ieshWgY&#010;HugkUrvaja1UZdKkFm0bdo4qQxUUmKHL9byHTQzPiLb6+WKeXaaQaMDvhA0DgbAp&#010;tJQ+4WKEPBzKx5MUvftY2oEiW8eVEnMIkZ6qLA0aPKxrenodlekz3eKlxJ/D8kxF&#010;dqf5UvncIYGNlzbThVlFaOpmp7FgF6dStrBDPuyGdhcLWpb4UkI/sVqo92/copnY&#010;tMR2uX9/Uscn+11pXlcTTg+YfGGwlguZIEkSBRlUBiAYMwiDG0fyDqRaVcv18BtS&#010;/iLB6hlB8xNkRArvIpDV+h7W2sHK6jekjzfCU80ZO72ZSgsiYUKMqWlY04GlPTU=&#010;=jCy7&#010;-----END PGP SIGNATURE-----&#010;&#010;---&#010;This email is free from viruses and malware because avast! contents:- We do this all the time and it always works.&#010;http://blog.artifact-software.com/tech/?p=121 Aggregation jars make development simpler and&#010;wars smaller&#010;&#010;&#010;Partial dependencies for org.mdeggers:iforeclosure:1.0-SNAPSHOT:war&#010;&#010;&lt;dependencies&gt;&#010;     &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;         &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;         &lt;artifactId&gt;IFCResources&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;         &lt;version&gt;1.0-SNAPSHOT&lt;/version&gt;&#010;     &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&#010;What are the dependencies for the war file? Partial list is not much help.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;&#010;On 04/12/2014 6:29 PM, Mark Eggers wrote:&#010;&gt; -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----&#010;&gt; Hash: SHA1&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Folks,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I admit it, I'm a bit confused (and relatively new to maven).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Goal:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; To release a WAR file with a minimal number of JAR files in WEB-INF/lib.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thought:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 1. I'm obviously missing something here. Thoughts, corrections, pointers&#010;&gt; are all appreciated.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I know, using a shaded JAR as a dependency is probably not best&#010;&gt; practice. However, the resulting WAR file is an end product and the&#010;&gt; shaded JAR only contains internal components from other web overlays&#010;&gt; used to build the final war.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; . . . just my (confused) 2 cents&#010;&gt; /mde/&#010;&gt; -----BEGIN PGP SIGNATURE-----&#010;&gt; Version: GnuPG v2&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; iQEcBAEBAgAGBQJUgO5LAAoJEEFGbsYNeTwt9YgIAKLuOll7rpDRI4Ea3ieshWgY&#010;&gt; HugkUrvaja1UZdKkFm0bdo4qQxUUmKHL9byHTQzPiLb6+WKeXaaQaMDvhA0DgbAp&#010;&gt; tJQ+4WKEPBzKx5MUvftY2oEiW8eVEnMIkZ6qLA0aPKxrenodlekz3eKlxJ/D8kxF&#010;&gt; dqf5UvncIYGNlzbThVlFaOpmp7FgF6dStrBDPuyGdhcLWpb4UkI/sVqo92/copnY&#010;&gt; tMR2uX9/Uscn+11pXlcTTg+YfGGwlguZIEkSBRlUBiAYMwiDG0fyDqRaVcv18BtS&#010;&gt; /iLB6hlB8xNkRArvIpDV+h7W2sHK6jekjzfCU80ZO72ZSgsiYUKMqWlY04GlPTU=&#010;&gt; =jCy7&#010;&gt; -----END PGP SIGNATURE-----&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---&#010;&gt; This email is free from viruses and malware because avast! Partial list is not &#010;&gt; much help.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; On 04/12/2014 6:29 PM, Mark Eggers wrote: Folks,&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I admit it, I'm a bit confused (and relatively new to maven).&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Goal:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; To release a WAR file with a minimal number of JAR files in &#010;&gt; WEB-INF/lib.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Thought:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; 1. Break up the WAR project into a WAR module and a JAR module 2. &#010;&gt; Make the WAR module be dependent on the JAR module 3. Use the&#010;&gt; Maven shade plugin in the JAR module to create a shaded JAR 4.&#010;&gt; Drive the entire project with an agregator pom.xml&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; The JAR module does shade properly, creating a single JAR with all &#010;&gt; of the dependencies bundled into a single JAR. It uses a pom &#010;&gt; dependency to gather in most of its requirements. None of the JAR &#010;&gt; or pom dependencies have further dependencies, so the resulting&#010;&gt; JAR is self-contained.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; However, when I build the WAR file and reference the shaded JAR &#010;&gt; file as a dependency, I do not get the shaded JAR file in &#010;&gt; WEB-INF/lib. Instead, I get all of the dependencies as individual &#010;&gt; JAR files in WEB-INF/lib.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I'm using the following environment (can post my complete pom.xml &#010;&gt; files if needed).&#010;&gt; Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Using shaded JAR as a dependency in a WAR module
contents:- Some forums are more concerned about form than content.&#010;Everyone here is pretty focused on solving your problem rather than &#010;telling how to post it.&#010;&#010;If you look at the examples in my post, you will see that the type is &#010;"pom" for dependencies on libraries.&#010;We also use "provided" scope since we install the libraries once rather &#010;than include them with each upload of a war file since they generally &#010;don't change.&#010;&#010;We set the content of our libraries (jars and versions) at the beginning &#010;of a release cycle and don't change them for the duration of the release &#010;unless there is an emergency.&#010;This gives everyone a stable environment and once you have the libraries &#010;loaded into Tomcat, in our case, they do not change as the application &#010;gets worked on.&#010;This makes the testing go quicker since you are only replacing the war &#010;file that you are working on and the war file only contains the code &#010;that we write.&#010;&#010;I am not sure if this applies to your libraries.&#010;&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;On 05/12/2014 12:04 PM, Mark Eggers wrote:&#010;&gt; -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----&#010;&gt; Hash: SHA1&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Ron,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks for the link. I'm attempting to do this with the shade plugin.&#010;&gt; I took a look at the JAR that the shade plugin generates with my&#010;&gt; configuration, and it seems to have the pom.xml files from which it&#010;&gt; was built, but not the reduced dependency pom.xml (or any pom.xml from&#010;&gt; the built / shaded artifact).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; This means that I have not configured the shade plugin properly to&#010;&gt; produce an artifact that can be consumed as if it was built without&#010;&gt; using the shade plugin.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The entire list of dependencies for the WAR module:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;artifactId&gt;CoreServer&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;version&gt;${coreserver.version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;artifactId&gt;CoreClient&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;version&gt;${coreclient.version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;type&gt;war&lt;/type&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;groupId&gt;javax.servlet&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;artifactId&gt;servlet-api&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;version&gt;2.5&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;scope&gt;provided&lt;/scope&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;groupId&gt;javax.servlet.jsp&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;artifactId&gt;jsp-api&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;version&gt;2.1&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;scope&gt;provided&lt;/scope&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;artifactId&gt;GlobalCalcWeb&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;version&gt;${globalweb.version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;type&gt;war&lt;/type&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;artifactId&gt;IHomeWeb&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;version&gt;${ihome.version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;type&gt;pom&lt;/type&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;artifactId&gt;IFCResources&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;version&gt;1.0-SNAPSHOT&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; There could be as many as 50 components going into the final WAR file,&#010;&gt; so it would be nice to manage them in a more organized fashion (as&#010;&gt; well as reduce the clutter in WEB-INF/lib).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; All of the versions with properties have properties defined. The last&#010;&gt; dependency is the shaded JAR, and the one that is not behaving as&#010;&gt; expected (but probably as built / configured).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The NetBeans graphical display of the dependencies shows IFCResources,&#010;&gt; as well as the three components it was shaded from.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Sorry for the top-post. It seems to be the norm on this list, whereas&#010;&gt; the Tomcat mailing list explicitly mentions replying at the bottom. I&#010;&gt; didn't see any mention of posting style on the site. If posting at the&#010;&gt; bottom is the encouraged form, I'll be happy to do so.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; . . . just my two cents&#010;&gt; /mde/&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 12/4/2014 8:41 PM, Ron Wheeler wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; We do this all the time and it always works.&#010;&gt;&gt; http://blog.artifact-software.com/tech/?p=121 Aggregation jars make&#010;&gt;&gt; development simpler and wars smaller&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Partial dependencies for&#010;&gt;&gt; org.mdeggers:iforeclosure:1.0-SNAPSHOT:war&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;dependencies&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;IFCResources&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;version&gt;1.0-SNAPSHOT&lt;/version&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt; &lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; What are the dependencies for the war file? &lt;modules&gt; &lt;module&gt;IFCResources&lt;/module&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;module&gt;iforeclosure&lt;/module&gt; &lt;/modules&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I'm obviously missing something here. Thoughts, corrections,&#010;&gt;&gt; pointers are all appreciated.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I know, using a shaded JAR as a dependency is probably not best&#010;&gt;&gt; practice. However, the resulting WAR file is an end product and the&#010;&gt;&gt; shaded JAR only contains internal components from other web&#010;&gt;&gt; overlays used to build the final war.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; . . . just my (confused) 2 cents /mde/&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; --- This email is free from viruses and malware because avast!&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Antivirus protection is active. http://www.avast.com&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; -----BEGIN PGP SIGNATURE-----&#010;&gt; Version: GnuPG v2&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; iQEcBAEBAgAGBQJUgeWDAAoJEEFGbsYNeTwtoTkH+wecGgNHc2VNaHxR8kp8PTXB&#010;&gt; xHFRfI7VeD2wrQgwqyZSCnL1pJSbSLUvhHopIQslTiHO1Rbr84/L0o4DZe8z+m49&#010;&gt; 4Oty9Jz7soEP+b0PnhomErNMD7aPsjtPjsAT59rYS4zlbT5FkphauYzFxfdnmCfC&#010;&gt; OCykAIN/dUgNRL0RlUfAX207RHLAx1Kvz3gHhxsMPgLr9HqFaBBHipGh2ZIv+jog&#010;&gt; reGqqmK0px2UoH1oniXREJ9fpMCB09dbQEX5UwtAHKgCeAvEblMLosxFuWH3fL/U&#010;&gt; VyjiaQNUZwt8pwhDeV1vCjQceOluooFgnYhn95pMxvnrDNHiHP4e+OxKiiczzqU=&#010;&gt; =2b8i&#010;&gt; -----END PGP SIGNATURE-----&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---&#010;&gt; This email is free from viruses and malware because avast! Name  :- Mark Eggers &lt;its_toas...@yahoo.com.INVALID&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Using shaded JAR as a dependency in a WAR module
contents:- -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----&#010;Hash: SHA1&#010;&#010;Ron and Stephen,&#010;&#010;Ron, we cannot use libraries installed into Tomcat's&#010;$CATALINA_BASE/lib directory for several reasons. While it's nice from&#010;a developer and deployment point of view, we do end up running&#010;multiple versions of the WAR file (with different versions of various&#010;dependencies) on the same Tomcat. We also release the WAR file, and it&#010;would be difficult to require people to modify their server environment.&#010;&#010;Thanks! I finally figured it out.&#010;&#010;1. Issue number 1&#010;&#010;I was using a POM artifact to aggregate a set of lower level&#010;libraries. In order to do this, I had to set the following in the&#010;shade plugin:&#010;&#010;&lt;promoteTransitiveDependencies&gt;true&lt;/promoteTransitiveDependencies&gt;&#010;&#010;This of course makes perfect sense.&#010;&#010;2. Issue number 2&#010;&#010;I needed to set the following:&#010;&#010;&lt;keepDependenciesWithProvidedScope&gt;true&lt;/keepDependenciesWithProvidedScope&gt;&#010;&#010;Both of these are mentioned (albeit not as clearly as it might be) in&#010;the fine documentation here:&#010;&#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-shade-plugin/shade-mojo.html&#010;&#010;Combining those two creates a JAR with all of the dependency pom.xml&#010;files in it, as well as the classes / resources / etc. An examination&#010;of the target WAR file shows a nice, clean WEB-INF/lib with managed&#010;dependencies all the way down the chain.&#010;&#010;For those people interested, the dependencies and shade plugin&#010;configuration are given below.&#010;&#010;&lt;dependencies&gt;&#010;    &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;        &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;        &lt;artifactId&gt;Calhost&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;        &lt;version&gt;${calhost.version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;    &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;    &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;        &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;        &lt;artifactId&gt;IHomeResources&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;        &lt;version&gt;${ihomeresources.version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;        &lt;type&gt;pom&lt;/type&gt;&#010;    &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&#010;&lt;build&gt;&#010;    &lt;plugins&gt;&#010;        &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;            &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;            &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-shade-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;            &lt;version&gt;2.3&lt;/version&gt;&#010;            &lt;executions&gt;&#010;                &lt;execution&gt;&#010;                    &lt;id&gt;combine&lt;/id&gt;&#010;                    &lt;phase&gt;package&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;                    &lt;goals&gt;&#010;                        &lt;goal&gt;shade&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;                    &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;                    &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&#010;&lt;keepDependenciesWithProvidedScope&gt;true&lt;/keepDependenciesWithProvidedScope&gt;&#010;&#010;&lt;promoteTransitiveDependencies&gt;true&lt;/promoteTransitiveDependencies&gt;&#010;                        &lt;artifactSet&gt;&#010;                            &lt;includes&gt;&#010;                                &lt;include&gt;org.mdeggers:*&lt;/include&gt;&#010;                            &lt;/includes&gt;&#010;                        &lt;/artifactSet&gt;&#010;                    &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;                &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;            &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;        &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;    &lt;/plugins&gt;&#010;&lt;/build&gt;&#010;&#010;Sorry for the line length.&#010;&#010;Obviously, if you don't have any transitive dependencies, you won't&#010;need the promote line.&#010;&#010;It works. Hope this is the correct solution.&#010;&#010;. . . just my two cents&#010;/mde/&#010;&#010;On 12/5/2014 10:57 AM, Ron Wheeler wrote:&#010;&gt; Some forums are more concerned about form than content. Everyone&#010;&gt; here is pretty focused on solving your problem rather than telling&#010;&gt; how to post it.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; If you look at the examples in my post, you will see that the type&#010;&gt; is "pom" for dependencies on libraries. We also use "provided"&#010;&gt; scope since we install the libraries once rather than include them&#010;&gt; with each upload of a war file since they generally don't change.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; We set the content of our libraries (jars and versions) at the&#010;&gt; beginning of a release cycle and don't change them for the duration&#010;&gt; of the release unless there is an emergency. This gives everyone a&#010;&gt; stable environment and once you have the libraries loaded into&#010;&gt; Tomcat, in our case, they do not change as the application gets&#010;&gt; worked on. This makes the testing go quicker since you are only&#010;&gt; replacing the war file that you are working on and the war file&#010;&gt; only contains the code that we write.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I am not sure if this applies to your libraries.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; On 05/12/2014 12:04 PM, Mark Eggers wrote: Ron,&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Thanks for the link. I'm attempting to do this with the shade&#010;&gt; plugin. I took a look at the JAR that the shade plugin generates&#010;&gt; with my configuration, and it seems to have the pom.xml files from&#010;&gt; which it was built, but not the reduced dependency pom.xml (or any&#010;&gt; pom.xml from the built / shaded artifact).&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; This means that I have not configured the shade plugin properly to &#010;&gt; produce an artifact that can be consumed as if it was built&#010;&gt; without using the shade plugin.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; The entire list of dependencies for the WAR module:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;dependencies&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;CoreClient&lt;/artifactId&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;version&gt;${coreclient.version}&lt;/version&gt; &lt;type&gt;war&lt;/type&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;javax.servlet&lt;/groupId&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;servlet-api&lt;/artifactId&gt; &lt;version&gt;2.5&lt;/version&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;scope&gt;provided&lt;/scope&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;javax.servlet.jsp&lt;/groupId&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;jsp-api&lt;/artifactId&gt; &lt;version&gt;2.1&lt;/version&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;scope&gt;provided&lt;/scope&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;GlobalCalcWeb&lt;/artifactId&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;version&gt;${globalweb.version}&lt;/version&gt; &lt;type&gt;war&lt;/type&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;IHomeWeb&lt;/artifactId&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;version&gt;${ihome.version}&lt;/version&gt; &lt;type&gt;pom&lt;/type&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&#010;&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;IFCResources&lt;/artifactId&gt; &#010;&gt; &lt;version&gt;1.0-SNAPSHOT&lt;/version&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt; &lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; There could be as many as 50 components going into the final WAR&#010;&gt; file, so it would be nice to manage them in a more organized&#010;&gt; fashion (as well as reduce the clutter in WEB-INF/lib).&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; All of the versions with properties have properties defined. The&#010;&gt; last dependency is the shaded JAR, and the one that is not behaving&#010;&gt; as expected (but probably as built / configured).&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; The NetBeans graphical display of the dependencies shows&#010;&gt; IFCResources, as well as the three components it was shaded from.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Sorry for the top-post. It seems to be the norm on this list,&#010;&gt; whereas the Tomcat mailing list explicitly mentions replying at the&#010;&gt; bottom. I didn't see any mention of posting style on the site. If&#010;&gt; posting at the bottom is the encouraged form, I'll be happy to do&#010;&gt; so.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; . . . just my two cents /mde/&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; On 12/4/2014 8:41 PM, Ron Wheeler wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; We do this all the time and it always works. &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; http://blog.artifact-software.com/tech/?p=121 Aggregation&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; jars make development simpler and wars smaller&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Partial dependencies for &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; org.mdeggers:iforeclosure:1.0-SNAPSHOT:war&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;dependencies&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;IFCResources&lt;/artifactId&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;version&gt;1.0-SNAPSHOT&lt;/version&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; What are the dependencies for the war file? Partial list is&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; not much help.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 04/12/2014 6:29 PM, Mark Eggers wrote: Folks,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I admit it, I'm a bit confused (and relatively new to&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; maven).&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Goal:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; To release a WAR file with a minimal number of JAR files in &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; WEB-INF/lib.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thought:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 1. Break up the WAR project into a WAR module and a JAR&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; module 2. Make the WAR module be dependent on the JAR module&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 3. Use the Maven shade plugin in the JAR module to create a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; shaded JAR 4. Drive the entire project with an agregator&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; pom.xml&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The JAR module does shade properly, creating a single JAR&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; with all of the dependencies bundled into a single JAR. It&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; uses a pom dependency to gather in most of its requirements.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; None of the JAR or pom dependencies have further&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; dependencies, so the resulting JAR is self-contained.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; However, when I build the WAR file and reference the shaded&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; JAR file as a dependency, I do not get the shaded JAR file&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; in WEB-INF/lib. Instead, I get all of the dependencies as&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; individual JAR files in WEB-INF/lib.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm using the following environment (can post my complete&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; pom.xml files if needed).&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; OS:    Fedora Linux 64 bit - latest updates JDK:   1.7.0_72&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 64 bit Maven: 3.2.3&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; maven-shade-plugin: 2.3 maven-war-plugin:   2.4&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; shade configuration and dependencies for &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; org.mdeggers:IFCResources:1.0-SNAPSHOT&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;version&gt;${calhost.version}&lt;/version&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm obviously missing something here. Thoughts, corrections, &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; pointers are all appreciated.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I know, using a shaded JAR as a dependency is probably not&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; best practice. However, the resulting WAR file is an end&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; product and the shaded JAR only contains internal components&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; from other web overlays used to build the final war.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; . . . just my (confused) 2 cents /mde/&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; --- This email is free from viruses and malware because&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; avast! Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Using shaded JAR as a dependency in a WAR module
contents:- Great.&#010;I hope that the discussion was helpful even if you found a better solution.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;On 05/12/2014 3:22 PM, Mark Eggers wrote:&#010;&gt; -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----&#010;&gt; Hash: SHA1&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Ron and Stephen,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Ron, we cannot use libraries installed into Tomcat's&#010;&gt; $CATALINA_BASE/lib directory for several reasons. While it's nice from&#010;&gt; a developer and deployment point of view, we do end up running&#010;&gt; multiple versions of the WAR file (with different versions of various&#010;&gt; dependencies) on the same Tomcat. We also release the WAR file, and it&#010;&gt; would be difficult to require people to modify their server environment.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks! I finally figured it out.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 1. Issue number 1&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I was using a POM artifact to aggregate a set of lower level&#010;&gt; libraries. In order to do this, I had to set the following in the&#010;&gt; shade plugin:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;promoteTransitiveDependencies&gt;true&lt;/promoteTransitiveDependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; This of course makes perfect sense.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 2. Issue number 2&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I needed to set the following:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;keepDependenciesWithProvidedScope&gt;true&lt;/keepDependenciesWithProvidedScope&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Both of these are mentioned (albeit not as clearly as it might be) in&#010;&gt; the fine documentation here:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-shade-plugin/shade-mojo.html&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Combining those two creates a JAR with all of the dependency pom.xml&#010;&gt; files in it, as well as the classes / resources / etc. An examination&#010;&gt; of the target WAR file shows a nice, clean WEB-INF/lib with managed&#010;&gt; dependencies all the way down the chain.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; For those people interested, the dependencies and shade plugin&#010;&gt; configuration are given below.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;artifactId&gt;Calhost&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;version&gt;${calhost.version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;artifactId&gt;IHomeResources&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;version&gt;${ihomeresources.version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;type&gt;pom&lt;/type&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;build&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;plugins&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-shade-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;version&gt;2.3&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;executions&gt;&#010;&gt;                  &lt;execution&gt;&#010;&gt;                      &lt;id&gt;combine&lt;/id&gt;&#010;&gt;                      &lt;phase&gt;package&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;&gt;                      &lt;goals&gt;&#010;&gt;                          &lt;goal&gt;shade&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;&gt;                      &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;&gt;                      &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;keepDependenciesWithProvidedScope&gt;true&lt;/keepDependenciesWithProvidedScope&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;promoteTransitiveDependencies&gt;true&lt;/promoteTransitiveDependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;                          &lt;artifactSet&gt;&#010;&gt;                              &lt;includes&gt;&#010;&gt;                                  &lt;include&gt;org.mdeggers:*&lt;/include&gt;&#010;&gt;                              &lt;/includes&gt;&#010;&gt;                          &lt;/artifactSet&gt;&#010;&gt;                      &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;                  &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/plugins&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;/build&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Sorry for the line length.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Obviously, if you don't have any transitive dependencies, you won't&#010;&gt; need the promote line.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; It works. Hope this is the correct solution.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; . . . just my two cents&#010;&gt; /mde/&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 12/5/2014 10:57 AM, Ron Wheeler wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; Some forums are more concerned about form than content. Everyone&#010;&gt;&gt; here is pretty focused on solving your problem rather than telling&#010;&gt;&gt; how to post it.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; If you look at the examples in my post, you will see that the type&#010;&gt;&gt; is "pom" for dependencies on libraries. We also use "provided"&#010;&gt;&gt; scope since we install the libraries once rather than include them&#010;&gt;&gt; with each upload of a war file since they generally don't change.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; We set the content of our libraries (jars and versions) at the&#010;&gt;&gt; beginning of a release cycle and don't change them for the duration&#010;&gt;&gt; of the release unless there is an emergency. This gives everyone a&#010;&gt;&gt; stable environment and once you have the libraries loaded into&#010;&gt;&gt; Tomcat, in our case, they do not change as the application gets&#010;&gt;&gt; worked on. This makes the testing go quicker since you are only&#010;&gt;&gt; replacing the war file that you are working on and the war file&#010;&gt;&gt; only contains the code that we write.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I am not sure if this applies to your libraries.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 05/12/2014 12:04 PM, Mark Eggers wrote: Ron,&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Thanks for the link. I'm attempting to do this with the shade&#010;&gt;&gt; plugin. I took a look at the JAR that the shade plugin generates&#010;&gt;&gt; with my configuration, and it seems to have the pom.xml files from&#010;&gt;&gt; which it was built, but not the reduced dependency pom.xml (or any&#010;&gt;&gt; pom.xml from the built / shaded artifact).&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; This means that I have not configured the shade plugin properly to&#010;&gt;&gt; produce an artifact that can be consumed as if it was built&#010;&gt;&gt; without using the shade plugin.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The entire list of dependencies for the WAR module:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;dependencies&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;CoreServer&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;version&gt;${coreserver.version}&lt;/version&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;CoreClient&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;version&gt;${coreclient.version}&lt;/version&gt; &lt;type&gt;war&lt;/type&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;javax.servlet&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;servlet-api&lt;/artifactId&gt; &lt;version&gt;2.5&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;scope&gt;provided&lt;/scope&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt; &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;javax.servlet.jsp&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;jsp-api&lt;/artifactId&gt; &lt;version&gt;2.1&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;scope&gt;provided&lt;/scope&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt; &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;GlobalCalcWeb&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;version&gt;${globalweb.version}&lt;/version&gt; &lt;type&gt;war&lt;/type&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;IHomeWeb&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;version&gt;${ihome.version}&lt;/version&gt; &lt;type&gt;pom&lt;/type&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;IFCResources&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;version&gt;1.0-SNAPSHOT&lt;/version&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt; &lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; There could be as many as 50 components going into the final WAR&#010;&gt;&gt; file, so it would be nice to manage them in a more organized&#010;&gt;&gt; fashion (as well as reduce the clutter in WEB-INF/lib).&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; All of the versions with properties have properties defined. The&#010;&gt;&gt; last dependency is the shaded JAR, and the one that is not behaving&#010;&gt;&gt; as expected (but probably as built / configured).&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The NetBeans graphical display of the dependencies shows&#010;&gt;&gt; IFCResources, as well as the three components it was shaded from.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Sorry for the top-post. It seems to be the norm on this list,&#010;&gt;&gt; whereas the Tomcat mailing list explicitly mentions replying at the&#010;&gt;&gt; bottom. I didn't see any mention of posting style on the site. If&#010;&gt;&gt; posting at the bottom is the encouraged form, I'll be happy to do&#010;&gt;&gt; so.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; . . . just my two cents /mde/&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 12/4/2014 8:41 PM, Ron Wheeler wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; We do this all the time and it always works.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; http://blog.artifact-software.com/tech/?p=121 Aggregation&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; jars make development simpler and wars smaller&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Partial dependencies for&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; org.mdeggers:iforeclosure:1.0-SNAPSHOT:war&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;dependencies&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;IFCResources&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;version&gt;1.0-SNAPSHOT&lt;/version&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; What are the dependencies for the war file? Partial list is&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; not much help.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 04/12/2014 6:29 PM, Mark Eggers wrote: Folks,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I admit it, I'm a bit confused (and relatively new to&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; maven).&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Goal:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; To release a WAR file with a minimal number of JAR files in&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; WEB-INF/lib.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thought:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 1. Break up the WAR project into a WAR module and a JAR&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; module 2. Make the WAR module be dependent on the JAR module&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 3. Use the Maven shade plugin in the JAR module to create a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; shaded JAR 4. Drive the entire project with an agregator&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; pom.xml&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The JAR module does shade properly, creating a single JAR&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; with all of the dependencies bundled into a single JAR. It&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; uses a pom dependency to gather in most of its requirements.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; None of the JAR or pom dependencies have further&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; dependencies, so the resulting JAR is self-contained.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; However, when I build the WAR file and reference the shaded&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; JAR file as a dependency, I do not get the shaded JAR file&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; in WEB-INF/lib. Instead, I get all of the dependencies as&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; individual JAR files in WEB-INF/lib.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm using the following environment (can post my complete&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; pom.xml files if needed).&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; OS:    Fedora Linux 64 bit - latest updates JDK:   1.7.0_72&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 64 bit Maven: 3.2.3&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; maven-shade-plugin: 2.3 maven-war-plugin:   2.4&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; shade configuration and dependencies for&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; org.mdeggers:IFCResources:1.0-SNAPSHOT&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;properties&gt; &lt;calhost.version&gt;1.0-SNAPSHOT&lt;/calhost.version&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;ihomeresources.version&gt;1.0-SNAPSHOT&lt;/ihomeresources.version&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;modules&gt; &lt;module&gt;IFCResources&lt;/module&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;module&gt;iforeclosure&lt;/module&gt; &lt;/modules&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm obviously missing something here. Thoughts, corrections,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; pointers are all appreciated.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I know, using a shaded JAR as a dependency is probably not&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; best practice. However, the resulting WAR file is an end&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; product and the shaded JAR only contains internal components&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; from other web overlays used to build the final war.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; . . . just my (confused) 2 cents /mde/&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; --- This email is free from viruses and malware because&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; avast!
