Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Little documentation issues
contents:- After using maven for 7+years, I decided that I finally knew enough &#010;about it to read the docs.&#010;I started here - &#010;http://maven.apache.org/guides/getting-started/index.html - and this led &#010;to other pages.&#010;&#010;I have found some places where a little cleaning up might help new users.&#010;There is one BIG issue and a few smaller ones.&#010;&#010;1) &#010;http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-the-lifecycle.html&#010;1a)&#010;  "Packaging&#010;&#010;The first, and most common way, is to set the packaging for your project &#010;via the equally named POM element &lt;packaging&gt;. Some of the valid &#010;packaging values are jar, war, ear and pom.&#010;"&#010;Could we have the full list here or a link to a page with the full list &#010;of the "normal" ones?&#010;Could we have a mention that plug-ins can provide new packaging. There &#010;is an example after the table of the Plexus. This discussion would be &#010;better if held together rather than split up with a discussion of &#010;binding and a table between the two parts of the story.&#010;&#010;&#010;1b) In the table following this line "Each packaging contains a list of &#010;goals to bind to a particular phase. For example, thejarpackaging will &#010;bind the following goals to build phases of the default lifecycle." a &#010;heading row would be nice.&#010;&#010;1c)&#010;Plugins are mentioned well before they are defined on the page. It would &#010;be helpful to briefly describe what a plugin is before using it as a &#010;known concept in "A Build Phase is Made Up of Plugin Goals" which never &#010;defines it before dropping "And this is done by declaring the plugin &#010;goals bound to those build phases."&#010;1d)&#010;The definition of plug-in is obscure to say the least "Plugins are &#010;artifacts that provide goals to Maven." Surely there must be a clearer &#010;way to describe the concept of plugin.&#010;This is one of the most important Maven concepts and this is a WTF &#010;definition.&#010;&#010;2) http://maven.apache.org/guides/getting-started/index.html&#010;&#010;2a)How can Maven benefit my development process? -&gt; How can Maven be of &#010;benefit to my development process? -&gt; How can Maven improve my &#010;development process?&#010;More common  English usage although the current wording is not wrong&#010;2b) How do I use plug-ins? -&gt; How do I use plugins?  no hyphen in &#010;plug-in. Whoops plugin!&#010;&#010;2c) How do I use plugins? has no description of what a plugin is.&#010;&#010;3) http://maven.apache.org/guides/mini/guide-configuring-plugins.html&#010;&#010;3a) No definition of what a plugin is; it just starts of with the &#010;assertion that there are 2 types. I am not sure that that statement is &#010;really true or if it is, it is not a very useful categorization.&#010;&#010;3b) It is recommended to always defined each version of the plugins used &#010;by the build to guarantee the build reproducibility. -&gt; It is &#010;recommended  the version of the each plugins used by the build is &#010;specified to guarantee the reproducibility of the build.&#010;A good practice is to specify them in &#010;the&lt;build&gt;&lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&lt;/build&gt;elements for*each*build plugins &#010;(generally, you will define a &lt;pluginManagement/&gt; element in a parent &#010;POM).  -&gt;&#010;  It is a good practice to specify the version in &#010;the&lt;build&gt;&lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&lt;/build&gt;element for*each*plugin. The &#010;&lt;pluginManagement/&gt; element is generally specified in a parent POM so &#010;that the same plugin version is use in all related projects.&#010;&#010;c) "Maven plugins (build and reporting) are configured by specifying &#010;a&lt;configuration&gt;element where the child elements of &#010;the&lt;configuration&gt;element are mapped to fields, or setters, inside your &#010;Mojo (remember that a plug-in consists of one or more Mojos where a Mojo &#010;maps to a goal). "&#010;Remember!!!. This is the first time a Mojo has been mentioned. It has no &#010;definition and if I look it up I get:&#010;&#010;"mo·jo1&#010;'mojo/&#010;nounUS&#010;a magic charm, talisman, or spell.&#010;"someone must have their mojo working over at the record company"&#010;magic power.&#010;synonyms:    magic, voodoo, hoodoo, wizardry, sorcery;&#010;"&#010;&#010;No wonder my builds aren't working!&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;Can these be fixed soon.&#010;&#010;Some of them are just little bugs but the lack of a clear definition and &#010;discussion  of plugins at the beginning of the "Getting Started" &#010;documentation is a really big oversight since so much of Maven depends &#010;on the built-in plugins and plugins that are created for special tasks.&#010;&#010;Now that we have a new logo and persona, it is time to fix the docs to &#010;make them more accessible.&#010;&#010;Is there a chance that I may eventually understand Maven!&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Little documentation issues
contents:- Do you want to create some pull requests?&#010;https://github.com/apache/maven-site is the repo... we can take care of&#010;pulling those patches back to SVN, so no need to worry about that part ;-)&#010;&#010;On 9 December 2014 at 16:42, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;&#010;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; After using maven for 7+years, I decided that I finally knew enough about&#010;&gt; it to read the docs.&#010;&gt; I started here - http://maven.apache.org/guides/getting-started/index.html&#010;&gt; - and this led to other pages.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I have found some places where a little cleaning up might help new users.&#010;&gt; There is one BIG issue and a few smaller ones.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 1) http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/&#010;&gt; introduction-to-the-lifecycle.html&#010;&gt; 1a)&#010;&gt;  "Packaging&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The first, and most common way, is to set the packaging for your project&#010;&gt; via the equally named POM element &lt;packaging&gt;. Some of the valid packaging&#010;&gt; values are jar, war, ear and pom.&#010;&gt; "&#010;&gt; Could we have the full list here or a link to a page with the full list of&#010;&gt; the "normal" ones?&#010;&gt; Could we have a mention that plug-ins can provide new packaging. There is&#010;&gt; an example after the table of the Plexus. This discussion would be better&#010;&gt; if held together rather than split up with a discussion of binding and a&#010;&gt; table between the two parts of the story.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 1b) In the table following this line "Each packaging contains a list of&#010;&gt; goals to bind to a particular phase. For example, thejarpackaging will bind&#010;&gt; the following goals to build phases of the default lifecycle." a heading&#010;&gt; row would be nice.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 1c)&#010;&gt; Plugins are mentioned well before they are defined on the page. It would&#010;&gt; be helpful to briefly describe what a plugin is before using it as a known&#010;&gt; concept in "A Build Phase is Made Up of Plugin Goals" which never defines&#010;&gt; it before dropping "And this is done by declaring the plugin goals bound to&#010;&gt; those build phases."&#010;&gt; 1d)&#010;&gt; The definition of plug-in is obscure to say the least "Plugins are&#010;&gt; artifacts that provide goals to Maven." Surely there must be a clearer way&#010;&gt; to describe the concept of plugin.&#010;&gt; This is one of the most important Maven concepts and this is a WTF&#010;&gt; definition.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 2) http://maven.apache.org/guides/getting-started/index.html&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 2a)How can Maven benefit my development process? -&gt; How can Maven be of&#010;&gt; benefit to my development process? -&gt; How can Maven improve my development&#010;&gt; process?&#010;&gt; More common  English usage although the current wording is not wrong&#010;&gt; 2b) How do I use plug-ins? -&gt; How do I use plugins?  no hyphen in plug-in.&#010;&gt; Whoops plugin!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 2c) How do I use plugins? has no description of what a plugin is.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 3) http://maven.apache.org/guides/mini/guide-configuring-plugins.html&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 3a) No definition of what a plugin is; it just starts of with the&#010;&gt; assertion that there are 2 types. I am not sure that that statement is&#010;&gt; really true or if it is, it is not a very useful categorization.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 3b) It is recommended to always defined each version of the plugins used&#010;&gt; by the build to guarantee the build reproducibility. -&gt; It is recommended&#010;&gt; the version of the each plugins used by the build is specified to guarantee&#010;&gt; the reproducibility of the build.&#010;&gt; A good practice is to specify them in the&lt;build&gt;&lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&lt;/build&gt;elements&#010;&gt; for*each*build plugins (generally, you will define a &lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&#010;&gt; element in a parent POM).  -&gt;&#010;&gt;  It is a good practice to specify the version in&#010;&gt; the&lt;build&gt;&lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&lt;/build&gt;element for*each*plugin. The&#010;&gt; &lt;pluginManagement/&gt; element is generally specified in a parent POM so that&#010;&gt; the same plugin version is use in all related projects.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; c) "Maven plugins (build and reporting) are configured by specifying&#010;&gt; a&lt;configuration&gt;element where the child elements of&#010;&gt; the&lt;configuration&gt;element are mapped to fields, or setters, inside your&#010;&gt; Mojo (remember that a plug-in consists of one or more Mojos where a Mojo&#010;&gt; maps to a goal). "&#010;&gt; Remember!!!. This is the first time a Mojo has been mentioned. It has no&#010;&gt; definition and if I look it up I get:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "mo·jo1&#010;&gt; 'mojo/&#010;&gt; nounUS&#010;&gt; a magic charm, talisman, or spell.&#010;&gt; "someone must have their mojo working over at the record company"&#010;&gt; magic power.&#010;&gt; synonyms:    magic, voodoo, hoodoo, wizardry, sorcery;&#010;&gt; "&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; No wonder my builds aren't working!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Can these be fixed soon.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Some of them are just little bugs but the lack of a clear definition and&#010;&gt; discussion  of plugins at the beginning of the "Getting Started"&#010;&gt; documentation is a really big oversight since so much of Maven depends on&#010;&gt; the built-in plugins and plugins that are created for special tasks.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Now that we have a new logo and persona, it is time to fix the docs to&#010;&gt; make them more accessible.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is there a chance that I may eventually understand Maven!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; President&#010;&gt; Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt; email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt; phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

There is&#010;&gt;&gt; an example after the table of the Plexus. This discussion would be better&#010;&gt;&gt; if held together rather than split up with a discussion of binding and a&#010;&gt;&gt; table between the two parts of the story.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 1b) In the table following this line "Each packaging contains a list of&#010;&gt;&gt; goals to bind to a particular phase. For example, thejarpackaging will bind&#010;&gt;&gt; the following goals to build phases of the default lifecycle." a heading&#010;&gt;&gt; row would be nice.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 1c)&#010;&gt;&gt; Plugins are mentioned well before they are defined on the page. It would&#010;&gt;&gt; be helpful to briefly describe what a plugin is before using it as a known&#010;&gt;&gt; concept in "A Build Phase is Made Up of Plugin Goals" which never defines&#010;&gt;&gt; it before dropping "And this is done by declaring the plugin goals bound to&#010;&gt;&gt; those build phases."&#010;&gt;&gt; 1d)&#010;&gt;&gt; The definition of plug-in is obscure to say the least "Plugins are&#010;&gt;&gt; artifacts that provide goals to Maven." Surely there must be a clearer way&#010;&gt;&gt; to describe the concept of plugin.&#010;&gt;&gt; This is one of the most important Maven concepts and this is a WTF&#010;&gt;&gt; definition.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 2) http://maven.apache.org/guides/getting-started/index.html&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 2a)How can Maven benefit my development process? -&gt; How can Maven be of&#010;&gt;&gt; benefit to my development process? -&gt; How can Maven improve my development&#010;&gt;&gt; process?&#010;&gt;&gt; More common  English usage although the current wording is not wrong&#010;&gt;&gt; 2b) How do I use plug-ins? -&gt; How do I use plugins?  no hyphen in&#010;&gt;&gt; plug-in. Whoops plugin!&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 2c) How do I use plugins? has no description of what a plugin is.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 3) http://maven.apache.org/guides/mini/guide-configuring-plugins.html&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 3a) No definition of what a plugin is; it just starts of with the&#010;&gt;&gt; assertion that there are 2 types. I am not sure that that statement is&#010;&gt;&gt; really true or if it is, it is not a very useful categorization.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 3b) It is recommended to always defined each version of the plugins used&#010;&gt;&gt; by the build to guarantee the build reproducibility. -&gt; It is recommended&#010;&gt;&gt; the version of the each plugins used by the build is specified to guarantee&#010;&gt;&gt; the reproducibility of the build.&#010;&gt;&gt; A good practice is to specify them in the&lt;build&gt;&lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&lt;/build&gt;elements&#010;&gt;&gt; for*each*build plugins (generally, you will define a &lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; element in a parent POM).  -&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  It is a good practice to specify the version in&#010;&gt;&gt; the&lt;build&gt;&lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&lt;/build&gt;element for*each*plugin. The&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;pluginManagement/&gt; element is generally specified in a parent POM so that&#010;&gt;&gt; the same plugin version is use in all related projects.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; c) "Maven plugins (build and reporting) are configured by specifying&#010;&gt;&gt; a&lt;configuration&gt;element where the child elements of&#010;&gt;&gt; the&lt;configuration&gt;element are mapped to fields, or setters, inside your&#010;&gt;&gt; Mojo (remember that a plug-in consists of one or more Mojos where a Mojo&#010;&gt;&gt; maps to a goal). "&#010;&gt;&gt; Remember!!!. This is the first time a Mojo has been mentioned. It has no&#010;&gt;&gt; definition and if I look it up I get:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; "mo·jo1&#010;&gt;&gt; 'mojo/&#010;&gt;&gt; nounUS&#010;&gt;&gt; a magic charm, talisman, or spell.&#010;&gt;&gt; "someone must have their mojo working over at the record company"&#010;&gt;&gt; magic power.&#010;&gt;&gt; synonyms:    magic, voodoo, hoodoo, wizardry, sorcery;&#010;&gt;&gt; "&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; No wonder my builds aren't working!&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Can these be fixed soon.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Some of them are just little bugs but the lack of a clear definition and&#010;&gt;&gt; discussion  of plugins at the beginning of the "Getting Started"&#010;&gt;&gt; documentation is a really big oversight since so much of Maven depends on&#010;&gt;&gt; the built-in plugins and plugins that are created for special tasks.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Now that we have a new logo and persona, it is time to fix the docs to&#010;&gt;&gt; make them more accessible.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Is there a chance that I may eventually understand Maven!&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; --&#010;&gt;&gt; Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt;&gt; President&#010;&gt;&gt; Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt;&gt; email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt;&gt; skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt;&gt; phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- James Green &lt;james.mk.gr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Little documentation issues
contents:- I've been wondering how to apply "explanations" to things. With ActiveMQ&#010;and Camel I just edit the Confluence wiki. If I can issue a GitHub pull&#010;request and see the change within a day or two that's fine.&#010;&#010;On 9 December 2014 at 16:52, Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Do you want to create some pull requests?&#010;&gt; https://github.com/apache/maven-site is the repo... we can take care of&#010;&gt; pulling those patches back to SVN, so no need to worry about that part ;-)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 9 December 2014 at 16:42, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;&#010;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; After using maven for 7+years, I decided that I finally knew enough about&#010;&gt; &gt; it to read the docs.&#010;&gt; &gt; I started here -&#010;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/guides/getting-started/index.html&#010;&gt; &gt; - and this led to other pages.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I have found some places where a little cleaning up might help new users.&#010;&gt; &gt; There is one BIG issue and a few smaller ones.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; 1) http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/&#010;&gt; &gt; introduction-to-the-lifecycle.html&#010;&gt; &gt; 1a)&#010;&gt; &gt;  "Packaging&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; The first, and most common way, is to set the packaging for your project&#010;&gt; &gt; via the equally named POM element &lt;packaging&gt;. Some of the valid&#010;&gt; packaging&#010;&gt; &gt; values are jar, war, ear and pom.&#010;&gt; &gt; "&#010;&gt; &gt; Could we have the full list here or a link to a page with the full list&#010;&gt; of&#010;&gt; &gt; the "normal" ones?&#010;&gt; &gt; Could we have a mention that plug-ins can provide new packaging. There is&#010;&gt; &gt; an example after the table of the Plexus. This discussion would be better&#010;&gt; &gt; if held together rather than split up with a discussion of binding and a&#010;&gt; &gt; table between the two parts of the story.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; 1b) In the table following this line "Each packaging contains a list of&#010;&gt; &gt; goals to bind to a particular phase. For example, thejarpackaging will&#010;&gt; bind&#010;&gt; &gt; the following goals to build phases of the default lifecycle." a heading&#010;&gt; &gt; row would be nice.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; 1c)&#010;&gt; &gt; Plugins are mentioned well before they are defined on the page. It would&#010;&gt; &gt; be helpful to briefly describe what a plugin is before using it as a&#010;&gt; known&#010;&gt; &gt; concept in "A Build Phase is Made Up of Plugin Goals" which never defines&#010;&gt; &gt; it before dropping "And this is done by declaring the plugin goals bound&#010;&gt; to&#010;&gt; &gt; those build phases."&#010;&gt; &gt; 1d)&#010;&gt; &gt; The definition of plug-in is obscure to say the least "Plugins are&#010;&gt; &gt; artifacts that provide goals to Maven." Surely there must be a clearer&#010;&gt; way&#010;&gt; &gt; to describe the concept of plugin.&#010;&gt; &gt; This is one of the most important Maven concepts and this is a WTF&#010;&gt; &gt; definition.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; 2) http://maven.apache.org/guides/getting-started/index.html&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; 2a)How can Maven benefit my development process? -&gt; How can Maven be of&#010;&gt; &gt; benefit to my development process? -&gt; How can Maven improve my&#010;&gt; development&#010;&gt; &gt; process?&#010;&gt; &gt; More common  English usage although the current wording is not wrong&#010;&gt; &gt; 2b) How do I use plug-ins? -&gt; How do I use plugins?  no hyphen in&#010;&gt; plug-in.&#010;&gt; &gt; Whoops plugin!&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; 2c) How do I use plugins? has no description of what a plugin is.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; 3) http://maven.apache.org/guides/mini/guide-configuring-plugins.html&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; 3a) No definition of what a plugin is; it just starts of with the&#010;&gt; &gt; assertion that there are 2 types. I am not sure that that statement is&#010;&gt; &gt; really true or if it is, it is not a very useful categorization.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; 3b) It is recommended to always defined each version of the plugins used&#010;&gt; &gt; by the build to guarantee the build reproducibility. -&gt; It is recommended&#010;&gt; &gt; the version of the each plugins used by the build is specified to&#010;&gt; guarantee&#010;&gt; &gt; the reproducibility of the build.&#010;&gt; &gt; A good practice is to specify them in&#010;&gt; the&lt;build&gt;&lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&lt;/build&gt;elements&#010;&gt; &gt; for*each*build plugins (generally, you will define a &lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; element in a parent POM).  -&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;  It is a good practice to specify the version in&#010;&gt; &gt; the&lt;build&gt;&lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&lt;/build&gt;element for*each*plugin.&#010;The&#010;&gt; &gt; &lt;pluginManagement/&gt; element is generally specified in a parent POM so&#010;&gt; that&#010;&gt; &gt; the same plugin version is use in all related projects.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; c) "Maven plugins (build and reporting) are configured by specifying&#010;&gt; &gt; a&lt;configuration&gt;element where the child elements of&#010;&gt; &gt; the&lt;configuration&gt;element are mapped to fields, or setters, inside your&#010;&gt; &gt; Mojo (remember that a plug-in consists of one or more Mojos where a Mojo&#010;&gt; &gt; maps to a goal). "&#010;&gt; &gt; Remember!!!. This is the first time a Mojo has been mentioned. It has no&#010;&gt; &gt; definition and if I look it up I get:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; "mo·jo1&#010;&gt; &gt; 'mojo/&#010;&gt; &gt; nounUS&#010;&gt; &gt; a magic charm, talisman, or spell.&#010;&gt; &gt; "someone must have their mojo working over at the record company"&#010;&gt; &gt; magic power.&#010;&gt; &gt; synonyms:    magic, voodoo, hoodoo, wizardry, sorcery;&#010;&gt; &gt; "&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; No wonder my builds aren't working!&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Can these be fixed soon.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Some of them are just little bugs but the lack of a clear definition and&#010;&gt; &gt; discussion  of plugins at the beginning of the "Getting Started"&#010;&gt; &gt; documentation is a really big oversight since so much of Maven depends on&#010;&gt; &gt; the built-in plugins and plugins that are created for special tasks.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Now that we have a new logo and persona, it is time to fix the docs to&#010;&gt; &gt; make them more accessible.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Is there a chance that I may eventually understand Maven!&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Ron&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; --&#010;&gt; &gt; Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; &gt; President&#010;&gt; &gt; Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt; &gt; email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; &gt; skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt; &gt; phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Little documentation issues
contents:- I have made some of the changes in the attached file.&#010;&#010;There is not much that can be done until the plugin definition is added.&#010;This definition will clarify a few things and may make it easier to fix &#010;some of the other things.&#010;&#010;There are sentences like this one:&#010;" The second way to add goals to phases is to configure plugins in your &#010;project. Plugins are artifacts that provide&#010;   goals to Maven."&#010;that is written from an odd point of view.&#010;&#010;If I am a Java developer, why would adding more goals be something that &#010;I want to do?&#010;&#010;Each entire sections should be written from a developers point of view. &#010;Rather than adding goals, I may want to perform some special processing &#010;during the build.&#010;This may require the configuration of additional plugins which in turn &#010;might get activated by invoking additional goals (or not).&#010;As a Java developer, I can not add goals unless the goals are part of &#010;the plugin and I would only add goals&#010;a) if the goals were not already in the standard maven build flow AND&#010;b) the goal is available in the plugin.&#010;&#010;I suspect that this is a common problem with the Introductory &#010;documentation that makes it hard for a Java developer to read.&#010;&#010;Can someone suggest a description of "plugin" and "Mojo" that is written &#010;from a developer's point of view but sufficiently close to the technical &#010;reality that it will not cause trouble when someone starts to read the &#010;Plugin Developer's sections.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;On 09/12/2014 11:42 AM, Ron Wheeler wrote:&#010;&gt; After using maven for 7+years, I decided that I finally knew enough &#010;&gt; about it to read the docs.&#010;&gt; I started here - &#010;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/guides/getting-started/index.html - and this &#010;&gt; led to other pages.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I have found some places where a little cleaning up might help new users.&#010;&gt; There is one BIG issue and a few smaller ones.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 1) &#010;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-the-lifecycle.html&#010;&gt; 1a)&#010;&gt;  "Packaging&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The first, and most common way, is to set the packaging for your &#010;&gt; project via the equally named POM element &lt;packaging&gt;. Some of the &#010;&gt; valid packaging values are jar, war, ear and pom.&#010;&gt; "&#010;&gt; Could we have the full list here or a link to a page with the full &#010;&gt; list of the "normal" ones?&#010;&gt; Could we have a mention that plug-ins can provide new packaging. There &#010;&gt; is an example after the table of the Plexus. This discussion would be &#010;&gt; better if held together rather than split up with a discussion of &#010;&gt; binding and a table between the two parts of the story.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 1b) In the table following this line "Each packaging contains a list &#010;&gt; of goals to bind to a particular phase. For example, thejarpackaging &#010;&gt; will bind the following goals to build phases of the default &#010;&gt; lifecycle." a heading row would be nice.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 1c)&#010;&gt; Plugins are mentioned well before they are defined on the page. It &#010;&gt; would be helpful to briefly describe what a plugin is before using it &#010;&gt; as a known concept in "A Build Phase is Made Up of Plugin Goals" which &#010;&gt; never defines it before dropping "And this is done by declaring the &#010;&gt; plugin goals bound to those build phases."&#010;&gt; 1d)&#010;&gt; The definition of plug-in is obscure to say the least "Plugins are &#010;&gt; artifacts that provide goals to Maven." Surely there must be a clearer &#010;&gt; way to describe the concept of plugin.&#010;&gt; This is one of the most important Maven concepts and this is a WTF &#010;&gt; definition.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 2) http://maven.apache.org/guides/getting-started/index.html&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 2a)How can Maven benefit my development process? -&gt; How can Maven be &#010;&gt; of benefit to my development process? -&gt; How can Maven improve my &#010;&gt; development process?&#010;&gt; More common  English usage although the current wording is not wrong&#010;&gt; 2b) How do I use plug-ins? -&gt; How do I use plugins?  no hyphen in &#010;&gt; plug-in. Whoops plugin!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 2c) How do I use plugins? has no description of what a plugin is.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 3) http://maven.apache.org/guides/mini/guide-configuring-plugins.html&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 3a) No definition of what a plugin is; it just starts of with the &#010;&gt; assertion that there are 2 types. I am not sure that that statement is &#010;&gt; really true or if it is, it is not a very useful categorization.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 3b) It is recommended to always defined each version of the plugins &#010;&gt; used by the build to guarantee the build reproducibility. -&gt; It is &#010;&gt; recommended  the version of the each plugins used by the build is &#010;&gt; specified to guarantee the reproducibility of the build.&#010;&gt; A good practice is to specify them in &#010;&gt; the&lt;build&gt;&lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&lt;/build&gt;elements for*each*build plugins&#010;&#010;&gt; (generally, you will define a &lt;pluginManagement/&gt; element in a parent &#010;&gt; POM).  -&gt;&#010;&gt;  It is a good practice to specify the version in &#010;&gt; the&lt;build&gt;&lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&lt;/build&gt;element for*each*plugin. The &#010;&gt; &lt;pluginManagement/&gt; element is generally specified in a parent POM so &#010;&gt; that the same plugin version is use in all related projects.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; c) "Maven plugins (build and reporting) are configured by specifying &#010;&gt; a&lt;configuration&gt;element where the child elements of &#010;&gt; the&lt;configuration&gt;element are mapped to fields, or setters, inside &#010;&gt; your Mojo (remember that a plug-in consists of one or more Mojos where &#010;&gt; a Mojo maps to a goal). "&#010;&gt; Remember!!!. This is the first time a Mojo has been mentioned. It has &#010;&gt; no definition and if I look it up I get:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "mo·jo1&#010;&gt; 'mojo/&#010;&gt; nounUS&#010;&gt; a magic charm, talisman, or spell.&#010;&gt; "someone must have their mojo working over at the record company"&#010;&gt; magic power.&#010;&gt; synonyms:    magic, voodoo, hoodoo, wizardry, sorcery;&#010;&gt; "&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; No wonder my builds aren't working!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Can these be fixed soon.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Some of them are just little bugs but the lack of a clear definition &#010;&gt; and discussion  of plugins at the beginning of the "Getting Started" &#010;&gt; documentation is a really big oversight since so much of Maven depends &#010;&gt; on the built-in plugins and plugins that are created for special tasks.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Now that we have a new logo and persona, it is time to fix the docs to &#010;&gt; make them more accessible.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is there a chance that I may eventually understand Maven!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Curtis Rueden &lt;ctrue...@wisc.edu&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Little documentation issues
contents:- Hi all,&#010;&#010;&gt; Can someone suggest a description of "plugin" and "Mojo" that is&#010;&gt; written from a developer's point of view but sufficiently close to the&#010;&gt; technical reality that it will not cause trouble when someone starts&#010;&gt; to read the Plugin Developer's sections.&#010;&#010;Here's my first cut at it:&#010;&#010;A *plugin* is an extension of Maven that provides additional behavior&#010;during a build. Nearly every aspect of a Maven build is defined as plugins.&#010;For example, the maven-compiler-plugin provides the logic needed to compile&#010;Java classes from sources, and the maven-jar-plugin knows how to packages&#010;those Java classes into JAR files.&#010;&#010;Plugins that are part of the official Maven project are named according to&#010;the pattern "maven-&lt;foo&gt;-plugin", where &lt;foo&gt; relates to the plugin's&#010;purpose (e.g., "compiler" or "jar" as described above). Unofficial plugins,&#010;such as those produced by the Codehaus project, are typically named&#010;according to the pattern "&lt;foo&gt;-maven-plugin" to avoid any implication that&#010;they are somehow official Maven(TM) products.&#010;&#010;Every plugin consists of a collection of *goals*, each of which defines&#010;specific behavior. Some goals automatically become part of the build when&#010;the plugin is declared in your POM, injecting themselves at the appropriate&#010;phase in the build's default lifecycle&#010;&lt;http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-the-lifecycle.html&gt;.&#010;Others need to be explicitly bound to the desired phase(s) as *executions*.&#010;Some sophisticated plugins (such as the nar-maven-plugin&#010;&lt;https://github.com/maven-nar/nar-maven-plugin&gt;) even define new phases of&#010;the lifecycle. Each plugin goal is implemented as a mojo&#010;&lt;http://maven.apache.org/developers/mojo-api-specification.html&gt;: a Java&#010;class providing the code necessary to accomplish that specific goal. For&#010;that reason, people sometimes use the terms "goal" and "mojo"&#010;interchangeably.&#010;&#010;The ecosystem of available plugins makes Maven an exceptionally versatile&#010;and powerful tool for managing nearly every imaginable aspect of your&#010;project's build process.&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;Curtis&#010;&#010;P.S. I disclaim all copyright interest in the above. Please use / steal /&#010;edit / tear apart / throw away as you wish.&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;On Tue, Dec 9, 2014 at 1:58 PM, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;&#010;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I have made some of the changes in the attached file.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; There is not much that can be done until the plugin definition is added.&#010;&gt; This definition will clarify a few things and may make it easier to fix&#010;&gt; some of the other things.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; There are sentences like this one:&#010;&gt; " The second way to add goals to phases is to configure plugins in your&#010;&gt; project. Plugins are artifacts that provide&#010;&gt;   goals to Maven."&#010;&gt; that is written from an odd point of view.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; If I am a Java developer, why would adding more goals be something that I&#010;&gt; want to do?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Each entire sections should be written from a developers point of view.&#010;&gt; Rather than adding goals, I may want to perform some special processing&#010;&gt; during the build.&#010;&gt; This may require the configuration of additional plugins which in turn&#010;&gt; might get activated by invoking additional goals (or not).&#010;&gt; As a Java developer, I can not add goals unless the goals are part of the&#010;&gt; plugin and I would only add goals&#010;&gt; a) if the goals were not already in the standard maven build flow AND&#010;&gt; b) the goal is available in the plugin.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I suspect that this is a common problem with the Introductory&#010;&gt; documentation that makes it hard for a Java developer to read.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Can someone suggest a description of "plugin" and "Mojo" that is written&#010;&gt; from a developer's point of view but sufficiently close to the technical&#010;&gt; reality that it will not cause trouble when someone starts to read the&#010;&gt; Plugin Developer's sections.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 09/12/2014 11:42 AM, Ron Wheeler wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; html - and this led to other pages.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I have found some places where a little cleaning up might help new users.&#010;&gt;&gt; There is one BIG issue and a few smaller ones.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 1) http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/&#010;&gt;&gt; introduction-to-the-lifecycle.html&#010;&gt;&gt; 1a)&#010;&gt;&gt;  "Packaging&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The first, and most common way, is to set the packaging for your project&#010;&gt;&gt; via the equally named POM element &lt;packaging&gt;. Some of the valid packaging&#010;&gt;&gt; values are jar, war, ear and pom.&#010;&gt;&gt; "&#010;&gt;&gt; Could we have the full list here or a link to a page with the full list&#010;&gt;&gt; of the "normal" ones?&#010;&gt;&gt; Could we have a mention that plug-ins can provide new packaging. There is&#010;&gt;&gt; an example after the table of the Plexus. This discussion would be better&#010;&gt;&gt; if held together rather than split up with a discussion of binding and a&#010;&gt;&gt; table between the two parts of the story.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 1b) In the table following this line "Each packaging contains a list of&#010;&gt;&gt; goals to bind to a particular phase. For example, thejarpackaging will bind&#010;&gt;&gt; the following goals to build phases of the default lifecycle." a heading&#010;&gt;&gt; row would be nice.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 1c)&#010;&gt;&gt; Plugins are mentioned well before they are defined on the page. It would&#010;&gt;&gt; be helpful to briefly describe what a plugin is before using it as a known&#010;&gt;&gt; concept in "A Build Phase is Made Up of Plugin Goals" which never defines&#010;&gt;&gt; it before dropping "And this is done by declaring the plugin goals bound to&#010;&gt;&gt; those build phases."&#010;&gt;&gt; 1d)&#010;&gt;&gt; The definition of plug-in is obscure to say the least "Plugins are&#010;&gt;&gt; artifacts that provide goals to Maven." Surely there must be a clearer way&#010;&gt;&gt; to describe the concept of plugin.&#010;&gt;&gt; This is one of the most important Maven concepts and this is a WTF&#010;&gt;&gt; definition.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 2) http://maven.apache.org/guides/getting-started/index.html&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 2a)How can Maven benefit my development process? -&gt; How can Maven be of&#010;&gt;&gt; benefit to my development process? -&gt; How can Maven improve my development&#010;&gt;&gt; process?&#010;&gt;&gt; More common  English usage although the current wording is not wrong&#010;&gt;&gt; 2b) How do I use plug-ins? -&gt; How do I use plugins?  no hyphen in&#010;&gt;&gt; plug-in. Whoops plugin!&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 2c) How do I use plugins? has no description of what a plugin is.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 3) http://maven.apache.org/guides/mini/guide-configuring-plugins.html&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 3a) No definition of what a plugin is; it just starts of with the&#010;&gt;&gt; assertion that there are 2 types. I am not sure that that statement is&#010;&gt;&gt; really true or if it is, it is not a very useful categorization.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 3b) It is recommended to always defined each version of the plugins used&#010;&gt;&gt; by the build to guarantee the build reproducibility. -&gt; It is recommended&#010;&gt;&gt; the version of the each plugins used by the build is specified to guarantee&#010;&gt;&gt; the reproducibility of the build.&#010;&gt;&gt; A good practice is to specify them in the&lt;build&gt;&lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&lt;/build&gt;elements&#010;&gt;&gt; for*each*build plugins (generally, you will define a &lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; element in a parent POM).  -&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  It is a good practice to specify the version in&#010;&gt;&gt; the&lt;build&gt;&lt;pluginManagement/&gt;&lt;/build&gt;element for*each*plugin. The&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;pluginManagement/&gt; element is generally specified in a parent POM so that&#010;&gt;&gt; the same plugin version is use in all related projects.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; c) "Maven plugins (build and reporting) are configured by specifying&#010;&gt;&gt; a&lt;configuration&gt;element where the child elements of&#010;&gt;&gt; the&lt;configuration&gt;element are mapped to fields, or setters, inside your&#010;&gt;&gt; Mojo (remember that a plug-in consists of one or more Mojos where a Mojo&#010;&gt;&gt; maps to a goal). "&#010;&gt;&gt; Remember!!!. This is the first time a Mojo has been mentioned. It has no&#010;&gt;&gt; definition and if I look it up I get:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; "mo·jo1&#010;&gt;&gt; 'mojo/&#010;&gt;&gt; nounUS&#010;&gt;&gt; a magic charm, talisman, or spell.&#010;&gt;&gt; "someone must have their mojo working over at the record company"&#010;&gt;&gt; magic power.&#010;&gt;&gt; synonyms:    magic, voodoo, hoodoo, wizardry, sorcery;&#010;&gt;&gt; "&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; No wonder my builds aren't working!&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Can these be fixed soon.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Some of them are just little bugs but the lack of a clear definition and&#010;&gt;&gt; discussion  of plugins at the beginning of the "Getting Started"&#010;&gt;&gt; documentation is a really big oversight since so much of Maven depends on&#010;&gt;&gt; the built-in plugins and plugins that are created for special tasks.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Now that we have a new logo and persona, it is time to fix the docs to&#010;&gt;&gt; make them more accessible.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Is there a chance that I may eventually understand Maven!&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; President&#010;&gt; Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt; email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt; phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- &quot;Mark H. Wood&quot; &lt;mw...@IUPUI.Edu&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Little documentation issues
contents:- Thinking about the developer's perspective a bit, I came up with some&#010;suggestions but no actual language.&#010;&#010;The developer is a person who wants to build units of software into&#010;distributable products, so it's useful to talk briefly about&#010;"lifecycle", "phase", "goal", "execution", and "artifact" in terms&#010;familiar to such a person.  *Briefly* -- full details should be&#010;linked.  This is simply to define terms which will then be used to map&#010;the nature of "Maven plugin" to his experience.&#010;&#010;A developer probably has a general notion of what a "plugin" is, so&#010;what he needs is to know what a *Maven* plugin is: an assembly of Java&#010;classes which provides additional concepts and behaviors that the&#010;Maven framework can use in building your projects.  It can define&#010;additional lifecycles and phases, and it provides goals that you may&#010;bind to phases in order to perform additional work during the build.&#010;There should be a link to how one creates a Maven plugin, elsewhere.&#010;&#010;It may be well to mention at *this* point that much of Maven's&#010;"built-in" behavior is actually provided by included plugins.  In this&#010;way, one first learns what a Maven plugin is and then immediately sees&#010;application of the concept through the lens of the knowledge one has&#010;just gained.  Perhaps pick one common plugin as an example.&#010;&#010;Someone noted that "goal" and "Mojo" are often used interchangeably,&#010;but it may be good to mention here that "goal" is a named behavior and&#010;"Mojo" is its implementation.  (If I have that right.)&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Mark H. Wood&#010;Lead Technology Analyst&#010;&#010;University Library&#010;Indiana University - Purdue University Indianapolis&#010;755 W. Michigan Street&#010;Indianapolis, IN 46202&#010;317-274-0749&#010;www.ulib.iupui.edu&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Little documentation issues
contents:- One of the wonderful features about Maven is that no matter how long one &#010;has been using it or how much one has studied Maven documentation , one &#010;still feels the necessity of ending every assertion about how it works &#010;with "(If I have that right.)" .&#010;&#010;I am so happy to not be alone!&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;On 10/12/2014 10:48 AM, Mark H. Wood wrote:&#010;&gt; Thinking about the developer's perspective a bit, I came up with some&#010;&gt; suggestions but no actual language.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The developer is a person who wants to build units of software into&#010;&gt; distributable products, so it's useful to talk briefly about&#010;&gt; "lifecycle", "phase", "goal", "execution", and "artifact" in terms&#010;&gt; familiar to such a person.  *Briefly* -- full details should be&#010;&gt; linked.  This is simply to define terms which will then be used to map&#010;&gt; the nature of "Maven plugin" to his experience.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; A developer probably has a general notion of what a "plugin" is, so&#010;&gt; what he needs is to know what a *Maven* plugin is: an assembly of Java&#010;&gt; classes which provides additional concepts and behaviors that the&#010;&gt; Maven framework can use in building your projects.  It can define&#010;&gt; additional lifecycles and phases, and it provides goals that you may&#010;&gt; bind to phases in order to perform additional work during the build.&#010;&gt; There should be a link to how one creates a Maven plugin, elsewhere.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; It may be well to mention at *this* point that much of Maven's&#010;&gt; "built-in" behavior is actually provided by included plugins.  In this&#010;&gt; way, one first learns what a Maven plugin is and then immediately sees&#010;&gt; application of the concept through the lens of the knowledge one has&#010;&gt; just gained.  Perhaps pick one common plugin as an example.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Someone noted that "goal" and "Mojo" are often used interchangeably,&#010;&gt; but it may be good to mention here that "goal" is a named behavior and&#010;&gt; "Mojo" is its implementation.  (If I have that right.)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Repositories settings best practice
contents:- On 12 December 2014 at 15:10, Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Where is in the official doc, this should land?&#010;&#010;&#010;That's an awfully good question.&#010;There is another thread about re-organising the documentation.&#010;&#010;The User Centre (http://maven.apache.org/users/index.html) docs are pretty&#010;thin, but I would expect this advice to land in there.&#010;&#010;Or perhaps the Run Maven &gt; Configuring Maven (&#010;http://maven.apache.org/guides/mini/guide-configuring-maven.html) has a&#010;section on Mirrors that links to&#010;http://maven.apache.org/guides/mini/guide-mirror-settings.html.&#010;The first sentence says "Repositories are declared inside a project, which&#010;means that if you have your own custom repositories, those sharing your&#010;project easily get the right settings out of the box." which runs against&#010;the current advice.&#010;&#010;Unfortunately those mini-guides dont have a hierarchy available on the left&#010;hand navigation page and hacking the URL to drop of the last path just&#010;gives a blank page.&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Adrien Rivard &lt;adrien.riv...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Errors that look like the compiler is using 1.5 jdk
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;Your are probably missing&#010;&#010;        &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;          &lt;source&gt;1.7&lt;/source&gt;&#010;          &lt;target&gt;1.7&lt;/target&gt;&#010;        &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;Basically you are using the 1.7 compiler to compile java5 source code&#010;to java 5 byte code (1.5 is the default value for source/target IIRC)&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;On Fri, Dec 12, 2014 at 5:11 PM, jeff_gaer &lt;jeff_gaer@yahoo.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I am building with jdk 1.7 but getting an compiler error that suggests mvn&#010;&gt; is&#010;&gt; using the 1.5 jdk ( which is not installed).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;  error: multi-catch statement is not supported in -source 1.5&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Here is my environment&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Maven home: /opt/apache-maven-3.0.4&#010;&gt; Java version: 1.7.0_25, vendor: Oracle Corporation&#010;&gt; Java home: /usr/java/jdk1.7.0_25/jre&#010;&gt; Default locale: en_US, platform encoding: UTF-8&#010;&gt; OS name: "linux", version: "2.6.18-274.el5", arch: "i386", family: "unix"&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I have even tried specifically specifying the JDK version in the compile&#010;&gt; plugin&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;plugins&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-compiler-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;version&gt;3.2&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;verbose&gt;true&lt;/verbose&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;fork&gt;true&lt;/fork&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;executable&gt;${JAVA_HOME}/bin/javac&lt;/executable&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;compilerVersion&gt;1.7&lt;/compilerVersion&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Name  :- Nick Stolwijk &lt;nick.stolw...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Building selected projects with nested aggregators
contents:- Hello all,&#010;&#010;We also want to build a --project-list with a aggregator pom, so all the&#010;modules of  that pom are getting build. In the mean time, we also want the&#010;dependencies of those module to  build. (So, --also-make). Only we can't&#010;get this to run. Is there anyone who can help with this?&#010;&#010;We were thinking of a Bash or Groovy script to parse the aggregator pom to&#010;build up the --project-list argument.&#010;&#010;Does anyone see an easier way?&#010;&#010;With regards,&#010;&#010;Nick Stolwijk&#010;&#010;~~~ Try to leave this world a little better than you found it and, when&#010;your turn comes to die, you can die happy in feeling that at any rate you&#010;have not wasted your time but have done your best ~~~&#010;&#010;Lord Baden-Powell&#010;&#010;On Tue, May 7, 2013 at 2:39 AM, spoots &lt;spootsy.ootsy@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Thanks for the reply, again :)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I don't think "-amd" covers my need though. Because there's no parent/child&#010;&gt; relationship between the modules/sub-modules there's no dependency between&#010;&gt; them. It feels to me like there's an option missing for the reactor here...&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; A simpler example for clarity:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &amp;lt;a&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;   &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;     &amp;lt;c /&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;     &amp;lt;d /&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;     &amp;lt;e /&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;   &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;   &amp;lt;f /&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;   &amp;lt;g /&amp;gt;&#010;&gt; &amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Each node is a project, and sub-projects are nested. For dependencies, say&#010;&gt; only that "c depends on f". There are no parent-child relationships.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; If I want to build &amp;lt;b&amp;gt; with all its sub-modules (&amp;lt;c&amp;gt; &amp;lt;d&amp;gt;&#010;&gt; &amp;lt;e&amp;gt;) and dependencies (&amp;lt;f&amp;gt;), can I do that? The only options&#010;I&#010;&gt; see are:&#010;&gt; 1 - change to b directory, then "mvn install"&#010;&gt; 2 - from top level, "mvn install -pl a/b -amd"&#010;&gt; 3 - from top level, "mvn install -pl a/b/c,a/b/d,a/b/e -amd"&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Option 1 builds the sub-modules I want, but doesn't build the dependency&#010;&gt; &amp;lt;f&amp;gt;.&#010;&gt; Option 2 only builds the project &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;, none of it's sub-modules&#010;&gt; because&#010;&gt; they are not dependents.&#010;&gt; Option 3 works, but it's no good because I need to know &amp; provide all the&#010;&gt; sub-modules of &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Ideally there'd be an option like "-ams" (also make sub-modules) which I&#010;&gt; could use in option 2, but I can't see any way to do it?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context:&#010;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Building-selected-projects-with-nested-aggregators-tp5753572p5755076.html&#010;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Nick Stolwijk &lt;nick.stolw...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Building selected projects with nested aggregators
contents:- Hello all,&#010;&#010;We also want to build a --project-list with a aggregator pom, so all the&#010;modules of  that pom are getting build. In the mean time, we also want the&#010;dependencies of those module to  build. (So, --also-make). Only we can't&#010;get this to run. Is there anyone who can help with this?&#010;&#010;We were thinking of a Bash or Groovy script to parse the aggregator pom to&#010;build up the --project-list argument.&#010;&#010;Does anyone see an easier way?&#010;&#010;With regards,&#010;&#010;Nick Stolwijk&#010;&#010;~~~ Try to leave this world a little better than you found it and, when&#010;your turn comes to die, you can die happy in feeling that at any rate you&#010;have not wasted your time but have done your best ~~~&#010;&#010;Lord Baden-Powell&#010;&#010;On Tue, May 7, 2013 at 2:39 AM, spoots &lt;spootsy.ootsy@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Thanks for the reply, again :)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I don't think "-amd" covers my need though. Because there's no parent/child&#010;&gt; relationship between the modules/sub-modules there's no dependency between&#010;&gt; them. It feels to me like there's an option missing for the reactor here...&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; A simpler example for clarity:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &amp;lt;a&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;   &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;     &amp;lt;c /&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;     &amp;lt;d /&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;     &amp;lt;e /&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;   &amp;lt;/b&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;   &amp;lt;f /&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;   &amp;lt;g /&amp;gt;&#010;&gt; &amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Each node is a project, and sub-projects are nested. For dependencies, say&#010;&gt; only that "c depends on f". There are no parent-child relationships.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; If I want to build &amp;lt;b&amp;gt; with all its sub-modules (&amp;lt;c&amp;gt; &amp;lt;d&amp;gt;&#010;&gt; &amp;lt;e&amp;gt;) and dependencies (&amp;lt;f&amp;gt;), can I do that? The only options&#010;I&#010;&gt; see are:&#010;&gt; 1 - change to b directory, then "mvn install"&#010;&gt; 2 - from top level, "mvn install -pl a/b -amd"&#010;&gt; 3 - from top level, "mvn install -pl a/b/c,a/b/d,a/b/e -amd"&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Option 1 builds the sub-modules I want, but doesn't build the dependency&#010;&gt; &amp;lt;f&amp;gt;.&#010;&gt; Option 2 only builds the project &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;, none of it's sub-modules&#010;&gt; because&#010;&gt; they are not dependents.&#010;&gt; Option 3 works, but it's no good because I need to know &amp; provide all the&#010;&gt; sub-modules of &amp;lt;b&amp;gt;.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Ideally there'd be an option like "-ams" (also make sub-modules) which I&#010;&gt; could use in option 2, but I can't see any way to do it?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context:&#010;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Building-selected-projects-with-nested-aggregators-tp5753572p5755076.html&#010;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Karl Heinz Marbaise &lt;khmarba...@gmx.de&gt;
Subject  :-Fwd: ApacheCon NA 2015 Travel Assistance Applications now open!
contents:- Hi to all,&#010;&#010;for you information about ApacheCON 2015...Travel Assistance Applications...&#010;&#010;-------- Forwarded Message --------&#010;Subject: &#009;ApacheCon NA 2015 Travel Assistance Applications now open!&#010;Date: &#009;Sat, 13 Dec 2014 13:59:15 +0100&#010;From: &#009;jan i &lt;jani@apache.org&gt;&#010;Reply-To: &#009;Maven Project Management Committee List&#010;&lt;private@maven.apache.org&gt;&#010;To: &#009;travel-assistance@apache.org &lt;travel-assistance@apache.org&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;Hi pmcs@,&#010;&#010;The Travel Assistance Committee (TAC) are pleased to announce that&#010;travel assistance applications for ApacheCon North America 2015 are now&#010;open! This announcement serves as a purpose for you (pmcs@) to let&#010;members of your community know about both ApacheConNA 2015 and about the&#010;TAC assistance to attend. Could you please forward this announcement to&#010;your community, along if possible with information on how your project&#010;is involved in ApacheCon this year?&#010;&#010;We'll be holding ApacheCon North America 2015 in populous Austin, TX&#010;April 13 - 17, 2015.&#010;&#010;TAC exists to help those that would like to attend ApacheCon events, but&#010;are unable to do so for financial reasons. For more info on this years&#010;applications and qualifying criteria please visit the TAC website at &lt;&#010;http://www.apache.org/travel/ &gt;.  Applications are already open, so&#010;don't delay!&#010;&#010;*Important dates*...&#010;&#010;   * Sunday 1th February2015 - CFP closes&#010;   * Friday 6th February 2015 - TAC Applications close&#010;&#010;Applicants have until the the closing date above to submit their&#010;applications (which should contain as much supporting material as&#010;required to efficiently and accurately process your request), this will&#010;enable TAC to announce successful awards shortly afterwards.&#010;&#010;As usual TAC expects to deal with a range of applications from a diverse&#010;range of backgrounds. We therefore encourage (as always) anyone thinking&#010;about sending in an application to do so ASAP.&#010;&#010;We look forward to greeting everyone in Austin, Texas in April.&#010;&#010;Kind Regards&#010;&#010;jan i&#010;&#010;(On behalf of the Travel Assistance Committee)&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;Kind regards&#010;Karl Heinz Marbaise&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

contents:- Hi to all,&#010;&#010;for you information about ApacheCON 2015...Travel Assistance Applications...&#010;&#010;-------- Forwarded Message --------&#010;Subject: &#009;ApacheCon NA 2015 Travel Assistance Applications now open!&#010;Date: &#009;Sat, 13 Dec 2014 13:59:15 +0100&#010;From: &#009;jan i &lt;jani@apache.org&gt;&#010;Reply-To: &#009;Maven Project Management Committee List&#010;&lt;private@maven.apache.org&gt;&#010;To: &#009;travel-assistance@apache.org &lt;travel-assistance@apache.org&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;Hi pmcs@,&#010;&#010;The Travel Assistance Committee (TAC) are pleased to announce that&#010;travel assistance applications for ApacheCon North America 2015 are now&#010;open! contents:- On the basis of any preference expressed:&#010;&#010;H: has 12 preferences expressed&#010;K: has 10 preferences expressed&#010;B: has 6 preferences expressed&#010;&#010;I declare the winners of the run-off to be H and K (i.e. "Shotgun" and "The&#010;Maven Owl")&#010;&#010;I will now start a vote thread to decide the overall winner&#010;&#010;(And hopefully fend off Kristian and any attempts to run a stalking horse&#010;3rd candidate of "Shotgun, the Maven Owl" ;-) )&#010;&#010;-Stephen&#010;&#010;&#010;On 15 December 2014 at 10:29, Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; A had no transfers to promote&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 15 December 2014 at 10:28, Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;&gt; stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; At this point we have:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; A with 2x1st pref, 1x2nd pref (or 3 any pref votes)&#010;&gt;&gt; B with 5x1st pref, 1x2nd pref (or 6 any pref votes)&#010;&gt;&gt; H with 10x1st pref, 2x2nd pref (or 12 any pref votes)&#010;&gt;&gt; K with 4x1st pref, 5x2nd pref, 1x3rd pref (or 10 any pref votes)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The lowest by any measure is A, so I will eliminate A and proceed to&#010;&gt;&gt; produce a count&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 15 December 2014 at 10:24, Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;&gt;&gt; stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; In Round 3, E only has 2nd preference votes (I could have eliminated E&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; earlier, but given the transfers it makes no difference to the result...) I&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; will now eliminate E and promote its preferences (which all go to K  by the&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; way)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 15 December 2014 at 10:21, Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; D has less second preferences that the other elimination candidate: A&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; (based on votes of any preference) so eliminating D and promoting it's&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; preferences accordingly (IOW Michael O's 2nd pref for A now becomes a 1st&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; pref for A in round 3)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 15 December 2014 at 10:16, Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; After counting the 21 votes cast. Name  :- Christian Domsch &lt;m...@landrus.de&gt;
Subject  :-Installing only javadocs
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;I have a continuous integration setup where the build is setup in two &#010;steps. First all modules are built and deployed. After that a second &#010;build is triggered that takes those artifacts and builds installers from &#010;that.&#010;&#010;Because of performance reasons and they are only needed for the &#010;installers, any javadoc jars are only being built in the second step. &#010;Now I want to install these jars into the local repo as well. A call to &#010;javadoc:jar only creates those jars, not copy them over to the local repo.&#010;&#010;I do not want to run mvn install, as that would run the complete build &#010;again. Now, I looked at the documentation of maven-javadoc-plugin and &#010;the maven-install-plugin but I couldnt find a way to only install the &#010;javadocs. (something like mvn javadoc:jar javadoc:install, if such a &#010;goal would exist).&#010;&#010;Is there a way to achieve that or am I on the wrong track?&#010;&#010;Greetings,&#010;&#010;Christian&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Christian Domsch &lt;m...@landrus.de&gt;
Subject  :-Installing only javadocs
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;I have a continuous integration setup where the build is setup in two &#010;steps. First all modules are built and deployed. After that a second &#010;build is triggered that takes those artifacts and builds installers from &#010;that.&#010;&#010;Because of performance reasons and they are only needed for the &#010;installers, any javadoc jars are only being built in the second step. &#010;Now I want to install these jars into the local repo as well. A call to &#010;javadoc:jar only creates those jars, not copy them over to the local repo.&#010;&#010;I do not want to run mvn install, as that would run the complete build &#010;again. Now, I looked at the documentation of maven-javadoc-plugin and &#010;the maven-install-plugin but I couldnt find a way to only install the &#010;javadocs. (something like mvn javadoc:jar javadoc:install, if such a &#010;goal would exist).&#010;&#010;Is there a way to achieve that or am I on the wrong track?&#010;&#010;Greetings,&#010;&#010;Christian&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Installing only javadocs
contents:- Wrong track.&#010;&#010;On 15 December 2014 at 13:13, Christian Domsch &lt;mail@landrus.de&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I have a continuous integration setup where the build is setup in two&#010;&gt; steps. First all modules are built and deployed. After that a second build&#010;&gt; is triggered that takes those artifacts and builds installers from that.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;You should have separate modules that transform the artifacts into&#010;installers for those artifacts.&#010;&#010;Those separate moduled can even be in a separate SCM root as you may&#010;release the first modules multiple times but only build installers from the&#010;last time.&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Because of performance reasons and they are only needed for the&#010;&gt; installers, any javadoc jars are only being built in the second step. Now I&#010;&gt; want to install these jars into the local repo as well. Name  :- Christian Domsch &lt;m...@landrus.de&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Installing only javadocs
contents:- Hi Stephen,&#010;&#010;that is actually the way it is setup. With one minor problem, the &#010;installers need the javadocs from the other modules as well. And we do &#010;not build them during the normal built because of performance reasons &#010;(it takes ~15mins to create them).&#010;&#010;You are right, the installer modules could be even completly decoupled, &#010;what we have are submodules that are activated via a profile.&#010;&#010;But to built the javadocs I have to go into the original modules again &#010;and create the javadocs. This so far is working. But in this setup, the &#010;installer modules have no access to the javadocs, since they onlide &#010;reside inside the target folders and not the local repository.&#010;&#010;Maybe to illustrate:&#010;&#010;Main module:&#010;   root/module/A&#010;              /B&#010;              /C&#010;              /D/D1&#010;                /D2&#010;&#010;Installer:&#010;   root/installers/instA&#010;                  /instB&#010;&#010;&#010;What I currently run is mvn deployin the main build, with disabled &#010;javadoc generation.&#010;For the installers, I runmvn javadoc:jarin the main module directory, &#010;and then mvn installin the installer directory. But again, javadoc:jar &#010;does not copy to local repo, so when the installers are run the &#010;(possibly) reference old javadocs that are still in the local repo, &#010;instead of using the just generated javadocs.&#010;&#010;Hope this clarifies the problem&#010;&#010;Thanks,&#010;Christian&#010;&#010;On 15.12.2014 15:47, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt; Wrong track.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 15 December 2014 at 13:13, Christian Domsch &lt;mail@landrus.de&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I have a continuous integration setup where the build is setup in two&#010;&gt;&gt; steps. First all modules are built and deployed. After that a second build&#010;&gt;&gt; is triggered that takes those artifacts and builds installers from that.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; You should have separate modules that transform the artifacts into&#010;&gt; installers for those artifacts.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Those separate moduled can even be in a separate SCM root as you may&#010;&gt; release the first modules multiple times but only build installers from the&#010;&gt; last time.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Because of performance reasons and they are only needed for the&#010;&gt;&gt; installers, any javadoc jars are only being built in the second step. Now I&#010;&gt;&gt; want to install these jars into the local repo as well. A call to&#010;&gt;&gt; javadoc:jar only creates those jars, not copy them over to the local repo.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I do not want to run mvn install, as that would run the complete build&#010;&gt;&gt; again. Now, I looked at the documentation of maven-javadoc-plugin and the&#010;&gt;&gt; maven-install-plugin but I couldnt find a way to only install the javadocs.&#010;&gt;&gt; (something like mvn javadoc:jar javadoc:install, if such a goal would&#010;&gt;&gt; exist).&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Is there a way to achieve that or am I on the wrong track?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Greetings,&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Christian&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Melvyn de Kort &lt;m.de.k...@portbase.com&gt;
Subject  :-SCM config with *special* setup
contents:- Hello everybody,&#010;&#010;My team is currently migrating a legacy Ant project with a bad Subversion layout to Maven.&#010;We're running into 2 problems with the Maven scm configuration.&#010;Let me first sketch the Subversion layout:&#010;&#010;ROOT&#010;  - trunk&#010;  -- department&#010;      - parent&#010;        - pom.xml&#010;      - project1&#010;        - pom.xml (inherits parent)&#010;      - project2&#010;        - pom.xml (inherits parent)&#010;      - release&#010;        - pom.xml (inherits parent)&#010;  - branches&#010;    - feature1&#010;      - department&#010;        - parent&#010;          - pom.xml&#010;        - project1&#010;          - pom.xml (inherits parent)&#010;        - project2&#010;          - pom.xml (inherits parent)&#010;        - release&#010;          - pom.xml (inherits parent)&#010;  - tags&#010;    - ...&#010;&#010;When developping code, we work on branches, we then merge back to trunk and at some point&#010;we make a new branch from trunk for the release.&#010;Since we have our trunk and branches on a higher level than the projects, we would have to&#010;add the branch name in the &lt;scm&gt; URL to gain a full path.&#010;Of course this is not what we want, because the Maven release plugin won't know how to make&#010;tags etc.&#010;One possibility might be to use a compound of 2 variables (base url and branch name) and a&#010;relative path, but this feels like a very dirty workaround.&#010;Does any of you have experience with a setup like this?&#010;&#010;Kind regards,&#010;&#010;Melvyn de Kort&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Borzh &lt;borz...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Maven follows symlinks
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;I have problem with mvn eclipse:eclipse, it generates hard paths in its&#010;projects, instead of using&#010;path as it is (symlink).&#010;How to tell maven not to follow symlinks?&#010;&#010;Thanks in advance.&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Adrien Rivard &lt;adrien.riv...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven follows symlinks
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;I'm not sure what you are trying to do, but mvn eclipse:eclipse is a&#010;totally deprecated way to use maven in eclipse.&#010;&#010;Now the way is to let m2e handle automatically the .classpath and others&#010;eclipse files on import projects&#010;&#010;That may (or not?) resolve your problem since the jars will now be linked&#010;to the local m2 repo  (~/m2/repo/..)&#010;&#010;&#010;Note that files generated by "mvn eclipse:eclipse" are incompatible with&#010;those generated by m2e so be sure to delete them completely before trying.&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Dec 17, 2014 at 1:37 PM, Borzh &lt;borzh62@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I have problem with mvn eclipse:eclipse, it generates hard paths in its&#010;&gt; projects, instead of using&#010;&gt; path as it is (symlink).&#010;&gt; How to tell maven not to follow symlinks?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks in advance.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Adrien Rivard&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- &quot;Robert Scholte&quot; &lt;rfscho...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Fwd: Error while creating hadoop package 2.6.0 with Maven 3.2.3
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;I guess you should be able to resolve the warnings, but that's a different  &#010;issue.&#010;&#010;When the build of the Apache Hadoop Maven Plugins 2.6.0 starts, I only see  &#010;"Downloading...."&#010;Normally this should be followed by "Downloaded...", which means that the  &#010;download attempt actually succeeded.&#010;For some reason something goes wrong here.&#010;&#010;You might want to add -e to get a stacktrace, which could give you an  &#010;extra hint (or worst case, add -X for debug logging)&#010;&#010;thanks,&#010;Robert&#010;&#010;Op Thu, 18 Dec 2014 18:18:51 +0100 schreef Venkat Ramakrishnan  &#010;&lt;venkat.architect@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I am getting an error related to an issue with Maven plugins while&#010;&gt; generating Hadoop 2.6.0 package with Maven 3.2.3.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I did check Maven plugin page to see if I can resolve the issue, but,&#010;&gt; could not figure out the exact course of action.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Any help to move forward with the hadoop installation would be&#010;&gt; much appreciated.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The logs are attached.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks &amp; Best Regards,&#010;&gt; Venkat Ramakrishnan.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- &quot;Robert Scholte&quot; &lt;rfscho...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Error while creating hadoop package 2.6.0 with Maven 3.2.3
contents:- So this is not a Maven3 issue, but a JDK8 (kind of) issue. (seems like you  &#010;upgraded the JDK as well)&#010;Oracle introduced with JDK8 a more strict parsing of the javadocs.&#010;&#010;Since the javadoc is incorrect, it fails.&#010;You have 3 options:&#010;- Use JDK7 or less&#010;- Fix the javadoc. The problem here is that &lt;String&gt; and &lt;File&gt; are  &#010;invalid HTML-tags. You should escape it to &amp;lt;String&amp;gt; and &amp;lt;File&amp;gt;&#010;- Add -Xdoclint:none or -Xdoclint:syntax (I think), see docs[1]. This way  &#010;you can suppress these errors.&#010;&#010;The maven-javadoc-plugin still struggles a bit with -Xdoclint[2]. A single  &#010;-Xdoclint argument works fine, multiple is not yet supported(comma  &#010;separation handling fails).&#010;&#010;thanks,&#010;Robert&#010;&#010;[1]  &#010;https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/tools/unix/javadoc.html#BEJEFABE&#010;[2] https://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MJAVADOC-387&#010;&#010;Op Fri, 19 Dec 2014 04:03:00 +0100 schreef Martin Gainty  &#010;&lt;mgainty@hotmail.com&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; take a look at :&#010;&gt; /**&#010;&gt;      * Method getExcludePackageNames.&#010;&gt;      *&#010;&gt;      * @return List&#010;&gt;      */&#010;&gt;     public java.util.List&lt;String&gt; getExcludePackageNames()&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; //if i change&#010;&gt; //@return List to&#010;&gt; //@return List&lt;String&gt;&#010;&gt; //i get the same error you get&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; please file enhancement request at&#010;&gt; https://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MJAVADOC&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; thanks,&#010;&gt; M-&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Date: Fri, 19 Dec 2014 07:50:15 +0530&#010;&gt; Subject: Fwd: Fwd: Error while creating hadoop package 2.6.0 with Maven  &#010;&gt; 3.2.3&#010;&gt; From: venkat.architect@gmail.com&#010;&gt; To: users@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks Robert.&#010;&gt; I did a -e and also a -X, -X option shows error messagesthat are  &#010;&gt; specifically related to 'Unknown tag' for String andFile. Looks like  &#010;&gt; something related to 'Mojo' declaration, butnot sure. I am not a full  &#010;&gt; time developer.&#010;&gt; Anything related to Maven with PATH variable?&#010;&gt; Logs attached.&#010;&gt; Thanks,Venkat.&#010;&gt; On Thu, Dec 18, 2014 at 11:27 PM, Robert Scholte &lt;rfscholte@apache.org&gt;  &#010;&gt; wrote:Hi,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I guess you should be able to resolve the warnings, but that's a  &#010;&gt; different issue.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; When the build of the Apache Hadoop Maven Plugins 2.6.0 starts, I only  &#010;&gt; see "Downloading...."&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Normally this should be followed by "Downloaded...", which means that  &#010;&gt; the download attempt actually succeeded.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; For some reason something goes wrong here.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; You might want to add -e to get a stacktrace, which could give you an  &#010;&gt; extra hint (or worst case, add -X for debug logging)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; thanks,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Robert&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Op Thu, 18 Dec 2014 18:18:51 +0100 schreef Venkat Ramakrishnan  &#010;&gt; &lt;venkat.architect@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I am getting an error related to an issue with Maven plugins while&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; generating Hadoop 2.6.0 package with Maven 3.2.3.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I did check Maven plugin page to see if I can resolve the issue, but,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; could not figure out the exact course of action.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Any help to move forward with the hadoop installation would be&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; much appreciated.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The logs are attached.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks &amp; Best Regards,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Venkat Ramakrishnan.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;
