Subject  :-Re: New logo?
contents:- maven-22: uses some of the imagery from the 60-seconds tutorial to form the&#010;logo&#010;&#010;https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/download/attachments/38569278/maven-22.png?version=1&amp;modificationDate=1389716094692&amp;api=v2&#010;&#010;&#010;On 14 January 2014 15:55, Stephen Connolly&#010;&lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 14 January 2014 15:51, Mark H. Wood &lt;mwood@iupui.edu&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On Tue, Jan 14, 2014 at 12:08:09PM +0000, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; &gt; Putting maven-20 in context, you get:&#010;&gt;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; http://people.apache.org/~stephenc/maven-logo-contest/maven-20-in-context.png&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; *Very* nice work, but...what does this Native Americans theme have to do&#010;&gt;&gt; with "maven"?  Yes, I know, but people *will* ask.  Especially since&#010;&gt;&gt; the answer has no connection with what Maven would do for them.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Unless I'm mistaken, the Maven landing page exists to sell Maven, not&#010;&gt;&gt; the Apache Software Foundation.  A link to the Foundation's landing&#010;&gt;&gt; page is quite appropriate and should be easy to find, but that's not&#010;&gt;&gt; why people come to this page.  They come because they've heard&#010;&gt;&gt; something about Maven and want to know more, or Google gave them a&#010;&gt;&gt; link when they asked something about software project management or&#010;&gt;&gt; build tools, or because some other project had a "built with Maven"&#010;&gt;&gt; link on its page and they're curious.  They'll probably be best&#010;&gt;&gt; pleased if, at a glance, they can get some notion of what Maven does.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Possibly that message simply isn't very visual, and the best one can&#010;&gt;&gt; do is to select a (formerly) meaningless but unique mascot or abstract&#010;&gt;&gt; symbol.  Possibly there is an image that will make people think, "yes!&#010;&gt;&gt; that is Maven in action."&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The best I have come up with for an image as to what Maven does is&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/Tutorial%3A+Maven+in+60+seconds&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; But that does not a good logo make.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Our current "logo" is just the word "maven" with the 'a' in orange&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; At least this version, or maven-21 includes the Apache feather... and&#010;&gt; hints at us being an Apache project...&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I'm really not that sort of visual thinker, but images of structure,&#010;&gt;&gt; assembly, or gathering seem appropriate.  The best(?) I've been able&#010;&gt;&gt; to imagine is a funnel with classes falling in and a package falling&#010;&gt;&gt; out.  Or perhaps an assembly line.  (What do classes look like? beats&#010;&gt;&gt; me.)  Maybe you can do something with the Reactor:  skinny pipes bring&#010;&gt;&gt; things in, one big pipe lets the product out.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; --&#010;&gt;&gt; Mark H. Wood, Lead System Programmer   mwood@IUPUI.Edu&#010;&gt;&gt; Machines should not be friendly.  Machines should be obedient.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-Re: New logo?
contents:- Maven is like a village made from tents... you can move from location to&#010;location (project to project) and you bring all the same tents (phases /&#010;conventions as to how to build a project) with you. Because we are an&#010;Apache project we chose a tent that is keeping with the stylings of the&#010;Apache feather logo&#010;&#010;There's a post-hoc justification for you ;-)&#010;&#010;&#010;On 14 January 2014 15:51, Mark H. Name  :- onlypq &lt;onl...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Adding the path to the pom file as a variable.
contents:- Thanks Wayne...&#010;&#010;In Teamcity I am trying to use maven to run Sonar to analyze a projects.&#010;When the projects build I need to execute Sonar in that directory, which the&#010;directories are created using a revision number so they will always be&#010;different. &#010;&#010;When the project builds it creates a text file (POMlastbuild3.0.txt) which&#010;has the build dir path. I then check out  my pom file into that dir... &#010;below is the command line script I run from TeamCity&#010;&#010;POMPATH=` cat /home/pomfiles/POMlastbuild3.0.txt`&#010;export POMPATH&#010;&#010;svn co https://atl-wdsvn1.abctm.org/svn/Pom/CDM $POMPATH&#010;&#010;export&#010;PATH=/home/teamcity/maven-3.0.3/apache-maven-3.0.3/bin:/usr/kerberos/sbin:/usr/kerberos/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin&#010;export M2_HOME=/home/teamcity/apache-maven-3.0.5&#010;export PATH=/usr/java/jdk1.6.0_21/bin:$PATH&#010;export JAVA_HOME=/usr/java/jdk1.6.0_21&#010;&#010;mvn sonar:sonar -Dsonar.host.url=http://12.219.180.137:9000&#010;-Dsonar.jdbc.url=jdbc:postgresql://12.219.180.137/sonar&#010;-Dsonar.jdbc.username=sonar -Dsonar.jdbc.password=sonar1dev&#010;-Dmaven.test.failure.ignore=true&#010;&#010;But when maven runs it looks for the pom in a directory Teamcity created. &#010;&#010;Do not know if i am doing this correctly, but I think all I need to do is&#010;use $POMPATH in the maven command so it can find the pom.&#010;&#010;Thank you for your help&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Adding-the-path-to-the-pom-file-as-a-variable-tp5779909p5779945.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Ziga GREGORIC &lt;ziga.grego...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Adding the path to the pom file as a variable.
contents:- I have to agree with Wayne here - this setup is not easy to understand.&#010;Since my setup consists of TeamCity and SonarSource, here are my 2 cents.&#010;&#010;Is this a maven project?&#010;Can it be build simply with 'mvn clean install'?&#010;&#010;If both answers are yes, than have a:&#010;- build configuration in TeamCity that builds it using project's pom.xml&#010;using goal 'mvn clean install' and&#010;- another build configuration that has a goal 'sonar:sonar' and you're&#010;done.&#010;Leave the checkout directory as default and make sure you use the same&#010;build agent to run both build configurations.&#010;All sonar specific environment settings can be moved to settings.xml of the&#010;build agent.&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;On Thu, Jan 2, 2014 at 8:14 PM, onlypq &lt;onlypq@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Thanks Wayne...&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; In Teamcity I am trying to use maven to run Sonar to analyze a projects.&#010;&gt; When the projects build I need to execute Sonar in that directory, which&#010;&gt; the&#010;&gt; directories are created using a revision number so they will always be&#010;&gt; different.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; When the project builds it creates a text file (POMlastbuild3.0.txt) which&#010;&gt; has the build dir path. I then check out  my pom file into that dir...&#010;&gt; below is the command line script I run from TeamCity&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; POMPATH=` cat /home/pomfiles/POMlastbuild3.0.txt`&#010;&gt; export POMPATH&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; svn co https://atl-wdsvn1.abctm.org/svn/Pom/CDM $POMPATH&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; export&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; PATH=/home/teamcity/maven-3.0.3/apache-maven-3.0.3/bin:/usr/kerberos/sbin:/usr/kerberos/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin&#010;&gt; export M2_HOME=/home/teamcity/apache-maven-3.0.5&#010;&gt; export PATH=/usr/java/jdk1.6.0_21/bin:$PATH&#010;&gt; export JAVA_HOME=/usr/java/jdk1.6.0_21&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; mvn sonar:sonar -Dsonar.host.url=http://12.219.180.137:9000&#010;&gt; -Dsonar.jdbc.url=jdbc:postgresql://12.219.180.137/sonar&#010;&gt; -Dsonar.jdbc.username=sonar -Dsonar.jdbc.password=sonar1dev&#010;&gt; -Dmaven.test.failure.ignore=true&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; But when maven runs it looks for the pom in a directory Teamcity created.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Do not know if i am doing this correctly, but I think all I need to do is&#010;&gt; use $POMPATH in the maven command so it can find the pom.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thank you for your help&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context:&#010;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Adding-the-path-to-the-pom-file-as-a-variable-tp5779909p5779945.html&#010;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Jim Garrison &lt;jim.garri...@nwea.org&gt;
Subject  :-assembly plugin jar-with-dependencies - how to refer to artifact name later?
contents:- I build a jar-with-dependencies in one execution of the assembly plugin.&#010;&#010;In a second execution I use the assembly plugin to package a distributable zip, and need to&#010;substitute the name of the jar-with-dependencies output artifact into a script file that launches&#010;the program.  &#010;&#010;Does the assembly plugin put the output artifact name into the environment so it can be substituted&#010;later? If so, what is the variable name? If not, is there another way to accomplish this?&#010;&#010;Assembly plugin configuration:&#010;&#010;      &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;        &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-assembly-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;        &lt;version&gt;2.4&lt;/version&gt;&#010;        &lt;executions&gt;&#010;          &lt;execution&gt;&#010;            &lt;id&gt;make-jwd&lt;/id&gt; &lt;!-- this is used for inheritance merges --&gt;&#010;            &lt;phase&gt;package&lt;/phase&gt; &lt;!-- bind to the packaging phase --&gt;&#010;            &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;              &lt;descriptorRefs&gt;&#010;                &lt;descriptorRef&gt;jar-with-dependencies&lt;/descriptorRef&gt;&#010;              &lt;/descriptorRefs&gt;&#010;              &lt;archive&gt;&#010;                &lt;manifest&gt;&#010;                  &lt;mainClass&gt;org.nwea.jhg.dbextract.Driver&lt;/mainClass&gt;&#010;                &lt;/manifest&gt;&#010;              &lt;/archive&gt;&#010;            &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;            &lt;goals&gt;&#010;              &lt;goal&gt;single&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;            &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;          &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;          &lt;execution&gt;&#010;            &lt;id&gt;make-zip&lt;/id&gt; &lt;!-- this is used for inheritance merges --&gt;&#010;            &lt;phase&gt;package&lt;/phase&gt; &lt;!-- bind to the packaging phase --&gt;&#010;            &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;              &lt;descriptors&gt;&#010;                &lt;descriptor&gt;src/main/assembly/zip.xml&lt;/descriptor&gt;&#010;              &lt;/descriptors&gt;&#010;            &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;            &lt;goals&gt;&#010;              &lt;goal&gt;single&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;            &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;          &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;        &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;      &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;Assembly descriptor:&#010;&#010;&lt;assembly xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-assembly-plugin/assembly/1.1.2"&#010;xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"&#010;  xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-assembly-plugin/assembly/1.1.2&#010;http://maven.apache.org/xsd/assembly-1.1.2.xsd"&gt;&#010;  &lt;id&gt;zip&lt;/id&gt;&#010;  &lt;formats&gt;&#010;    &lt;format&gt;zip&lt;/format&gt;&#010;  &lt;/formats&gt;&#010;  &lt;fileSets&gt;&#010;    &lt;fileSet&gt;&#010;      &lt;directory&gt;${project.basedir}/src/main/scripts&lt;/directory&gt;&#010;      &lt;outputDirectory&gt;/&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;      &lt;filtered&gt;true&lt;/filtered&gt;&#010;    &lt;/fileSet&gt;&#010;    &lt;fileSet&gt;&#010;      &lt;directory&gt;${project.basedir}/config&lt;/directory&gt;&#010;      &lt;outputDirectory&gt;/&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;    &lt;/fileSet&gt;&#010;    &lt;fileSet&gt;&#010;      &lt;directory&gt;${project.build.directory}&lt;/directory&gt;&#010;      &lt;outputDirectory&gt;/&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;      &lt;includes&gt;&#010;        &lt;include&gt;*-jar-with-dependencies.jar&lt;/include&gt;&#010;      &lt;/includes&gt;&#010;    &lt;/fileSet&gt;&#010;  &lt;/fileSets&gt;&#010;&lt;/assembly&gt;&#010;&#010;File into which I wish to substitute the name of the jar-with-dependencies artifact:&#010;&#010;#!/bin/bash&#010;export DBEX_CMD=dbex&#010;java -jar ${what-do-i-put-here} $*&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

         &lt;version&gt;2.4&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;executions&gt;&#010;&gt;            &lt;execution&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;id&gt;make-jwd&lt;/id&gt; &lt;!-- this is used for inheritance merges&#010;--&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;&gt;            &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;&gt;            &lt;execution&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;id&gt;make-zip&lt;/id&gt; &lt;!-- this is used for inheritance merges&#010;--&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;phase&gt;package&lt;/phase&gt; &lt;!-- bind to the packaging phase --&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;                &lt;descriptors&gt;&#010;&gt;                  &lt;descriptor&gt;src/main/assembly/zip.xml&lt;/descriptor&gt;&#010;&gt;            &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Assembly descriptor:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;assembly xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-assembly-plugin/assembly/1.1.2"&#010;xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"&#010;&gt;    xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-assembly-plugin/assembly/1.1.2&#010;http://maven.apache.org/xsd/assembly-1.1.2.xsd"&gt;&#010;&gt;    &lt;id&gt;zip&lt;/id&gt;&#010;&gt;    &lt;formats&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;format&gt;zip&lt;/format&gt;&#010;&gt;    &lt;/formats&gt;&#010;&gt;    &lt;fileSets&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;directory&gt;${project.basedir}/src/main/scripts&lt;/directory&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;outputDirectory&gt;/&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;filtered&gt;true&lt;/filtered&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;directory&gt;${project.basedir}/config&lt;/directory&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;outputDirectory&gt;/&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;directory&gt;${project.build.directory}&lt;/directory&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;outputDirectory&gt;/&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;includes&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;include&gt;*-jar-with-dependencies.jar&lt;/include&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;/includes&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt;    &lt;/fileSets&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;/assembly&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; File into which I wish to substitute the name of the jar-with-dependencies artifact:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; instance"&#010;&gt; &gt;    xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-&#010;&gt; assembly-plugin/assembly/1.1.2 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/assembly-&#010;&gt; 1.1.2.xsd"&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;    &lt;id&gt;zip&lt;/id&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;    &lt;formats&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;      &lt;format&gt;zip&lt;/format&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;    &lt;/formats&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;    &lt;fileSets&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;      &lt;fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;        &lt;directory&gt;${project.basedir}/src/main/scripts&lt;/directory&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;        &lt;outputDirectory&gt;/&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;        &lt;filtered&gt;true&lt;/filtered&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;      &lt;/fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;      &lt;fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;        &lt;directory&gt;${project.basedir}/config&lt;/directory&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;        &lt;outputDirectory&gt;/&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;      &lt;/fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;      &lt;fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;        &lt;directory&gt;${project.build.directory}&lt;/directory&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;        &lt;outputDirectory&gt;/&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;        &lt;includes&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;          &lt;include&gt;*-jar-with-dependencies.jar&lt;/include&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;        &lt;/includes&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;      &lt;/fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;    &lt;/fileSets&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &lt;/assembly&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; File into which I wish to substitute the name of the jar-with-dependencies&#010;&gt; artifact:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; #!/bin/bash&#010;&gt; &gt; export DBEX_CMD=dbex&#010;&gt; &gt; java -jar ${what-do-i-put-here} $*&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&#010;I think I figured out how to do this. I just used&#010;&#010;     ${project.build.finalName}-jar-with-dependencies.jar&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Benson Margulies &lt;bimargul...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-[ANN] Maven Wagon 2.6 Released
contents:- The Apache Maven team is pleased to announce the release of the Apache&#010;Maven Wagon, version 2.6.&#010;&#010;The Wagon component provides communications between Maven and repositories.&#010;&#010;Typically, to use a particular version of Wagon, you would add an&#010;'extension' to your POM, such as:&#010;&#010;        &lt;extensions&gt;&#010;            &lt;extension&gt;&#010;                &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.wagon&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;                &lt;artifactId&gt;wagon-ssh&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;                &lt;version&gt;2.6&lt;/version&gt;&#010;            &lt;/extension&gt;&#010;        &lt;/extensions&gt;&#010;&#010;Here are the issues addressed in version 2.6:&#010;&#010;** Improvement&#010;    * [WAGON-401] - Access Denied due to missing User-Agent&#010;    * [WAGON-402] - Upgrade Apache HttpClient based wagon provider to&#010;HttpClient 4.3&#010;    * [WAGON-403] - SSH agent support for wagon-ssh&#010;&#010;&#010;Enjoy,&#010;&#010;-The Apache Maven team&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- &quot;Omar@Gmail&quot; &lt;omarnet...@googlemail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Maven Plugin Logging
contents:- Hi All,&#010;&#010;I implemented my own Maven plugin mojo in which I used log4j + slf4j. In&#010;the plugin project I have included the correct jars and can see correct&#010;logging of statements from code.&#010;&#010;Now I want use this new maven plugin in another client project but having&#010;trouble getting it to work correctly.&#010;&#010;In the plugin itself I have included a log4j.properties under&#010;src/main/resources which works fine as mentioned above. But when I try to&#010;include the plugin in another client project the log file is not being&#010;created.&#010;&#010;The question is what else do I have to try or do to get this working&#010;correctly?&#010;&#010;Thank you.&#010;Omar&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Cleuton Sampaio &lt;cleuton.samp...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Plugin Logging
contents:- Did you based your mojo on class AbstractMojo ?  If you did, then you should use the getLog()&#010;method. See:&#010;&#010;http://maven.apache.org/ref/2.2.1/maven-plugin-api/apidocs/org/apache/maven/plugin/AbstractMojo.html&#010;&#010;Cleuton Sampaio&#010;&#010;&gt; Em 03/01/2014, às 07:44, "Omar@Gmail" &lt;omarnetbox@googlemail.com&gt; escreveu:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Hi All,&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I implemented my own Maven plugin mojo in which I used log4j + slf4j. But when I try to&#010;&gt; include the plugin in another client project the log file is not being&#010;&gt; created.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; The question is what else do I have to try or do to get this working&#010;&gt; correctly?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Thank you.&#010;&gt; Omar&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Cleuton Sampaio &lt;cleuton.samp...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Plugin Logging
contents:- You should use the object returned by the getLog method, which is an implementation of &#010;&#010;org.apache.maven.plugin.logging &#010;Interface Log&#010;&#010;It is exactly the architecture that I am using in my own plugin: jQana (Github). It is still&#010;in early dev stage, but I am facing that same problem. The only way to solve is to use the&#010;Log implemantation returned by getLog. &#010;&#010;Here I am instantiating my pojo from the mojo, and passing the Log Object:&#010;&#010;                        DefaultProjectProcessor dpp = new DefaultProjectProcessor(new Context());&#010;                        dpp.setLog(getLog());&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;Here I am logging in my pojo:&#010;&#010;                         // using maven plugin logger&#010;                         switch (type) {&#010;                         case INFO:&#010;                                 this.log.info(msg);&#010;                                 break;&#010;                         case DEBUG:&#010;                                 this.log.debug(msg);&#010;                                 break;&#010;                         case ERROR:&#010;                                 this.log.error(msg);&#010;                         }&#010;&#010;&#010;Cleuton Sampaio&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; Em 03/01/2014, às 18:46, "Omar@Gmail" &lt;omarnetbox@googlemail.com&gt; escreveu:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Thanks Cleuton, in my custom plugin which I developed I have a Mojo that&#010;&gt; extends AbstractMojo but this Mojo delegates to a Pojo. Both the Mojo and&#010;&gt; Pojo each have  their won logger. In this case does your suggestion still&#010;&gt; stand? can you suggest some simple steps to use the AbstractMojo getLog()&#010;&gt; method.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Omar&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; On 3 January 2014 16:02, Cleuton Sampaio &lt;cleuton.sampaio@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; Did you based your mojo on class AbstractMojo ?  If you did, then you&#010;&gt;&gt; should use the getLog() method. See:&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/ref/2.2.1/maven-plugin-api/apidocs/org/apache/maven/plugin/AbstractMojo.html&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; Cleuton Sampaio&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Em 03/01/2014, às 07:44, "Omar@Gmail" &lt;omarnetbox@googlemail.com&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; escreveu:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Hi All,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I implemented my own Maven plugin mojo in which I used log4j + slf4j. In&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; the plugin project I have included the correct jars and can see correct&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; logging of statements from code.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Now I want use this new maven plugin in another client project but having&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; trouble getting it to work correctly.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; In the plugin itself I have included a log4j.properties under&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; src/main/resources which works fine as mentioned above. But when I try to&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; include the plugin in another client project the log file is not being&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; created.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; The question is what else do I have to try or do to get this working&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; correctly?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thank you.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Omar&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&#010;

contents:- The Maven team is pleased to announce the release of the Apache Maven Jarsigner,  &#010;version 1.3&#010;&#010;This component provides some utilities to sign/verify jars/files in your Mojos.&#010;&#010;http://maven.apache.org/shared/maven-jarsigner/&#010;&#010;To use the Maven Jarsigner, add the following dependency to your project:&#010;&#010;   &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;     &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.shared&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;     &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-jarsigner&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;     &lt;version&gt;1.3&lt;/version&gt;&#010;   &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&#010;Release Notes - Maven Shared Components - Version maven-jarsigner-1.3&#010;&#010;** Bug&#010;    * [MSHARED-314] - Unsigning a jar is not correct&#010;&#010;Enjoy,&#010;&#010;-The Maven team&#010;&#010;tony.&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Tony Chemit&#010;--------------------&#010;tél: +33 (0) 2 40 50 29 28&#010;http://www.codelutin.com&#010;email: chemit@codelutin.com&#010;twitter: https://twitter.com/tchemit&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Tony Chemit &lt;tche...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-[ANN] Maven Jarsigner Plugin 1.3 Released
contents:- The Maven team is pleased to announce the release of the Maven Jarsigner&#010;Plugin, version 1.3.&#010;&#010;This plugin signs and verifies the project artifacts using the jarsigner&#010;tool. See the plugin's site for more details:&#010;&#010;    http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-jarsigner-plugin/&#010;&#010;This plugin is meant to supercede the existing jar:sign and&#010;jar:verify goals from the Maven Jar Plugin which will be deprecated&#010;in a future release.&#010;&#010;To use the updated plugin in your projects, you need to add the &#010;following snippet to the plugins or plugin management section of your POM:&#010;&#010;    &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;      &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;      &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-jarsigner-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;      &lt;version&gt;1.3&lt;/version&gt;&#010;      &lt;executions&gt;&#010;        ...&#010;      &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;    &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;Release Notes - Maven Jar Signer Plugin - Version 1.3&#010;&#010;** Bug&#010;    * [MJARSIGNER-13] - signing in multi-module project fails on windows&#010;    * [MJARSIGNER-21] - jars signed using Java 7 have "invalid SHA1 signature"&#010;    * [MJARSIGNER-26] - Jar Signer does not support protected authentication path&#010;    * [MJARSIGNER-29] - verbose parameter is not filled in jarsigner requests&#010;&#010;** Improvement&#010;    * [MJARSIGNER-28] - verify mojo can also use keystore and alias parameters&#010;&#010;** New Feature&#010;    * [MJARSIGNER-12] - It should be possible to save the keystore in one location for multi&#010;module projects&#010;    * [MJARSIGNER-16] - Add the option -tsa to the configuration&#010;    * [MJARSIGNER-18] - Support for Jar plugin's "errorWhenNotSigned" option&#010;    * [MJARSIGNER-24] - Use Password Encryption in pom.xml&#010;&#010;** Task&#010;    * [MJARSIGNER-9] - Add toolchain in JarSignMojo.java#getJDKCommandExe()&#010;    * [MJARSIGNER-22] - Add french translations&#010;    * [MJARSIGNER-25] - use maven-plugin-tools' java 5 annotations&#010;    * [MJARSIGNER-27] - Use maven-jarsigner 1.3&#010;    * [MJARSIGNER-31] - Update maven-shared-utils to 0.5&#010;    * [MJARSIGNER-32] - Update requirements to maven 2.1.0&#010;&#010;Enjoy,&#010;&#010;The Maven team.&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Tony Chemit&#010;--------------------&#010;tél: +33 (0) 2 40 50 29 28&#010;http://www.codelutin.com&#010;email: chemit@codelutin.com&#010;twitter: https://twitter.com/tchemit&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- &quot;Robert Scholte&quot; &lt;rfscho...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: New site content
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;I like the idea of images, however I would avoid a graph to make something  &#010;clear for new Maven users.&#010;Instead I'd prefer a linear model.&#010;&#010;I think you should split the current model into pieces:&#010;&#010;A project model contains:&#010;- dependencies&#010;- a build plan&#010;- other project models ( you can call this the Droste effect[1] )&#010;- ...&#010;&#010;There are several build-plans, namely: a build-plan for jar, war, ear, etc.&#010;Every build plan has a set of predefined plugins,  which you can adjust  &#010;(with switches?)&#010;&#010;Now, what does Maven do?&#010;&#010;Maven reads the build plan and executes it. Some steps of the build plan  &#010;deliver products ( compiled classes, test results, a package)&#010;&#010;I think the reactor might be confusing at this level.&#010;&#010;my 2 cents,&#010;&#010;Robert&#010;&#010;[1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Droste_effect&#010;&#010;&#010;Op Fri, 03 Jan 2014 15:41:15 +0100 schreef Stephen Connolly  &#010;&lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; Just in case it wasn't clear... I'm looking for comments and feedback&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 3 January 2014 14:35, Stephen Connolly&#010;&gt; &lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; OK, so to start working on new content I created some pages on the wiki:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The first page is a 60 seconds overview of Maven's build process&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/Tutorial:+Maven+in+60+seconds&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I am using icons because I want to have subsequent pages give more  &#010;&gt;&gt; detail&#010;&gt;&gt; and use the iconography to enable people to see what is being discussed&#010;&gt;&gt; more easily&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: New site content
contents:- On 3 January 2014 15:17, Robert Scholte &lt;rfscholte@apache.org&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I like the idea of images, however I would avoid a graph to make something&#010;&gt; clear for new Maven users.&#010;&gt; Instead I'd prefer a linear model.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;My first draft did not have the graph at the top... perhaps it would be&#010;better suited at the bottom ;-)&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I think you should split the current model into pieces:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; A project model contains:&#010;&gt; - dependencies&#010;&gt; - a build plan&#010;&gt; - other project models ( you can call this the Droste effect[1] )&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;I like to think of the project model as not just the root pom.xml but all&#010;the pom.xml files, so there is only one project model, this should make&#010;understanding how -pl, -am and -amd switches have their effects&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; - ...&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; There are several build-plans, namely: a build-plan for jar, war, ear, etc.&#010;&gt; Every build plan has a set of predefined plugins,  which you can adjust&#010;&gt; (with switches?)&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;No there is one and only one build plan. We would have to redefine build&#010;plan everywhere else to be able to use it like that. There is a lifecycle&#010;binding for each packaging&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Now, what does Maven do?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Maven reads the build plan and executes it. Some steps of the build plan&#010;&gt; deliver products ( compiled classes, test results, a package)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I think the reactor might be confusing at this level.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;I want the 60sec tutorial to be the grand overview, the next tutorial is a&#010;5 minute one on how a .jar file gets built&#010;&#010;Then you have a multi-module webapp tutorial at 10-15min&#010;&#010;I want to reference all the core concepts from the 60 second overview even&#010;if only briefly, that way people can come back to the short page and say&#010;"ahh yes that is where that fits in again"&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; my 2 cents,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Robert&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; [1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Droste_effect&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Op Fri, 03 Jan 2014 15:41:15 +0100 schreef Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;&gt; stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;  Just in case it wasn't clear... I'm looking for comments and feedback&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 3 January 2014 14:35, Stephen Connolly&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  OK, so to start working on new content I created some pages on the wiki:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; The first page is a 60 seconds overview of Maven's build process&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Tutorial:+Maven+in+60+seconds&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I am using icons because I want to have subsequent pages give more detail&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; and use the iconography to enable people to see what is being discussed&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; more easily&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- &quot;Robert Scholte&quot; &lt;rfscho...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: New site content
contents:- Op Fri, 03 Jan 2014 16:46:33 +0100 schreef Stephen Connolly  &#010;&lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; On 3 January 2014 15:17, Robert Scholte &lt;rfscholte@apache.org&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I like the idea of images, however I would avoid a graph to make  &#010;&gt;&gt; something&#010;&gt;&gt; clear for new Maven users.&#010;&gt;&gt; Instead I'd prefer a linear model.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My first draft did not have the graph at the top... perhaps it would be&#010;&gt; better suited at the bottom ;-)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I think you should split the current model into pieces:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; A project model contains:&#010;&gt;&gt; - dependencies&#010;&gt;&gt; - a build plan&#010;&gt;&gt; - other project models ( you can call this the Droste effect[1] )&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I like to think of the project model as not just the root pom.xml but all&#010;&gt; the pom.xml files, so there is only one project model, this should make&#010;&gt; understanding how -pl, -am and -amd switches have their effects&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;IMO these switches are way too detailed for a 60 sec tutorial. I even  &#010;think that a large group of the average Maven users don't know these  &#010;switches or use them.&#010;&#010;&gt;&gt; - ...&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; There are several build-plans, namely: a build-plan for jar, war, ear,  &#010;&gt;&gt; etc.&#010;&gt;&gt; Every build plan has a set of predefined plugins,  which you can adjust&#010;&gt;&gt; (with switches?)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; No there is one and only one build plan. We would have to redefine build&#010;&gt; plan everywhere else to be able to use it like that. There is a lifecycle&#010;&gt; binding for each packaging&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Then buildplan is too abstract. With a real world example: the buildplan  &#010;for a house and a bike are completely different. Unless you say: you have  &#010;a design, some goods, you mix those goods and you have your product.&#010;Not a useful plan IMO.&#010;At least keep the audience in mind: do they need to know the actual  &#010;implementation or do they first need to understand the overall process. I  &#010;think the latter is more important, even if this conflicts a bit with the  &#010;idiom used by experienced Maven users.&#010;What if we call it "build instructions" (per packaging type) ?&#010;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Now, what does Maven do?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Maven reads the build plan and executes it. Some steps of the build plan&#010;&gt;&gt; deliver products ( compiled classes, test results, a package)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I think the reactor might be confusing at this level.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I want the 60sec tutorial to be the grand overview, the next tutorial is  &#010;&gt; a&#010;&gt; 5 minute one on how a .jar file gets built&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Then you have a multi-module webapp tutorial at 10-15min&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I want to reference all the core concepts from the 60 second overview  &#010;&gt; even&#010;&gt; if only briefly, that way people can come back to the short page and say&#010;&gt; "ahh yes that is where that fits in again"&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; my 2 cents,&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Robert&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; [1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Droste_effect&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Op Fri, 03 Jan 2014 15:41:15 +0100 schreef Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;&gt;&gt; stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  Just in case it wasn't clear... I'm looking for comments and feedback&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 3 January 2014 14:35, Stephen Connolly&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;  OK, so to start working on new content I created some pages on the  &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; wiki:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The first page is a 60 seconds overview of Maven's build process&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Tutorial:+Maven+in+60+seconds&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I am using icons because I want to have subsequent pages give more  &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; detail&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; and use the iconography to enable people to see what is being  &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; discussed&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; more easily&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: New site content
contents:- On 3 January 2014 16:09, Robert Scholte &lt;rfscholte@apache.org&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Op Fri, 03 Jan 2014 16:46:33 +0100 schreef Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;&gt; stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;  On 3 January 2014 15:17, Robert Scholte &lt;rfscholte@apache.org&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  Hi,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I like the idea of images, however I would avoid a graph to make&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; something&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; clear for new Maven users.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Instead I'd prefer a linear model.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; My first draft did not have the graph at the top... perhaps it would be&#010;&gt;&gt; better suited at the bottom ;-)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think you should split the current model into pieces:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; A project model contains:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; - dependencies&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; - a build plan&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; - other project models ( you can call this the Droste effect[1] )&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I like to think of the project model as not just the root pom.xml but all&#010;&gt;&gt; the pom.xml files, so there is only one project model, this should make&#010;&gt;&gt; understanding how -pl, -am and -amd switches have their effects&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; IMO these switches are way too detailed for a 60 sec tutorial. I even&#010;&gt; think that a large group of the average Maven users don't know these&#010;&gt; switches or use them.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;  - ...&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; There are several build-plans, namely: a build-plan for jar, war, ear,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; etc.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Every build plan has a set of predefined plugins,  which you can adjust&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; (with switches?)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; No there is one and only one build plan. We would have to redefine build&#010;&gt;&gt; plan everywhere else to be able to use it like that. There is a lifecycle&#010;&gt;&gt; binding for each packaging&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; Then buildplan is too abstract. With a real world example: the buildplan&#010;&gt; for a house and a bike are completely different. Unless you say: you have a&#010;&gt; design, some goods, you mix those goods and you have your product.&#010;&gt; Not a useful plan IMO.&#010;&gt; At least keep the audience in mind: do they need to know the actual&#010;&gt; implementation or do they first need to understand the overall process. I&#010;&gt; think the latter is more important, even if this conflicts a bit with the&#010;&gt; idiom used by experienced Maven users.&#010;&gt; What if we call it "build instructions" (per packaging type) ?&#010;&#010;&#010;Well I have no issue with saying that each packaging has a template for how&#010;when to use plugins during the lifecycle.&#010;&#010;But the build plan is the plan of what will be done, and it is a well used&#010;term in Maven.&#010;&#010;The lifecycle is also a well used term in Maven.&#010;&#010;This is the 20,000ft reference that lets people get to understand what&#010;these terms are... I think it is OK for it to skim over the detail (we can&#010;make the images be links to more detail as people need it), but I don't&#010;believe we do anyone a service by avoiding introducing our core concepts...&#010;especially if these core concepts and their poor understanding are part of&#010;the root for the misuse and misunderstanding of maven by a large body of&#010;people&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Now, what does Maven do?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven reads the build plan and executes it. Some steps of the build plan&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; deliver products ( compiled classes, test results, a package)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think the reactor might be confusing at this level.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I want the 60sec tutorial to be the grand overview, the next tutorial is a&#010;&gt;&gt; 5 minute one on how a .jar file gets built&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Then you have a multi-module webapp tutorial at 10-15min&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I want to reference all the core concepts from the 60 second overview even&#010;&gt;&gt; if only briefly, that way people can come back to the short page and say&#010;&gt;&gt; "ahh yes that is where that fits in again"&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; my 2 cents,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Robert&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; [1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Droste_effect&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Op Fri, 03 Jan 2014 15:41:15 +0100 schreef Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;  Just in case it wasn't clear... I'm looking for comments and feedback&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 3 January 2014 14:35, Stephen Connolly&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;  OK, so to start working on new content I created some pages on the&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; wiki:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The first page is a 60 seconds overview of Maven's build process&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Tutorial:+Maven+in+60+seconds&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I am using icons because I want to have subsequent pages give more&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; detail&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; and use the iconography to enable people to see what is being discussed&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; more easily&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: New site content
contents:- I agree with Robert's comment.&#010;There is a danger that the page will become architecturally elegant and &#010;will correctly describe all of the possible uses of Maven but will be &#010;too obscure to be useful as a starting point for a new person.&#010;&#010;It is sufficiently difficult to understand the basic concepts in using &#010;Maven to create a simple jar with a single POM.&#010;You are introducing a lot of new concepts:&#010;-Lifecycle&#010;-Dependencies&#010;-Plug-ins&#010;- Project model&#010;that a person coming from make or Ant has to grasp.&#010;&#010;Defining these and the relationships among them in a simple way is &#010;sufficiently challenging without trying to abstract a sufficiently &#010;general model to handle all of the edge cases.&#010;&#010;The "Maven way" needs to be explained very simply rather than &#010;conceptually complete.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;&#010;On 03/01/2014 11:09 AM, Robert Scholte wrote:&#010;&gt; Op Fri, 03 Jan 2014 16:46:33 +0100 schreef Stephen Connolly &#010;&gt; &lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 3 January 2014 15:17, Robert Scholte &lt;rfscholte@apache.org&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I like the idea of images, however I would avoid a graph to make &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; something&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; clear for new Maven users.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Instead I'd prefer a linear model.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; My first draft did not have the graph at the top... perhaps it would be&#010;&gt;&gt; better suited at the bottom ;-)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think you should split the current model into pieces:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; A project model contains:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; - dependencies&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; - a build plan&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; - other project models ( you can call this the Droste effect[1] )&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I like to think of the project model as not just the root pom.xml but &#010;&gt;&gt; all&#010;&gt;&gt; the pom.xml files, so there is only one project model, this should make&#010;&gt;&gt; understanding how -pl, -am and -amd switches have their effects&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; IMO these switches are way too detailed for a 60 sec tutorial. I even &#010;&gt; think that a large group of the average Maven users don't know these &#010;&gt; switches or use them.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; - ...&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; There are several build-plans, namely: a build-plan for jar, war, &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; ear, etc.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Every build plan has a set of predefined plugins,  which you can adjust&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; (with switches?)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; No there is one and only one build plan. We would have to redefine build&#010;&gt;&gt; plan everywhere else to be able to use it like that. There is a &#010;&gt;&gt; lifecycle&#010;&gt;&gt; binding for each packaging&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Then buildplan is too abstract. With a real world example: the &#010;&gt; buildplan for a house and a bike are completely different. Unless you &#010;&gt; say: you have a design, some goods, you mix those goods and you have &#010;&gt; your product.&#010;&gt; Not a useful plan IMO.&#010;&gt; At least keep the audience in mind: do they need to know the actual &#010;&gt; implementation or do they first need to understand the overall &#010;&gt; process. I think the latter is more important, even if this conflicts &#010;&gt; a bit with the idiom used by experienced Maven users.&#010;&gt; What if we call it "build instructions" (per packaging type) ?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Now, what does Maven do?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven reads the build plan and executes it. Some steps of the build &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; plan&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; deliver products ( compiled classes, test results, a package)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think the reactor might be confusing at this level.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I want the 60sec tutorial to be the grand overview, the next tutorial &#010;&gt;&gt; is a&#010;&gt;&gt; 5 minute one on how a .jar file gets built&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Then you have a multi-module webapp tutorial at 10-15min&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I want to reference all the core concepts from the 60 second overview &#010;&gt;&gt; even&#010;&gt;&gt; if only briefly, that way people can come back to the short page and say&#010;&gt;&gt; "ahh yes that is where that fits in again"&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; my 2 cents,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Robert&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; [1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Droste_effect&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Op Fri, 03 Jan 2014 15:41:15 +0100 schreef Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;  Just in case it wasn't clear... I'm looking for comments and feedback&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 3 January 2014 14:35, Stephen Connolly&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;  OK, so to start working on new content I created some pages on the &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; wiki:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The first page is a 60 seconds overview of Maven's build process&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Tutorial:+Maven+in+60+seconds&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I am using icons because I want to have subsequent pages give more &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; detail&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; and use the iconography to enable people to see what is being &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; discussed&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; more easily&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-Re: New site content
contents:- FYI here is my current plan for content:&#010;&#010;https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/New+Main+Site&#010;&#010;&#010;On 3 January 2014 16:27, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I agree with Robert's comment.&#010;&gt; There is a danger that the page will become architecturally elegant and&#010;&gt; will correctly describe all of the possible uses of Maven but will be too&#010;&gt; obscure to be useful as a starting point for a new person.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;I actually think that the page is near complete from my point of view...&#010;the remaining content is actually to provide links to pages describing what&#010;each individual concept is and a link to the next level of depth tutorial.&#010;&#010;I what to draw only the outline of what maven does... on the other hand, if&#010;you can think of an alternative set of content I am only too happy to see&#010;such suggestions. If you need write access to the wiki, shout out and I'll&#010;make it so (assuming you are a regular user/dev list contributor)&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; It is sufficiently difficult to understand the basic concepts in using&#010;&gt; Maven to create a simple jar with a single POM.&#010;&gt; You are introducing a lot of new concepts:&#010;&gt; -Lifecycle&#010;&gt; -Dependencies&#010;&gt; -Plug-ins&#010;&gt; - Project model&#010;&gt; that a person coming from make or Ant has to grasp.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Defining these and the relationships among them in a simple way is&#010;&gt; sufficiently challenging without trying to abstract a sufficiently general&#010;&gt; model to handle all of the edge cases.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The "Maven way" needs to be explained very simply rather than conceptually&#010;&gt; complete.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 03/01/2014 11:09 AM, Robert Scholte wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Op Fri, 03 Jan 2014 16:46:33 +0100 schreef Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;&gt;&gt; stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  On 3 January 2014 15:17, Robert Scholte &lt;rfscholte@apache.org&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;  Hi,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I like the idea of images, however I would avoid a graph to make&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; something&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; clear for new Maven users.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Instead I'd prefer a linear model.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; My first draft did not have the graph at the top... perhaps it would be&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; better suited at the bottom ;-)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think you should split the current model into pieces:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; A project model contains:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; - dependencies&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; - a build plan&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; - other project models ( you can call this the Droste effect[1] )&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I like to think of the project model as not just the root pom.xml but all&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; the pom.xml files, so there is only one project model, this should make&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; understanding how -pl, -am and -amd switches have their effects&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; IMO these switches are way too detailed for a 60 sec tutorial. I even&#010;&gt;&gt; think that a large group of the average Maven users don't know these&#010;&gt;&gt; switches or use them.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  - ...&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; There are several build-plans, namely: a build-plan for jar, war, ear,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; etc.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Every build plan has a set of predefined plugins,  which you can adjust&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; (with switches?)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; No there is one and only one build plan. We would have to redefine build&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; plan everywhere else to be able to use it like that. There is a lifecycle&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; binding for each packaging&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Then buildplan is too abstract. With a real world example: the buildplan&#010;&gt;&gt; for a house and a bike are completely different. Unless you say: you have a&#010;&gt;&gt; design, some goods, you mix those goods and you have your product.&#010;&gt;&gt; Not a useful plan IMO.&#010;&gt;&gt; At least keep the audience in mind: do they need to know the actual&#010;&gt;&gt; implementation or do they first need to understand the overall process. I&#010;&gt;&gt; think the latter is more important, even if this conflicts a bit with the&#010;&gt;&gt; idiom used by experienced Maven users.&#010;&gt;&gt; What if we call it "build instructions" (per packaging type) ?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Now, what does Maven do?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven reads the build plan and executes it. Some steps of the build plan&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; deliver products ( compiled classes, test results, a package)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think the reactor might be confusing at this level.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I want the 60sec tutorial to be the grand overview, the next tutorial is&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; 5 minute one on how a .jar file gets built&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Then you have a multi-module webapp tutorial at 10-15min&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I want to reference all the core concepts from the 60 second overview&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; even&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; if only briefly, that way people can come back to the short page and say&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; "ahh yes that is where that fits in again"&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; my 2 cents,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Robert&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; [1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Droste_effect&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Op Fri, 03 Jan 2014 15:41:15 +0100 schreef Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;  Just in case it wasn't clear... I'm looking for comments and feedback&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 3 January 2014 14:35, Stephen Connolly&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;  OK, so to start working on new content I created some pages on the&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; wiki:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The first page is a 60 seconds overview of Maven's build process&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Tutorial:+Maven+in+60+seconds&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I am using icons because I want to have subsequent pages give more&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; detail&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; and use the iconography to enable people to see what is being&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; discussed&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; more easily&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; President&#010;&gt; Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt; email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt; phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: New site content
contents:- Also, in case it is not clear, my preferred style is to tell you&#010;information that is important later without distracting you by that&#010;information&#010;&#010;A case in point is the information that&#010;&#010;&gt; The list of modules in the reactor is sorted in order to ensure that any&#010;dependencies that will be created by the reactor will be built before they&#010;are needed by other modules in the reactor&#010;&#010;I'd like a bit snappier text, so it might be that we say&#010;&#010;&gt; The list of modules in the reactor is sorted in order to ensure that&#010;modules are built before they are referenced by other other modules in the&#010;reactor&#010;&#010;Or better yet, maybe just&#010;&#010;&gt; The list of modules in the reactor is sorted&#010;&#010;Where "sorted" is a link to a page describing the sort order.&#010;&#010;But the most important thing from my point of view is to empower people&#010;with correct information so that if they have a maven command such as&#010;&#010;$ mvn clean javadoc:javadoc javadoc:aggregate-jar deploy site-deploy -pl&#010;foo -am&#010;&#010;Once they understand Maven, they can come back to the 60 second page and&#010;see that it has not lied to them and that it actually hinted at how you&#010;might go about understanding exactly what will go on with that execution&#010;&#010;i.e. there is a build plan for that execution... there are lifecycle phases&#010;and plugin goals... the aggregator goal affects the build plan in the&#010;reactor, etc&#010;&#010;But *and this is the important bit* the page itself does not have to&#010;explain such a complex use of maven.&#010;&#010;&#010;*aside*&#010;&#010;One of the most annoying things to me about learning chemistry is that it&#010;is a constant case of being thought something and then at the next level&#010;they pull the rug out from under you and say, oh but actually it's not like&#010;that at all...&#010;&#010;They start telling you about electron shells&#010;&#010;Then they say, oh but it's Bohr shells&#010;&#010;Then they say, oh but it's QM&#010;&#010;Then you dig deeper and there are layers to QM&#010;&#010;By the time I got my degree in Chemistry I had gone through about 6 layers&#010;of analogies for how the hydrogen atom works:&#010;&#010;1st year-3rd year school analogy&#010;4th year-6th year school analogy&#010;1st year Chemistry analogy&#010;2nd year Chemistry analogy&#010;3rd year Chemistry analogy&#010;4th year Chemistry analogy&#010;&#010;Worst of all is that each analogy showed the previous ones as being&#010;hopelessly wrong in so many ways.&#010;&#010;Now I am fine with explaining things simply until you need to know more,&#010;but when that simply way is just plain wrong!&#010;&#010;Newtonian mechanics is at least a very good approximation of relativity for&#010;normal velocities, and if I remember correctly, when the velocities are&#010;small with respect to the speed of light the newtonian solutions are&#010;trivially shown to be a simplified approximation of the general&#010;relativistic model.&#010;&#010;But you cannot say the same of QM and the lies I was fed in school...&#010;&#010;To bring this back home, I want our top level tutorial to be viewable as a&#010;simplification of what goes on *without* lying to you, i.e. like newtonian&#010;mechanics vs general relativity not like 1st year school chemistry vs 4th&#010;year university chemistry&#010;&#010;&#010;On 3 January 2014 16:33, Stephen Connolly&#010;&lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; FYI here is my current plan for content:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/New+Main+Site&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 3 January 2014 16:27, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I agree with Robert's comment.&#010;&gt;&gt; There is a danger that the page will become architecturally elegant and&#010;&gt;&gt; will correctly describe all of the possible uses of Maven but will be too&#010;&gt;&gt; obscure to be useful as a starting point for a new person.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I actually think that the page is near complete from my point of view...&#010;&gt; the remaining content is actually to provide links to pages describing what&#010;&gt; each individual concept is and a link to the next level of depth tutorial.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I what to draw only the outline of what maven does... on the other hand,&#010;&gt; if you can think of an alternative set of content I am only too happy to&#010;&gt; see such suggestions. If you need write access to the wiki, shout out and&#010;&gt; I'll make it so (assuming you are a regular user/dev list contributor)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; It is sufficiently difficult to understand the basic concepts in using&#010;&gt;&gt; Maven to create a simple jar with a single POM.&#010;&gt;&gt; You are introducing a lot of new concepts:&#010;&gt;&gt; -Lifecycle&#010;&gt;&gt; -Dependencies&#010;&gt;&gt; -Plug-ins&#010;&gt;&gt; - Project model&#010;&gt;&gt; that a person coming from make or Ant has to grasp.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Defining these and the relationships among them in a simple way is&#010;&gt;&gt; sufficiently challenging without trying to abstract a sufficiently general&#010;&gt;&gt; model to handle all of the edge cases.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The "Maven way" needs to be explained very simply rather than&#010;&gt;&gt; conceptually complete.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 03/01/2014 11:09 AM, Robert Scholte wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Op Fri, 03 Jan 2014 16:46:33 +0100 schreef Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;  On 3 January 2014 15:17, Robert Scholte &lt;rfscholte@apache.org&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;  Hi,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I like the idea of images, however I would avoid a graph to make&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; something&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; clear for new Maven users.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Instead I'd prefer a linear model.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; My first draft did not have the graph at the top... perhaps it would be&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; better suited at the bottom ;-)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think you should split the current model into pieces:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; A project model contains:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; - dependencies&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; - a build plan&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; - other project models ( you can call this the Droste effect[1] )&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I like to think of the project model as not just the root pom.xml but&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; all&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; the pom.xml files, so there is only one project model, this should make&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; understanding how -pl, -am and -amd switches have their effects&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; IMO these switches are way too detailed for a 60 sec tutorial. I even&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; think that a large group of the average Maven users don't know these&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; switches or use them.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;  - ...&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; There are several build-plans, namely: a build-plan for jar, war, ear,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; etc.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Every build plan has a set of predefined plugins,  which you can adjust&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; (with switches?)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; No there is one and only one build plan. We would have to redefine build&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; plan everywhere else to be able to use it like that. There is a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; lifecycle&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; binding for each packaging&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Then buildplan is too abstract. With a real world example: the buildplan&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; for a house and a bike are completely different. Unless you say: you have a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; design, some goods, you mix those goods and you have your product.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Not a useful plan IMO.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; At least keep the audience in mind: do they need to know the actual&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; implementation or do they first need to understand the overall process. I&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; think the latter is more important, even if this conflicts a bit with the&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; idiom used by experienced Maven users.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; What if we call it "build instructions" (per packaging type) ?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Now, what does Maven do?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven reads the build plan and executes it. Some steps of the build&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; plan&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; deliver products ( compiled classes, test results, a package)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think the reactor might be confusing at this level.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I want the 60sec tutorial to be the grand overview, the next tutorial&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; is a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 5 minute one on how a .jar file gets built&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Then you have a multi-module webapp tutorial at 10-15min&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I want to reference all the core concepts from the 60 second overview&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; even&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; if only briefly, that way people can come back to the short page and say&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "ahh yes that is where that fits in again"&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; my 2 cents,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Robert&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; [1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Droste_effect&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Op Fri, 03 Jan 2014 15:41:15 +0100 schreef Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;  Just in case it wasn't clear... Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: New site content
contents:- https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/Tutorial%3A+Maven+in+60+seconds&#010;Still think that it is overly vague.&#010;&#010;It would be easier to understand if the passive voice was eliminated. &#010;Makes it clearer to understand what the developer has to do and what &#010;maven is going to do while processing the POM.&#010;&#010;The page should start with a statement saying that Maven builds &#010;artifacts based on information provided by the developer.&#010;&#010;You might want to talk about convention over configuration and how this &#010;compares to Make or Ant.&#010;&#010;"It all starts with a *project model"* -&gt;"It all starts with a *project &#010;model* that you create to tell Maven how you want your project (artifact?)."&#010;&#010;/Note: reactor is just the name that Maven has given to the list of &#010;modules that are being built&#010;/Is module different than artifact? Are modules input or output?&#010;See below for confusion about whether a reactor is a list or a thing &#010;that does stuff./&#010;/&#010;The *packaging* of each module (artifact?) implies that modules are &#010;output - should provide example "such as jar, war, tar or zip" (90 &#010;percent of cases?)&#010;&#010;"The *dependencies* of each module" =&gt; "The dependencies that are &#010;required to build, test and run the resulting  project/module/artifact."&#010;&#010;"Any additional *plugins* that are needed to build each module" =&gt; "Any &#010;*plugins* that are needed to build each module."&#010;  What does additional mean to the new user?&#010;Perhaps a sentence about default plug-ins that Maven includes &#010;automatically might be useful but conceptually I don't think that the &#010;distinction is useful at this point&#010;&#010;"The lifecycle defines the default plugins that are used to build a &#010;specific packaging. "&#010;This is a bit startling to a new user even if it is correct.&#010;It might be better to describe the lifecycle in terms of steps rather &#010;than plug-ins.&#010;It might also be worth being explicit that lifecycles are defined in &#010;Maven not in the model.&#010;&#010;These next 2 sentences need to be rewritten in the active case saying &#010;that Maven does these things.&#010;&#010;"The list of modules in the reactor is sorted in order to ensure that &#010;any dependencies that will be created by the reactor will be built &#010;before they are needed by other modules in the reactor&#010;The *build plan* is then populated for each module using the lifecycle &#010;and the plugin information from the model"&#010;&#010;Build plan is not defined. Who creates it? What does it have in it &#010;before it is populated? How many build plan are there - one for each &#010;module?/ one for all?.&#010;Should say that a single build plan is created that builds the &#010;xxxx(components - no definition in the diagram of what the programmer &#010;has programmed) in the correct sequence.&#010;&#010;Maven then starts executing the build plan and building your project, &#010;downloading dependencies that are not produced by the reactor.&#010;A reactor was defined as a list of modules, now it is a thing that does &#010;produced dependencies.&#010;&#010;Final diagram is missing the output from the process.&#010;It seems to say that Maven builds "Build Plans"(square box).&#010;The developer wants an artifact out of this.&#010;&#010;I hope that this helps.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;On 03/01/2014 11:33 AM, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt; FYI here is my current plan for content:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/New+Main+Site&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 3 January 2014 16:27, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com &#010;&gt; &lt;mailto:rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     I agree with Robert's comment.&#010;&gt;     There is a danger that the page will become architecturally&#010;&gt;     elegant and will correctly describe all of the possible uses of&#010;&gt;     Maven but will be too obscure to be useful as a starting point for&#010;&gt;     a new person.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I actually think that the page is near complete from my point of &#010;&gt; view... the remaining content is actually to provide links to pages &#010;&gt; describing what each individual concept is and a link to the next &#010;&gt; level of depth tutorial.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I what to draw only the outline of what maven does... on the other &#010;&gt; hand, if you can think of an alternative set of content I am only too &#010;&gt; happy to see such suggestions. If you need write access to the wiki, &#010;&gt; shout out and I'll make it so (assuming you are a regular user/dev &#010;&gt; list contributor)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     It is sufficiently difficult to understand the basic concepts in&#010;&gt;     using Maven to create a simple jar with a single POM.&#010;&gt;     You are introducing a lot of new concepts:&#010;&gt;     -Lifecycle&#010;&gt;     -Dependencies&#010;&gt;     -Plug-ins&#010;&gt;     general model to handle all of the edge cases.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     The "Maven way" needs to be explained very simply rather than&#010;&gt;     conceptually complete.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; With a real world example: the&#010;&gt;         buildplan for a house and a bike are completely different.&#010;&gt;         Unless you say: you have a design, some goods, you mix those&#010;&gt;         goods and you have your product.&#010;&gt;         Not a useful plan IMO.&#010;&gt;         At least keep the audience in mind: do they need to know the&#010;&gt;         actual implementation or do they first need to understand the&#010;&gt;         overall process. I think the latter is more important, even if&#010;&gt;         this conflicts a bit with the idiom used by experienced Maven&#010;&gt;         users.&#010;&gt;         What if we call it "build instructions" (per packaging type) ?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;                 Now, what does Maven do?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;                 Maven reads the build plan and executes it. Some steps&#010;&gt;                 of the build plan&#010;&gt;                 deliver products ( compiled classes, test results, a&#010;&gt;                 package)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;                 I think the reactor might be confusing at this level.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;             I want the 60sec tutorial to be the grand overview, the&#010;&gt;             next tutorial is a&#010;&gt;             5 minute one on how a .jar file gets built&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;             Then you have a multi-module webapp tutorial at 10-15min&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;             I want to reference all the core concepts from the 60&#010;&gt;             second overview even&#010;&gt;             if only briefly, that way people can come back to the&#010;&gt;             short page and say&#010;&gt;             "ahh yes that is where that fits in again"&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;                 my 2 cents,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;                 Robert&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;                 [1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Droste_effect&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;                 Op Fri, 03 Jan 2014 15:41:15 +0100 schreef Stephen&#010;&gt;                 Connolly &lt;&#010;&gt;                 stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&#010;&gt;                 &lt;mailto:stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;&gt;:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;                  Just in case it wasn't clear... I'm looking for&#010;&gt;                 comments and feedback&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;                     On 3 January 2014 14:35, Stephen Connolly&#010;&gt;                     &lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&#010;&gt;                     &lt;mailto:stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;                      OK, so to start working on new content I created&#010;&gt;                     some pages on the wiki:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;
