Name  :- Mirko Friedenhagen &lt;mfriedenha...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: New site content
contents:- Hello there,&#010;&#010;I recently wrote in an internal blog article about failsafe vs. surefire:&#010;&#010;"Maven defines lifecycles, each lifecycle is a sequence of well&#010;defined phases[0].&#010;Each phase executes bound goals, which are defined as so called Mojo&#010;classes in Maven plugins. Lifecycles typically produce output:&#010;* phase "clean" of lifecycle "clean" cleans your workspace of built&#010;artifacts. Just call "mvn clean".&#010;* phase "test" of lifecycle "default" compiles your sources and test&#010;sources and runs your unit tests. Just call "mvn test".&#010;* phase "deploy" of lifecycle "default" includes the phase "test" and&#010;uploads your packaged artifacts to a binary repository. Just call "mvn&#010;deploy".&#010;* phase "site" of lifecycle "site" produces a standard documentation&#010;site from your sources). Just call "mvn site".&#010;&#010;The bound standard goals[1] of the the default lifecycle depend on the&#010;type of your project. You may bind additional goals to each phase."&#010;&#010;Probably this would mean a 120 seconds introduction :-).&#010;&#010;[0] http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-the-lifecycle.html#Lifecycle_Reference&#010;[1] http://maven.apache.org/ref/3.1.1/maven-core/default-bindings.html&#010;Regards Mirko&#010;--&#010;http://illegalstateexception.blogspot.com/&#010;https://github.com/mfriedenhagen/ (http://osrc.dfm.io/mfriedenhagen)&#010;https://bitbucket.org/mfriedenhagen/&#010;&#010;&#010;On Fri, Jan 3, 2014 at 6:19 PM, Ron Wheeler&#010;&lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/Tutorial%3A+Maven+in+60+seconds&#010;&gt; Still think that it is overly vague.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; It would be easier to understand if the passive voice was eliminated. Makes&#010;&gt; it clearer to understand what the developer has to do and what maven is&#010;&gt; going to do while processing the POM.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The page should start with a statement saying that Maven builds artifacts&#010;&gt; based on information provided by the developer.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; You might want to talk about convention over configuration and how this&#010;&gt; compares to Make or Ant.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "It all starts with a *project model"* -&gt;"It all starts with a *project&#010;&gt; model* that you create to tell Maven how you want your project (artifact?)."&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; /Note: reactor is just the name that Maven has given to the list of modules&#010;&gt; that are being built&#010;&gt; /Is module different than artifact? Are modules input or output?&#010;&gt; See below for confusion about whether a reactor is a list or a thing that&#010;&gt; does stuff./&#010;&gt; /&#010;&gt; The *packaging* of each module (artifact?) implies that modules are output -&#010;&gt; should provide example "such as jar, war, tar or zip" (90 percent of cases?)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "The *dependencies* of each module" =&gt; "The dependencies that are required&#010;&gt; to build, test and run the resulting  project/module/artifact."&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "Any additional *plugins* that are needed to build each module" =&gt; "Any&#010;&gt; *plugins* that are needed to build each module."&#010;&gt;  What does additional mean to the new user?&#010;&gt; Perhaps a sentence about default plug-ins that Maven includes automatically&#010;&gt; might be useful but conceptually I don't think that the distinction is&#010;&gt; useful at this point&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "The lifecycle defines the default plugins that are used to build a specific&#010;&gt; packaging. "&#010;&gt; This is a bit startling to a new user even if it is correct.&#010;&gt; It might be better to describe the lifecycle in terms of steps rather than&#010;&gt; plug-ins.&#010;&gt; It might also be worth being explicit that lifecycles are defined in Maven&#010;&gt; not in the model.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; These next 2 sentences need to be rewritten in the active case saying that&#010;&gt; Maven does these things.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "The list of modules in the reactor is sorted in order to ensure that any&#010;&gt; dependencies that will be created by the reactor will be built before they&#010;&gt; are needed by other modules in the reactor&#010;&gt; The *build plan* is then populated for each module using the lifecycle and&#010;&gt; the plugin information from the model"&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Build plan is not defined. Who creates it? What does it have in it before it&#010;&gt; is populated? How many build plan are there - one for each module?/ one for&#010;&gt; all?.&#010;&gt; Should say that a single build plan is created that builds the&#010;&gt; xxxx(components - no definition in the diagram of what the programmer has&#010;&gt; programmed) in the correct sequence.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Maven then starts executing the build plan and building your project,&#010;&gt; downloading dependencies that are not produced by the reactor.&#010;&gt; A reactor was defined as a list of modules, now it is a thing that does&#010;&gt; produced dependencies.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Final diagram is missing the output from the process.&#010;&gt; It seems to say that Maven builds "Build Plans"(square box).&#010;&gt; The developer wants an artifact out of this.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I hope that this helps.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 03/01/2014 11:33 AM, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; FYI here is my current plan for content:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/New+Main+Site&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 3 January 2014 16:27, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;mailto:rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     I agree with Robert's comment.&#010;&gt;&gt;     There is a danger that the page will become architecturally&#010;&gt;&gt;     elegant and will correctly describe all of the possible uses of&#010;&gt;&gt;     Maven but will be too obscure to be useful as a starting point for&#010;&gt;&gt;     a new person.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I actually think that the page is near complete from my point of view...&#010;&gt;&gt; the remaining content is actually to provide links to pages describing what&#010;&gt;&gt; each individual concept is and a link to the next level of depth tutorial.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I what to draw only the outline of what maven does... on the other hand,&#010;&gt;&gt; if you can think of an alternative set of content I am only too happy to see&#010;&gt;&gt; such suggestions. If you need write access to the wiki, shout out and I'll&#010;&gt;&gt; make it so (assuming you are a regular user/dev list contributor)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     It is sufficiently difficult to understand the basic concepts in&#010;&gt;&gt;     using Maven to create a simple jar with a single POM.&#010;&gt;&gt;     You are introducing a lot of new concepts:&#010;&gt;&gt;     -Lifecycle&#010;&gt;&gt;     -Dependencies&#010;&gt;&gt;     -Plug-ins&#010;&gt;&gt;     - Project model&#010;&gt;&gt;     that a person coming from make or Ant has to grasp.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     Defining these and the relationships among them in a simple way is&#010;&gt;&gt;     sufficiently challenging without trying to abstract a sufficiently&#010;&gt;&gt;     general model to handle all of the edge cases.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     The "Maven way" needs to be explained very simply rather than&#010;&gt;&gt;     conceptually complete.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     Ron&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     On 03/01/2014 11:09 AM, Robert Scholte wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;         Op Fri, 03 Jan 2014 16:46:33 +0100 schreef Stephen Connolly&#010;&gt;&gt;                 I think you should split the current model into pieces:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;                 A project model contains:&#010;&gt;&gt;                 - dependencies&#010;&gt;&gt;             effects&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;         IMO these switches are way too detailed for a 60 sec tutorial.&#010;&gt;&gt;         I even think that a large group of the average Maven users&#010;&gt;&gt; Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: New site content
contents:- &#010;"The *reactor* of modules that will be built when building your project"&#010;&#010;&#010; From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia&#010;*Reactor* can mean:&#010;&#010;In science&#010;&#010;  * Bioreactor &lt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bioreactor&gt;, any device or&#010;    system that supports a biologically active environment.&#010;  * Chemical reactor &lt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemical_reactor&gt;, a&#010;    device for containing and controlling a chemical reaction&#010;  * Fusion reactor &lt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fusion_power&gt;, a device&#010;    for containing and controlling a fusion power reaction&#010;  * An inductor &lt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inductor&gt; (possessing&#010;    reactance &lt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrical_reactance&gt;) in an&#010;    electrical power grid&#010;      o A line reactor &lt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Line_reactor&gt; is&#010;        used to limit starting current of motors and to protect variable&#010;        frequency drives&#010;  * Nuclear reactor &lt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_reactor&gt;, a&#010;    device for containing and controlling a nuclear reaction&#010;  * Reactor (Havok) &lt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reactor_%28Havok%29&gt;,&#010;    a physics simulation engine&#010;  * The reactor pattern &lt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reactor_pattern&gt;,&#010;    a design pattern used in concurrent programming&#010;&#010;&#010;Probably needs a more detailed definition since "reactor" has many &#010;meanings to people.&#010;Not clear why this word was chosen or what is means in this context.&#010;I guess that I have been building "reactors of modules" without knowing &#010;what I am doing.&#010;&#010;It might be helpful to mention the word "artifact".&#010;The idea of a build producing a single artifact seems to be concept that &#010;people miss when starting out.&#010;&#010;You might want to label the arrows to explain the nature of the links &#010;between the joined items.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;&#010;On 03/01/2014 9:41 AM, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt; Just in case it wasn't clear... I'm looking for comments and feedback&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 3 January 2014 14:35, Stephen Connolly&#010;&gt; &lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; OK, so to start working on new content I created some pages on the wiki:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The first page is a 60 seconds overview of Maven's build process&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/Tutorial:+Maven+in+60+seconds&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I am using icons because I want to have subsequent pages give more detail&#010;&gt;&gt; and use the iconography to enable people to see what is being discussed&#010;&gt;&gt; more easily&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Laird Nelson &lt;ljnel...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Topologically sorted list of Artifacts for use by a plugin?
contents:- Hello; in Maven 3.0.5 and 3.1.x, what is the preferred way, given a&#010;MavenProject representing the current pom.xml/project, to obtain a list of&#010;its resolved dependency Artifacts in test scope that has been topologically&#010;sorted such that the Artifact at the head of the list has the fewest&#010;dependencies and the artifact at the tail of the list has the most?&#010;&#010;I asked this question many moons ago (&#010;http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Topologically-sorting-dependencies-tp3384898p3387803.html)&#010;and after no answers, came up with what felt like an awful hack to produce&#010;what I wanted, whose code I pasted in that message.&#010;&#010;If you follow the link, you'll see that I used the ProjectSorter class,&#010;which is what Maven's reactor uses when processing a multi-module&#010;project--which gives me exactly the order I wanted--but seems like overkill&#010;and like misusing a tool, and maybe isn't the Right Way given all the new&#010;Aether stuff and whatnot.  Nevertheless, it is still how Maven's reactor&#010;works, so...who knows.&#010;&#010;Anyway, I started there and "worked backwards"--needed a List of&#010;MavenProjects to feed to it, so ended up using the MavenProjectBuilder, as&#010;you can see in the link.&#010;&#010;That class has since been deprecated and moved to the compat layer, though,&#010;and its replacement (another class named DefaultMavenProjectBuilder) has&#010;removed the convenience method that I was using.  I'd like to update my&#010;plugin to avoid depending on this deprecated subsystem.&#010;&#010;So then: suppose I'm writing a Maven plugin that needs to fetch a&#010;particular well-known classpath resource from all artifacts available in&#010;test scope, and needs that list to be in topological order (starting with&#010;an artifact that has the fewest dependencies and ending with the artifact&#010;that has the most).  What is the preferred mechanism for doing this these&#010;days?  Is it still by way of the ProjectSorter hammer?  Or is there a more&#010;elegant way to do it?&#010;&#010;(As background: I am working with Liquibase (http://www.liquibase.org/).&#010; Each of my .jar projects has a META-INF/liquibase/changelog.xml file in&#010;it.  Various of these .jar projects already depend on each other--for unit&#010;and integration testing, I'd like to use this dependency order, harvest the&#010;changelog.xml resources in each .jar file, and then combine them to create&#010;only the database tables actually needed for the test.  If a.jar has A's&#010;tables, and b.jar has B's tables and b.jar depends on a.jar, then I'd like&#010;to run a.jar!/META-INF/liquibase/changelog.xml first, then&#010;b.jar!/META-INF/liquibase/changelog.xml next, and I'd like to not have to&#010;specify this in any place in my pom.xmls, since the dependency order is&#010;already captured there.)&#010;&#010;Best,&#010;Happy 2014,&#010;Laird&#010;&#010;-- &#010;http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Laird Nelson &lt;ljnel...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Topologically sorted list of Artifacts for use by a plugin?
contents:- On Fri, Jan 3, 2014 at 2:03 PM, Laird Nelson &lt;ljnelson@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hello; in Maven 3.0.5 and 3.1.x, what is the preferred way, given a&#010;&gt; MavenProject representing the current pom.xml/project, to obtain a list of&#010;&gt; its resolved dependency Artifacts in test scope that has been topologically&#010;&gt; sorted such that the Artifact at the head of the list has the fewest&#010;&gt; dependencies and the artifact at the tail of the list has the most?&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;As an aside, I found&#010;http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Sort-dependencies-topologically-tp4971787p5036212.html,&#010;but am not clear if that follows the same rules that Maven does (regarding&#010;things like dependency management, pom inheritance, settings.xmls etc.).&#010;&#010;Thanks,&#010;Best,&#010;Laird&#010;&#010;-- &#010;http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Martin Gainty &lt;mgai...@hotmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-RE: Topologically sorted list of Artifacts for use by a plugin?
contents:- &gt; Date: Fri, 3 Jan 2014 14:03:22 -0800&#010;&gt; Subject: Topologically sorted list of Artifacts for use by a plugin?&#010;&gt; From: ljnelson@gmail.com&#010;&gt; To: users@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Hello; in Maven 3.0.5 and 3.1.x, what is the preferred way, given a&#010;&gt; MavenProject representing the current pom.xml/project, to obtain a list of&#010;&gt; its resolved dependency Artifacts in test scope that has been topologically&#010;&gt; sorted such that the Artifact at the head of the list has the fewest&#010;&gt; dependencies and the artifact at the tail of the list has the most?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I asked this question many moons ago (&#010;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Topologically-sorting-dependencies-tp3384898p3387803.html)&#010;&gt; and after no answers, came up with what felt like an awful hack to produce&#010;&gt; what I wanted, whose code I pasted in that message.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; If you follow the link, you'll see that I used the ProjectSorter class,&#010;&gt; which is what Maven's reactor uses when processing a multi-module&#010;&gt; project--which gives me exactly the order I wanted--but seems like overkill&#010;&gt; and like misusing a tool, and maybe isn't the Right Way given all the new&#010;&gt; Aether stuff and whatnot.  Nevertheless, it is still how Maven's reactor&#010;&gt; works, so...who knows.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Anyway, I started there and "worked backwards"--needed a List of&#010;&gt; MavenProjects to feed to it, so ended up using the MavenProjectBuilder, as&#010;&gt; you can see in the link.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; That class has since been deprecated and moved to the compat layer, though,&#010;&gt; and its replacement (another class named DefaultMavenProjectBuilder) has&#010;&gt; removed the convenience method that I was using.  I'd like to update my&#010;&gt; plugin to avoid depending on this deprecated subsystem.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; So then: suppose I'm writing a Maven plugin that needs to fetch a&#010;&gt; particular well-known classpath resource from all artifacts available in&#010;&gt; test scope, and needs that list to be in topological order (starting with&#010;&gt; an artifact that has the fewest dependencies and ending with the artifact&#010;&gt; that has the most).  What is the preferred mechanism for doing this these&#010;&gt; days?  Is it still by way of the ProjectSorter hammer?  Or is there a more&#010;&gt; elegant way to do it?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; (As background: I am working with Liquibase (http://www.liquibase.org/).&#010;&gt;  Each of my .jar projects has a META-INF/liquibase/changelog.xml file in&#010;&gt; it.  Various of these .jar projects already depend on each other--for unit&#010;&gt; and integration testing, I'd like to use this dependency order, harvest the&#010;&gt; changelog.xml resources in each .jar file, and then combine them to create&#010;&gt; only the database tables actually needed for the test.  If a.jar has A's&#010;&gt; tables, and b.jar has B's tables and b.jar depends on a.jar, then I'd like&#010;&gt; to run a.jar!/META-INF/liquibase/changelog.xml first, then&#010;&gt; b.jar!/META-INF/liquibase/changelog.xml next, and I'd like to not have to&#010;&gt; specify this in any place in my pom.xmls, since the dependency order is&#010;&gt; already captured there.)&#010;MG&gt;so I would say you are definitely on the right track&#010;MG&gt;so ....ProjectSorter.java.....&#010;MG&gt;public List  getDependents( String id ) {  return dag.getParentLabels( id );    }&#010;MG&gt;will get you the required count of dependents you want&#010;MG&gt;&#010;MG&gt;so processing each child module strategy might implement something like:&#010;MG&gt;"include in my reactor a known subset of selected artifacts" which would be implemented&#010;by..&#010;MG&gt;mvn reactor:make-dependents -Dmake.folders=childModule1&#010;MG&gt;(from features of maven-reactor-plugin)&#010;MG&gt;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-reactor-plugin/examples.html&#010;MG&gt;&#010;MG&gt;so a way of assessing all of the modules by executing each module ..one at a time&#010;MG&gt;&#010;MG&gt;for dir in /tmp/*&#010;MG&gt;do&#010;MG&gt; dir=${dir%*/}&#010;MG&gt; mvn reactor:make-dependents -Dmake.folders=${dir##*/}&#010;MG&gt;done&#010;MG&gt;&#010;MG&gt;*may* work as a Q&amp;D test-harness to exercise each of your child modules&#010;MG&gt;any reason for topological sorting of dependencies?&#010;&#010;&gt; Best,&#010;&gt; Happy 2014,&#010;&gt; Laird&#010;MG&gt;Happy 2014 Laird,&#010;MG&gt;Martin&#010;&gt; -- &#010;&gt; http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010; &#009;&#009; &#009;   &#009;&#009;  &#010;

================

Name  :- Laird Nelson &lt;ljnel...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Topologically sorted list of Artifacts for use by a plugin?
contents:- On Fri, Jan 3, 2014 at 6:17 PM, Martin Gainty &lt;mgainty@hotmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; MG&gt;so I would say you are definitely on the right track&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Thanks; I'm not sure I am.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; MG&gt;any reason for topological sorting of dependencies?&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;In my original post, I wrote:&#010;&#010;(As background: I am working with Liquibase (http://www.liquibase.org/).&#010;&gt;  Each of my .jar projects has a META-INF/liquibase/changelog.xml file in&#010;&gt; it.  Various of these .jar projects already depend on each other--for unit&#010;&gt; and integration testing, I'd like to use this dependency order, harvest the&#010;&gt; changelog.xml resources in each .jar file, and then combine them to create&#010;&gt; only the database tables actually needed for the test.  If a.jar has A's&#010;&gt; tables, and b.jar has B's tables and b.jar depends on a.jar, then I'd like&#010;&gt; to run a.jar!/META-INF/liquibase/changelog.xml first, then&#010;&gt; b.jar!/META-INF/liquibase/changelog.xml next, and I'd like to not have to&#010;&gt; specify this in any place in my pom.xmls, since the dependency order is&#010;&gt; already captured there.)&#010;&#010;&#010;So the fact that I'm using&#010;ProjectSorter&lt;http://maven.apache.org/ref/3.0.5/maven-core/apidocs/org/apache/maven/project/ProjectSorter.html&gt;strikes&#010;me as wrong—worse than wrong: an awful hack, in fact—because I am&#010;basically using the reactor to sort MavenProjects that I've roped in from&#010;elsewhere.  Yucko.&#010;&#010;Various people have noted tersely that the maven-dependency-plugin is what&#010;I want.  Of course, its *goals* are completely useless for this task—but&#010;buried in an obscure StackOverflow comment tangentially related to the&#010;maven-dependency-plugin I found a reference to this class:&#010;http://maven.apache.org/shared/maven-dependency-tree/apidocs/index.html?org/apache/maven/shared/dependency/graph/DependencyGraphBuilder.html&#010;If I understand it right, then code like the following should do the&#010;trick&#010;(untested, but you get the general idea):&#010;&#010;public class Artifacts {&#010;&#010;  private final DependencyGraphBuilder dependencyGraphBuilder;&#010;&#010;  public Artifacts(final DependencyGraphBuilder dependencyGraphBuilder) {&#010;    super();&#010;    this.dependencyGraphBuilder = dependencyGraphBuilder;&#010;  }&#010;&#010;  public Collection&lt;? extends Artifact&gt;&#010;getDependencyArtifactsInTopologicalOrder(final MavenProject project) throws&#010;DependencyGraphBuilderException {&#010;    List&lt;Artifact&gt; returnValue = null;&#010;    final DependencyNode projectNode =&#010;this.dependencyGraphBuilder.buildDependencyGraph(project, null /* no&#010;ArtifactFilter; prob. need one */);&#010;    assert projectNode != null;&#010;    final CollectingDependencyNodeVisitor visitor = new&#010;CollectingDependencyNodeVisitor();&#010;    projectNode.accept(visitor);&#010;    final Collection&lt;? extends DependencyNode&gt; nodes = visitor.getNodes();&#010;    if (nodes != null &amp;&amp; !nodes.isEmpty()) {&#010;      returnValue = new ArrayList&lt;Artifact&gt;();&#010;      for (final DependencyNode node : nodes) {&#010;        if (node != null) {&#010;          final Artifact artifact = node.getArtifact();&#010;          if (artifact != null) {&#010;            returnValue.add(artifact);&#010;          }&#010;        }&#010;      }&#010;      if (!returnValue.isEmpty()) {&#010;        Collections.reverse(returnValue);&#010;      }&#010;    }&#010;    return returnValue;&#010;  }&#010;&#010;}&#010;&#010;&#010;I think that might be the right way to do it.  It's unclear to me how&#010;Maven's internals themselves make use of this class, but it is probably&#010;used somewhere, and it clearly hides and mediates between the Sonatype&#010;Aether and Eclipse Aether kerfuffle that occurred between 3.0.5 and 3.1.x,&#010;so this also seems like something that isn't going to be deprecated any&#010;time soon.&#010;&#010;IWBNI there were a quick primer in the documentation somewhere about how&#010;Maven loads its own guts.  I know that fundamentally Maven is just a bundle&#010;of components that get instantiated and wired together by Plexus but it&#010;sure is confusing to try to figure out how and where something is called—as&#010;a result when there are problems you have to go digging through, well,&#010;obscure StackOverflow questions.  :-)&#010;&#010;Best,&#010;Laird&#010;&#010;-- &#010;http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Martin Gainty &lt;mgai...@hotmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-RE: Topologically sorted list of Artifacts for use by a plugin?
contents:- &gt; Date: Sat, 4 Jan 2014 16:11:02 -0800&#010;&gt; Subject: Re: Topologically sorted list of Artifacts for use by a plugin?&#010;&gt; From: ljnelson@gmail.com&#010;&gt; To: users@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; On Fri, Jan 3, 2014 at 6:17 PM, Martin Gainty &lt;mgainty@hotmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &gt; MG&gt;so I would say you are definitely on the right track&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Thanks; I'm not sure I am.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &gt; MG&gt;any reason for topological sorting of dependencies?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; In my original post, I wrote:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; (As background: I am working with Liquibase (http://www.liquibase.org/).&#010;&gt; &gt; Each of my .jar projects has a META-INF/liquibase/changelog.xml file in&#010;&gt; &gt; it. Various of these .jar projects already depend on each other--for unit&#010;&gt; &gt; and integration testing, I'd like to use this dependency order, harvest the&#010;&gt; &gt; changelog.xml resources in each .jar file, and then combine them to create&#010;&gt; &gt; only the database tables actually needed for the test. If a.jar has A's&#010;&gt; &gt; tables, and b.jar has B's tables and b.jar depends on a.jar, then I'd like&#010;&gt; &gt; to run a.jar!/META-INF/liquibase/changelog.xml first, then&#010;&gt; &gt; b.jar!/META-INF/liquibase/changelog.xml next, and I'd like to not have to&#010;&gt; &gt; specify this in any place in my pom.xmls, since the dependency order is&#010;&gt; &gt; already captured there.)&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; So the fact that I'm using&#010;&gt; ProjectSorter&lt;http://maven.apache.org/ref/3.0.5/maven-core/apidocs/org/apache/maven/project/ProjectSorter.html&gt;strikes&#010;&gt; me as wrong—worse than wrong: an awful hack, in fact—because I am&#010;&gt; basically using the reactor to sort MavenProjects that I've roped in from&#010;&gt; elsewhere. Yucko.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Various people have noted tersely that the maven-dependency-plugin is what&#010;&gt; I want. Of course, its *goals* are completely useless for this task&#010;MG_01_05&gt;I went the same tack but I couldnt find a goal to collect all the dependencies&#010;so I deprecated that thought process&#010;&#010; &#010;&#010;&gt;—but&#010;&gt; buried in an obscure StackOverflow comment tangentially related to the&#010;&gt; maven-dependency-plugin I found a reference to this class:&#010;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/shared/maven-dependency-tree/apidocs/index.html?org/apache/maven/shared/dependency/graph/DependencyGraphBuilder.html&#010;&gt; If I understand it right, then code like the following should do the&#010;&gt; trick&#010;&gt; (untested, but you get the general idea):&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; public class Artifacts {&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; private final DependencyGraphBuilder dependencyGraphBuilder;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; public Artifacts(final DependencyGraphBuilder dependencyGraphBuilder) {&#010;&gt; super();&#010;&gt; this.dependencyGraphBuilder = dependencyGraphBuilder;&#010;&gt; }&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; public Collection&lt;? extends Artifact&gt;&#010;&gt; getDependencyArtifactsInTopologicalOrder(final MavenProject project) throws&#010;&gt; DependencyGraphBuilderException {&#010;&gt; List&lt;Artifact&gt; returnValue = null;&#010;&gt; final DependencyNode projectNode =&#010;&gt; this.dependencyGraphBuilder.buildDependencyGraph(project, null /* no&#010;&gt; ArtifactFilter; prob. need one */);&#010;&gt; assert projectNode != null;&#010;&gt; final CollectingDependencyNodeVisitor visitor = new&#010;&gt; CollectingDependencyNodeVisitor();&#010;&gt; projectNode.accept(visitor);&#010;&gt; final Collection&lt;? extends DependencyNode&gt; nodes = visitor.getNodes();&#010;&gt; if (nodes != null &amp;&amp; !nodes.isEmpty()) {&#010;&gt; returnValue = new ArrayList&lt;Artifact&gt;();&#010;&gt; for (final DependencyNode node : nodes) {&#010;&gt; if (node != null) {&#010;&gt; final Artifact artifact = node.getArtifact();&#010;&gt; if (artifact != null) {&#010;&gt; returnValue.add(artifact);&#010;&gt; }&#010;&gt; }&#010;&gt; }&#010;&gt; if (!returnValue.isEmpty()) {&#010;&gt; Collections.reverse(returnValue);&#010;&gt; }&#010;&gt; }&#010;&gt; return returnValue;&#010;&gt; }&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; }&#010;MG_01_05&gt;An excellent test-case for maven-dependency-tree&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I think that might be the right way to do it. It's unclear to me how&#010;&gt; Maven's internals themselves make use of this class, but it is probably&#010;&gt; used somewhere, and it clearly hides and mediates between the Sonatype&#010;&gt; Aether and&#010;MG_01_05&gt;most of the Original Sonatype authors monitor this list..&#010;&#010;&gt; Eclipse Aether kerfuffle that occurred between 3.0.5 and 3.1.x,&#010;MG_01_05&gt;a fair amount of confusion once IBM orphaned Eclipse to OpenSource mavens&#010;MG_01_05&gt;The one 'positive' we 'gain' is seamless integration to Eclipse IDE..&#010;&#010;&gt; so this also seems like something that isn't going to be deprecated any&#010;&gt; time soon.&#010;MG_01_05&gt;lets hope..!&#010;&#010;&gt; IWBNI there were a quick primer in the documentation somewhere about how&#010;&gt; Maven loads its own guts. I know that fundamentally Maven is just a bundle&#010;&gt; of components that get instantiated and wired together by Plexus but it&#010;&gt; sure is confusing to try to figure out how and where something is called—as&#010;&gt; a result when there are problems you have to go digging through, well,&#010;&gt; obscure StackOverflow questions. :-)&#010;MG_01_05&gt;usually if we can funnel the permutations of thought processes to one specific&#010;question an answer will be MG_01_05&gt;shortly forthcoming for a real adventure in managing&#010;maven repositories thru Embedding I invite you to take ride on MG_01_05&gt;the Aether train&#010;&#010;MG_01_05&gt;http://blog.sonatype.com/2010/08/introducing-aether/&#010;&gt; Best,&#010;&gt; Laird&#010;MG_01_05&gt;Thanks for taking time to 'think this through'&#010;MG_01_05&gt;All the Best, Martin-&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; -- &#010;&gt; http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010;&#010; &#009;&#009; &#009;   &#009;&#009;  &#010;

Name  :- Laird Nelson &lt;ljnel...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Topologically sorted list of Artifacts for use by a plugin?
contents:- On Sun, Jan 5, 2014 at 3:24 PM, Martin Gainty &lt;mgainty@hotmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; MG_01_05&gt;Thanks for taking time to 'think this through'&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;More thinking and coding.  Here's my final answer:&#010;https://github.com/ljnelson/maven-artifacts/blob/master/src/main/java/com/edugility/maven/Artifacts.java#L80&#010;&#010;That method builds the dependency graph in a way that is friendly to both&#010;Maven 3.1.1 and Maven 3.0.5, using only non-deprecated classes and methods,&#010;and using the same dependency graph building and resolution strategy that&#010;Maven uses internally.  The output is a non-null unmodifiable Collection of&#010;non-null resolved Artifacts sorted from most standalone to most dependent&#010;that contains a MavenProject's associated Artifact and all of the Artifacts&#010;that he depends on.  I'm putting this here in the mailing list for&#010;posterity; there have been several questions about it (not just mine) and&#010;so hopefully I've helped someone out.&#010;&#010;Best,&#010;Laird&#010;&#010;-- &#010;http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-How to copy unversioned test resources during release:perform?
contents:- Hi&#010;&#010;I have a question about the release plugin.&#010;&#010;I have test resources which are not under version control. As testing is part &#010;of release:perform that fails without those resources.&#010;&#010;How can I tell Maven to copy those unversioned test resources into &#010;target/checkout/target/test-classes/. I really would prefer not to skip &#010;testing. Those test resource won't come into the public vcs as they have &#010;credentials for a webservice.&#010;&#010;Markus&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- &quot;Robert Scholte&quot; &lt;rfscho...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: How to copy unversioned test resources during release:perform?
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;This is probably not only an issue during a release, but also during  &#010;standard builds.&#010;Depending on where those test resource are, you could look at the  &#010;maven-scm-plugin[1] (private vcs) or&#010;wagon-maven-plugin.&#010;If this works for a usual build, it should work for the  &#010;maven-release-plugin as well.&#010;&#010;Robert&#010;&#010;[1] http://maven.apache.org/scm/maven-scm-plugin/&#010;[2] http://mojo.codehaus.org/wagon-maven-plugin/&#010;&#010;Op Sat, 04 Jan 2014 16:22:10 +0100 schreef Markus Malkusch  &#010;&lt;markus@malkusch.de&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I have a question about the release plugin.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I have test resources which are not under version control. As testing is  &#010;&gt; part&#010;&gt; of release:perform that fails without those resources.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; How can I tell Maven to copy those unversioned test resources into&#010;&gt; target/checkout/target/test-classes/. I really would prefer not to skip&#010;&gt; testing. Those test resource won't come into the public vcs as they have&#010;&gt; credentials for a webservice.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Markus&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Markus Malkusch &lt;mar...@malkusch.de&gt;
Subject  :-Re: How to copy unversioned test resources during  release:perform?
contents:- Robert Scholte:&#010;&#010;&gt; This is probably not only an issue during a release, but also during&#010;&gt; standard builds.&#010;&#010;It is only a issue during release:perform.&#010;&#010;release:perform checks out the tag which release:prepare made and does&#010;every operation (incl. testing) in this new copy. As the test resources&#010;are not in the vcs they are missing in the tag and testing fails.&#010;&#010;Markus&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- &quot;Robert Scholte&quot; &lt;rfscho...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: How to copy unversioned test resources during  release:perform?
contents:- You don't have to explain the maven-release-plugin to me, I think I did  &#010;the 3 latest releases ;)&#010;&#010;In short: release:perform is the same as&#010;cd target/checkout&#010;mvn deploy (apart from some release specific arguments/configuration, if  &#010;these are there)&#010;&#010;This makes it a normal build again.&#010;For that reason: how are these test-resources retrieved during a normal  &#010;build?&#010;If this is automated, then the release:perform should work as well.&#010;&#010;So "How can I tell Maven to copy those unversioned test resources into  &#010;target/checkout/target/test-classes/."&#010;What's the origin of these sources?&#010;&#010;Stephens answer should work as well, although IMO it shouldn't matter if  &#010;it is a SNAPSHOT or non-SNAPSHOT build.&#010;&#010;Robert&#010;&#010;Op Sat, 04 Jan 2014 17:24:34 +0100 schreef Markus Malkusch  &#010;&lt;markus@malkusch.de&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; Robert Scholte:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; This is probably not only an issue during a release, but also during&#010;&gt;&gt; standard builds.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; It is only a issue during release:perform.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; release:perform checks out the tag which release:prepare made and does&#010;&gt; every operation (incl. testing) in this new copy. As the test resources&#010;&gt; are not in the vcs they are missing in the tag and testing fails.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Markus&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Markus Malkusch &lt;mar...@malkusch.de&gt;
Subject  :-Re: How to copy unversioned test resources during   release:perform?
contents:- Robert Scholte:&#010;&#010;&gt; In short: release:perform is the same as&#010;&gt; cd target/checkout&#010;&gt; mvn deploy (apart from some release specific arguments/configuration,&#010;&gt; if  these are there)&#010;&#010;I thought release:perform is doing a checkout from the last vcs tag &#010;which&#010;was created by release:prepare.&#010;&#010;Anyways, something is doing a checkout of the latest tag. My test &#010;resources&#010;are not included in the vcs (as they have credentials). But that's all &#010;fine&#010;and the way I want it.&#010;&#010;I just need a way to copy those unversioned files from&#010;src/test/resources/ to target/checkout/target/test-classes/ before&#010;mvn:release is running test.&#010;&#010;&gt; For that reason: how are these test-resources retrieved during a normal &#010;&gt;  build?&#010;&#010;They're in src/test/resources/ and everything works as usual. I guess &#010;those&#010;resources are somewhere in maven's super pom defined.&#010;&#010;&gt; Stephens answer should work as well&#010;&#010;I'll try that. Name  :- &quot;Robert Scholte&quot; &lt;rfscho...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: How to copy unversioned test resources during   release:perform?
contents:- Op Sat, 04 Jan 2014 21:29:02 +0100 schreef Markus Malkusch  &#010;&lt;markus@malkusch.de&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; Robert Scholte:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; In short: release:perform is the same as&#010;&gt;&gt; cd target/checkout&#010;&gt;&gt; mvn deploy (apart from some release specific arguments/configuration,&#010;&gt;&gt; if  these are there)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I thought release:perform is doing a checkout from the last vcs tag which&#010;&gt; was created by release:prepare.&#010;&#010;http://maven.apache.org/maven-release/maven-release-plugin/examples/perform-release.html&#010;Sure, checking out is the first step, but the next step is less magic then  &#010;most users think.&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Anyways, something is doing a checkout of the latest tag. My test  &#010;&gt; resources&#010;&gt; are not included in the vcs (as they have credentials). But that's all  &#010;&gt; fine&#010;&gt; and the way I want it.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I just need a way to copy those unversioned files from&#010;&gt; src/test/resources/ to target/checkout/target/test-classes/ before&#010;&gt; mvn:release is running test.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; For that reason: how are these test-resources retrieved during a normal  &#010;&gt;&gt;  build?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; They're in src/test/resources/ and everything works as usual. I guess  &#010;&gt; those&#010;&gt; resources are somewhere in maven's super pom defined.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Ok, so they are placed there manual, not really the Maven way.&#010;This means that a co-worker cannot check out the sources and run the tests  &#010;without getting the test-resources from...?&#010;Depending on your requirements I would suggest putting the test-sources  &#010;under a common folder like ${user.home}/myproject/test-resources and copy  &#010;them during process-test-resources[1] or use filtering[2].&#010;&#010;I'm just not a fan of a different build during release. There are too much  &#010;things that can go wrong.&#010;&#010;Robert&#010;&#010;[1]  &#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-resources-plugin/testResources-mojo.html&#010;[2]  &#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-resources-plugin/examples/filter.html&#010;&#010;or go for the quick solution of Stephen&#010;&#010;&gt;&gt; Stephens answer should work as well&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'll try that. I forgot that I already posted here and didn't subscribe&#010;&gt; so I read today the first time about it.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Markus&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Need an example of calling a batch file from maven please.
contents:- On 5 January 2014 11:34, rajiv &lt;rajivkumarnandvani@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Hi I am using maven3&#010;&gt; I want to execute my bat file from pom but it is not working please guide me&#010;&#010;[del]&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; i used following commands&#010;&gt;&gt;mvn target:run&#010;&gt;&gt;mvn verify&#010;&gt;&gt;mvn run&#010;&gt;&gt;mvn exe:run&#010;&gt;&gt;mvn package&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; only build success but bat file not run&#010;&#010;Maven is not Ant.&#010;There is too much here to explain properly and you would be much&#010;better served to spend a few minutes reading one of the freely&#010;available books at http://maven.apache.org/articles.html&#010;&#010;This will give you some of the overview you need on you Maven journey.&#010;&#010;I suspect you will even find example of how to invoke the ant plugin.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Tommy Svensson &lt;to...@natusoft.se&gt;
Subject  :-Maven Central Opinion
contents:- I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven central. This turned out&#010;to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&#010;Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to maven central:&#010;&#010;- You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus inherit things you&#010;have no control over. &#010;- You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;- You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your software even if you&#010;have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new functionality at this point in time. &#010;- Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out in your pom are no&#010;longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during the submission process. &#010;- After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to Sonatypes nexus server&#010;and ”release” the artifacts before the become available. &#010;&#010;The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself is a completely brilliant&#010;idea. It takes open source to a new level where anyone can just depend on other open source&#010;code and automatically download it on build. This is really good for the open source world&#010;(well, at least the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process to this central&#010;repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem, inhibiting the easy sharing&#010;of open source work. I have often found open source tools and frameworks that are not available&#010;in maven central, and that is because not everyone is willing to put up with this, which now&#010;also includes myself. As I see it, either this procedure needs to be changed to provide a&#010;trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms, or there need to be an alternative&#010;open repository providing ease of release, where it is trivial for anyone to share their binaries&#010;for easy access by others. I’m wondering if I’m alone in this view or if there are others&#010;who agree with me ? &#010;&#010;Tommy Svensson&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Karl Heinz Marbaise &lt;khmarba...@gmx.de&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- Hi Tommy,&#010;&#010; &gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools&#010; &gt; at github to maven central.&#010;&#010;So just create a ticket on JIRA ...&#010;&#010; &gt; This turned out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to maven central:&#010;&#010;Can you give a hint from where this "requirements" are comming from?&#010;&#010;I know of the following:&#010;&#010;https://docs.sonatype.org/display/Repository/Sonatype+OSS+Maven+Repository+Usage+Guide&#010;&#010;This is what i use...&#010;&#010;http://search.maven.org/#artifactdetails%7Ccom.soebes.smpp%7Csmpp%7C0.6.3%7Cpom&#010;&#010;I don't have Sontype pom as parent for example....&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus inherit&#010; &gt; things you have no control over.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your&#010; &gt; software even if you have no idea if it will be&#010; &gt;  a minor, bugfix or new functionality at this point in time.&#010;&#010;This is the basic workflow with Maven release plugin.&#010;&#010;&gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point&#010; &gt;  out in your pom are no longer yours to decide over.&#010; &gt;  It will be updated during the submission process.&#010;&#010;Sure. During the release workflow a tag is created...&#010;&#010;&gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to&#010; &gt;  login to Sonatypes nexus server and ”release” the artifacts before&#010; &gt;  the become available.&#010;&#010;Needed to promote the artifacts to Maven Central..&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself&#010; &gt;  is a completely brilliant idea. It takes open source to a new level&#010; &gt; where anyone can just depend on other open source code and automatically&#010; &gt; download it on build. This is really good for the open source world&#010; &gt; (well, at least the Java/JVM part of it).&#010;&#010;Do you have something which is not Java/JVM based ? Like &#010;Ruby/Python/Perl/Whatever ?&#010;&#010; &gt; The&#010; &gt; fact that the release process to this central repository&#010; &gt;is far too complex, I see as a really great problem,&#010; &gt;inhibiting the easy sharing of open source work.&#010;&#010;The problem in earlier days where that it was too easy to put something &#010;on Maven central and the results have been:&#010;bad quality, many arfitacts which are not signed,&#010;containing repositories in the pom's which results in many problems and&#010;other problems...&#010;&#010; &gt; I have often found open source tools and frameworks that are not&#010; &gt; available in maven central, and that is because not everyone&#010; &gt;is willing to put up with this, which now also includes myself.&#010;&#010;The point in this is: To hold a quality level inside of Maven central.&#010;&#010;I think the price it's worth the effort. It's a real centralized area &#010;where everyone can get the artifacts from. If you use &#010;Maven/Gradle/BuildR/Ant+IVY/WhatEver etc.&#010;&#010; &gt;  As I see it, either this procedure needs to be changed to provide&#010; &gt;  a trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms,&#010;&#010;What do you mean by "without affecting you poms?" During the release &#010;process the versions of your artifacts are being changed from &#010;X.Y-SNAPSHOT to X.Y so the pom's must be changed.&#010;&#010;May be i misundestand a thing here...&#010;&#010; &gt;  or there need to be an alternative open repository providing ease&#010; &gt;  of release, where it is trivial for anyone to share their binaries&#010; &gt; for easy access by others.&#010;&#010;Don't hesitate to make suggestions how to make it simpler and reliable &#010;too...&#010;&#010; &gt;  I’m wondering if I’m alone in this&#010; &gt;  view or if there are others who agree with me ?&#010;&#010;Unfortunately I don't, cause i know the drawbacks of a simpler &#010;procedure...but i'm willing to learn to get things better...&#010;&#010;Kind regards&#010;Karl Heinz Marbaise&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Adam Retter &lt;adam.ret...@googlemail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- On the flip side - I would argue that the process is not too&#010;difficult. It is well documented and easy to understand, it can also&#010;be automated if you wish.&#010;&#010;You need not necessarily inherit the Sonatype pom, and if you do you&#010;can override whatever you like anyway.&#010;&#010;I think the current process means that artifacts that are released are&#010;well thought about and that their pom's provided a minimum of useful&#010;information.&#010;&#010;If you want to release something and you care about it, then I will&#010;assume that it is of good quality, then I would ask the question "Why&#010;should you care less about a high quality release than the code?"&#010;&#010;On 5 January 2014 13:15, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven central. This turned&#010;out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to maven central:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus inherit things&#010;you have no control over.&#010;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;&gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your software even if&#010;you have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new functionality at this point in time.&#010;&gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out in your pom&#010;are no longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during the submission process.&#010;&gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to Sonatypes nexus server&#010;and ”release” the artifacts before the become available.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself is a completely&#010;brilliant idea. It takes open source to a new level where anyone can just depend on other&#010;open source code and automatically download it on build. This is really good for the open&#010;source world (well, at least the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process&#010;to this central repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem, inhibiting&#010;the easy sharing of open source work. I have often found open source tools and frameworks&#010;that are not available in maven central, and that is because not everyone is willing to put&#010;up with this, which now also includes myself. As I see it, either this procedure needs to&#010;be changed to provide a trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms, or&#010;there need to be an alternative open repository providing ease of release, where it is trivial&#010;for anyone to share their binaries for easy access by others. I’m wondering if I’m alone&#010;in this view or if there are others who agree with me ?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Tommy Svensson&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Adam Retter&#010;&#010;skype: adam.retter&#010;tweet: adamretter&#010;http://www.adamretter.org.uk&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Thomas Broyer &lt;t.bro...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- On Sun, Jan 5, 2014 at 2:15 PM, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven&#010;&gt; central. This turned out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to&#010;&gt; maven central:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus&#010;&gt; inherit things you have no control over.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Wrong. That POM only helps you having things setup properly, by configuring&#010;everything for you to fulfill the requirements without even thinking about&#010;it.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for&#010;&gt; such.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Wrong (see notes below about the maven-release-plugin and "the Maven Way™").&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your&#010;&gt; software even if you have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new&#010;&gt; functionality at this point in time.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;If by "submission time" you mean "mvn release:prepare release:perform",&#010;then, well, you're releasing stuff so you'd better know how you want to&#010;call it "at that point in time".&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out&#010;&gt; in your pom are no longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during&#010;&gt; the submission process.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Wrong. This is a result of the maven-release-plugin and "the Maven Way™",&#010;but you're not forced to use it to release your artifacts. Some people just&#010;put non-SNAPSHOT version in their POM and then use "mvn deploy" to deploy&#010;to a Maven repo (such as Sonatype OSS); see&#010;https://github.com/resteasy/Resteasy/tree/master/jaxrs, they don't use&#010;snapshots.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to&#010;&gt; Sonatypes nexus server and ”release” the artifacts before the become&#010;&gt; available.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Yes, that's how it goes. The idea I think is that the artifacts are&#010;temporarily published in a special repository (this is called "staging") so&#010;you can update your POMs and test those artifacts before actually releasing&#010;them / pushing them to Central. Some people use that to make "release&#010;candidates": their stage artifacts, announce it on their project's mailing&#010;list and have people test the new thing, and after a few days, if nobody&#010;reported a blocking issue, they can just push the "release" button. I&#010;believe the Apache Foundation works that way (where people vote +1/0/-1 on&#010;the staged artifacts during a couple days to a week)&#010;I believe many other people just push the release button right away.&#010;Note that you can use the nexus-staging-maven-plugin in your POM to&#010;automatically close the staging repository (make it read-only) and even&#010;automatically release it afterwards:&#010;http://books.sonatype.com/nexus-book/reference/staging-sect-deployment.html#staging-sect-deployment-nexus-staging-maven-plugin&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself&#010;&gt; is a completely brilliant idea. It takes open source to a new level where&#010;&gt; anyone can just depend on other open source code and automatically download&#010;&gt; it on build. This is really good for the open source world (well, at least&#010;&gt; the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process to this&#010;&gt; central repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem,&#010;&gt; inhibiting the easy sharing of open source work.&#010;&#010;&#010;Before going further, have you ever deployed artifacts to a repository?&#010;More than half of what you're ranting about is about releasing artifacts&#010;with Maven and deploying them to a repository, and more specifically about&#010;the maven-release-plugin (and many people hate it); only a couple points&#010;are about Sonatype OSS and Central.&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Thomas Broyer&#010;/tɔ.ma.bʁwa.je/ &lt;http://xn--nna.ma.xn--bwa-xxb.je/&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Stuart McCulloch &lt;mccu...@sonatype.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- On 5 Jan 2014, at 13:15, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven central. This turned&#010;out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&#010;[ disclaimer: I work at Sonatype ]&#010;&#010;Any suggestions for improving the process are welcome - most of the requirements below are&#010;actually more recommendations / effects of the maven-release-plugin workflow, so maybe we&#010;need to clarify this on the wiki.&#010;&#010;&gt; Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to maven central:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus inherit things&#010;you have no control over. &#010;&#010;The wiki recommends a parent pom with the relevant distributionManagement (so Maven knows&#010;where to deploy artifacts) plus some release configuration for adding sources, javadoc, signatures,&#010;etc.&#010;&#010;You can always use a different parent pom and copy the distributionManagement section across&#010;- feel free to ask for help with this, and we can always add a section to the wiki if others&#010;would find this useful&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;&#010;This is the standard Maven release workflow - you don’t strictly need this if you’re just&#010;uploading releases, just go to the existing tagged release and use “mvn deploy”&#010;&#010;(you’ll need override the deploy properties on the command line ie. http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-deploy-plugin/deploy-mojo.html#altDeploymentRepository&#010;if your pom doesn’t point to OSSRH)&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your software even if&#010;you have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new functionality at this point in time.&#010;&#010;&#010;As above, you can always deploy an existing release - either with “mvn deploy” or by packaging&#010;it up as a bundle and uploading it using the UI:&#010;&#010;    https://docs.sonatype.org/display/Repository/Sonatype+OSS+Maven+Repository+Usage+Guide#SonatypeOSSMavenRepositoryUsageGuide-UploadStagingBundle&#010;&#010;However, once you have released an artifact to central its content should never change&#010;&#010;&gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out in your pom&#010;are no longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during the submission process. &#010;&#010;That’s the Maven release plugin - it updates the released pom so it points to the right&#010;tagged release, then changes it back for development&#010;&#010;Some projects do releases differently by using the versions plugin to update the poms, tagging&#010;the release manually, then finally using “mvn deploy"&#010;&#010;&gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to Sonatypes nexus server&#010;and ”release” the artifacts before the become available. &#010;&#010;That’s so you can check the uploaded artifacts before they get distributed to central, mirrors,&#010;and from there to developers machines - because once a release is on central its content should&#010;never change&#010;&#010;If you want to skip this step then you can by configuring the nexus-staging-maven-plugin which&#010;can help manage the staging workflow:&#010;&#010;    http://books.sonatype.com/nexus-book/reference/staging-sect-deployment.html#staging-sect-deployment-nexus-staging-maven-plugin&#010;&#010;    &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;      &lt;groupId&gt;org.sonatype.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;      &lt;artifactId&gt;nexus-staging-maven-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;      &lt;extensions&gt;true&lt;/extensions&gt;&#010;      &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;        &lt;releaseAfterClose&gt;true&lt;/releaseAfterClose&gt;&#010;      &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;    &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;You can also use this plugin to access the same staging commands available to you through&#010;the Nexus UI (or you could even use the underlying REST API if you wish)&#010;&#010;Finally depending on your project there are alternative routes to central, such as http://www.apache.org/dev/publishing-maven-artifacts.html&#010;for Apache projects, or the new https://bintray.com/ service. &#010;&#010;&gt; The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself is a completely&#010;brilliant idea. It takes open source to a new level where anyone can just depend on other&#010;open source code and automatically download it on build. This is really good for the open&#010;source world (well, at least the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process&#010;to this central repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem, inhibiting&#010;the easy sharing of open source work. I have often found open source tools and frameworks&#010;that are not available in maven central, and that is because not everyone is willing to put&#010;up with this, which now also includes myself. As I see it, either this procedure needs to&#010;be changed to provide a trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms, or&#010;there need to be an alternative open repository providing ease of release, where it is trivial&#010;for anyone to share their binaries for easy access by others. I’m wondering if I’m alone&#010;in this view or if there are others who agree with me ? &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Tommy Svensson&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Tommy Svensson &lt;to...@natusoft.se&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- Hello again,&#010;&#010;OK, I suspected that I get a lot of replies on this :-). &#010;&#010;From experience in other forums I also expected to have people tell me to go screw myself,&#010;but that has not happened. There are apparently only professionals here! That said, there&#010;some very good replies and explanations but also some I do react to.  &#010;&#010;I'll start with the latter. The arguments about quality I just don't buy. We are only talking&#010;poms here. Whatever is in the poms says nothing about the quality of the software itself.&#010;What is really bothering me however is the argument that if you don't have your things in&#010;the way we think they should be, you are not serious enough. It hasn't been said straight&#010;out but implied. The word that pops into my head here is "Moralizing"! I take my work very&#010;seriously and I take my open source work even more seriously (since in that case I'm allowed&#010;the time for it :-)). That if I have one file that is not up to someones liking I'm not taking&#010;releasing of my software seriously is just absurd. &#010;_______&#010;&#010;From one of the replies:&#010;&gt; As I said in a previous message, deploying to the remote repo is just a&#010;&gt; matter of "mvn deploy", using either the maven-deploy-plugin (by default)&#010;&gt; or the nexus-staging-maven-plugin.&#010;&#010;That is good, that is how easy it should be!&#010;&#010;&gt; You'll have to configure the GPG plugin to sign your artifacts though, as&#010;&gt; it's a requirement to deploy to Central.&#010;&#010;No problem!&#010;&#010;I'm going to go though the documentation again and solve the "easy" way to do it :-).  And&#010;If I can't find a page that explains this clearly I will create such! I have gotten very much&#010;information here to go on. &#010;&#010;Someone also pointed out that local webserver repositories are good enough for "small" projects.&#010;I basically agree with that. I only considered maven central since someone asked me. But it&#010;is easier to have things in central and not have to add multiple repository specifications&#010;in your pom/settings. OK, you can use nexus to merge several repositories into one and then&#010;use that. But if submission to central can be made easy then it is worth to do it. Software&#010;does not have to be large apache projects to be useful. There are some truly useful software&#010;out there that comes from single individuals.&#010;________&#010;&#010;Here is my view of how I would want a maven repository to be:&#010;&#010;- No requirements of javadoc or sources. If you want to include those, no problem, but if&#010;you don't  it is up to you. Personally I like to have sources available in the repository&#010;for the third party software I'm using so I would also submit sources to my software, but&#010;that is entirely up to me.&#010;&#010;- Tags on submitted software (not required - can be empty). &#010;&#010;- Searchable data in addition to group and artifact:&#010;  - Tags&#010;  - Descriptions&#010;&#010;- A browsable (navigable) web gui, not just searches. &#010;&#010;- A standardized documentation zip containing PDFs and/or markdown.&#010;&#010;- Quality indication:&#010;  - The possibility to star artifacts just like you can star repos in github. Also for group&#010;level.&#010;  - Download statistics (filtered on ip-address, multiple downloads from the same ip-address&#010;only count as one).&#010;  - A quality value based on these two as sorting order for search results.&#010;&#010;- When an artifact or group is selected in the web gui the following should be displayed:&#010;  - Dependency tags for the artifact (obviously :-))&#010;  - Pom information like description, web url, developers, scm url, etc.&#010;  - Stars and download stats.&#010;  - Any submitted docs.&#010;&#010;With so much software available in one place it would be very nice to have it more searchable&#010;and on more useful criteria, and also to have the ability to get more details on the software&#010;at the same place.&#010;&#010;Tommy&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Adam Retter &lt;adam.ret...@googlemail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- &gt; I'll start with the latter. The arguments about quality I just don't buy. We are only&#010;talking poms here. Whatever is in the poms says nothing about the quality of the software&#010;itself.&#010;&#010;I agree the pom says nothing about the quality of the software.&#010;However, having a standard mechanism for describing in small detail&#010;software releases. By ensuring that this is consistent, it ensures&#010;that the quality of searching for artifacts in Maven central is&#010;maintained, it also ensures that when someone finds an artifact they&#010;can look at the pom to see what it does and who to contact should they&#010;have a problem. I consider that a small investment.&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Adam Retter&#010;&#010;skype: adam.retter&#010;tweet: adamretter&#010;http://www.adamretter.org.uk&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Tamás Cservenák &lt;ta...@cservenak.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- &gt;&#010;&gt; The arguments about quality I just don't buy. We are only talking poms&#010;&gt; here. Whatever is in the poms says nothing about the quality of the&#010;&gt; software itself.&#010;&#010;&#010;Quality of metadata. POM serve as "metadata" in this case, so, I'd rather&#010;say Central enforces quality of "metadata" (ie. POM properly "filled in",&#010;using proper and proven/owned groupId, sane artifactId, etc, minimal set of&#010;fields are given, file signatures, checksums are present, no update of&#010;already deployed stuff happens [ie. your deploy request would overwrite&#010;something in Cenral] etc).&#010;&#010;Still, you can deploy a jar full of zeroes to Central if you wish, all&#010;until you use proper GA, the checksums and signatures matches, and POM&#010;fulfills minimal requirements :)&#010;&#010;&#010;My 5 cents&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Tommy Svensson &lt;to...@natusoft.se&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- &#010;6 jan 2014 kl. 14:10 skrev Tamás Cservenák &lt;tamas@cservenak.net&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; The arguments about quality I just don't buy. We are only talking poms&#010;&gt;&gt; here. Whatever is in the poms says nothing about the quality of the&#010;&gt;&gt; software itself.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Quality of metadata. POM serve as "metadata" in this case, so, I'd rather&#010;&gt; say Central enforces quality of "metadata" (ie. POM properly "filled in",&#010;&gt; using proper and proven/owned groupId, sane artifactId, etc, minimal set of&#010;&gt; fields are given, file signatures, checksums are present, no update of&#010;&gt; already deployed stuff happens [ie. your deploy request would overwrite&#010;&gt; something in Cenral] etc).&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Still, you can deploy a jar full of zeroes to Central if you wish, all&#010;&gt; until you use proper GA, the checksums and signatures matches, and POM&#010;&gt; fulfills minimal requirements :)&#010;&#010;And I think that is a good thing! It would be rather stupid to do that, but that is beside&#010;the point :-).&#010;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; My 5 cents&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- I am assuming that you are putting this in Central so I can easily use &#010;it without having to worry about the effect on my build process or &#010;without having to get into your sources and dependencies to build my app &#010;and I have appropriate license agreements included so I know what I am &#010;incorporating into my app.&#010;&#010;In that case, I would like you to follow the Maven "Best Practices" for &#010;deploying to Central.&#010;&#010;Using the Release plug-in may save you some steps if you do not already &#010;have a private repo for releasing software internally.&#010;It seems to me that if you are already "releasing" to your own repo &#010;prior to trying to upload it to Central, you are probably going to find &#010;that the Release plug-in is not the "best practice".&#010;We would be in the same situation if we ever decided to put some of our &#010;utilities into Maven Central. We have already done the release and our &#010;SCM is in the state in which we want it.&#010;We would probably have to look at our parent POM/child POM structure to &#010;be sure that it met Maven Central requirements.&#010;&#010;I think that you did the right thing by raising your concerns here and I &#010;think that you got some very good advice and concrete suggestions.&#010;&#010;This is a very good group that is usually well-mannered when approached &#010;in the way that you did.&#010;You were very clear about what you wanted to do and you raised very &#010;specified issues that you wanted to discuss.&#010;You also reacted to the advice in a positive way that encouraged a &#010;factual discussion rather than a personal attack.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;On 06/01/2014 7:49 AM, Tommy Svensson wrote:&#010;&gt; Hello again,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; OK, I suspected that I get a lot of replies on this :-).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;  From experience in other forums I also expected to have people tell me to go screw myself,&#010;but that has not happened. It hasn't been said straight&#010;out but implied. The word that pops into my head here is "Moralizing"! I take my work very&#010;seriously and I take my open source work even more seriously (since in that case I'm allowed&#010;the time for it :-)). That if I have one file that is not up to someones liking I'm not taking&#010;releasing of my software seriously is just absurd.&#010;&gt; _______&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;  From one of the replies:&#010;&gt;&gt; As I said in a previous message, deploying to the remote repo is just a&#010;&gt;&gt; matter of "mvn deploy", using either the maven-deploy-plugin (by default)&#010;&gt;&gt; or the nexus-staging-maven-plugin.&#010;&gt; That is good, that is how easy it should be!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; You'll have to configure the GPG plugin to sign your artifacts though, as&#010;&gt;&gt; it's a requirement to deploy to Central.&#010;&gt; No problem!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'm going to go though the documentation again and solve the "easy" way to do it :-).&#010; And If I can't find a page that explains this clearly I will create such! I basically agree with that. I only considered maven central since someone asked&#010;me. But it is easier to have things in central and not have to add multiple repository specifications&#010;in your pom/settings. OK, you can use nexus to merge several repositories into one and then&#010;use that. But if submission to central can be made easy then it is worth to do it. Software&#010;does not have to be large apache projects to be useful. There are some truly useful software&#010;out there that comes from single individuals.&#010;&gt; ________&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Here is my view of how I would want a maven repository to be:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - No requirements of javadoc or sources. If you want to include those, no problem, but&#010;if you don't  it is up to you. Personally I like to have sources available in the repository&#010;for the third party software I'm using so I would also submit sources to my software, but&#010;that is entirely up to me.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - Tags on submitted software (not required - can be empty).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - Searchable data in addition to group and artifact:&#010;&gt;    - Tags&#010;&gt;    - Descriptions&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - A browsable (navigable) web gui, not just searches.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - A standardized documentation zip containing PDFs and/or markdown.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - Quality indication:&#010;&gt;    - The possibility to star artifacts just like you can star repos in github.
