Name  :- Markus Malkusch &lt;mar...@malkusch.de&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- Tommy Svensson:&#010;&#010;&gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven&#010;&gt; central. This turned out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&#010;That was my first impression as well. But after reading the excellent&#010;documentation and setting everything properly up, I'm impressed how&#010;smooth releasing is.&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and&#010;&gt; thus inherit things you have no control over.&#010;&#010;I don't think that's a requirement. I think it's more a help to make&#010;releasing more easy for you.&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your&#010;&gt; software even if you have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new&#010;&gt; functionality at this point in time.&#010;&#010;I always go the proposed minor version change. If I later decide to make &#010;a&#010;major change nobody prevents me to change the version at any time.&#010;&#010;&gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point&#010;&gt; out in your pom are no longer yours to decide over. It will be updated&#010;&gt; during the submission process.&#010;&#010;Yeah and that's really great. Without the release plugin I had to tag it&#010;myself. But AFAIK that's not a requirement for submitting a release to&#010;Maven Central.&#010;&#010;&gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to&#010;&gt; Sonatypes nexus server and ”release” the artifacts before the become&#010;&gt; available.&#010;&#010;You can configure the nexus-staging-maven-plugin to do that for you.&#010;autoReleaseAfterClose does that trick.&#010;&#010;My projects use a common parent pom (which itself uses the sonatype &#010;parent)&#010;where a typical release is done with two mvn commands and nothing more:&#010;mvn release:prepare and mvn release:perform. This releases to sonatype,&#010;tags a new version in vcs and makes a site-deploy to github. I'm really&#010;impressed how smooth things are.&#010;&#010;I understand that the process might look very complicated as first&#010;impression. But if you don't want to go it, you might ask the guy who&#010;opened the ticket to put your project into Maven Central:&#010;https://docs.sonatype.org/display/Repository/Uploading+3rd-party+Artifacts+to+The+Central+Repository&#010;&#010;Markus&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Markus Karg &lt;k...@quipsy.de&gt;
Subject  :-RE: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- I uploaded lots of not-even-Mavenized prebuilt JARs to Maven Central and can tell you that&#010;you simply misunderstood these terms as "essential" requirements -- in fact most of them are&#010;only "best practices". You do neither need to have the Sonatype POM, it will just make things&#010;easier, nor do you have to use SNAPSHOTs. You can simply upload a prebuilt JAR file. The only&#010;"hard" requirements are a "good" POM, signing the JAR with GPG, uploading it to the OSS nexus&#010;instance, then closing and releasing it. This it at-most simple and done in minutes. If you&#010;need help, feel free to contact me at markus@headcrashing.eu, I can guide you.&#010;&#010;-----Original Message-----&#010;From: Tommy Svensson [mailto:tommy@natusoft.se] &#010;Sent: Sonntag, 5. Januar 2014 14:15&#010;To: Maven Users List&#010;Subject: Maven Central Opinion&#010;&#010;I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven central. This turned out&#010;to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&#010;Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to maven central:&#010;&#010;- You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus inherit things you&#010;have no control over. &#010;- You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;- You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your software even if you&#010;have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new functionality at this point in time. &#010;- Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out in your pom are no&#010;longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during the submission process. &#010;- After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to Sonatypes nexus server&#010;and "release" the artifacts before the become available. &#010;&#010;The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself is a completely brilliant&#010;idea. It takes open source to a new level where anyone can just depend on other open source&#010;code and automatically download it on build. This is really good for the open source world&#010;(well, at least the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process to this central&#010;repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem, inhibiting the easy sharing&#010;of open source work. I have often found open source tools and frameworks that are not available&#010;in maven central, and that is because not everyone is willing to put up with this, which now&#010;also includes myself. As I see it, either this procedure needs to be changed to provide a&#010;trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms, or there need to be an alternative&#010;open repository providing ease of release, where it is trivial for anyone to share their binaries&#010;for easy access by others. I'm wondering if I'm alone in this view or if there are others&#010;who agree with me ? &#010;&#010;Tommy Svensson&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Tommy Svensson &lt;to...@natusoft.se&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- Well, I guess I have my answer, I am alone :-).&#010;&#010;Many people are telling me that both the sonatype super pom and SNAPSHOTs are optional. I&#010;obviously have been reading the wrong instructions. This is the instructions I've followed:&#010;&#010;&#010;&#009;https://docs.sonatype.org/display/Repository/Sonatype+OSS+Maven+Repository+Usage+Guide&#010;&#010;Are there better, clearer instructions somewhere else ? One of the "mvn release:*" commands&#010;(dont rember which ) failed if I did not have a SNAPSHOT version and told me the problem was&#010;that I did not have a SNAPSHOT version. So is the above page completely wrong ? Are there&#010;other "mvn release:*" goals to run ? &#010;&#010;I also don't buy the argument that release complexity gives better quality. &#010;&#010;Many of the responses to my mail have also indicated that the update of my github repository&#010;is a totally obvious thing. I simply do not accept that. When I update my repository and what&#010;I update it with is my and only my decision! I went around this problem by making a copy repository&#010;before going through the release steps, and then deleted the copy afterwards, keeping my original&#010;intact. It was already in the state I wanted it before releasing to maven central. The only&#010;thing I want to release to maven central is binaries! My repository should not be touched.&#010;So if there is no way around that happening I guess I have released my first and last code&#010;to maven central.&#010;&#010;Anyhow, my question have been answered very clearly.&#010;&#010;Tommy&#010;&#010;&#010;5 jan 2014 kl. 16:18 skrev Markus Karg &lt;karg@quipsy.de&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; I uploaded lots of not-even-Mavenized prebuilt JARs to Maven Central and can tell you&#010;that you simply misunderstood these terms as "essential" requirements -- in fact most of them&#010;are only "best practices". You do neither need to have the Sonatype POM, it will just make&#010;things easier, nor do you have to use SNAPSHOTs. You can simply upload a prebuilt JAR file.&#010;The only "hard" requirements are a "good" POM, signing the JAR with GPG, uploading it to the&#010;OSS nexus instance, then closing and releasing it. This it at-most simple and done in minutes.&#010;If you need help, feel free to contact me at markus@headcrashing.eu, I can guide you.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; -----Original Message-----&#010;&gt; From: Tommy Svensson [mailto:tommy@natusoft.se] &#010;&gt; Sent: Sonntag, 5. Januar 2014 14:15&#010;&gt; To: Maven Users List&#010;&gt; Subject: Maven Central Opinion&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven central. This turned&#010;out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to maven central:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus inherit things&#010;you have no control over. &#010;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;&gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your software even if&#010;you have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new functionality at this point in time.&#010;&#010;&gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out in your pom&#010;are no longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during the submission process. &#010;&gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to Sonatypes nexus server&#010;and "release" the artifacts before the become available. &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself is a completely&#010;brilliant idea. It takes open source to a new level where anyone can just depend on other&#010;open source code and automatically download it on build. This is really good for the open&#010;source world (well, at least the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process&#010;to this central repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem, inhibiting&#010;the easy sharing of open source work. I have often found open source tools and frameworks&#010;that are not available in maven central, and that is because not everyone is willing to put&#010;up with this, which now also includes myself. As I see it, either this procedure needs to&#010;be changed to provide a trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms, or&#010;there need to be an alternative open repository providing ease of release, where it is trivial&#010;for anyone to share their binaries for easy access by others. I'm wondering if I'm alone in&#010;this view or if there are others who agree with me ? &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Tommy Svensson&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Benson Margulies &lt;bimargul...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- Read section 7b of the page you link, it addresses your desires&#010;directly. I quote:&#010;&#010;You don't have to go through steps 7.a.1. through 7.a.3. if your&#010;artifacts have already been released or if you've generated your&#010;artifacts using something other than Maven.  The steps below allow you&#010;to skip using the maven-release-plugin entirely.  You can either use&#010;the maven-gpg-plugin to sign and deploy your artifacts or upload a&#010;staging bundle.&#010;&#010;On Sun, Jan 5, 2014 at 11:29 AM, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Well, I guess I have my answer, I am alone :-).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Many people are telling me that both the sonatype super pom and SNAPSHOTs are optional.&#010;I obviously have been reading the wrong instructions. This is the instructions I've followed:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;         https://docs.sonatype.org/display/Repository/Sonatype+OSS+Maven+Repository+Usage+Guide&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Are there better, clearer instructions somewhere else ? One of the "mvn release:*" commands&#010;(dont rember which ) failed if I did not have a SNAPSHOT version and told me the problem was&#010;that I did not have a SNAPSHOT version. So is the above page completely wrong ? Are there&#010;other "mvn release:*" goals to run ?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I also don't buy the argument that release complexity gives better quality.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Many of the responses to my mail have also indicated that the update of my github repository&#010;is a totally obvious thing. I simply do not accept that. When I update my repository and what&#010;I update it with is my and only my decision! I went around this problem by making a copy repository&#010;before going through the release steps, and then deleted the copy afterwards, keeping my original&#010;intact. It was already in the state I wanted it before releasing to maven central. The only&#010;thing I want to release to maven central is binaries! My repository should not be touched.&#010;So if there is no way around that happening I guess I have released my first and last code&#010;to maven central.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Anyhow, my question have been answered very clearly.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Tommy&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 5 jan 2014 kl. 16:18 skrev Markus Karg &lt;karg@quipsy.de&gt;:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I uploaded lots of not-even-Mavenized prebuilt JARs to Maven Central and can tell&#010;you that you simply misunderstood these terms as "essential" requirements -- in fact most&#010;of them are only "best practices". You do neither need to have the Sonatype POM, it will just&#010;make things easier, nor do you have to use SNAPSHOTs. You can simply upload a prebuilt JAR&#010;file. The only "hard" requirements are a "good" POM, signing the JAR with GPG, uploading it&#010;to the OSS nexus instance, then closing and releasing it. This it at-most simple and done&#010;in minutes. If you need help, feel free to contact me at markus@headcrashing.eu, I can guide&#010;you.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; -----Original Message-----&#010;&gt;&gt; From: Tommy Svensson [mailto:tommy@natusoft.se]&#010;&gt;&gt; Sent: Sonntag, 5. Januar 2014 14:15&#010;&gt;&gt; To: Maven Users List&#010;&gt;&gt; Subject: Maven Central Opinion&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven central. This&#010;turned out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to maven central:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus inherit&#010;things you have no control over.&#010;&gt;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;&gt;&gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your software even&#010;if you have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new functionality at this point in time.&#010;&gt;&gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out in your&#010;pom are no longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during the submission process.&#010;&gt;&gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to Sonatypes nexus&#010;server and "release" the artifacts before the become available.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself is a completely&#010;brilliant idea. It takes open source to a new level where anyone can just depend on other&#010;open source code and automatically download it on build. This is really good for the open&#010;source world (well, at least the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process&#010;to this central repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem, inhibiting&#010;the easy sharing of open source work. I have often found open source tools and frameworks&#010;that are not available in maven central, and that is because not everyone is willing to put&#010;up with this, which now also includes myself. As I see it, either this procedure needs to&#010;be changed to provide a trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms, or&#010;there need to be an alternative open repository providing ease of release, where it is trivial&#010;for anyone to share their binaries for easy access by others. I'm wondering if I'm alone in&#010;this view or if there are others who agree with me ?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Tommy Svensson&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Thomas Broyer &lt;t.bro...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- On Sun, Jan 5, 2014 at 5:29 PM, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Well, I guess I have my answer, I am alone :-).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Many people are telling me that both the sonatype super pom and SNAPSHOTs&#010;&gt; are optional. I obviously have been reading the wrong instructions.&#010;&#010;&#010;Maven dependency versionning is based on snapshots and releases, with&#010;releases that cannot change once published (if you messed up with your 1.0,&#010;you have to release a 1.0.1 (or whatever version you want))&#010;That doesn't mean you *have* to publish snapshots, and that doesn't even&#010;mean you have to use snapshot versions in your POM.&#010;But consider the pros and cons of not using snapshots: if your POM doesn't&#010;use a snapshot version, then anyone cloning your repo and doing a "mvn&#010;install" will have in its local repo the artifact it just built, and then&#010;when you publish that release yourself, that developer won't see it&#010;(because Maven won't check for a more recent version: non-snapshot versions&#010;do not change from Maven point of view – OK, it might no longer be true&#010;with recent versions of Maven, where the version is tied to the repo it&#010;comes from, IIRC).&#010;&#010;I agree the doc is strongly biased towards using sonatype-parent though,&#010;but as others pointed out, this is not a requirement (see&#010;https://docs.sonatype.org/display/Repository/Sonatype+OSS+Maven+Repository+Usage+Guide#SonatypeOSSMavenRepositoryUsageGuide-6.CentralSyncRequirement&#010;)&#010;&#010;I think the doc is for people who don't really know what they're doing and&#010;don't really want to know and just want to proceed, and sonatype-parent and&#010;the maven-release-plugin make it really easier for them.&#010;If you don't want to use the sonatype-parent parent, then you'll have to&#010;invest time into understanding what you have to do ("Central Sync&#010;Requirement") and how to configure your POM to achieve it.&#010;Similarly if you don't want to use the maven-release-plugin.&#010;&#010;Are there better, clearer instructions somewhere else ? One of the "mvn&#010;&gt; release:*" commands (dont rember which ) failed if I did not have a&#010;&gt; SNAPSHOT version and told me the problem was that I did not have a SNAPSHOT&#010;&gt; version. So is the above page completely wrong ? Are there other "mvn&#010;&gt; release:*" goals to run ?&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;The maven-release-plugin is *one* way (the preferred way) to release&#010;artifacts, but it's actually only a big workflow that calls into other&#010;plugins: update the POMs with a non-snapshot version, verify that it&#010;builds, commit the change and tag the commit, deploy to the remote repo,&#010;then change the POMs to a snapshot version, verify that it builds, and&#010;commit the change.&#010;You're not forced to use the maven-release-plugin to release artifacts, you&#010;can do some or all of the above steps "by hand", and you could use&#010;non-snapshot versions all the time (but then you *cannot* use the&#010;maven-release-plugin).&#010;&#010;Again, the maven-release-plugin makes it simpler if you follow the rules&#010;(use snapshot versions) and accept the conditions; you're not forced to use&#010;it but you'll have to invest time into understanding what it does (that is&#010;mandatory or optional) and how to do (some of) it by other means.&#010;&#010;As I said in a previous message, deploying to the remote repo is just a&#010;matter of "mvn deploy", using either the maven-deploy-plugin (by default)&#010;or the nexus-staging-maven-plugin.&#010;You'll have to configure the GPG plugin to sign your artifacts though, as&#010;it's a requirement to deploy to Central.&#010;&#010;I bet you'll find many blogs online about how to do releases without the&#010;maven-release-plugin, and how to then deploy to Central.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; Many of the responses to my mail have also indicated that the update of my&#010;&gt; github repository is a totally obvious thing. I simply do not accept that.&#010;&gt; When I update my repository and what I update it with is my and only my&#010;&gt; decision! I went around this problem by making a copy repository before&#010;&gt; going through the release steps, and then deleted the copy afterwards,&#010;&gt; keeping my original intact. It was already in the state I wanted it before&#010;&gt; releasing to maven central. The only thing I want to release to maven&#010;&gt; central is binaries! My repository should not be touched. So if there is no&#010;&gt; way around that happening I guess I have released my first and last code to&#010;&gt; maven central.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;The maven-release-plugin has many configuration properties related to SCM:&#010;whether to push changes, tag changes, etc.&#010;http://maven.apache.org/maven-release/maven-release-plugin/prepare-mojo.html&#010;&#010;Note, I never tried it but you could apparently just do "mvn&#010;release:perform -DconnectionUrl=…" (or creating a release.properties file&#010;and then using "mvn release:perform"):&#010;http://maven.apache.org/maven-release/maven-release-plugin/examples/perform-release.html&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Curtis Rueden &lt;ctrue...@wisc.edu&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- Hi Tommy,&#010;&#010;&gt; One of the "mvn release:*" commands (dont rember which ) failed if I&#010;&gt; did not have a SNAPSHOT version and told me the problem was that I did&#010;&gt; not have a SNAPSHOT version.&#010;&#010;I did not notice any other reply specifically troubleshooting this problem,&#010;so... my guess is that you have a SNAPSHOT dependency in your dependency&#010;hierarchy. You cannot cut a release unless it only depends on releases.&#010;Otherwise, the behavior of the release could change out from under you&#010;if/when that SNAPSHOT version is updated.&#010;&#010;If you share the exact error message you received, others can assist in&#010;more detail.&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;Curtis&#010;&#010;&#010;On Sun, Jan 5, 2014 at 10:29 AM, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Well, I guess I have my answer, I am alone :-).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Many people are telling me that both the sonatype super pom and SNAPSHOTs&#010;&gt; are optional. I obviously have been reading the wrong instructions. This is&#010;&gt; the instructions I've followed:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; https://docs.sonatype.org/display/Repository/Sonatype+OSS+Maven+Repository+Usage+Guide&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Are there better, clearer instructions somewhere else ? One of the "mvn&#010;&gt; release:*" commands (dont rember which ) failed if I did not have a&#010;&gt; SNAPSHOT version and told me the problem was that I did not have a SNAPSHOT&#010;&gt; version. So is the above page completely wrong ? Are there other "mvn&#010;&gt; release:*" goals to run ?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I also don't buy the argument that release complexity gives better quality.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Many of the responses to my mail have also indicated that the update of my&#010;&gt; github repository is a totally obvious thing. I simply do not accept that.&#010;&gt; When I update my repository and what I update it with is my and only my&#010;&gt; decision! I went around this problem by making a copy repository before&#010;&gt; going through the release steps, and then deleted the copy afterwards,&#010;&gt; keeping my original intact. It was already in the state I wanted it before&#010;&gt; releasing to maven central. The only thing I want to release to maven&#010;&gt; central is binaries! My repository should not be touched. So if there is no&#010;&gt; way around that happening I guess I have released my first and last code to&#010;&gt; maven central.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Anyhow, my question have been answered very clearly.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Tommy&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 5 jan 2014 kl. 16:18 skrev Markus Karg &lt;karg@quipsy.de&gt;:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I uploaded lots of not-even-Mavenized prebuilt JARs to Maven Central and&#010;&gt; can tell you that you simply misunderstood these terms as "essential"&#010;&gt; requirements -- in fact most of them are only "best practices". You do&#010;&gt; neither need to have the Sonatype POM, it will just make things easier, nor&#010;&gt; do you have to use SNAPSHOTs. You can simply upload a prebuilt JAR file.&#010;&gt; The only "hard" requirements are a "good" POM, signing the JAR with GPG,&#010;&gt; uploading it to the OSS nexus instance, then closing and releasing it. This&#010;&gt; it at-most simple and done in minutes. If you need help, feel free to&#010;&gt; contact me at markus@headcrashing.eu, I can guide you.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; -----Original Message-----&#010;&gt; &gt; From: Tommy Svensson [mailto:tommy@natusoft.se]&#010;&gt; &gt; Sent: Sonntag, 5. Januar 2014 14:15&#010;&gt; &gt; To: Maven Users List&#010;&gt; &gt; Subject: Maven Central Opinion&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven&#010;&gt; central. This turned out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to&#010;&gt; maven central:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and&#010;&gt; thus inherit things you have no control over.&#010;&gt; &gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for&#010;&gt; such.&#010;&gt; &gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your&#010;&gt; software even if you have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new&#010;&gt; functionality at this point in time.&#010;&gt; &gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out&#010;&gt; in your pom are no longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during&#010;&gt; the submission process.&#010;&gt; &gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to&#010;&gt; Sonatypes nexus server and "release" the artifacts before the become&#010;&gt; available.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself&#010;&gt; is a completely brilliant idea. It takes open source to a new level where&#010;&gt; anyone can just depend on other open source code and automatically download&#010;&gt; it on build. This is really good for the open source world (well, at least&#010;&gt; the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process to this&#010;&gt; central repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem,&#010;&gt; inhibiting the easy sharing of open source work. I have often found open&#010;&gt; source tools and frameworks that are not available in maven central, and&#010;&gt; that is because not everyone is willing to put up with this, which now also&#010;&gt; includes myself. As I see it, either this procedure needs to be changed to&#010;&gt; provide a trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms,&#010;&gt; or there need to be an alternative open repository providing ease of&#010;&gt; release, where it is trivial for anyone to share their binaries for easy&#010;&gt; access by others. I'm wondering if I'm alone in this view or if there are&#010;&gt; others who agree with me ?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Tommy Svensson&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- On 6 January 2014 06:48, Curtis Rueden &lt;ctrueden@wisc.edu&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Hi Tommy,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; One of the "mvn release:*" commands (dont rember which ) failed if I&#010;&gt;&gt; did not have a SNAPSHOT version and told me the problem was that I did&#010;&gt;&gt; not have a SNAPSHOT version.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I did not notice any other reply specifically troubleshooting this problem,&#010;&gt; so... my guess is that you have a SNAPSHOT dependency in your dependency&#010;&gt; hierarchy. You cannot cut a release unless it only depends on releases.&#010;&gt; Otherwise, the behavior of the release could change out from under you&#010;&gt; if/when that SNAPSHOT version is updated.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; If you share the exact error message you received, others can assist in&#010;&gt; more detail.&#010;&#010;Tommy originally said "- You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version&#010;even if you have no use for such."&#010;So I believe that the release plugin is failing because he doesn't&#010;have a -SNAPSHOT in his pom.&#010;The release plugin checks that your artifact has a -SNAPSHOT version&#010;before it starts the workflow.&#010;If there is no -SNAPSHOT it assumes the artifact is already released&#010;and so stops.&#010;&#010;As others have already said, if that is not your workflow you need to&#010;do the stuff manually instead.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Graham Leggett &lt;minf...@sharp.fm&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- On 05 Jan 2014, at 3:15 PM, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;&#010;Maven works because there is a consistent level of standards and a consistent methodology,&#010;and these standards are enforced in central. If you pick and choose to ignore standards, you&#010;put the quality level of central at risk.&#010;&#010;Snapshots and releases are a fundamental part of maven, the maven system doesn't work without&#010;it. It is entirely right that central should block projects that refuse to follow the rules.&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;Graham&#010;--&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Benson Margulies &lt;bimargul...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- On Sun, Jan 5, 2014 at 11:55 AM, Graham Leggett &lt;minfrin@sharp.fm&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; On 05 Jan 2014, at 3:15 PM, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Maven works because there is a consistent level of standards and a consistent methodology,&#010;and these standards are enforced in central. If you pick and choose to ignore standards, you&#010;put the quality level of central at risk.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Snapshots and releases are a fundamental part of maven, the maven system doesn't work&#010;without it. It is entirely right that central should block projects that refuse to follow&#010;the rules.&#010;&#010;All well and good, but there _is no such rule_, and SNAPSHOT versus&#010;release isn't really all that 'central'. To post up to central, you&#010;have to own the group ID, provide source, sign the artfacts. That's&#010;about it. If you don't want to use -SNAPSHOT, don't use -SNAPSHOT. If&#010;you don't want to use the m-r-p, don't. (I happen to be partial to the&#010;jgitflow alternative, myself.) No one will know. Heck, you can wear a&#010;tutu while pushing your bundle to central, too.&#010;&#010;To give a concrete example: we push some rather large data resources&#010;to our internal Maven repo at work. We don't use snapshots. We don't&#010;use the release plugin. A script assembles the tarball and shoves it&#010;to the repo with deploy:deploy-file. -SNAPSHOTs are a solution to a&#010;need -- a common need when building code into binaries, but not a&#010;universal need.&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Regards,&#010;&gt; Graham&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Kevin Krumwiede &lt;kjk...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- IMO, while uploading to Maven Central is ideal, it is sufficient for a&#010;small OSS project to provide Maven artifacts *somewhere*.  And you&#010;don't need a repository manager for this.  You can automatically&#010;deploy your artifacts via SCP to a cheap shared host.  That's what I&#010;do.&#010;&#010;On 1/5/14, Benson Margulies &lt;bimargulies@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; On Sun, Jan 5, 2014 at 11:55 AM, Graham Leggett &lt;minfrin@sharp.fm&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; On 05 Jan 2014, at 3:15 PM, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; such.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Maven works because there is a consistent level of standards and a&#010;&gt;&gt; consistent methodology, and these standards are enforced in central. If&#010;&gt;&gt; you pick and choose to ignore standards, you put the quality level of&#010;&gt;&gt; central at risk.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Snapshots and releases are a fundamental part of maven, the maven system&#010;&gt;&gt; doesn't work without it. It is entirely right that central should block&#010;&gt;&gt; projects that refuse to follow the rules.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; All well and good, but there _is no such rule_, and SNAPSHOT versus&#010;&gt; release isn't really all that 'central'. To post up to central, you&#010;&gt; have to own the group ID, provide source, sign the artfacts. That's&#010;&gt; about it. If you don't want to use -SNAPSHOT, don't use -SNAPSHOT. If&#010;&gt; you don't want to use the m-r-p, don't. (I happen to be partial to the&#010;&gt; jgitflow alternative, myself.) No one will know. Heck, you can wear a&#010;&gt; tutu while pushing your bundle to central, too.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; To give a concrete example: we push some rather large data resources&#010;&gt; to our internal Maven repo at work. We don't use snapshots. We don't&#010;&gt; use the release plugin. A script assembles the tarball and shoves it&#010;&gt; to the repo with deploy:deploy-file. -SNAPSHOTs are a solution to a&#010;&gt; need -- a common need when building code into binaries, but not a&#010;&gt; universal need.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Regards,&#010;&gt;&gt; Graham&#010;&gt;&gt; --&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- JBaruch &lt;jbar...@jfrog.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven Central Opinion
contents:- Hi Tommy et al,&#010;&#010;here's another option for you:&#010;&#010;You can leverage bintray.com to sync to Maven Central from there. For&#010;starter, you'll just get your artifacts to Maven Central in more sane way -&#010;no parent poms, no maven-release-plugin, no 20 pages guides. Just get your&#010;artifacts to Bintray, include them in the JCenter repo (which is a superset&#010;of central, btw), and voila, once your pom is good (all the needed tags&#010;like description, developers, etc), your artifacts are in Central. But&#010;that's just a start. You'll probably discover some nice features of Bintray&#010;by its own merit - near real-time stats, packages watching and inclusion,&#010;organizations support, fast CDN downloads, etc.&#010;&#010;Anyway, give it a try, your opinion on a painful Maven Central onboading&#010;might change.&#010;&#010;Baruch.&#010;&#010;P.S. I am very much affiliated with Bintray and proud of it :)&#010;--&#010;JFrog Developer Advocate&#010;www.jfrog.com&#010;+972544954353F&#010;@jbaruch &lt;https://twitter.com/jbaruch/&gt;&#010;http://linkd.in/jbaruch&#010; &lt;http://jax.de/node/901&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I am assuming that you are putting this in Central so I can easily use it&#010;&gt; without having to worry about the effect on my build process or without&#010;&gt; having to get into your sources and dependencies to build my app and I have&#010;&gt; appropriate license agreements included so I know what I am incorporating&#010;&gt; into my app.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; In that case, I would like you to follow the Maven "Best Practices" for&#010;&gt; deploying to Central.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Using the Release plug-in may save you some steps if you do not already&#010;&gt; have a private repo for releasing software internally.&#010;&gt; It seems to me that if you are already "releasing" to your own repo prior&#010;&gt; to trying to upload it to Central, you are probably going to find that the&#010;&gt; Release plug-in is not the "best practice".&#010;&gt; We would be in the same situation if we ever decided to put some of our&#010;&gt; utilities into Maven Central. We have already done the release and our SCM&#010;&gt; is in the state in which we want it.&#010;&gt; We would probably have to look at our parent POM/child POM structure to be&#010;&gt; sure that it met Maven Central requirements.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I think that you did the right thing by raising your concerns here and I&#010;&gt; think that you got some very good advice and concrete suggestions.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; This is a very good group that is usually well-mannered when approached in&#010;&gt; the way that you did.&#010;&gt; You were very clear about what you wanted to do and you raised very&#010;&gt; specified issues that you wanted to discuss.&#010;&gt; You also reacted to the advice in a positive way that encouraged a factual&#010;&gt; discussion rather than a personal attack.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 06/01/2014 7:49 AM, Tommy Svensson wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Hello again,&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; OK, I suspected that I get a lot of replies on this :-).&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  From experience in other forums I also expected to have people tell me&#010;&gt;&gt; to go screw myself, but that has not happened. There are apparently only&#010;&gt;&gt; professionals here! That said, there some very good replies and&#010;&gt;&gt; explanations but also some I do react to.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I'll start with the latter. The arguments about quality I just don't buy.&#010;&gt;&gt; We are only talking poms here. Whatever is in the poms says nothing about&#010;&gt;&gt; the quality of the software itself. What is really bothering me however is&#010;&gt;&gt; the argument that if you don't have your things in the way we think they&#010;&gt;&gt; should be, you are not serious enough. It hasn't been said straight out but&#010;&gt;&gt; implied. The word that pops into my head here is "Moralizing"! I take my&#010;&gt;&gt; work very seriously and I take my open source work even more seriously&#010;&gt;&gt; (since in that case I'm allowed the time for it :-)). That if I have one&#010;&gt;&gt; file that is not up to someones liking I'm not taking releasing of my&#010;&gt;&gt; software seriously is just absurd.&#010;&gt;&gt; _______&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  From one of the replies:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; As I said in a previous message, deploying to the remote repo is just a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; matter of "mvn deploy", using either the maven-deploy-plugin (by default)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; or the nexus-staging-maven-plugin.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; That is good, that is how easy it should be!&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  You'll have to configure the GPG plugin to sign your artifacts though, as&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; it's a requirement to deploy to Central.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; No problem!&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I'm going to go though the documentation again and solve the "easy" way&#010;&gt;&gt; to do it :-).  And If I can't find a page that explains this clearly I will&#010;&gt;&gt; create such! I have gotten very much information here to go on.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Someone also pointed out that local webserver repositories are good&#010;&gt;&gt; enough for "small" projects. I basically agree with that. I only considered&#010;&gt;&gt; maven central since someone asked me. But it is easier to have things in&#010;&gt;&gt; central and not have to add multiple repository specifications in your&#010;&gt;&gt; pom/settings. OK, you can use nexus to merge several repositories into one&#010;&gt;&gt; and then use that. But if submission to central can be made easy then it is&#010;&gt;&gt; worth to do it. Software does not have to be large apache projects to be&#010;&gt;&gt; useful. There are some truly useful software out there that comes from&#010;&gt;&gt; single individuals.&#010;&gt;&gt; ________&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Here is my view of how I would want a maven repository to be:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; - No requirements of javadoc or sources. If you want to include those, no&#010;&gt;&gt; problem, but if you don't  it is up to you. Personally I like to have&#010;&gt;&gt; sources available in the repository for the third party software I'm using&#010;&gt;&gt; so I would also submit sources to my software, but that is entirely up to&#010;&gt;&gt; me.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; - Tags on submitted software (not required - can be empty).&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; - Searchable data in addition to group and artifact:&#010;&gt;&gt;    - Tags&#010;&gt;&gt;    - Descriptions&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; - A browsable (navigable) web gui, not just searches.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; - A standardized documentation zip containing PDFs and/or markdown.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; - Quality indication:&#010;&gt;&gt;    - The possibility to star artifacts just like you can star repos in&#010;&gt;&gt; github. Also for group level.&#010;&gt;&gt;    - Download statistics (filtered on ip-address, multiple downloads from&#010;&gt;&gt; the same ip-address only count as one).&#010;&gt;&gt;    - A quality value based on these two as sorting order for search&#010;&gt;&gt; results.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; - When an artifact or group is selected in the web gui the following&#010;&gt;&gt; should be displayed:&#010;&gt;&gt;    - Dependency tags for the artifact (obviously :-))&#010;&gt;&gt;    - Pom information like description, web url, developers, scm url, etc.&#010;&gt;&gt;    - Stars and download stats.&#010;&gt;&gt;    - Any submitted docs.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; With so much software available in one place it would be very nice to&#010;&gt;&gt; have it more searchable and on more useful criteria, and also to have the&#010;&gt;&gt; ability to get more details on the software at the same place.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Tommy&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; President&#010;&gt; Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt; email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt; phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Laird Nelson &lt;ljnel...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Armed with a collection of Artifacts, what is the Maven Way™ to resolve them?
contents:- Hello; suppose I have a Collection&lt;Artifact&gt; in my left hand, all elements&#010;of which are not resolved.&#010;&#010;(As it happens, I got these indirectly from a DependencyGraphBuilder&#010;invocation.)&#010;&#010;What is the Maven Way™ to resolve these Artifacts?&#010;&#010;I know that these Artifacts are unresolved, because each of them returns&#010;false from its isResolved() method.&#010;&#010;I need to resolve them so that when I call someArtifact.getFile() it will&#010;return me a non-null File object that actually exists.  At the moment, each&#010;Artifact returns null from this method.&#010;&#010;&gt;From this documentation link: http://maven.apache.org/shared/ I found a&#010;project called maven-artifact-resolver.  Great, I thought; this must be how&#010;the innards of Maven do it.&#010;&#010;However, that project appears to either be deprecated or incomplete or&#010;orphaned or not used or something; it is at version 1.0 and has no&#010;Javadocs: http://maven.apache.org/shared/maven-artifact-resolver/  All of&#010;its Maven-related dependencies are at 2.1.0, which I've learned through&#010;painful experience means "not the version that does dependency resolution&#010;in the right way but the old Maven 2.x non-Aether way".  So I am led to&#010;conclude that this project is deprecated and to the extent that it is used&#010;anywhere it is old and busted, to quote Will Smith.&#010;&#010;(It is true that I am using this from a plugin, and I could of course mark&#010;the plugin as requiring dependency resolution in a particuclar scope..  But&#010;I am now just curious, and want to know what abstraction layer, if any, I'm&#010;missing in Maven that hides the Aether-related details in a similar way as&#010;DependencyGraphBuilder does (from maven-dependency-tree).  I have to assume&#010;there is one, but I haven't been able to find it.)&#010;&#010;Thanks,&#010;Best,&#010;Laird&#010;&#010;-- &#010;http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Laird Nelson &lt;ljnel...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Armed with a collection of Artifacts, what is the Maven Way™ to resolve them?
contents:- On Sun, Jan 5, 2014 at 3:56 PM, Laird Nelson &lt;ljnelson@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; What is the Maven Way™ to resolve these Artifacts?&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;For completeness, I also looked at&#010;http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-artifact-resolution.htmlbut&#010;this didn't seem to have ever been completed.&#010;&#010;Thanks,&#010;Best,&#010;Laird&#010;&#010;-- &#010;http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Baptiste Mathus &lt;bmat...@batmat.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Armed with a collection of Artifacts, what is the Maven Way™ to resolve them?
contents:- Does&#010;http://svn.codehaus.org/mojo/trunk/mojo/extra-enforcer-rules/src/main/java/org/apache/maven/plugins/enforcer/AbstractResolveDependencies.java&#010;help&#010;you?&#010;&#010;Cheers&#010;&#010;&#010;2014/1/6 Laird Nelson &lt;ljnelson@gmail.com&gt;&#010;&#010;&gt; On Sun, Jan 5, 2014 at 3:56 PM, Laird Nelson &lt;ljnelson@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; What is the Maven Way™ to resolve these Artifacts?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; For completeness, I also looked at&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-artifact-resolution.htmlbut&#010;&gt; this didn't seem to have ever been completed.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks,&#010;&gt; Best,&#010;&gt; Laird&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Baptiste &lt;Batmat&gt; MATHUS - http://batmat.net&#010;Sauvez un arbre,&#010;Mangez un castor !&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Laird Nelson &lt;ljnel...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Armed with a collection of Artifacts, what is the Maven Way™ to resolve them?
contents:- On Mon, Jan 6, 2014 at 1:05 AM, Baptiste Mathus &lt;bmathus@batmat.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Does&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://svn.codehaus.org/mojo/trunk/mojo/extra-enforcer-rules/src/main/java/org/apache/maven/plugins/enforcer/AbstractResolveDependencies.java&#010;&gt; help you?&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Yes; I see that it uses maven-artifact-resolver.  If indeed the&#010;ArtifactResolver class from version 2.1 of maven-artifact-resolver is the&#010;way to go, won't be deprecated, handles the Eclipse/Sonatype Aether split&#010;transparently, etc. then that's what I'll use. ================

Name  :- Laird Nelson &lt;ljnel...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Armed with a collection of Artifacts, what is the Maven Way™ to resolve them?
contents:- On Mon, Jan 6, 2014 at 5:44 AM, Laird Nelson &lt;ljnelson@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; On Mon, Jan 6, 2014 at 1:05 AM, Baptiste Mathus &lt;bmathus@batmat.net&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Does&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; http://svn.codehaus.org/mojo/trunk/mojo/extra-enforcer-rules/src/main/java/org/apache/maven/plugins/enforcer/AbstractResolveDependencies.java&#010;&gt;&gt; help you?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Yes; I see that it uses maven-artifact-resolver.  If indeed the&#010;&gt; ArtifactResolver class from version 2.1 of maven-artifact-resolver is the&#010;&gt; way to go, won't be deprecated, handles the Eclipse/Sonatype Aether split&#010;&gt; transparently, etc. then that's what I'll use.  Thanks!&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;(Meant to say maven-artifact-resolver version 1.0.)&#010;&#010;Best,&#010;Laird&#010;&#010;-- &#010;http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010;&#010;

Name  :- &quot;Omar@Gmail&quot; &lt;omarnet...@googlemail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Using Plugin Truncated Name
contents:- I have written my own maven mojo plugin and wish to use the truncated name&#010;instead of the long name to invoke it, like so:&#010;&#010;Instead of&#010;mvn org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-pce-plugin:pull&#010;&#010;I want use:&#010;&#010;mvn pce:pull&#010;&#010;But even though I put it under group 'org.apache.maven.plugins' and named&#010;it maven-pce-plugin I still get error message:&#010;No plugin found for prefix 'pce' in the current project and in the plugin&#010;groups [*org.apache.maven.plugins*, org.codehaus.mojo] available from the&#010;repositories [local (C:\Users\omar\.m2\repository), central (&#010;http://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2)]&#010;&#010;What am I doing wrong? thanks for the help.&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Using Plugin Truncated Name
contents:- On 6 January 2014 12:40, Omar@Gmail &lt;omarnetbox@googlemail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I have written my own maven mojo plugin and wish to use the truncated name&#010;&gt; instead of the long name to invoke it, like so:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Instead of&#010;&gt; mvn org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-pce-plugin:pull&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I want use:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; mvn pce:pull&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; But even though I put it under group 'org.apache.maven.plugins' and named&#010;&gt; it maven-pce-plugin I still get error message:&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Nooooo don't put it there... you don't own that group Id.&#010;&#010;Put it in your own groupId and then in your settings.xml just add your&#010;group Id as the &lt;pluginGroups&gt;&#010;http://maven.apache.org/settings.html#Plugin_Groups&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; No plugin found for prefix 'pce' in the current project and in the plugin&#010;&gt; groups [*org.apache.maven.plugins*, org.codehaus.mojo] available from the&#010;&gt; repositories [local (C:\Users\omar\.m2\repository), central (&#010;&gt; http://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2)]&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; What am I doing wrong? thanks for the help.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- &quot;Omar@Gmail&quot; &lt;omarnet...@googlemail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Using Plugin Truncated Name
contents:- Thanks Stephen,&#010;&#010;What you suggest sounds like good practice (not sure why though) however&#010;not a fix for my issue.&#010;&#010;The fix is as follows: - somehow your response inspired me :)&#010;&#010;In the pom.xml file of the custom plugin there is a plugin configured&#010;maven-plugin-plugin in that plugin add configuration&#010;&#010;&lt;goalPrefix&gt;pce&lt;/goalPrefix&gt;&#010;&#010;I then installed the plugin and I tried mvn pce:pull and that worked fine.&#010;Job done.&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;On 6 January 2014 12:44, Stephen Connolly&#010;&lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; On 6 January 2014 12:40, Omar@Gmail &lt;omarnetbox@googlemail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I have written my own maven mojo plugin and wish to use the truncated&#010;&gt; name&#010;&gt; &gt; instead of the long name to invoke it, like so:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Instead of&#010;&gt; &gt; mvn org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-pce-plugin:pull&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I want use:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; mvn pce:pull&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; But even though I put it under group 'org.apache.maven.plugins' and named&#010;&gt; &gt; it maven-pce-plugin I still get error message:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Nooooo don't put it there... you don't own that group Id.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Put it in your own groupId and then in your settings.xml just add your&#010;&gt; group Id as the &lt;pluginGroups&gt;&#010;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/settings.html#Plugin_Groups&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; No plugin found for prefix 'pce' in the current project and in the plugin&#010;&gt; &gt; groups [*org.apache.maven.plugins*, org.codehaus.mojo] available from the&#010;&gt; &gt; repositories [local (C:\Users\omar\.m2\repository), central (&#010;&gt; &gt; http://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2)]&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; What am I doing wrong? thanks for the help.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Baptiste Mathus ...@batmat.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Using Plugin Truncated Name
contents:- Hi Omar,&#010;Well, what Stephen advices *is* actually at least a part of the solution&#010;you're looking for.&#010;&#010;Stephen says you MUST NOT use the org.apache.maven.plugins and&#010;maven-yourplugin-plugin naming scheme because this is a naming strategy&#010;reserved for core maven plugins.&#010;See the first section of&#010;http://maven.apache.org/guides/plugin/guide-java-plugin-development.html for&#010;example.&#010;&#010;In your case, maybe even more specifically this page:&#010;http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-plugin-prefix-mapping.html&#010;&#010;(btw, note the sentence "If your plugin's artifactId fits this pattern,&#010;Maven will automatically map your plugin to the correct prefix in the&#010;metadata stored within your plugin's groupId path on the repository").&#010;&#010;HTH&#010;Cheers&#010;&#010;&#010;2014/1/6 Omar@Gmail &lt;omarnetbox@googlemail.com&gt;&#010;&#010;&gt; Thanks Stephen,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; What you suggest sounds like good practice (not sure why though) however&#010;&gt; not a fix for my issue.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The fix is as follows: - somehow your response inspired me :)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; In the pom.xml file of the custom plugin there is a plugin configured&#010;&gt; maven-plugin-plugin in that plugin add configuration&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;goalPrefix&gt;pce&lt;/goalPrefix&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I then installed the plugin and I tried mvn pce:pull and that worked fine.&#010;&gt; Job done.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 6 January 2014 12:44, Stephen Connolly&#010;&gt; &lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; On 6 January 2014 12:40, Omar@Gmail &lt;omarnetbox@googlemail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; I have written my own maven mojo plugin and wish to use the truncated&#010;&gt; &gt; name&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; instead of the long name to invoke it, like so:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Instead of&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; mvn org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-pce-plugin:pull&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; I want use:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; mvn pce:pull&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; But even though I put it under group 'org.apache.maven.plugins' and&#010;&gt; named&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; it maven-pce-plugin I still get error message:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Nooooo don't put it there... you don't own that group Id.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Put it in your own groupId and then in your settings.xml just add your&#010;&gt; &gt; group Id as the &lt;pluginGroups&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; http://maven.apache.org/settings.html#Plugin_Groups&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; No plugin found for prefix 'pce' in the current project and in the&#010;&gt; plugin&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; groups [*org.apache.maven.plugins*, org.codehaus.mojo] available from&#010;&gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; repositories [local (C:\Users\omar\.m2\repository), central (&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; http://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2)]&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; What am I doing wrong? thanks for the help.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Baptiste &lt;Batmat&gt; MATHUS - http://batmat.net&#010;&gt; Sauvez un arbre,&#010;&gt; Mangez un castor ! nbsp;!&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- &quot;Lyons, Roy&quot; &lt;Roy.Ly...@cmegroup.com&gt;
Subject  :-short and snappy description of what Maven is
contents:- on https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/New+Main+Site it says:&#010;&#010;We need a short and snappy description of what Maven is:&#010;&#010;"Apache Maven is a software project management and comprehension tool."&#010;&#010;Is just not an easy to understand description of what Maven is.&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;I would like to submit my short description for review.&#010;&#010;"Apache Maven is a convention-over-configuration build tool which has great dependency management&#010;features."&#010;&#010;I know that it does more than that - but I feel that at its core, this is what it really is.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-Re: short and snappy description of what Maven is
contents:- Of course, you could say that about Gradle, too. And ant now does have the ability to use those&#010;dependency features.&#010;&#010;I went through this when creating my video course (not in the sig because this is work email).&#010;It’s not clear to me that you can make a one sentence description that will provide sufficiently&#010;useful information unless something like:&#010;&#010;"Maven is a build tool which consumes and produces artifacts managed in a repository."&#010;&#010;But that is not going to help people coming new to the project.&#010;&#010;I think I am missing the motivation here.Is the target for this description people deciding&#010;whether to try Maven? People trying to learn how to use it?&#010;&#010;On Jan 6, 2014, at 12:43 PM, Lyons, Roy &lt;Roy.Lyons@cmegroup.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; on https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/New+Main+Site it says:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; We need a short and snappy description of what Maven is:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; "Apache Maven is a software project management and comprehension tool."&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Is just not an easy to understand description of what Maven is.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I would like to submit my short description for review.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; "Apache Maven is a convention-over-configuration build tool which has great dependency&#010;management features."&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I know that it does more than that - but I feel that at its core, this is what it really&#010;is.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Richard Sand &lt;rs...@idfconnect.com&gt;
Subject  :-RE: short and snappy description of what Maven is
contents:- When people ask me what Maven is, I tell them it's a build and library&#010;management tool. If I take it a  step further I explain it manages library&#010;and dependency versions akin to how SCM systems manage source code. It's&#010;not a perfect analogy but I find it works for a lay description.&#010;&#010;Richard Sand | CEO&#010;IDF Connect, Inc.&#010;2207 Concord Ave, #359&#010;Wilmington | Delaware 19803 | USA&#010;Office: +1 888 765 1611 | Fax: +1 866 765 7284&#010;Mobile: +1 267 984 3651&#010;&#010;&#010;-----Original Message-----&#010;From: Russell Gold [mailto:russell.gold@oracle.com]&#010;Sent: Monday, January 06, 2014 12:57 PM&#010;To: Maven Users List&#010;Subject: Re: short and snappy description of what Maven is&#010;&#010;Of course, you could say that about Gradle, too. And ant now does have the&#010;ability to use those dependency features.&#010;&#010;I went through this when creating my video course (not in the sig because&#010;this is work email). It's not clear to me that you can make a one sentence&#010;description that will provide sufficiently useful information unless&#010;something like:&#010;&#010;"Maven is a build tool which consumes and produces artifacts managed in a&#010;repository."&#010;&#010;But that is not going to help people coming new to the project.&#010;&#010;I think I am missing the motivation here.Is the target for this&#010;description people deciding whether to try Maven? Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: short and snappy description of what Maven is
contents:- I think that the target has to be people deciding whether to try Maven.&#010;They initially want to know what it does and why it is better than Ant &#010;or whatever they are using now.&#010;&#010;Trying to teach Maven in a single sentence is too much to ask.&#010;&#010;"Maven is a build tool which consumes and produces artifacts managed in &#010;a repository." doesn't sound like it will help build my application.&#010;At the start, one doesn't have any artifacts or own a repository.&#010;&#010;"Apache Maven is a convention-over-configuration build tool which has &#010;great dependency management features." is pretty clear for a single &#010;sentence description and it true.&#010;Maybe we can come up with a follow-up sentence to amplify/explain this one.&#010;Most programmers or project managers should be able to find the time to &#010;read 2 or maybe 3 sentences before deciding on a build tool.&#010;As long as each sentence draws the person deeper into Maven, that would &#010;work.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;&#010;On 06/01/2014 12:57 PM, Russell Gold wrote:&#010;&gt; Of course, you could say that about Gradle, too. And ant now does have the ability to&#010;use those dependency features.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I went through this when creating my video course (not in the sig because this is work&#010;email). It’s not clear to me that you can make a one sentence description that will provide&#010;sufficiently useful information unless something like:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "Maven is a build tool which consumes and produces artifacts managed in a repository."&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; But that is not going to help people coming new to the project.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I think I am missing the motivation here.Is the target for this description people deciding&#010;whether to try Maven? People trying to learn how to use it?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Jan 6, 2014, at 12:43 PM, Lyons, Roy &lt;Roy.Lyons@cmegroup.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; on https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/New+Main+Site it says:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; We need a short and snappy description of what Maven is:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; "Apache Maven is a software project management and comprehension tool."&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Is just not an easy to understand description of what Maven is.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I would like to submit my short description for review.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; "Apache Maven is a convention-over-configuration build tool which has great dependency&#010;management features."&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I know that it does more than that - but I feel that at its core, this is what it&#010;really is.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Russell Gold &lt;russell.g...@oracle.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: short and snappy description of what Maven is
contents:- Several sentences sounds good. But here’s another question. Comparing Maven to ant is almost&#010;too easy in terms of advantages. Is gradle now a serious competitor (I had been working on&#010;converting an enormous project to maven, but the architect decided to switch to gradle, so&#010;I am particularly sensitive to the issue). I can see some superficial advantages of gradle&#010;that might appeal to some projects. Is it better to ignore or address this?&#010;&#010;On Jan 6, 2014, at 3:02 PM, Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; On Monday, 6 January 2014, Ron Wheeler wrote:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; I think that the target has to be people deciding whether to try Maven.&#010;&gt;&gt; They initially want to know what it does and why it is better than Ant or&#010;&gt;&gt; whatever they are using now.&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; Trying to teach Maven in a single sentence is too much to ask.&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; "Maven is a build tool which consumes and produces artifacts managed in a&#010;&gt;&gt; repository." doesn't sound like it will help build my application.&#010;&gt;&gt; At the start, one doesn't have any artifacts or own a repository.&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; "Apache Maven is a convention-over-configuration build tool which has&#010;&gt;&gt; great dependency management features."&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I think we should hint at the descriptive philosophy rather than the&#010;&gt; procedural philosophy most tools take&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; is pretty clear for a single sentence description and it true.&#010;&gt;&gt; Maybe we can come up with a follow-up sentence to amplify/explain this one.&#010;&gt;&gt; Most programmers or project managers should be able to find the time to&#010;&gt;&gt; read 2 or maybe 3 sentences before deciding on a build tool.&#010;&gt;&gt; As long as each sentence draws the person deeper into Maven, that would&#010;&gt;&gt; work.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Yes that is the idea&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; On 06/01/2014 12:57 PM, Russell Gold wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Of course, you could say that about Gradle, too. And ant now does have&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; the ability to use those dependency features.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I went through this when creating my video course (not in the sig because&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; this is work email). It’s not clear to me that you can make a one sentence&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; description that will provide sufficiently useful information unless&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; something like:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; "Maven is a build tool which consumes and produces artifacts managed in a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; repository."&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; But that is not going to help people coming new to the project.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think I am missing the motivation here.Is the target for this&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; description people deciding whether to try Maven? People trying to learn&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; how to use it?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On Jan 6, 2014, at 12:43 PM, Lyons, Roy &lt;Roy.Lyons@cmegroup.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; on https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/New+Main+Site it&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; says:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; We need a short and snappy description of what Maven is:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "Apache Maven is a software project management and comprehension tool."&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Is just not an easy to understand description of what Maven is.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I would like to submit my short description for review.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "Apache Maven is a convention-over-configuration build tool which has&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; great dependency management features."&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I know that it does more than that - but I feel that at its core, this&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; is what it really is.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: short and snappy description of what Maven is
contents:- On 06/01/2014 3:08 PM, Russell Gold wrote:&#010;&gt; Several sentences sounds good. But here’s another question. Comparing Maven to ant&#010;is almost too easy in terms of advantages. Is gradle now a serious competitor (I had been&#010;working on converting an enormous project to maven, but the architect decided to switch to&#010;gradle, so I am particularly sensitive to the issue). I can see some superficial advantages&#010;of gradle that might appeal to some projects. Is it better to ignore or address this?&#010;&#010;The more that can be said to relate Maven to what the reader already &#010;knows or is considering, the more useful the paragraph.&#010;There is no reason why the following paragraphs could not point deeper &#010;into the documentation for comparisons with Ant or Gradle.&#010;I would suggest that the first paragraph not include links so that the &#010;reader can at least get through one clear section before starting to &#010;jump around and get carried off into the world of hyperlinks.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;&gt; On Jan 6, 2014, at 3:02 PM, Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt;&#010;wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On Monday, 6 January 2014, Ron Wheeler wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think that the target has to be people deciding whether to try Maven.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; They initially want to know what it does and why it is better than Ant or&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; whatever they are using now.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Trying to teach Maven in a single sentence is too much to ask.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; "Maven is a build tool which consumes and produces artifacts managed in a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; repository." doesn't sound like it will help build my application.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; At the start, one doesn't have any artifacts or own a repository.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; "Apache Maven is a convention-over-configuration build tool which has&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; great dependency management features."&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I think we should hint at the descriptive philosophy rather than the&#010;&gt;&gt; procedural philosophy most tools take&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; is pretty clear for a single sentence description and it true.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maybe we can come up with a follow-up sentence to amplify/explain this one.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Most programmers or project managers should be able to find the time to&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; read 2 or maybe 3 sentences before deciding on a build tool.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; As long as each sentence draws the person deeper into Maven, that would&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; work.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Yes that is the idea&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 06/01/2014 12:57 PM, Russell Gold wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Of course, you could say that about Gradle, too. And ant now does have&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; the ability to use those dependency features.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I went through this when creating my video course (not in the sig because&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; this is work email). It’s not clear to me that you can make a one sentence&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; description that will provide sufficiently useful information unless&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; something like:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "Maven is a build tool which consumes and produces artifacts managed in a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; repository."&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; But that is not going to help people coming new to the project.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think I am missing the motivation here.Is the target for this&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; description people deciding whether to try Maven? People trying to learn&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; how to use it?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On Jan 6, 2014, at 12:43 PM, Lyons, Roy &lt;Roy.Lyons@cmegroup.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; on https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/New+Main+Site it&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; says:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; We need a short and snappy description of what Maven is:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "Apache Maven is a software project management and comprehension tool."&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Is just not an easy to understand description of what Maven is.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I would like to submit my short description for review.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "Apache Maven is a convention-over-configuration build tool which has&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; great dependency management features."&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I know that it does more than that - but I feel that at its core, this&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; is what it really is.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;
