Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Misunderstanding modules: &quot;Two or more projects in the reactor have the same identifier&quot;
contents:- On 7 January 2014 09:42, erich8 &lt;Eric.Herrmann@intermedix.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Barrie Treloar wrote&#010;&gt;&gt; When you build Product X the libraries A, B and C should already&#010;&gt;&gt; exist.  You dont want to rebuild them just to build Product X, that&#010;&gt;&gt; will slow down your development process.&#010;&gt;&gt; Ideally A, B, and C are released versions, but if you find a bug in&#010;&gt;&gt; them then you will be using SNAPSHOT versions, which will need to be&#010;&gt;&gt; released separately prior to releasing Product X.&#010;&gt;&gt; If developers are rarely touching the libraries then its better to let&#010;&gt;&gt; your continuous build system (e.g. Jenkins) build the libraries and&#010;&gt;&gt; Maven will automatically pull down the latest SNAPSHOT for you.&#010;&gt;&gt; This way Developer D can fix a bug in A and Developer E will&#010;&gt;&gt; automatically get the bug fix the next time they pull down the&#010;&gt;&gt; SNAPSHOT build of library A, they no longer need to resync and&#010;&gt;&gt; manually build.&#010;&gt;&gt; You can configure how often Maven will check for a snapshot update&#010;&gt;&gt; (see updatePolicy&#010;&gt;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/ref/3.0.3/maven-settings/settings.html#class_snapshots)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; With a continuous build system in place whenever C changes it will&#010;&gt;&gt; automatically schedule a build for A and B, run your unit tests and&#010;&gt;&gt; report success or failure.&#010;&gt;&gt; It should also then build Product X and Y for you (since a downstream&#010;&gt;&gt; dependency changed), again running your unit tests.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; You will also want a Repository Manager so that it can keep some&#010;&gt;&gt; control over how many SNAPSHOT versions to keep (otherwise you can&#010;&gt;&gt; find yourself running out of disk space)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Hope this helps some.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I understand the need to treat internally-developed dependencies as actual&#010;&gt; dependencies rather than forcing them to be modules, but I'm having some&#010;&gt; problems with the workflow.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; When the project is relatively new and the internally-developed dependency&#010;&gt; "A" is no where near being mature, nearly every change being made to&#010;&gt; "Project X" requires a corresponding change to A. At this point in the&#010;&gt; development cycle (and for many months in the foreseeable future) I actually&#010;&gt; /do/ need to rebuild A every time I build X.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I can setup our CI system so that A SNAPSHOTS are built and published to&#010;&gt; Nexus after every commit, but what about during development, before I'm&#010;&gt; ready commit my changes? Am I stuck with what my IDE provides? We have&#010;&gt; developers using a wide range of IDEs, or no IDE at all, so I was hoping&#010;&gt; that Maven itself would have some way of kicking off builds of downstream&#010;&gt; dependency A when X is built, if in fact that's what I want to do.&#010;&#010;Ideally you want your development to be only against releases, but as&#010;you notice in the early days that just can't happen.&#010;&#010;One thing I neglected to mention is that publishing SNAPSHOT to a&#010;repository can be a pain.&#010;&#010;The reason is that while you are happily working with your artifacts,&#010;if a new SNAPSHOT is published and Maven decides to start downloading&#010;it then you can find your local development hosed by bugs in the new&#010;SNAPSHOT.&#010;Obviously there is a trade-off here. You want to see bugs quickly so&#010;that you can get them fixed correctly - either your code, or the&#010;dependency. But you can also waste a lot of time if you have people&#010;checking in things that cause breakage all the time (perhaps you then&#010;need to investigate why that is occurring and deal with that as well).&#010; You should be able to manage this with the --no-snapshot-updates&#010;option so you can when you want to pull in newer SNAPSHOTS.  Just&#010;remember that you may have to rebuild your code again so that your&#010;local .m2 cache has your code changes in it and not the CI version.&#010;&#010;The next thing to ask is who is making the changes to A and X.&#010;If it is the same person then they dont need Maven yet.&#010;They can build via the command line, IDE, whatever.&#010;I prefer to let the IDE (Eclipse in my case) handle the incremental&#010;build problems.&#010;I keep working on whatever projects I need until they are ready to&#010;commit into version control and the IDE will ensure that everything is&#010;building correctly so I can run my unit tests, etc all in the IDE.&#010;I'm not using Maven at all here.&#010;&#010;Before I commit this to version control, then I break out Maven and&#010;build the projects in the correct order and ensure everything works.&#010;Once committed to version control then CI will publish the SNAPSHOTS&#010;and other developers can then decide when they want to start using the&#010;new SNAPSHOTS.&#010;&#010;&gt; Right now we're simply telling folks to build A, then build X. And this&#010;&gt; certainly makes sense when you step back and think about it... it's just not&#010;&gt; terribly convenient.&#010;&#010;If those folks are working on A and X they dont have any other&#010;options, they want to build their code with their changes and not&#010;suddenly get something from CI (which obviously can not have their&#010;changes in it).&#010;For those working with IDEs they should be able to just work in the&#010;IDE. I'm fairly sure there is Maven integration with m2e like features&#010;in NetBeans and IDEA.&#010;I dont understand how you can efficiently develop without an IDE and&#010;I'm not prepared to spend any of my time trying to help them out :)&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Misunderstanding modules: &quot;Two or more projects in the reactor have the same identifier&quot;
contents:- During active development, we have found that libraries A,B and C should &#010;be released as SNAPSHOTs with a spec and warranty from the developer.&#010;These may be informal but without this, the developer of X has a hard &#010;time testing if A,B and C are changing specification/behaviour without &#010;warning.&#010;&#010;This implies that there is a series of stubs for methods in A,B and C &#010;that are not complete.&#010;&#010;If it is not possible for the developers of A,B and C to do this, the &#010;developer of X needs to program to interfaces of A,B and C and find a &#010;way (DI for instance ) of substituting is own versions (stubs) of A,B &#010;and C for testing while A,B and C are being developed to a point where &#010;they are suitable for testing and can be released as SNAPSHOTS with &#010;specs and warranties.&#010;&#010;Otherwise the developer of X will waste a lot of time debugging the &#010;intermediate versions of A, B and C rather than focusing on X. While &#010;debugging, the developer of X will never know whether changes to X are &#010;not working or changes to the behaviour of X are caused by undocumented &#010;changes to the dependencies.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;On 06/01/2014 6:12 PM, erich8 wrote:&#010;&gt; Barrie Treloar wrote&#010;&gt;&gt; When you build Product X the libraries A, B and C should already&#010;&gt;&gt; exist.  You dont want to rebuild them just to build Product X, that&#010;&gt;&gt; will slow down your development process.&#010;&gt;&gt; Ideally A, B, and C are released versions, but if you find a bug in&#010;&gt;&gt; them then you will be using SNAPSHOT versions, which will need to be&#010;&gt;&gt; released separately prior to releasing Product X.&#010;&gt;&gt; If developers are rarely touching the libraries then its better to let&#010;&gt;&gt; your continuous build system (e.g. Jenkins) build the libraries and&#010;&gt;&gt; Maven will automatically pull down the latest SNAPSHOT for you.&#010;&gt;&gt; This way Developer D can fix a bug in A and Developer E will&#010;&gt;&gt; automatically get the bug fix the next time they pull down the&#010;&gt;&gt; SNAPSHOT build of library A, they no longer need to resync and&#010;&gt;&gt; manually build.&#010;&gt;&gt; You can configure how often Maven will check for a snapshot update&#010;&gt;&gt; (see updatePolicy&#010;&gt;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/ref/3.0.3/maven-settings/settings.html#class_snapshots)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; With a continuous build system in place whenever C changes it will&#010;&gt;&gt; automatically schedule a build for A and B, run your unit tests and&#010;&gt;&gt; report success or failure.&#010;&gt;&gt; It should also then build Product X and Y for you (since a downstream&#010;&gt;&gt; dependency changed), again running your unit tests.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; You will also want a Repository Manager so that it can keep some&#010;&gt;&gt; control over how many SNAPSHOT versions to keep (otherwise you can&#010;&gt;&gt; find yourself running out of disk space)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Hope this helps some.&#010;&gt; I understand the need to treat internally-developed dependencies as actual&#010;&gt; dependencies rather than forcing them to be modules, but I'm having some&#010;&gt; problems with the workflow.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; When the project is relatively new and the internally-developed dependency&#010;&gt; "A" is no where near being mature, nearly every change being made to&#010;&gt; "Project X" requires a corresponding change to A. At this point in the&#010;&gt; development cycle (and for many months in the foreseeable future) I actually&#010;&gt; /do/ need to rebuild A every time I build X.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I can setup our CI system so that A SNAPSHOTS are built and published to&#010;&gt; Nexus after every commit, but what about during development, before I'm&#010;&gt; ready commit my changes? Am I stuck with what my IDE provides? We have&#010;&gt; developers using a wide range of IDEs, or no IDE at all, so I was hoping&#010;&gt; that Maven itself would have some way of kicking off builds of downstream&#010;&gt; dependency A when X is built, if in fact that's what I want to do.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Right now we're simply telling folks to build A, then build X. And this&#010;&gt; certainly makes sense when you step back and think about it... it's just not&#010;&gt; terribly convenient.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Misunderstanding-modules-Two-or-more-projects-in-the-reactor-have-the-same-identifier-tp4614001p5780688.html&#010;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- &quot;Mark Derricutt&quot; &lt;m...@talios.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Misunderstanding modules: &quot;Two or more projects in the reactor have the same identifier&quot;
contents:- &#010;&gt;&gt; When the project is relatively new and the internally-developed dependency&#010;&gt;&gt; "A" is no where near being mature, nearly every change being made to&#010;&gt;&gt; "Project X" requires a corresponding change to A. At this point in the&#010;&gt;&gt; development cycle (and for many months in the foreseeable future) I actually&#010;&gt;&gt; /do/ need to rebuild A every time I build X.&#010;&#010;What I've often done here is create a new workspace area that contains symlinks ( or git submodule&#010;checkouts ) of each of the modules I'm working on, and having a simple pom.xml in the top&#010;level that sets up a reactor build, then just build that.&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Misunderstanding modules: &quot;Two or more projects in the reactor have the same identifier&quot;
contents:- On 7 January 2014 15:29, Mark Derricutt &lt;mark@talios.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; When the project is relatively new and the internally-developed dependency&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; "A" is no where near being mature, nearly every change being made to&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; "Project X" requires a corresponding change to A. At this point in the&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; development cycle (and for many months in the foreseeable future) I actually&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; /do/ need to rebuild A every time I build X.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; What I've often done here is create a new workspace area that contains symlinks ( or&#010;git submodule checkouts ) of each of the modules I'm working on, and having a simple pom.xml&#010;in the top level that sets up a reactor build, then just build that.&#010;&#010;There was also some talk about automating this step.&#010;But its vapourware at the moment.&#010;&#010;It would work by checking your current pom for any -SNAPSHOT&#010;dependencies and then pulling out the source code for those and&#010;sitting them in the parent directory.&#010;And as you say the parent pom is just a helper that has a bunch of&#010;modules to make building things easier - and you would never check&#010;that pom into version control.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Patrick Turcotte &lt;pat...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Misunderstanding modules: &quot;Two or more projects in the reactor have the same identifier&quot;
contents:- &#010;We are doing something similar with what I call an assembly project.&#010;&#010;I have the following structure:&#010;&#010;assembly&#010;   - pom.xml&#010;   - projectA&#010;     - pom.xml&#010;   - projectB&#010;     - pom.xml&#010;   - projectC&#010;     - pom.xml&#010;   - projectX&#010;     - pom.xml&#010;&#010;Where the assembly's pom.xml contains like:&#010;&#010;&lt;packaging&gt;pom&lt;/packaging&gt;&#010;&lt;modules&gt;&#010;   &lt;module&gt;projectA&lt;/module&gt;&#010;   &lt;module&gt;projectB&lt;/module&gt;&#010;   &lt;module&gt;projectC&lt;/module&gt;&#010;   &lt;module&gt;projectX&lt;/module&gt;&#010;&lt;/modules&gt;&#010;&#010;And dependencies between projects are set within each module (versions &#010;may be in a parent pom)&#010;&#010;Then, in my "assembly" project, I do&#010;mvn install&#010;&#010;Or, with multiple windows open, I would do a mvn install for projectA &#010;and then switch to projectX and build it.&#010;&#010;Hope this helps.&#010;&#010;Patrick&#010;&#010;On 07/01/14 12:49 AM, Barrie Treloar wrote:&#010;&gt; On 7 January 2014 15:29, Mark Derricutt &lt;mark@talios.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; When the project is relatively new and the internally-developed dependency&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "A" is no where near being mature, nearly every change being made to&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "Project X" requires a corresponding change to A. At this point in the&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; development cycle (and for many months in the foreseeable future) I actually&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; /do/ need to rebuild A every time I build X.&#010;&gt;&gt; What I've often done here is create a new workspace area that contains symlinks (&#010;or git submodule checkouts ) of each of the modules I'm working on, and having a simple pom.xml&#010;in the top level that sets up a reactor build, then just build that.&#010;&gt; There was also some talk about automating this step.&#010;&gt; But its vapourware at the moment.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; It would work by checking your current pom for any -SNAPSHOT&#010;&gt; dependencies and then pulling out the source code for those and&#010;&gt; sitting them in the parent directory.&#010;&gt; And as you say the parent pom is just a helper that has a bunch of&#010;&gt; modules to make building things easier - and you would never check&#010;&gt; that pom into version control.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Misunderstanding modules: &quot;Two or more projects in the reactor have the same identifier&quot;
contents:- FYI I call that a local aggregator pom. I typically set them up for the&#010;various projects I jump between. I can then just open the whole set of&#010;projects from intellij in one go and as this is maven I can safely discard&#010;all the IDE's project info and have it regenerated from the pom and the&#010;pom's reactor.&#010;&#010;When I check a local aggregator into SCM I typically use the file based&#010;activation to add each module via a profile for that module... but usually&#010;I just keep them local only&#010;&#010;&#010;On 7 January 2014 13:25, Patrick Turcotte &lt;patrek@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We are doing something similar with what I call an assembly project.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I have the following structure:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; assembly&#010;&gt;   - pom.xml&#010;&gt;   - projectA&#010;&gt;     - pom.xml&#010;&gt;   - projectB&#010;&gt;     - pom.xml&#010;&gt;   - projectC&#010;&gt;     - pom.xml&#010;&gt;   - projectX&#010;&gt;     - pom.xml&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Where the assembly's pom.xml contains like:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;packaging&gt;pom&lt;/packaging&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;modules&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;module&gt;projectA&lt;/module&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;module&gt;projectB&lt;/module&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;module&gt;projectC&lt;/module&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;module&gt;projectX&lt;/module&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;/modules&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; And dependencies between projects are set within each module (versions may&#010;&gt; be in a parent pom)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Then, in my "assembly" project, I do&#010;&gt; mvn install&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Or, with multiple windows open, I would do a mvn install for projectA and&#010;&gt; then switch to projectX and build it.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Hope this helps.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Patrick&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 07/01/14 12:49 AM, Barrie Treloar wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 7 January 2014 15:29, Mark Derricutt &lt;mark@talios.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; When the project is relatively new and the internally-developed&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; dependency&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "A" is no where near being mature, nearly every change being made to&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "Project X" requires a corresponding change to A. At this point in the&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; development cycle (and for many months in the foreseeable future) I&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; actually&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; /do/ need to rebuild A every time I build X.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; What I've often done here is create a new workspace area that contains&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; symlinks ( or git submodule checkouts ) of each of the modules I'm working&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; on, and having a simple pom.xml in the top level that sets up a reactor&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; build, then just build that.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; There was also some talk about automating this step.&#010;&gt;&gt; But its vapourware at the moment.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; It would work by checking your current pom for any -SNAPSHOT&#010;&gt;&gt; dependencies and then pulling out the source code for those and&#010;&gt;&gt; sitting them in the parent directory.&#010;&gt;&gt; And as you say the parent pom is just a helper that has a bunch of&#010;&gt;&gt; modules to make building things easier - and you would never check&#010;&gt;&gt; that pom into version control.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Simone Tripodi &lt;simonetrip...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-clarifications on ArtifactRepository#find(Artifact) and ArtifactRepository#findVersions(Artifact)
contents:- Hi all mates,&#010;&#010;I am having some troubles about how the methods in subject should behave,&#010;due to the not exhaustive javadoc: given the artifact&#010;&#010;com.acme:mycomponent:1.0&#010;&#010;when invoking ArtifactRepository#find(Artifact) it always return an&#010;artifact, even if it doesn';t exist in the target repo; given the artifact&#010;&#010;com.acme:mycomponent&#010;&#010;when invoking ArtifactRepository#findVersions(Artifact) it always return an&#010;empty list, even if there are versions deployed o the target repo.&#010;&#010;Can you please explain me which is the right way to check if an artifact&#010;exists on a repo?&#010;&#010;Many thanks in advance and happy new year!&#010;-Simo&#010;&#010;http://people.apache.org/~simonetripodi/&#010;http://twitter.com/simonetripodi&#010;&#010;

Name  :- &quot;S. Ali Tokmen&quot; &lt;nos...@alishomepage.com&gt;
Subject  :-Maven2/Maven3 plugin development: Ensuring only the available parameters are allowed
contents:- Dear Maven users&#010;&#010;I am one of the owners of Codehaus CARGO, which has a Maven2/Maven3&#010;plugin; and would have a question with regards to how parameters are&#010;managed.&#010;&#010;We defined our MOJOs with parameters (you can see&#010;http://svn.codehaus.org/cargo/extensions/trunk/maven2/plugin/src/main/java/org/codehaus/cargo/maven2/AbstractCargoMojo.java&#010;for example), but what happens is that if a user unwillingly puts a&#010;parameter in the wrong place then the plugin execution doesn't stop.&#010;&#010;As an example, I can write the below POM and build still works (even&#010;thought the MOJO has no parameter called "foo"):&#010;&#010;  &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;    &lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.cargo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;    &lt;artifactId&gt;cargo-maven2-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;    &lt;version&gt;1.4.6&lt;/version&gt;&#010;    &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;      &lt;foo&gt;&#010;        bar&#010;      &lt;/foo&gt;&#010;    &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;  &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;Is there any way I can instruct by MOJO to fail if there is an unknown&#010;parameter?&#010;&#010;Please advise&#010;&#010;Thank you&#010;&#010;-- &#010;&#010;S. Ali Tokmen&#010;http://ali.tokmen.com/&#010;&#010;My IM, GSM, PGP and other contact details&#010;are on http://contact.ali.tokmen.com&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Anders Hammar &lt;and...@hammar.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven2/Maven3 plugin development: Ensuring only the available parameters are allowed
contents:- AFAIK there is no support for this. If you think there should be, please&#010;file a ticket [1].&#010;&#010;/Anders&#010;&#010;[1] http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MNG/&#010;&#010;&#010;On Tue, Jan 7, 2014 at 7:38 PM, S. Ali Tokmen &lt;nospam@alishomepage.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Dear Maven users&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I am one of the owners of Codehaus CARGO, which has a Maven2/Maven3&#010;&gt; plugin; and would have a question with regards to how parameters are&#010;&gt; managed.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We defined our MOJOs with parameters (you can see&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://svn.codehaus.org/cargo/extensions/trunk/maven2/plugin/src/main/java/org/codehaus/cargo/maven2/AbstractCargoMojo.java&#010;&gt; for example), but what happens is that if a user unwillingly puts a&#010;&gt; parameter in the wrong place then the plugin execution doesn't stop.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; As an example, I can write the below POM and build still works (even&#010;&gt; thought the MOJO has no parameter called "foo"):&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.cargo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;artifactId&gt;cargo-maven2-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;version&gt;1.4.6&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;foo&gt;&#010;&gt;         bar&#010;&gt;       &lt;/foo&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is there any way I can instruct by MOJO to fail if there is an unknown&#010;&gt; parameter?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Please advise&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thank you&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; S. Ali Tokmen&#010;&gt; http://ali.tokmen.com/&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My IM, GSM, PGP and other contact details&#010;&gt; are on http://contact.ali.tokmen.com&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Ali Tokmen &lt;nospam@alishomepage.com&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Dear Maven users&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I am one of the owners of Codehaus CARGO, which has a Maven2/Maven3&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; plugin; and would have a question with regards to how parameters are&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; managed.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; We defined our MOJOs with parameters (you can see&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; http://svn.codehaus.org/cargo/extensions/trunk/maven2/plugin/src/main/java/org/codehaus/cargo/maven2/AbstractCargoMojo.java&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; for example), but what happens is that if a user unwillingly puts a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; parameter in the wrong place then the plugin execution doesn't stop.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; As an example, I can write the below POM and build still works (even&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; thought the MOJO has no parameter called "foo"):&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;   &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     &lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.cargo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     &lt;artifactId&gt;cargo-maven2-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     &lt;version&gt;1.4.6&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;       &lt;foo&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         bar&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;       &lt;/foo&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;   &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Is there any way I can instruct by MOJO to fail if there is an unknown&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; parameter?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Please advise&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thank you&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; --&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; S. I am one of the owners of Codehaus CARGO, which has a Maven2/Maven3&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; plugin; and would have a question with regards to how parameters&#010;are&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; managed.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; We defined our MOJOs with parameters (you can see&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; parameter in the wrong place then the plugin execution doesn't&#010;stop.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; As an example, I can write the below POM and build still works&#010;(even&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; thought the MOJO has no parameter called "foo"):&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;   &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     &lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.cargo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     &lt;artifactId&gt;cargo-maven2-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     &lt;version&gt;1.4.6&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;       &lt;foo&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         bar&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;       &lt;/foo&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;   &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Is there any way I can instruct by MOJO to fail if there is&#010;an&#010;&gt; unknown&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; parameter?&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Please advise&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thank you&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; --&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; S. Ali Tokmen&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; http://ali.tokmen.com/&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; My IM, GSM, PGP and other contact details&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; are on http://contact.ali.tokmen.com&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; --&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Baptiste &lt;Batmat&gt; MATHUS - http://batmat.net&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Sauvez un arbre,&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Mangez un castor ! nbsp;! &lt;users-help@maven.apache.org&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven2/Maven3 plugin development: Ensuring only the available parameters are allowed
contents:- There are valid reasons why a configuration having "invalid" elements may&#010;be "valid".&#010;&#010;Consider the case where&#010;xpath:/project/build/pluginManagement/plugins/plugin/version specifies the&#010;*default* version and xpath:/project/build/plugins/plugin/version is&#010;absent... In this case xpath:/project/build/plugins/plugin/configuration&#010;applies to any version of the plugin, so somebody invoking a specific&#010;version of the plugin directly would/should get that configuration... Thus&#010;an element that does not make sense to the executing version of the plugin&#010;*may* make sense to a future/older version if the plugin... Hence failing&#010;because of unknown parameters would be a "bad thing"&#010;&#010;You could request the dom node yourself and parse it by hand if you want to&#010;issue warning though&#010;&#010;On Tuesday, 7 January 2014, S. Ali Tokmen wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Dear Maven users&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I am one of the owners of Codehaus CARGO, which has a Maven2/Maven3&#010;&gt; plugin; and would have a question with regards to how parameters are&#010;&gt; managed.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We defined our MOJOs with parameters (you can see&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://svn.codehaus.org/cargo/extensions/trunk/maven2/plugin/src/main/java/org/codehaus/cargo/maven2/AbstractCargoMojo.java&#010;&gt; for example), but what happens is that if a user unwillingly puts a&#010;&gt; parameter in the wrong place then the plugin execution doesn't stop.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; As an example, I can write the below POM and build still works (even&#010;&gt; thought the MOJO has no parameter called "foo"):&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.cargo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;artifactId&gt;cargo-maven2-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;version&gt;1.4.6&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;foo&gt;&#010;&gt;         bar&#010;&gt;       &lt;/foo&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is there any way I can instruct by MOJO to fail if there is an unknown&#010;&gt; parameter?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Please advise&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thank you&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; S. Ali Tokmen&#010;&gt; http://ali.tokmen.com/&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My IM, GSM, PGP and other contact details&#010;&gt; are on http://contact.ali.tokmen.com&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org &lt;javascript:;&gt;&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&lt;javascript:;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Sent from my phone&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Thomas Broyer &lt;t.bro...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven2/Maven3 plugin development: Ensuring only the available parameters are allowed
contents:- Isn't that simply because the &lt;configuration&gt; is shared by all goals? (or&#010;all goals of the parent &lt;execution&gt;)&#010;&#010;&#010;On Tue, Jan 7, 2014 at 7:38 PM, S. Ali Tokmen &lt;nospam@alishomepage.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Dear Maven users&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I am one of the owners of Codehaus CARGO, which has a Maven2/Maven3&#010;&gt; plugin; and would have a question with regards to how parameters are&#010;&gt; managed.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We defined our MOJOs with parameters (you can see&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://svn.codehaus.org/cargo/extensions/trunk/maven2/plugin/src/main/java/org/codehaus/cargo/maven2/AbstractCargoMojo.java&#010;&gt; for example), but what happens is that if a user unwillingly puts a&#010;&gt; parameter in the wrong place then the plugin execution doesn't stop.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; As an example, I can write the below POM and build still works (even&#010;&gt; thought the MOJO has no parameter called "foo"):&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.cargo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;artifactId&gt;cargo-maven2-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;version&gt;1.4.6&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;foo&gt;&#010;&gt;         bar&#010;&gt;       &lt;/foo&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is there any way I can instruct by MOJO to fail if there is an unknown&#010;&gt; parameter?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Please advise&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thank you&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; S. Ali Tokmen&#010;&gt; http://ali.tokmen.com/&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My IM, GSM, PGP and other contact details&#010;&gt; are on http://contact.ali.tokmen.com&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Thomas Broyer&#010;/tɔ.ma.bʁwa.je/ &lt;http://xn--nna.ma.xn--bwa-xxb.je/&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- juliangeo &lt;julianhernand...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: DefaultProjectBuilder ... mavenTools: null [Was: Re: Programmatically get maven properties]
contents:- Hi! &#010;&#010;I'm new to Maven and I've been struggling with this for a while. I just need&#010;to be able to programmatically build a project from a pom file in order to&#010;retrieve its relevant information. I am not using, nor want to, a maven&#010;plugin, just need this functionality as part of my application.&#010;&#010;I've tried the code you successfully got to work but no luck so far. I still&#010;get the "mavenTools: null" from the repositoryManager being null. Am I&#010;missing something? Should I run this on some kind of special environment?&#010;&#010;I'd appreciate any help as I'm really lost here.&#010;&#010;Thanks in advance.&#010;&#010;&#010;Max Spring wrote&#010;&gt; Yes, having a projectBuilder in the Mojo did the trick.&#010;&gt; Thank you!&#010;&gt; The complete working example is down below.&#010;&gt; -Max&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; package org.example;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; import java.io.File;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.model.Model;&#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.model.building.ModelBuildingRequest;&#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.plugin.AbstractMojo;&#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.plugin.MojoExecutionException;&#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.project.DefaultProjectBuildingRequest;&#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.project.MavenProject;&#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.project.ProjectBuilder;&#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.project.ProjectBuildingResult;&#010;&gt; import org.sonatype.aether.RepositorySystemSession;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; /**&#010;&gt;   * run with: mvn $groupId:$artifactId:$version:fetch-pom&#010;&gt; -DpomFile=$pomFile&#010;&gt;   *&#010;&gt;   * @goal fetch-pom&#010;&gt;   */&#010;&gt; public class FetchModelMojo extends AbstractMojo{&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;    /**&#010;&gt;     * Current repository/network configuration of Maven.&#010;&gt;     * @parameter default-value="${repositorySystemSession}"&#010;&gt;     * @readonly&#010;&gt;     */&#010;&gt;    private RepositorySystemSession repoSession;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;    /**&#010;&gt;     * @component&#010;&gt;     */&#010;&gt;    private ProjectBuilder projectBuilder;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;    /**&#010;&gt;     * @parameter expression="${pomFile}" default-value=""&#010;&gt;     */&#010;&gt;    private String pomFile;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;    public void execute() throws MojoExecutionException {&#010;&gt;      try {&#010;&gt;        DefaultProjectBuildingRequest req = new&#010;&gt; DefaultProjectBuildingRequest();&#010;&gt;        req.setRepositorySession(repoSession);&#010;&gt;       &#010;&gt; req.setValidationLevel(ModelBuildingRequest.VALIDATION_LEVEL_STRICT);&#010;&gt;        ProjectBuildingResult res = projectBuilder.build(new&#010;&gt; File(pomFile),req);&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;        // do something with the project&#010;&gt;        MavenProject prj = res.getProject();&#010;&gt;        System.out.println("prj=" + prj);&#010;&gt;        Model model = prj.getModel();&#010;&gt;        System.out.println("id="+model.getId());&#010;&gt;      } catch (Exception e) {&#010;&gt;        throw new MojoExecutionException(e.getMessage(), e);&#010;&gt;      }&#010;&gt;    }&#010;&gt; }&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; On 02/10/2012 01:19 PM, Olivier Lamy wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; Hello,&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; You must probably use:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;      /**&#010;&gt;&gt;       * @component&#010;&gt;&gt;       */&#010;&gt;&gt;      private ProjectBuilder projectBuilder;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 2012/2/10 Max Spring&amp;lt;&#010;&#010;&gt; m2spring@&#010;&#010;&gt; &amp;gt;:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm running into the same "mavenTools: null" problem, but my code sits&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; in a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven 3.0.3 mojo:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;   public class MyMojo extends AbstractMojo{&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     /** @parameter default-value="${repositorySystemSession}" */&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     private RepositorySystemSession repoSession;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     public void execute() throws MojoExecutionException{&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;       DefaultProjectBuilder builder = new DefaultProjectBuilder();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;       DefaultProjectBuildingRequest req = new&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; DefaultProjectBuildingRequest();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;       req.setRepositorySession(repoSession);&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;       builder.build(new File("my-pom.xml"),req);&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;       MavenProject prj = req.getProject();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;       Model model = prj.getModel();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     }&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;   }&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; It barfs with&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;   Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: mavenTools: null&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     at org.apache.maven.project.MavenProject.&#010;&gt; &lt;init&gt;&#010;&gt; (MavenProject.java:249)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     at&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; org.apache.maven.project.DefaultProjectBuilder.build(DefaultProjectBuilder.java:128)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     at&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; org.apache.maven.project.DefaultProjectBuilder.build(DefaultProjectBuilder.java:102)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     at MyMojo.execute(MyMojo.java:59)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; This is because repositorySystem in DefaultProjectBuilder is null, i.e.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; hasn't been injected:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     @Requirement&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     private RepositorySystem repositorySystem;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; How can I get the right repositorySystem injected?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Context:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm essentially trying to do the M2E "Import Project" use case, but&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; completely outside of Eclipse.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I want to populate a workspace using the SCM pointer given by a POM&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; fetched&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; from the group repository.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; -Max&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 10/18/2011 04:59 AM, Barrie Treloar wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On Tue, Oct 18, 2011 at 10:02 PM, deusaquilus&amp;lt;&#010;&#010;&gt; deusaquilus@&#010;&#010;&gt; &amp;gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;   wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Here's what I'm doing:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; File pom = new File("pom.xml");&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; DefaultProjectBuildingRequest request = new&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; DefaultProjectBuildingRequest();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; DefaultProjectBuilder builder = new DefaultProjectBuilder();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; String mavenHome = System.getenv("M2_HOME");&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ArtifactRepository localRepository = new MavenArtifactRepository(&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         "local",&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         new File(mavenHome +&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "/repository").toURI().toURL().toString(),&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         new DefaultRepositoryLayout(),&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         new ArtifactRepositoryPolicy(),&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         new ArtifactRepositoryPolicy());&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; request.setLocalRepository(localRepository);&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; MavenProject project = builder.build(pom, request).getProject();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Properties properties = project.getProperties();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Trouble is it's giving me errors with "mavenTools: null"&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'd be surprised if that worked.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven makes heavy use of dependency injection via Plexus and chances&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; are you haven't set up some component that is being used.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; What is your actual use case.  I dont see why you would want to expose&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven properties as a Java properties object...&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Programmatically-get-maven-properties-tp4912280p5780906.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

       System.out.println("prj=" + prj);&#010;&gt;        Model model = prj.getModel();&#010;&gt;        System.out.println("id="+model.getId());&#010;&gt;      } catch (Exception e) {&#010;&gt;        throw new MojoExecutionException(e.getMessage(), e);&#010;&gt; I'd be surprised if that worked.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven makes heavy use of dependency injection via Plexus and chances&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; are you haven't set up some component that is being used.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; What is your actual use case.  I dont see why you would want to expose&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven properties as a Java properties object...&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Programmatically-get-maven-properties-tp4912280p5780906.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: DefaultProjectBuilder ... mavenTools: null [Was: Re: Programmatically get maven properties]
contents:- On 8 January 2014 09:00, juliangeo &lt;julianhernandeze@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Hi!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'm new to Maven and I've been struggling with this for a while. I just need&#010;&gt; to be able to programmatically build a project from a pom file in order to&#010;&gt; retrieve its relevant information. I am not using, nor want to, a maven&#010;&gt; plugin, just need this functionality as part of my application.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I've tried the code you successfully got to work but no luck so far. I still&#010;&gt; get the "mavenTools: null" from the repositoryManager being null. Am I&#010;&gt; missing something? Should I run this on some kind of special environment?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'd appreciate any help as I'm really lost here.&#010;[del]&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'd be surprised if that worked.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven makes heavy use of dependency injection via Plexus and chances&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; are you haven't set up some component that is being used.&#010;&#010;Your answer is already here.&#010;&#010;You just can't use the classes outside of the Maven environment&#010;without also setting up all the other dependencies that are needed by&#010;that class.&#010;And as noted, this is done by Dependency Injection (via Plexus).&#010;You will need to look at MavenArtifactRepository and see what other&#010;objects need to be instantiated and set into it for it to work&#010;properly.&#010;&#010;Your use case is not something others are really trying to do, so you&#010;are unlikely to find someone with the knowledge to help.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- andre999 &lt;andre...@hotmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Maven install phase - Access is denied
contents:- Hi all,&#010;&#010;I have a project which maven generates the following output in the target&#010;folder;&#010;&lt;drive&gt;\projects\mywork\trunk\target\&lt;projectname&gt;.jar&#010;&lt;drive&gt;\projects\mywork\trunk\target\&lt;projectname&gt;-sources.jar&#010;&lt;drive&gt;\projects\mywork\trunk\target\installer\folder&#010;&#010;The above installer\folder is basically an empty folder which contains&#010;subfolders to be part of installer.&#010;&#010;&#010;I have a Build Error that displays "/Error installing artifact:&#010;&lt;drive&gt;\projects\mywork\trunk\target\installer\folder (Access is denied)/"&#010;when executing *mvn clean install*.&#010; &#010;The maven copies the &lt;drive&gt;\projects\mywork\trunk\target\&lt;projectname&gt;.jar, &#010;&#010;&lt;drive&gt;\projects\mywork\trunk\target\&lt;projectname&gt;-sources.jar into local&#010;repository with success. However the maven attempts to copy the &#010;&lt;drive&gt;\projects\mywork\trunk\target\installer\folder into the local&#010;repository which is not I want to. This cause maven to throw the Build&#010;Error.&#010;&#010;How do I prevent maven copying the empty folder into local/remote repository&#010;as an artifact?&#010;&#010;Thanks,&#010;Andrew&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Maven-install-phase-Access-is-denied-tp5780920.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven install phase - Access is denied
contents:- On 9 January 2014 06:56, andre999 &lt;andre999@hotmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &lt;build&gt;&#010;[del]&#010;&gt;                         &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;                                 &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-install-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;version&gt;2.5.1&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;                                 &lt;file&gt;certloader-custom-action.jar&lt;/file&gt;&#010;&gt;                                 &lt;file&gt;certloader-custom-action-sources.jar&lt;/file&gt;&#010;&#010;What do you expect this section to do?&#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-install-plugin/install-mojo.html&#010;does not have a file property.&#010;And file implies a single entry, specifying it a second time would&#010;mean you overwrite the previous value.&#010;Lists are normally plural. (something like&#010;&lt;files&gt;&lt;file&gt;A&lt;/file&gt;&lt;file&gt;B&lt;/file&gt;&lt;/files&gt;&#010;&#010;If you want the sources to also be installed use the source plugin&#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-source-plugin/&#010;&#010;You shouldn't need this section on install at all.&#010;&#010;I can't see anything in that pom that would mean a directory is being&#010;installed into your local m2 cache.&#010;&#010;The assembly plugin can have these types of issues when you specify&#010;"dir" as a distribution format on deploy.&#010;But deploy is after install so this is not the problem.&#010;&#010;The problem I have is that it is trying to install&#010;P:\Projects\HlkProjects\CertLoader\hlk-certloader\trunk\target\install4j\certImport&#010;to&#010;P:\.m2\repository\net\healthlink\certloader\hlk-certloader\1.0.2-SNAPSHOT\lk-certloader-1.0.2-SNAPSHOT-certImport&#010;&#010;Why is maven attaching \target\install4j\certImport as a build&#010;artifact that it thinks it needs to install.&#010;&#010;Try running mvn -X and redirect the output to a file.&#010;Then search for target\install4j\certImport and see which plugin is&#010;being configured with this value.&#010;That might give you a hint as to where to look to turn that off.&#010;I'd almost suspect the parent pom.&#010;Using resources:copy-resource does not attach anything to be installed&#010;and it is the only thing that is using target\install4j\certImport&#010;from your supplied output.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- andre999 &lt;andre...@hotmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven install phase - Access is denied
contents:- Thanks for the input. Apologies for the goose chase. I have found that there&#010;is an element &lt;attach&gt;true&lt;/attach&gt; property in the&#010;&lt;artifactId&gt;maven-install4j-plugin&lt;artifactId&gt;, which I did not include in&#010;this thread.&#010;&#010;With the &lt;attach&gt; set to false, the maven install has stopped reading any&#010;resources from the "install4j/certImport" folder, and copying resource into&#010;repository. &#010;&#010;Thanks again.&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Maven-install-phase-Access-is-denied-tp5780920p5781054.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

contents:- Le 8 janv. 2014 20:39, "andre999" &lt;andre999@hotmail.com&gt; a écrit :&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Caused by: java.io.FileNotFoundException:&#010;&gt;&#010;P:\Projects\HlkProjects\CertLoader\hlk-certloader\trunk\target\install4j\certImport&#010;&gt; (Access is denied)&#010;&gt;         at java.io.FileInputStream.open(Native Method)&#010;&#010;Isn't the problem that you're trying to install a directory rather than a&#010;file? Name  :- thorsten.h...@vkb.de
Subject  :-Re: release-plugin non-interactive release and system properties
contents:- Hi Steve,&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;&gt; I’m confused as to how the version number in a pom file and the &#013;&#010;&gt; system properties like -DdevelopmentVersion=2.0-SNAPSHOT and -&#013;&#010;&gt; DreleaseVersion=1.2&#013;&#010;&gt; interact.&#013;&#010;&gt; When I run a mvn –B release:prepare –DdryRun=true –Dtag=1.2 -&#013;&#010;&gt; DdevelopmentVersion=2.0-SNAPSHOT -DreleaseVersion=1.2 for a pom.xml &#013;&#010;&gt; where &lt;version&gt;1.0&lt;/version&gt; and &lt;packaging&gt;jar&lt;/packaging&gt; the&#010;&#013;&#010;&gt; resulting jar file uses the pom version number not the command line &#013;&#010;&gt; version, i.e xxx-1.0.jar . Is this expected behaviour and if so what&#013;&#010;&gt; is the point of specifying the versions on the command line ?&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;AFAIK this will only work when you have a snapshot version in your pom, &#013;&#010;i.e. &lt;version&gt;1.0-SNAPSHOT&lt;/version&gt;.&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;Regards&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;Thorsten&#013;&#010;

Name  :- &quot;Omar@Gmail&quot; &lt;omarnet...@googlemail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Depend on a jar via another pom file
contents:- I have a maven module (lets call it M) that requires aspectjrt but M&#010;already depends on another pom file that has aspectjrt within its&#010;dependency tree  like so:&#010;&#010;M -&gt;  middle pom -&gt; aspectjrt&#010;&#010;The problem is M would not compile unless I express the aspectjrt&#010;dependency directly in the M pom file, why?&#010;&#010;Is there a way for M to get apsectjrt via the middle pom without directly&#010;depending on aspectjrt?&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Nick Stolwijk &lt;nick.stolw...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Depend on a jar via another pom file
contents:- That's called a transitive dependency and this blog[1] explains nicely why&#010;you shouldn't use those.&#010;&#010;[1] http://uglycoder.blogspot.nl/2008/04/flaw-with-mavens-transitive.html&#010;&#010;Hth,&#010;&#010;Nick Stolwijk&#010;&#010;~~~ Try to leave this world a little better than you found it and, when&#010;your turn comes to die, you can die happy in feeling that at any rate you&#010;have not wasted your time but have done your best ~~~&#010;&#010;Lord Baden-Powell&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Jan 8, 2014 at 4:56 PM, Omar@Gmail &lt;omarnetbox@googlemail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I have a maven module (lets call it M) that requires aspectjrt but M&#010;&gt; already depends on another pom file that has aspectjrt within its&#010;&gt; dependency tree  like so:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; M -&gt;  middle pom -&gt; aspectjrt&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The problem is M would not compile unless I express the aspectjrt&#010;&gt; dependency directly in the M pom file, why?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is there a way for M to get apsectjrt via the middle pom without directly&#010;&gt; depending on aspectjrt?&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Baptiste Mathus &lt;bmat...@batmat.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Depend on a jar via another pom file
contents:- Well, what "scope" are used here? Thus is a central element to manage&#010;transitivity.&#010;&#010;Btw, you should never rely on a dependency to get a dependency you're also&#010;using. You must redeclare it in your own pom. (mvn dependency:analyze can&#010;also help you here).&#010;&#010;Cheers&#010;Le 8 janv. 2014 16:59, "Omar@Gmail" &lt;omarnetbox@googlemail.com&gt; a écrit :&#010;&#010;&gt; I have a maven module (lets call it M) that requires aspectjrt but M&#010;&gt; already depends on another pom file that has aspectjrt within its&#010;&gt; dependency tree  like so:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; M -&gt;  middle pom -&gt; aspectjrt&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The problem is M would not compile unless I express the aspectjrt&#010;&gt; dependency directly in the M pom file, why?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is there a way for M to get apsectjrt via the middle pom without directly&#010;&gt; depending on aspectjrt?&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Laird Nelson &lt;ljnel...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-During plugin development, what is the context classloader set to?
contents:- I have a plugin that I'm writing that needs to do two things during the&#010;course of its execution:&#010;Load a resource from the current project's classpath&#010;Load a resource from its own guts&#010;&#010;This is a fallback kind of thing: if the plugin can't find anything&#010;appropriate on the project classpath, then and only then do I want it to&#010;examine its own .jar file for the resource in question.&#010;&#010;My hunch is that there are probably already two classloaders set up for&#010;just this purpose.&#010;&#010;I am guessing (haven't tried yet) that the project classpath is probably&#010;visible to Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader().  Is that right?&#010;&#010;I'm also guessing (haven't tried yet) that from within my mojo&#010;this.getClass().getClassLoader() will return me a ClassLoader that is set&#010;up to be able to see my mojo's innards.  Is that right?&#010;&#010;Best,&#010;Laird&#010;&#010;-- &#010;http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Baptiste Mathus ...@batmat.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: During plugin development, what is the context classloader set to?
contents:- Hi,&#010;ClassWorlds is your friend if you need to do classloader fine-tuning.&#010;&#010;For example (taken in an old poc, so this should be adapted to use&#010;annotations etc.), something along the following would create a classpath&#010;with test scope elements.&#010;&#010;...&#010;public class SomeMojo extends AbstractMojo&#010;{&#010;        /**&#010;         * @parameter expression="${project.testClasspathElements}"&#010;         */&#010;        private&#010;List&lt;http://www.google.com/search?sitesearch=java.sun.com&amp;q=allinurl%3Aj2se%2F1+5+0%2Fdocs%2Fapi+List&gt;&#010;&lt;String &lt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/lang/String.html&gt;&gt;&#010; testProjectArtifacts;&#010;...&#010;        protected&#010;ClassLoader&lt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/lang/ClassLoader.html&gt;&#010; getClassLoader()&#010;        {&#010;                try&#010;                {&#010;                        ClassWorld world = new ClassWorld();&#010;                        ClassRealm realm = world.newRealm("project");&#010;                        for&#010;(String&lt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/lang/String.html&gt;&#010;artifact&#010;: testProjectArtifacts)&#010;                        {&#010;                                getLog().debug("Constituent : " + artifact);&#010;                                realm.addConstituent(new&#010;File&lt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/io/File.html&gt;&#010;(artifact).toURL());&#010;                        }&#010;                        return realm.getClassLoader();&#010;                }&#010;                catch&#010;(Exception&lt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/lang/Exception.html&gt;&#010; e)&#010;                {&#010;                        throw new&#010;RuntimeException&lt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/lang/RuntimeException.html&gt;&#010;("WTF", e);&#010;                }&#010;        }&#010;&#010;HTH&#010;&#010;&#010;2014/1/8 Laird Nelson &lt;ljnelson@gmail.com&gt;&#010;&#010;&gt; I have a plugin that I'm writing that needs to do two things during the&#010;&gt; course of its execution:&#010;&gt; Load a resource from the current project's classpath&#010;&gt; Load a resource from its own guts&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; This is a fallback kind of thing: if the plugin can't find anything&#010;&gt; appropriate on the project classpath, then and only then do I want it to&#010;&gt; examine its own .jar file for the resource in question.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My hunch is that there are probably already two classloaders set up for&#010;&gt; just this purpose.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I am guessing (haven't tried yet) that the project classpath is probably&#010;&gt; visible to Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader().  Is that right?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'm also guessing (haven't tried yet) that from within my mojo&#010;&gt; this.getClass().getClassLoader() will return me a ClassLoader that is set&#010;&gt; up to be able to see my mojo's innards.  Is that right?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Best,&#010;&gt; Laird&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Baptiste &lt;Batmat&gt; MATHUS - http://batmat.net&#010;&gt; Sauvez un arbre,&#010;&gt; Mangez un castor ! nbsp;! &lt;http://about.me/lairdnelson&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Todd Chapman &lt;t...@chaka.net&gt;
Subject  :-Need advice automating a Java test suite.
contents:- Hello,&#010;&#010;We have a java multi-module project that has a somewhat painful to run test&#010;suite that I would like to get under control using Maven.&#010;&#010;Currently it takes 5 separate Maven commands to setup, run, and teardown&#010;all the tests and test databases. I'd like to get this down to one command.&#010;Also I would like this structured so that individual parts of the process&#010;can be run separately to aid in debugging problems.&#010;&#010;The pom has 1 profile for each part of the task, all bound to the "test"&#010;goal:&#010;&#010;mvn clean test -P test-setup-1,local-enterprise-test-db  (exec:java plugin&#010;to setup up a database)&#010;mvn test -P test-setup-2,local-enterprise-test-db           (exec:java&#010;plugin to setup up a 2nd database)&#010;mvn test -P test-design,local-enterprise-test-db            (surefire&#010;plugin to run a subset of the tests with maven properties set)&#010;mvn test -P test-transactional,local-enterprise-test-db   (surefire plugin&#010;to run a different subset of the tests with different maven properties set)&#010;mvn test -P test-tear-down,local-enterprise-test-db        (exec:java&#010;plugin to teardown the databases)&#010;&#010;&#010;The problem I am running into is how to get this organized so that it all&#010;happens with 1 command. It seems nearly unpossible.&#010;&#010;Can anyone offer any advice on how to accomplish this? Pointer to relevant&#010;articles, blog posts, stackoverflow questions would be most appreciated.&#010;&#010;Thanks!&#010;&#010;-Todd&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Need advice automating a Java test suite.
contents:- Profiles are the path to madness.&#010;&#010;There are two ways I can see to tackle this:&#010;&#010;1. Use the invoker plugin to fork maven builds for each of your test steps&#010;&#010;Or&#010;&#010;2. Use a multi-module project so that the separate modules do the separate&#010;parts.&#010;&#010;The second is likely the more "maven way" but the 1st is not too far off,&#010;if done right, and probably the easiest to implement... Not too hard to&#010;refactor to #2 if you decide to later&#010;&#010;On Wednesday, 8 January 2014, Todd Chapman wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hello,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We have a java multi-module project that has a somewhat painful to run test&#010;&gt; suite that I would like to get under control using Maven.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Currently it takes 5 separate Maven commands to setup, run, and teardown&#010;&gt; all the tests and test databases. I'd like to get this down to one command.&#010;&gt; Also I would like this structured so that individual parts of the process&#010;&gt; can be run separately to aid in debugging problems.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The pom has 1 profile for each part of the task, all bound to the "test"&#010;&gt; goal:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; mvn clean test -P test-setup-1,local-enterprise-test-db  (exec:java plugin&#010;&gt; to setup up a database)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-setup-2,local-enterprise-test-db           (exec:java&#010;&gt; plugin to setup up a 2nd database)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-design,local-enterprise-test-db            (surefire&#010;&gt; plugin to run a subset of the tests with maven properties set)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-transactional,local-enterprise-test-db   (surefire plugin&#010;&gt; to run a different subset of the tests with different maven properties set)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-tear-down,local-enterprise-test-db        (exec:java&#010;&gt; plugin to teardown the databases)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The problem I am running into is how to get this organized so that it all&#010;&gt; happens with 1 command. It seems nearly unpossible.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Can anyone offer any advice on how to accomplish this? Pointer to relevant&#010;&gt; articles, blog posts, stackoverflow questions would be most appreciated.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -Todd&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Sent from my phone&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Martin Gainty &lt;mgai...@hotmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-RE: Need advice automating a Java test suite.
contents:- &#010;&#010;  &#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; Date: Wed, 8 Jan 2014 17:08:53 -0500&#010;&gt; Subject: Need advice automating a Java test suite.&#010;&gt; From: todd@chaka.net&#010;&gt; To: users@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Hello,&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; We have a java multi-module project that has a somewhat painful to run test&#010;&gt; suite that I would like to get under control using Maven.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Currently it takes 5 separate Maven commands to setup, run, and teardown&#010;&gt; all the tests and test databases. I'd like to get this down to one command.&#010;&gt; Also I would like this structured so that individual parts of the process&#010;&gt; can be run separately to aid in debugging problems.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; The pom has 1 profile for each part of the task, all bound to the "test"&#010;&gt; goal:&#010;MG&gt;My initial thought was to bind each profile-group to different phases&#010;MG&gt;that way the reactor will govern the execution order of who gets executed first (mvn&#010;initialize),&#010;MG&gt;which profile gets executed second (mvn generate-test-sources) &#010;MG&gt;and finally last profile gets executed (mvn package)&#010;MG&gt;the problem is you have alot of testcases to run so perhaps running a string of profiles&#010;maybe the answer&#010; &#010;MG&gt;Profile1&#010;&gt; mvn clean test -P test-setup-1,local-enterprise-test-db (exec:java plugin&#010;&gt; to setup up a database)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-setup-2,local-enterprise-test-db (exec:java&#010;&gt; plugin to setup up a 2nd database)&#010;MG&gt;Profile1&#010; &#010;MG&gt;Profile2&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-design,local-enterprise-test-db (surefire&#010;&gt; plugin to run a subset of the tests with maven properties set)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-transactional,local-enterprise-test-db (surefire plugin&#010;&gt; to run a different subset of the tests with different maven properties set)&#010;MG&gt;Profile2&#010;&#010;MG&gt;Profile3&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-tear-down,local-enterprise-test-db (exec:java&#010;&gt; plugin to teardown the databases)&#010;MG&gt;Profile3&#010; &#010;MG&gt;Off the top of my head i would setup a 'marker file' for the successful completion of&#010;each Profile&#010;MG&gt;When marker file from Profile1 exists trigger Profile 2 &#010;MG&gt;When marker file from Profile2 exists trigger Profile3&#010; &#010;MG&gt;mvn help:active-profiles -P Profile1,Profile2,Profile3 &#010;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; The problem I am running into is how to get this organized so that it all&#010;&gt; happens with 1 command. It seems nearly unpossible.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Can anyone offer any advice on how to accomplish this? Pointer to relevant&#010;&gt; articles, blog posts, stackoverflow questions would be most appreciated.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; -Todd&#010;MG&gt;assuming the IDentifiers are unique (and presence of marker files are unique) synchronous&#010;profile execution *should* work&#010; &#009;&#009; &#009;   &#009;&#009;  &#010;

Name  :- Anders Hammar &lt;and...@hammar.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Need advice automating a Java test suite.
contents:- It's little bit hard understanding all of the magic with your profiles and&#010;why you can''t combine them. But if I assume that you want to test your&#010;application with different configuration (different db, different&#010;configuration/properties, etc.) I suggest that you create a separate&#010;multi-module project for your testing. Each of the modules there would test&#010;ONE specific setup/config for the applicatation. You would bind the setup&#010;of the environment to the pre-integration-test phase and the tear down of&#010;the same to the post-integration-test phase. And then you use the&#010;maven-failsafe-plugin to execute all tests (for that app config) in the&#010;integration-test phase.&#010;&#010;If you have the same set of JUnit test classes to be used in all modules,&#010;you have these in a separate module which would create a test artifact that&#010;you re-use in the other modules. If you have a lot of the same pom config&#010;magics in the modules this can be moved to the pluginManagement section of&#010;the parent (more advanced Maven usage, do that last when everything already&#010;works).&#010;&#010;This will make it possible to build all modules for a complete test suite&#010;("mvn verify"). If you just want to test one setup/config you only build&#010;that module ("mvn verify").&#010;&#010;/Anders&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Jan 8, 2014 at 11:08 PM, Todd Chapman &lt;todd@chaka.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hello,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We have a java multi-module project that has a somewhat painful to run test&#010;&gt; suite that I would like to get under control using Maven.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Currently it takes 5 separate Maven commands to setup, run, and teardown&#010;&gt; all the tests and test databases. I'd like to get this down to one command.&#010;&gt; Also I would like this structured so that individual parts of the process&#010;&gt; can be run separately to aid in debugging problems.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The pom has 1 profile for each part of the task, all bound to the "test"&#010;&gt; goal:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; mvn clean test -P test-setup-1,local-enterprise-test-db  (exec:java plugin&#010;&gt; to setup up a database)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-setup-2,local-enterprise-test-db           (exec:java&#010;&gt; plugin to setup up a 2nd database)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-design,local-enterprise-test-db            (surefire&#010;&gt; plugin to run a subset of the tests with maven properties set)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-transactional,local-enterprise-test-db   (surefire plugin&#010;&gt; to run a different subset of the tests with different maven properties set)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-tear-down,local-enterprise-test-db        (exec:java&#010;&gt; plugin to teardown the databases)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The problem I am running into is how to get this organized so that it all&#010;&gt; happens with 1 command. It seems nearly unpossible.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Can anyone offer any advice on how to accomplish this? Pointer to relevant&#010;&gt; articles, blog posts, stackoverflow questions would be most appreciated.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -Todd&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Christofer Dutz &lt;christofer.d...@c-ware.de&gt;
Subject  :-AW: Need advice automating a Java test suite.
contents:- Hi Todd,&#010;&#010;we use a combination of the cargo, antrun and surefire plugin for this. &#010;&#010;I dumped the pom for one of our Projects in my Confluence, so feel free to have a look:&#010;https://dev.c-ware.de/confluence/display/PUBLIC/Maven+setup+for+Integrationtesting&#010;&#010;In general we use:&#010;- Cargo to install/configure/deploy/start/stop the application.&#010;- Antrun is used to Setup the Database with Default values.&#010;- Surefire is configured to run tests ending with "IT" after starting the Container and before&#010;stopping it again.&#010;&#010;Perhaps this helps.&#010;&#010;Chris&#010;&#010;________________________________________&#010;Von: Todd Chapman &lt;todd@chaka.net&gt;&#010;Gesendet: Mittwoch, 8. Januar 2014 23:08&#010;An: users@maven.apache.org&#010;Betreff: Need advice automating a Java test suite.&#010;&#010;Hello,&#010;&#010;We have a java multi-module project that has a somewhat painful to run test&#010;suite that I would like to get under control using Maven.&#010;&#010;Currently it takes 5 separate Maven commands to setup, run, and teardown&#010;all the tests and test databases. I'd like to get this down to one command.&#010;Also I would like this structured so that individual parts of the process&#010;can be run separately to aid in debugging problems.&#010;&#010;The pom has 1 profile for each part of the task, all bound to the "test"&#010;goal:&#010;&#010;mvn clean test -P test-setup-1,local-enterprise-test-db  (exec:java plugin&#010;to setup up a database)&#010;mvn test -P test-setup-2,local-enterprise-test-db           (exec:java&#010;plugin to setup up a 2nd database)&#010;mvn test -P test-design,local-enterprise-test-db            (surefire&#010;plugin to run a subset of the tests with maven properties set)&#010;mvn test -P test-transactional,local-enterprise-test-db   (surefire plugin&#010;to run a different subset of the tests with different maven properties set)&#010;mvn test -P test-tear-down,local-enterprise-test-db        (exec:java&#010;plugin to teardown the databases)&#010;&#010;&#010;The problem I am running into is how to get this organized so that it all&#010;happens with 1 command. It seems nearly unpossible.&#010;&#010;Can anyone offer any advice on how to accomplish this? Pointer to relevant&#010;articles, blog posts, stackoverflow questions would be most appreciated.&#010;&#010;Thanks!&#010;&#010;-Todd&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Paul Benedict &lt;pbened...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Skip copying resources
contents:- Your problem is that, I think, you attached the execution to the "compile"&#010;phase. However, the "process-resources" phase already happened so you're&#010;not getting the right behavior. Attach to the correct phase.&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Jan 8, 2014 at 4:05 PM, Kuo, Joncheng (HP Storage - MSDU) &lt;&#010;joncheng.kuo@hp.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; How do I skip copying resources? I try &lt;skip&gt; in &lt;configuration&gt; but it&#010;&gt; does not work.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-resources-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;executions&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;execution&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;id&gt;copy-xxx&lt;/id&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;phase&gt;compile&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;goals&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;goal&gt;copy-resources&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;skip&gt;true&lt;/skip&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;outputDirectory&gt;${webapp.dir}/example/resources&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;resources&gt;&#010;&gt;                 &lt;resource&gt;&#010;&gt;                   &lt;directory&gt;${webapp.dir}/resources&lt;/directory&gt;&#010;&gt;                   &lt;includes&gt;&#010;&gt;                     &lt;include&gt;**&lt;/include&gt;&#010;&gt;                   &lt;/includes&gt;&#010;&gt;                 &lt;/resource&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;/resources&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Joncheng Kuo&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Cheers,&#010;Paul&#010;&#010;
