Name  :- Anders Hammar &lt;and...@hammar.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Skip copying resources
contents:- I'm pretty sure it works for the binding (execution) you have configured.&#010;Look for the id 'copy-xxx' in the console output and for the execution it&#010;should say that it is skipping. (Unless you have the plugin config in&#010;pluginManagement).&#010;&#010;At the same time the config you should doesn't make sense. Why would you&#010;create a binding but set skip to true?&#010;&#010;What is it that you're trying to do?&#010;&#010;/Anders&#010;&#010;&#010;On Thu, Jan 9, 2014 at 1:05 AM, Kuo, Joncheng (HP Storage - MSDU) &lt;&#010;joncheng.kuo@hp.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; How do I skip copying resources? Name  :- &quot;Earl.Bennett&quot; &lt;earl.benn...@compuware.com&gt;
Subject  :-Can't set Class-Path in jar using external manifest file
contents:- I've been going around and around with this one for a few hours now.&#010;&#010;I am using Maven 3.1.1&#010;&#010;I created a jar file, and had the maven-jar-plugin generate the manifest&#010;file with the classPath for me. I am then able to sucessfully execute the&#010;jar file with java -jar.&#010;&#010;I then exported the manifest from the jar file to a file. I modified the&#010;pom.xml to not generate the classpath automatically, but to use the external&#010;manifest file I created.  When I try to run the resulting jar file using&#010;java -jar, I get a class not found extension. After some testing, I have&#010;concluded that the classpath in the manifest file is not being read.&#010;&#010;I exported the manifest from the non-working jar file to a second file.  I&#010;then compared the two files. The files are identical except for the position&#010;of the Built-By and Build-Jdk elements. In the maven generated manifest,&#010;these lines appear before the class path. In the manifest generated from the&#010;external file, these lines appear after the class path, even though they are&#010;defined before the class path in my external manifest file.&#010;&#010;The Class-Path elements themselves are identical!!&#010;&#010;The elements in the manifest are not supposed to be order sensitive as far&#010;as I know.&#010;&#010;So, I am at a loss.  I need to be able to define the classpath using an&#010;external manifest file because I need to be able to add directories to it,&#010;and I need to be able to control the order of the jar files in the&#010;classpath.&#010;&#010;I would very much appreciate any thoughts anyone may have on this.&#010;&#010;Earl&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Can-t-set-Class-Path-in-jar-using-external-manifest-file-tp5781041.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-Re: Can't set Class-Path in jar using external manifest file
contents:- Well... This is weird...&#010;&#010;I was generating an index.list file in my jar using&#010;&lt;archive&gt;&lt;index&gt;true&lt;/index&gt;&lt;/archive&gt;&#010;&#010;When I removed that, all my problems with the external manifest went away...&#010;&#010;It looks like there is some kind of problem with the index element and using&#010;an external manifest.&#010;&#010;My thanks to those who replied in an attempt to help me out.&#010;&#010;Earl&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Can-t-set-Class-Path-in-jar-using-external-manifest-file-tp5781041p5781049.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Mirko Friedenhagen &lt;mfriedenha...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Options for producing class files with different compilers via Maven
contents:- Hello,&#010;&#010;in the JaCoCo project (a Java code coverage library which uses a Java&#010;agent approach during runtime) we produce some false positives of&#010;uncovered code because of unreachable (e.g. private constructor of a&#010;util class) or synthetic java code (e.g. enum values()).&#010;&#010;As we inspect the class files only, we may not (or better do not want&#010;to) rely on parsing the source code for discovering such conditions.&#010;During some experiments we detected that different compilers (javac vs&#010;eclipse ecj) produce very different byte code in classes for the&#010;above. This might be the case for different versions of Sun/Oracle JDK&#010;or JDKs of other vendors as well. I already took a look at "Using&#010;Non-Javac Compilers" of the maven-compiler-plugin[1]&#010;&#010;Now my question:&#010;- What would be the best approach to produce JARs which contain class&#010;files of above mentioned false positives produced by the different&#010;compilers?&#010;- My first idea was to define a define a multi module project with a&#010;JAR module which will only produce a source jar, which will be&#010;unpacked as "generated-sources" in sibling modules which are then&#010;compiled by the different compilers.&#010;&#010;For additional ideas or caveats I would be grateful.&#010;&#010;&#010;Regards Mirko&#010;[0] https://github.com/jacoco/jacoco/wiki/FilteringOptions&#010;[1] http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-compiler-plugin/non-javac-compilers.html&#010;--&#010;http://illegalstateexception.blogspot.com/&#010;https://github.com/mfriedenhagen/ (http://osrc.dfm.io/mfriedenhagen)&#010;https://bitbucket.org/mfriedenhagen/&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Evgeny Mandrikov &lt;mandri...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: [jacoco-dev] Options for producing class files with different compilers via Maven
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;I have feeling that you ( "we" :) ) could simply use single module and&#010;define several executions of:&#010;&#010;   1. maven-compiler-plugin for compilation&#010;   2. maven-assembly-plugin to create JARs and attach them as additional&#010;   project artifacts&#010;&#010;But I never tried this.&#010;&#010;On Thu, Jan 9, 2014 at 10:13 PM, Mirko Friedenhagen &lt;mfriedenhagen@gmail.com&#010;&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hello,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; in the JaCoCo project (a Java code coverage library which uses a Java&#010;&gt; agent approach during runtime) we produce some false positives of&#010;&gt; uncovered code because of unreachable (e.g. private constructor of a&#010;&gt; util class) or synthetic java code (e.g. enum values()).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; As we inspect the class files only, we may not (or better do not want&#010;&gt; to) rely on parsing the source code for discovering such conditions.&#010;&gt; During some experiments we detected that different compilers (javac vs&#010;&gt; eclipse ecj) produce very different byte code in classes for the&#010;&gt; above. This might be the case for different versions of Sun/Oracle JDK&#010;&gt; or JDKs of other vendors as well. I already took a look at "Using&#010;&gt; Non-Javac Compilers" of the maven-compiler-plugin[1]&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Now my question:&#010;&gt; - What would be the best approach to produce JARs which contain class&#010;&gt; files of above mentioned false positives produced by the different&#010;&gt; compilers?&#010;&gt; - My first idea was to define a define a multi module project with a&#010;&gt; JAR module which will only produce a source jar, which will be&#010;&gt; unpacked as "generated-sources" in sibling modules which are then&#010;&gt; compiled by the different compilers.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; For additional ideas or caveats I would be grateful.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Regards Mirko&#010;&gt; [0] https://github.com/jacoco/jacoco/wiki/FilteringOptions&#010;&gt; [1]&#010;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-compiler-plugin/non-javac-compilers.html&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; http://illegalstateexception.blogspot.com/&#010;&gt; https://github.com/mfriedenhagen/ (http://osrc.dfm.io/mfriedenhagen)&#010;&gt; https://bitbucket.org/mfriedenhagen/&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups&#010;&gt; "JaCoCo Developers" group.&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an&#010;&gt; email to jacoco-dev+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.&#010;&gt; For more options, visit https://groups.google.com/groups/opt_out.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Best regards,&#010;Evgeny Mandrikov aka Godin &lt;http://godin.net.ru&gt;&#010;http://twitter.com/_godin_&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-Project Description Contest
contents:- I have added a Wiki page to track the submissions in this space also&#010;&#010;https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/Project+Description+Contest&#010;&#010;&#010;On 6 January 2014 17:43, Lyons, Roy &lt;Roy.Lyons@cmegroup.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; on https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/New+Main+Site it&#010;&gt; says:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We need a short and snappy description of what Maven is:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "Apache Maven is a software project management and comprehension tool."&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is just not an easy to understand description of what Maven is.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I would like to submit my short description for review.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "Apache Maven is a convention-over-configuration build tool which has&#010;&gt; great dependency management features."&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I know that it does more than that - but I feel that at its core, this is&#010;&gt; what it really is.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Project Description Contest
contents:- I like Roy Lyons contribution as an opening sentence.&#010;I think that the second and third sentence should be about what Maven is &#010;not what it is not. If we are going to compare it to Ant or Gradle, it &#010;should be done in a way that explains what Maven does not what it does &#010;not do.&#010;&#010;"Apache Maven is a convention-over-configuration build tool which has &#010;great dependency management features.  Maven uses a project object model &#010;to describe the dependencies and any special processes that are required &#010;to build the software. This encapsulates all of the knowledge required &#010;to repeatedly build the software as well as the supporting documentation &#010;and project reports. This frees the software developer from many of the &#010;routine tasks associated with software development. Maven enforces a set &#010;of best practices around version control and the software release &#010;process which encourages adherence to enterprise and project  standards &#010;regarding dependent libraries and collaborative development."&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;&#010;On 10/01/2014 8:35 AM, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt; I have added a Wiki page to track the submissions in this space also&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/Project+Description+Contest&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 6 January 2014 17:43, Lyons, Roy &lt;Roy.Lyons@cmegroup.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; on https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/New+Main+Site it&#010;&gt;&gt; says:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; We need a short and snappy description of what Maven is:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; "Apache Maven is a software project management and comprehension tool."&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Is just not an easy to understand description of what Maven is.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I would like to submit my short description for review.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; "Apache Maven is a convention-over-configuration build tool which has&#010;&gt;&gt; great dependency management features."&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I know that it does more than that - but I feel that at its core, this is&#010;&gt;&gt; what it really is.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Project Description Contest
contents:- On 10 January 2014 14:01, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; If we are going to compare it to Ant or Gradle, it should be done in a way&#010;&gt; that explains what Maven does not what it does not do.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Did you even read the sentence I had in bold?&#010;&#010;&gt; *It is *not* our job to educate the reader about other build tools. Our&#010;job is to educate the reader about Maven*.&#010;&#010;The *reader* will be comparing Maven with Ant/Gradle/etc, so we need to&#010;give them the *information* they need. We do not need to (and in my opinion&#010;should not) mention Ant/Gradle/etc at all...&#010;&#010;To try and frame this better, consider a sentence like:&#010;&#010;"Maven takes a philosophy that most builds can be categorised based on the&#010;type of thing you are building and that there is a best way to build each&#010;type of thing, so you tell Maven the type of thing that you want to build&#010;rather than spelling out the exact build steps you want" (this specific is&#010;not a sentence I am suggesting as it is too long winded... a snappier&#010;version of this *could* be good though)&#010;&#010;Allows a reader who is used to the spelling out exact build steps (e.g.&#010;ANT/Make/etc) to identify one of the key differences in Maven's&#010;philosophy...&#010;&#010;http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hC_r-dC4PqA Marmite^H^H^H^H^Hven you either&#010;love it or hate it!&#010;&#010;We are not going to convince the people who hate Maven that they love it,&#010;despite how ever much we provide a nice introduction or however much we&#010;improve our documentation... (though the fence sitters are up for grabs ;-)&#010;&#010;Just like no amount of waxing lyrical from the Marmite fans will convince&#010;me that it tastes nice... as far as I am concerned it is vile... I would&#010;rather starve to death than eat Marmite... but I can respect that some&#010;people like it.&#010;&#010;What we need to do is filter out the people who will hate Maven with as&#010;little time of theirs wasted... that way they will say "Maven you either&#010;love it or hate it" and move on, rather than spending hours ranting about&#010;how Maven is wrong, they can instead recognise that Maven has picked a&#010;different philosophy that is better for some people and worse for them.&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Project Description Contest
contents:- On 10/01/2014 10:05 AM, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt; On 10 January 2014 14:01, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; If we are going to compare it to Ant or Gradle, it should be done in a way&#010;&gt;&gt; that explains what Maven does not what it does not do.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; Did you even read the sentence I had in bold?&#010;&#010;Yes.&#010;I think that I was agreeing with that sentiment.&#010;&#010;&gt;&gt; *It is *not* our job to educate the reader about other build tools. Our&#010;&gt; job is to educate the reader about Maven*.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The *reader* will be comparing Maven with Ant/Gradle/etc, so we need to&#010;&gt; give them the *information* they need. We do not need to (and in my opinion&#010;&gt; should not) mention Ant/Gradle/etc at all...&#010;&#010;I still think that a product comparison page/chart is a useful way to &#010;help a reader understand whether maven is a good choice in their &#010;circumstance.&#010;It should be on a separate page but could be linked from the front page.&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; To try and frame this better, consider a sentence like:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "Maven takes a philosophy that most builds can be categorised based on the&#010;&gt; type of thing you are building and that there is a best way to build each&#010;&gt; type of thing, so you tell Maven the type of thing that you want to build&#010;&gt; rather than spelling out the exact build steps you want" (this specific is&#010;&gt; not a sentence I am suggesting as it is too long winded... a snappier&#010;&gt; version of this *could* be good though)&#010;Good start on a second paragraph for the opening page.&#010;It explains why Maven was built the way it was.&#010;One has to read between the lines to understand the "what's in it for &#010;me" but does hint at simplifying the build instructions through taking &#010;advantage of common patterns based on the output to be created.&#010;Perhaps if we focus on the benefits to this approach, we could add some &#010;framing around what you wrote to come up with a solid second paragraph.&#010;&#010;&gt; Allows a reader who is used to the spelling out exact build steps (e.g.&#010;&gt; ANT/Make/etc) to identify one of the key differences in Maven's&#010;&gt; philosophy...&#010;Could be incorporated into the text above.&#010;I am not sure that I would put the onus on the user to make the inference.&#010;We should just state the benefits - simplification, standardization, &#010;adherence to corporate/enterprise best practices - and how Maven/"Maven &#010;way" achieves these (by taking advantage of commonality of build flow, &#010;etc. as you stated above).&#010;&#010;I am not sure that I would mention the other build tools specifically here.&#010;I would save it for the comparison.&#010;&#010;&gt; http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hC_r-dC4PqA Marmite^H^H^H^H^Hven you either&#010;&gt; love it or hate it!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We are not going to convince the people who hate Maven that they love it,&#010;&gt; despite how ever much we provide a nice introduction or however much we&#010;&gt; improve our documentation... (though the fence sitters are up for grabs ;-)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Just like no amount of waxing lyrical from the Marmite fans will convince&#010;&gt; me that it tastes nice... as far as I am concerned it is vile... I would&#010;&gt; rather starve to death than eat Marmite... but I can respect that some&#010;&gt; people like it.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; What we need to do is filter out the people who will hate Maven with as&#010;&gt; little time of theirs wasted... that way they will say "Maven you either&#010;&gt; love it or hate it" and move on, rather than spending hours ranting about&#010;&gt; how Maven is wrong, they can instead recognise that Maven has picked a&#010;&gt; different philosophy that is better for some people and worse for them.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;I see this discussion as part of a flame war that can be buried deeper &#010;in the site.&#010;I think that we should assume that a person who is arriving on the front &#010;page is coming looking for a solution not a range war.&#010;If they decide to use Ant, so be it.&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Project Description Contest
contents:- On 10 January 2014 15:50, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; On 10/01/2014 10:05 AM, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 10 January 2014 14:01, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt;&gt; &gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  If we are going to compare it to Ant or Gradle, it should be done in a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; way&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; that explains what Maven does not what it does not do.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;  Did you even read the sentence I had in bold?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Yes.&#010;&gt; I think that I was agreeing with that sentiment.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;  *It is *not* our job to educate the reader about other build tools. Our&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; job is to educate the reader about Maven*.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The *reader* will be comparing Maven with Ant/Gradle/etc, so we need to&#010;&gt;&gt; give them the *information* they need. We do not need to (and in my&#010;&gt;&gt; opinion&#010;&gt;&gt; should not) mention Ant/Gradle/etc at all...&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I still think that a product comparison page/chart is a useful way to help&#010;&gt; a reader understand whether maven is a good choice in their circumstance.&#010;&gt; It should be on a separate page but could be linked from the front page.&#010;&#010;&#010;I would link it from a FAQ page, not the front page... as understanding our&#010;choice of metrics to compare on requires some understanding of Maven&#010;first... otherwise a comparison that we think is fair to Maven will not be&#010;well understood.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; To try and frame this better, consider a sentence like:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; "Maven takes a philosophy that most builds can be categorised based on the&#010;&gt;&gt; type of thing you are building and that there is a best way to build each&#010;&gt;&gt; type of thing, so you tell Maven the type of thing that you want to build&#010;&gt;&gt; rather than spelling out the exact build steps you want" (this specific is&#010;&gt;&gt; not a sentence I am suggesting as it is too long winded... a snappier&#010;&gt;&gt; version of this *could* be good though)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; Good start on a second paragraph for the opening page.&#010;&gt; It explains why Maven was built the way it was.&#010;&gt; One has to read between the lines to understand the "what's in it for me"&#010;&gt; but does hint at simplifying the build instructions through taking&#010;&gt; advantage of common patterns based on the output to be created.&#010;&gt; Perhaps if we focus on the benefits to this approach, we could add some&#010;&gt; framing around what you wrote to come up with a solid second paragraph.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;  Allows a reader who is used to the spelling out exact build steps (e.g.&#010;&gt;&gt; ANT/Make/etc) to identify one of the key differences in Maven's&#010;&gt;&gt; philosophy...&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; Could be incorporated into the text above.&#010;&gt; I am not sure that I would put the onus on the user to make the inference.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;1. Don't preach to the reader... we should not tell them what to think&#010;&#010;2. Don't speak ill of others&#010;&#010;3. Don't assume that the reader cannot think for themselves.&#010;&#010;I am not saying we put the onus on the reader to make the inference. This&#010;could be the very first tool in this space that they have discovered.&#010;&#010;We should state our philosophy... give links to explain what we mean in the&#010;description, so that loaded terms can be understood by people who are&#010;unfamiliar with them... and by all means lets give links to&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; We should just state the benefits - simplification, standardization,&#010;&gt; adherence to corporate/enterprise best practices - and how Maven/"Maven&#010;&gt; way" achieves these (by taking advantage of commonality of build flow, etc.&#010;&gt; as you stated above).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I am not sure that I would mention the other build tools specifically here.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;I am saying *no way* will we mention other build tools on the front page or&#010;in the project description.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; I would save it for the comparison.&#010;&#010;&#010;If we even need a comparison... but a comparison is not needed as much as a&#010;rebrand of the initial RX (or reader experience)&#010;&#010;Let's get the content needed to get a reader up and running and doing a few&#010;builds quickly that they can develop a feel for the Maven way... again that&#010;hits the theme of letting the reader find out - as quickly as we can let&#010;them - whether they love maven or hate it.&#010;&#010;The first level content should also hit things like the release plugin and&#010;project documentation&#010;&#010;The second level content should then be focused on more advanced things...&#010;&#010;* deviating from the conventions&#010;&#010;* writing simple plugins&#010;&#010;* forging a new path for a new packaging type&#010;&#010;The third level content, if we get that far, would be the more advanced&#010;plugin writing stuff...&#010;&#010;Only when we get that far should we start thinking about comparisons with&#010;other tooling&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hC_r-dC4PqA Marmite^H^H^H^H^Hven you&#010;&gt;&gt; either&#010;&gt;&gt; love it or hate it!&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; We are not going to convince the people who hate Maven that they love it,&#010;&gt;&gt; despite how ever much we provide a nice introduction or however much we&#010;&gt;&gt; improve our documentation... (though the fence sitters are up for grabs&#010;&gt;&gt; ;-)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Just like no amount of waxing lyrical from the Marmite fans will convince&#010;&gt;&gt; me that it tastes nice... as far as I am concerned it is vile... I would&#010;&gt;&gt; rather starve to death than eat Marmite... but I can respect that some&#010;&gt;&gt; people like it.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; What we need to do is filter out the people who will hate Maven with as&#010;&gt;&gt; little time of theirs wasted... that way they will say "Maven you either&#010;&gt;&gt; love it or hate it" and move on, rather than spending hours ranting about&#010;&gt;&gt; how Maven is wrong, they can instead recognise that Maven has picked a&#010;&gt;&gt; different philosophy that is better for some people and worse for them.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; I see this discussion as part of a flame war that can be buried deeper in&#010;&gt; the site.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Why would we want to put a flame war on our site?&#010;&#010;I think in the FAQ we could have a "comparison to other tools" section with&#010;things like&#010;&#010;Q: "I just want to specify the exact steps that Maven should build, like I&#010;can with Gradle. Why does Maven make this hard to do?"&#010;&#010;Q: "I just want to keep my dependencies in source control like Ant lets me.&#010;Why can't Maven use the dependencies that are in source control, forcing me&#010;to run a repository manager just to host them?"&#010;&#010;Such content sits best in a FAQ... but we should not knock these other&#010;tools. They are just as valid at building software as Maven is... look at&#010;the end result... the software is built.&#010;&#010;&gt;From our philosophy there is a big difference... there is a whole larger&#010;layer of trade-offs that we see... and from our point of view once you see&#010;the bigger picture that we see... well why would you use anything other&#010;than Maven... *but* that does not make us _right_... it just makes us&#010;self-consistent.&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; I think that we should assume that a person who is arriving on the front&#010;&gt; page is coming looking for a solution not a range war.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;We don't know why somebody has landed on our front page... what we want to&#010;do is get the people who don't want to be here to move on as fast as&#010;possible so that they appreciate the fact that we have not wasted their&#010;time.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; If they decide to use Ant, so be it.&#010;&#010;&#010;Maven... you either love it or hate it... I am happy with that&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; President&#010;&gt; Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt; email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt; phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

But it does work on my&#010;&gt; phone. Looks way cool! But we should probably support firefox as well...:-)&#010;&#010;MG&gt;so saw this in your JQuery function... a.fn.carousel.defaults={interval:5000,pause:"hover"}&#010;MG&gt;5 sec interval is too slow...is there any way I can crank up to 'ridiculous speed' ?&#010;MG&gt;Thanks!&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; /Anders&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; On Fri, Jan 10, 2014 at 9:13 PM, Stephen Connolly &lt;&#010;&gt; stephen.alan.connolly@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &gt; an extra space in the xdoc... should be fixed now&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; On 10 January 2014 19:46, Anders Hammar &lt;anders@hammar.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &lt;http://stephenc.github.io/junit/&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I recommend clicking the Let's take a tour button.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Does not work in my browser! (tm)&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; https://www.dropbox.com/s/oezmyk4khsynl78/Screenshot%202014-01-10%2020.45.35.png&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; /Anders&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; -Stephen&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010; &#009;&#009; &#009;   &#009;&#009;  &#010;

================

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Value of a prodyct comparison
contents:- I am not sure that I agree with this section of &#010;https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/Project+Description+Contest*&#010;"Note: *this does not preclude us from including a "feature comparison &#010;matrix" page somewhere in our site... but we should recognise that such &#010;a matrix would likely be biased by our philosophy, which most likely &#010;negates the utility of hosting such a page on our site. Let us leave the &#010;feature comparison matrices to those that have no axe to grind (and &#010;spend our energy ensuring that their matrices are fair to us, just as &#010;other solutions in this space should be doing for the representation of &#010;their tools on such matrices)"&#010;&#010;There may be some value is writing the comparison from a Maven point of &#010;view.&#010;It does give a chance to describe where there are differences and why &#010;they are important from the POV of the "Maven way". Maven is based on &#010;certain beliefs about the way software should be developed and built. As &#010;most politicians can tell you, it is better to define yourself than have &#010;someone else define you.&#010;It is most uncertain that third parties will give the same weighting to &#010;the value of certain practices and features that the Maven community would.&#010;It is clear from the discussions in this forum, that it is easy to get &#010;off to a shaky start when first trying to use Maven. A person doing a &#010;quick evaluation of development tools could easily bring with them some &#010;assumptions about software development processes and come up with a very &#010;distorted view of Maven.&#010;&#010;I think that an accurate product comparison written from the maven POV &#010;is fair and useful for someone coming to Maven for the first time. It &#010;will highlight things that Maven does that other systems don't do as &#010;well and there is no reason to exclude things where Ant is better and &#010;explain why the Maven community does not consider that a deal breaker.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Value of a prodyct comparison
contents:- On 10 January 2014 15:02, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I am not sure that I agree with this section of https://cwiki.apache.org/&#010;&gt; confluence/display/MAVEN/Project+Description+Contest*&#010;&gt; "Note: *this does not preclude us from including a "feature comparison&#010;&gt; matrix" page somewhere in our site... but we should recognise that such a&#010;&gt; matrix would likely be biased by our philosophy, which most likely negates&#010;&gt; the utility of hosting such a page on our site. Let us leave the feature&#010;&gt; comparison matrices to those that have no axe to grind (and spend our&#010;&gt; energy ensuring that their matrices are fair to us, just as other solutions&#010;&gt; in this space should be doing for the representation of their tools on such&#010;&gt; matrices)"&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; There may be some value is writing the comparison from a Maven point of&#010;&gt; view.&#010;&gt; It does give a chance to describe where there are differences and why they&#010;&gt; are important from the POV of the "Maven way". Maven is based on certain&#010;&gt; beliefs about the way software should be developed and built. As most&#010;&gt; politicians can tell you, it is better to define yourself than have someone&#010;&gt; else define you.&#010;&gt; It is most uncertain that third parties will give the same weighting to&#010;&gt; the value of certain practices and features that the Maven community would.&#010;&gt; It is clear from the discussions in this forum, that it is easy to get off&#010;&gt; to a shaky start when first trying to use Maven. A person doing a quick&#010;&gt; evaluation of development tools could easily bring with them some&#010;&gt; assumptions about software development processes and come up with a very&#010;&gt; distorted view of Maven.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I think that an accurate product comparison written from the maven POV is&#010;&gt; fair and useful for someone coming to Maven for the first time. It will&#010;&gt; highlight things that Maven does that other systems don't do as well and&#010;&gt; there is no reason to exclude things where Ant is better and explain why&#010;&gt; the Maven community does not consider that a deal breaker.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;Such a comparison should not be on the first page people land on. If we can&#010;come up with a comparison that we think is fair to all, even if comparing&#010;on our best feature set, then that is fine. The point I was making in that&#010;"note" is that excluding mentioning the competition in the project&#010;description does not mean we are excluding mentioning them at all. The&#010;second point is that there is an argument against having such a comparison&#010;chart anyway... but if we have one that we think is fair to all and&#010;reflects our philosophy then that is fine... not priority #1, #2 or #3 for&#010;a re-design of the maven site&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; President&#010;&gt; Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt; email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt; phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Value of a prodyct comparison
contents:- I agree. No product comparison on the first page.&#010;&#010;If one is written, it should be accurate and fair but, of course, it &#010;will focus on things that the Maven community values and that reflect &#010;the most common development practices as the community sees them.&#010;&#010;It should be written in such a way that people who should use Ant will &#010;understand why Maven is not the right choice and people who should use &#010;Gradle will understand what they are gaining and what they are losing. &#010;(Marmite haters should be allowed to go in peace with our blessing)&#010;It should not be written in a way that starts a flame war or is &#010;unhelpful to the developer who reads it.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;On 10/01/2014 10:19 AM, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt; On 10 January 2014 15:02, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com &#010;&gt; &lt;mailto:rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     I am not sure that I agree with this section of&#010;&gt;     https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/Project+Description+Contest*&#010;&gt;     "Note: *this does not preclude us from including a "feature&#010;&gt;     comparison matrix" page somewhere in our site... but we should&#010;&gt;     recognise that such a matrix would likely be biased by our&#010;&gt;     philosophy, which most likely negates the utility of hosting such&#010;&gt;     a page on our site. Let us leave the feature comparison matrices&#010;&gt;     to those that have no axe to grind (and spend our energy ensuring&#010;&gt;     that their matrices are fair to us, just as other solutions in&#010;&gt;     this space should be doing for the representation of their tools&#010;&gt;     on such matrices)"&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     There may be some value is writing the comparison from a Maven&#010;&gt;     point of view.&#010;&gt;     It does give a chance to describe where there are differences and&#010;&gt;     why they are important from the POV of the "Maven way". Maven is&#010;&gt;     based on certain beliefs about the way software should be&#010;&gt;     developed and built. As most politicians can tell you, it is&#010;&gt;     better to define yourself than have someone else define you.&#010;&gt;     It is most uncertain that third parties will give the same&#010;&gt;     weighting to the value of certain practices and features that the&#010;&gt;     Maven community would.&#010;&gt;     It is clear from the discussions in this forum, that it is easy to&#010;&gt;     get off to a shaky start when first trying to use Maven. A person&#010;&gt;     doing a quick evaluation of development tools could easily bring&#010;&gt;     with them some assumptions about software development processes&#010;&gt;     and come up with a very distorted view of Maven.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     I think that an accurate product comparison written from the maven&#010;&gt;     POV is fair and useful for someone coming to Maven for the first&#010;&gt;     time. It will highlight things that Maven does that other systems&#010;&gt;     don't do as well and there is no reason to exclude things where&#010;&gt;     Ant is better and explain why the Maven community does not&#010;&gt;     consider that a deal breaker.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Such a comparison should not be on the first page people land on. If &#010;&gt; we can come up with a comparison that we think is fair to all, even if &#010;&gt; comparing on our best feature set, then that is fine. The point I was &#010;&gt; making in that "note" is that excluding mentioning the competition in &#010;&gt; the project description does not mean we are excluding mentioning them &#010;&gt; at all. The second point is that there is an argument against having &#010;&gt; such a comparison chart anyway... but if we have one that we think is &#010;&gt; fair to all and reflects our philosophy then that is fine... not &#010;&gt; priority #1, #2 or #3 for a re-design of the maven site&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     -- &#010;&gt;     Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt;     President&#010;&gt;     Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt;     email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt;     &lt;mailto:rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;&#010;&gt;     skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt;     phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Todd Chapman &lt;t...@chaka.net&gt;
Subject  :-Running cleanup code after tests in multi-module project.
contents:- What is the best way to run cleanup code after testing a multi-module&#010;project?&#010;&#010;Basically, post-integration-test for the entire reactor. Is the best way to&#010;create another module that is last to run in the reactor order?&#010;&#010;Thanks!&#010;&#010;-Todd&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Anders Hammar &lt;and...@hammar.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Running cleanup code after tests in multi-module project.
contents:- IMO each Maven project should be independent, even test projects. So there&#010;should be cleanup code in each module.&#010;&#010;&#010;On Fri, Jan 10, 2014 at 10:59 PM, Todd Chapman &lt;todd@chaka.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; What is the best way to run cleanup code after testing a multi-module&#010;&gt; project?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Basically, post-integration-test for the entire reactor. Is the best way to&#010;&gt; create another module that is last to run in the reactor order?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -Todd&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Todd Chapman &lt;t...@chaka.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Running cleanup code after tests in multi-module project.
contents:- Anders,&#010;&#010;I agree with you. Unfortunately I inherited this project and there is setup&#010;required that is identical for each module and is expensive to set up and&#010;tear down. It will take time to refactor the tests to be less expensive to&#010;prepare.&#010;&#010;In the mean time I'm looking for ways to deal with situation I have now.&#010;&#010;Thanks!&#010;&#010;-Todd&#010;&#010;&#010;On Mon, Jan 13, 2014 at 2:48 PM, Anders Hammar &lt;anders@hammar.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; IMO each Maven project should be independent, even test projects. So there&#010;&gt; should be cleanup code in each module.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Fri, Jan 10, 2014 at 10:59 PM, Todd Chapman &lt;todd@chaka.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; What is the best way to run cleanup code after testing a multi-module&#010;&gt; &gt; project?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Basically, post-integration-test for the entire reactor. Is the best way&#010;&gt; to&#010;&gt; &gt; create another module that is last to run in the reactor order?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; -Todd&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Running cleanup code after tests in multi-module project.
contents:- On 14 January 2014 10:49, Todd Chapman &lt;todd@chaka.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Anders,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I agree with you. Unfortunately I inherited this project and there is setup&#010;&gt; required that is identical for each module and is expensive to set up and&#010;&gt; tear down. It will take time to refactor the tests to be less expensive to&#010;&gt; prepare.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; In the mean time I'm looking for ways to deal with situation I have now.&#010;&#010;It sounds like these tests are not unit tests if they need any&#010;setup/teardown of external systems.&#010;These are integration tests.&#010;&#010;It would make more sense to move these tests into one integration-test module.&#010;You then get your one setup/teardown and all the tests are together.&#010;&#010;It should be a matter of moving things around in version control&#010;rather than having to refactor the tests.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Benoît Berthonneau &lt;ben...@berthonneau.com&gt;
Subject  :-RE: Work-around to the Maven restriction on AND condition profile activation?
contents:- Hi Dave,&#010;&#010;I don't what is the purpose of your double activation profile but I did something that could&#010;help you.&#010;I implement 2 profiles: "should-i-do-something" and "do-something".&#010;&#010; - The "should-i-do-something" profile is automatically activated by the existence of a file&#010;in a project, but the phase of all plugins involved was set to "none" (that's the trick)&#010; - The "do-something" profile is activated on demand and just set the phase(s) of the plugins&#010;involved in the previous profile&#010;&#010;Hope this help,&#010;Benoît.&#010;&#010;&#010;-----Message d'origine-----&#010;De : laredotornado-3 [mailto:laredotornado@gmail.com] &#010;Envoyé : vendredi 31 janvier 2014 22:19&#010;À : users@maven.apache.org&#010;Objet : Work-around to the Maven restriction on AND condition profile activation?&#010;&#010;Hi,&#010;&#010;I’m using Maven 3.1.1 and Java 1.6.  From reading over posts online, it seems a profile&#010;cannot be activated based on two conditions (i.e. there is no such thing as logical AND in&#010;Maven profile activation).  So I was wondering if someone knows of a work-around for what&#010;I want to do.  I want to run a plugin if a flag is given on the command line (“-DdeployWars”)&#010;and a file is present in my module, e.g.&#010;&#010;                        &lt;activation&gt;&#010;                                &lt;file&gt;&#010;&#010;&lt;exists&gt;${basedir}/src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/web.xml&lt;/exists&gt;&#010;                                &lt;/file&gt;&#010;                        &lt;/activation&gt;&#010;&#010;Unfortunately, its not an option to include the AND profile activation extension (https://github.com/johnjcool/and-activation-profile-selector)&#010;in our Maven installation, unless there is some way to reference that extension from the Maven&#010;project itself.&#010;&#010;Thanks for your thoughts, - Dave&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: &#010;http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Work-around-to-the-Maven-restriction-on-AND-condition-profile-activation-tp5782919.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Benoît Berthonneau &lt;ben...@berthonneau.com&gt;
Subject  :-RE: Work-around to the Maven restriction on AND condition profile activation?
contents:- Hi Dave,&#010;&#010;I don't what is the purpose of your double activation profile but I did something that could&#010;help you.&#010;I implement 2 profiles: "should-i-do-something" and "do-something".&#010;&#010; - The "should-i-do-something" profile is automatically activated by the existence of a file&#010;in a project, but the phase of all plugins involved was set to "none" (that's the trick)&#010; - The "do-something" profile is activated on demand and just set the phase(s) of the plugins&#010;involved in the previous profile&#010;&#010;Hope this help,&#010;Benoît.&#010;&#010;&#010;-----Message d'origine-----&#010;De : laredotornado-3 [mailto:laredotornado@gmail.com] &#010;Envoyé : vendredi 31 janvier 2014 22:19&#010;À : users@maven.apache.org&#010;Objet : Work-around to the Maven restriction on AND condition profile activation?&#010;&#010;Hi,&#010;&#010;I’m using Maven 3.1.1 and Java 1.6.  From reading over posts online, it seems a profile&#010;cannot be activated based on two conditions (i.e. there is no such thing as logical AND in&#010;Maven profile activation).  So I was wondering if someone knows of a work-around for what&#010;I want to do.  I want to run a plugin if a flag is given on the command line (“-DdeployWars”)&#010;and a file is present in my module, e.g.&#010;&#010;                        &lt;activation&gt;&#010;                                &lt;file&gt;&#010;&#010;&lt;exists&gt;${basedir}/src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/web.xml&lt;/exists&gt;&#010;                                &lt;/file&gt;&#010;                        &lt;/activation&gt;&#010;&#010;Unfortunately, its not an option to include the AND profile activation extension (https://github.com/johnjcool/and-activation-profile-selector)&#010;in our Maven installation, unless there is some way to reference that extension from the Maven&#010;project itself.&#010;&#010;Thanks for your thoughts, - Dave&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: &#010;http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Work-around-to-the-Maven-restriction-on-AND-condition-profile-activation-tp5782919.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- laredotornado-3 &lt;laredotorn...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-RE: Work-around to the Maven restriction on AND condition profile activation?
contents:- Thanks for that ingenious solution.  It worked perfectly.&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Work-around-to-the-Maven-restriction-on-AND-condition-profile-activation-tp5782919p5783107.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Something about it&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; being stuck reading a char from stdin or something - only it wasn't time&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; related, sometimes resizes/splitting the terminal would kick it back into&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; gear.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 31 Jan 2014, at 23:12, Stephane Nicoll wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I am definitely impatient because looking at that closer, the shell is&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; not&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; stuck but it takes several seconds to give back hand. Name  :- Stephane Nicoll &lt;stephane.nic...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Maven process stuck on MacOS with Java8
contents:- On Fri, Jan 31, 2014 at 8:45 PM, Mark Derricutt&#010;&lt;mark@talios.com&lt;javascript:_e(%7B%7D,'cvml','mark@talios.com');&gt;&#010;&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; That's the terminal, not the shell ( bash, zsh, fish, csh etc. ).&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Yes, right. I am just using the default (bash). Something about it&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; being stuck reading a char from stdin or something - only it wasn't time&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; related, sometimes resizes/splitting the terminal would kick it back into&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; gear.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 31 Jan 2014, at 23:12, Stephane Nicoll wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I am definitely impatient because looking at that closer, the shell is&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; not&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; stuck but it takes several seconds to give back hand. Name  :- Russ Tremain &lt;ru...@releasetools.org&gt;
Subject  :-enough entropy for jarsigning?
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;I ran into a very weird problem the other day that I thought I would &#010;share with the list.&#010;&#010;We recently switched our maven builds to Fedora linux running on a &#010;really great VMWARE cluster with very fast SSD-based storage.&#010;&#010;However, our average java build inexplicably increased to several &#010;hours.  In my own build environment under mac osx, similar builds &#010;would complete in minutes (some of the small builds take only 2-3 &#010;minutes under normal circumstances).&#010;&#010;I eventually noticed that the jobs were hanging during jarsigning.&#010;&#010;After investigating many red herrings, it boiled down to the linux &#010;"secure random" device, /dev/random, not supplying enough data.  It &#010;is a blocking device, and therefore, if you are using the jarsigner &#010;plugin, the jarsigner will read from /dev/random to seed the &#010;encryption for the signature for each class.  If you have a jar with &#010;many classes that need to be signed, it can literally take hours.&#010;&#010;In our case, a 2 minute build was taking up to 4 hours.&#010;&#010;Note that if you are running under mac osx, this will not occur, &#010;because Apple maps /dev/random to the psuedo random number device &#010;which is /dev/urandom:&#010;&#010;# ls -l /dev/random /dev/urandom&#010;crw-rw-rw-  1 root  wheel    9,   0 Feb  1 09:31 /dev/random&#010;crw-rw-rw-  1 root  wheel    9,   1 Jan 23 19:22 /dev/urandom&#010;&#010;You may not experience this problem if you are running on real &#010;hardware, because the so-called "entropy pool" can be supplied with &#010;hardware sources of noise, even at the chip level in some cases.&#010;&#010;However, if you are running in a virtual environment, apparently &#010;there is not enough noise to supply the entropy pool with a steady &#010;stream of data, and so /dev/random runs out and blocks very quickly.&#010;&#010;The problem is very easy to detect:&#010;&#010;&#009;$ dd if=/dev/random of=/dev/null bs=1 count=1000&#010;&#010;If dd hangs while reading from the device, or takes a very long time, &#010;then you have the problem.&#010;&#010;Once you identify the problem, it is easy to solve [1,2].  In our &#010;case, we opted for a system-wide solution using the rngd-tools [3] &#010;package, since this problem can impact many things, including ssl &#010;connections with jenkins [4], or any other programs that consume &#010;encryption services.&#010;&#010;Cheers,&#010;-Russ&#010;&#010;References:&#010;&#010;[1] &#010;http://stackoverflow.com/questions/137212/how-to-solve-performance-problem-with-java-securerandom&#010;[2] http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E12529_01/wlss31/configwlss/jvmrand.html&#010;[3] on fedora/centos/etc:  sudo yum install rng-utils&#010;     start daemon with:  rngd --rng-device=/dev/urandom&#010;[4] &#010;"&lt;https://groups.google.com/forum/?hl=en_US#!searchin/jenkinsci-users/Re$3A$20How$20does$20Jenkins$20checkout$20sources$20from$20svn$20to$20the$20slaves/jenkinsci-users/sqp6hvzdXDY/P-ZYkDO-8TgJ&gt;How&#010;&#010;does Jenkins checkout sources from svn to the slaves", &#010;jenkinsci-users list.&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Stephane Nicoll &lt;stephane.nic...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: dependency management across projects
contents:- On Fri, Jan 31, 2014 at 1:16 PM, Anders Hammar &lt;anders@hammar.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; The release of the BOM would be that release of "a single coherent unit"&#010;&gt; then. It would specify the (marketing) version of the "platform" P.&#010;&gt; For example, P v1.0.0 will include v1.2.3 of SP1 (sub-product 1), v1.4.3 of&#010;&gt; SP2, etc.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Isn't it what I just write in my original post? (without mentioning the BOM)&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Creating the BOM would be a manual work I think, as you want to make sure&#010;&gt; that exactly the correct versions are included (might not be the latest&#010;&gt; releases).&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Yes, this is already what I do. The very point I am trying to make here is&#010;"how do you manage that manual BOM on a daily basis". Each sub-project has&#010;its own release cycle and we cannot force the versions it has to use for a&#010;specific branch. For instance, the product might state that the dependency&#010;D should be 2.2.0 (because that's the latest or the one that people&#010;generally use) but for backward compatibility reason SP2 has to use 1.8.0.&#010;&#010;Creating manually the first BOM for P v1.0.0 isn't a problem: i've created&#010;a set of tools that I am happy to share once they are fully ready. But&#010;maintaining that BOM in the long run is more of a challenge (because we&#010;can't force the sub-projects to use those versions so we have to monitor&#010;what happens in each sub-project to take the appropriate version at the&#010;product level).&#010;&#010;Thanks again for the feedback!&#010;&#010;S.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; /Anders&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; There is also the possibility of creating a "grouping pom", which lists&#010;&gt; &gt; all&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; artifacts as dependencies. You would then declare a dependency to that&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; grouping pom and get all deps magically sucked in. However, this is not&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; really the "Maven way" in my opinion as you wouldn't specify your&#010;&gt; direct&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; deps bu sort of relly on transitive deps. There are some fans of this&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; approach though here on this list.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; 2. Build configs that *force* each sub-project to run with the list&#010;&gt; of&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; dependencies for the project (to ensure all tests pass, etc). This is&#010;&gt; &gt; to&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; be&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; used alongside the regular build job for validation purpose&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Maybe some enforcer rule?&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Like I said, this is to be used alongside the regular build job. So my&#010;&gt; SP4&#010;&gt; &gt; 1.2.0-SNAPSHOT is building with a set of dependencies on its own and I&#010;&gt; want&#010;&gt; &gt; to validate that with the dependencies of the target release for P, it is&#010;&gt; &gt; also working just fine. It may just be the same ideally or slightly&#010;&gt; &gt; different (or not slightly at all which requires an explicit validation).&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; So I need to be able to swap those versions for validation purposes and&#010;&gt; run&#010;&gt; &gt; the build with that.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; S.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; /Anders&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I started to look at this and my first trial was to generate a report&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; with&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; all the dependencies of each project and build a consolidated report&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; that I&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; can match against the candidates. This would help manage the first&#010;&gt; goal&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; as&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; if a dependency gets added, removed or updated, the global&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; dependencyManagement has to be impacted manually (do we upgrade or&#010;&gt; not,&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; etc).&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; For the second part, it's not easy to force a dependency change in&#010;&gt; &gt; Maven,&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; especially if the version has been specified at the project level.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks for reading that far. If you have any idea or know any&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; organisation&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; that tried to implement that, I'd be interested&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; S.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Stephane Nicoll &lt;stephane.nic...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: dependency management across projects
contents:- On Fri, Jan 31, 2014 at 1:16 PM, Anders Hammar &lt;anders@hammar.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; The release of the BOM would be that release of "a single coherent unit"&#010;&gt; then. It would specify the (marketing) version of the "platform" P.&#010;&gt; For example, P v1.0.0 will include v1.2.3 of SP1 (sub-product 1), v1.4.3 of&#010;&gt; SP2, etc.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Isn't it what I just write in my original post? (without mentioning the BOM)&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Creating the BOM would be a manual work I think, as you want to make sure&#010;&gt; that exactly the correct versions are included (might not be the latest&#010;&gt; releases).&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Yes, this is already what I do. The very point I am trying to make here is&#010;"how do you manage that manual BOM on a daily basis". Each sub-project has&#010;its own release cycle and we cannot force the versions it has to use for a&#010;specific branch. For instance, the product might state that the dependency&#010;D should be 2.2.0 (because that's the latest or the one that people&#010;generally use) but for backward compatibility reason SP2 has to use 1.8.0.&#010;&#010;Creating manually the first BOM for P v1.0.0 isn't a problem: i've created&#010;a set of tools that I am happy to share once they are fully ready. But&#010;maintaining that BOM in the long run is more of a challenge (because we&#010;can't force the sub-projects to use those versions so we have to monitor&#010;what happens in each sub-project to take the appropriate version at the&#010;product level).&#010;&#010;Thanks again for the feedback!&#010;&#010;S.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; /Anders&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; There is also the possibility of creating a "grouping pom", which lists&#010;&gt; &gt; all&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; artifacts as dependencies. You would then declare a dependency to that&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; grouping pom and get all deps magically sucked in. However, this is not&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; really the "Maven way" in my opinion as you wouldn't specify your&#010;&gt; direct&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; deps bu sort of relly on transitive deps. There are some fans of this&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; approach though here on this list.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; 2. Build configs that *force* each sub-project to run with the list&#010;&gt; of&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; dependencies for the project (to ensure all tests pass, etc). This is&#010;&gt; &gt; to&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; be&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; used alongside the regular build job for validation purpose&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Maybe some enforcer rule?&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Like I said, this is to be used alongside the regular build job. So my&#010;&gt; SP4&#010;&gt; &gt; 1.2.0-SNAPSHOT is building with a set of dependencies on its own and I&#010;&gt; want&#010;&gt; &gt; to validate that with the dependencies of the target release for P, it is&#010;&gt; &gt; also working just fine. It may just be the same ideally or slightly&#010;&gt; &gt; different (or not slightly at all which requires an explicit validation).&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; So I need to be able to swap those versions for validation purposes and&#010;&gt; run&#010;&gt; &gt; the build with that.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; S.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; /Anders&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I started to look at this and my first trial was to generate a report&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; with&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; all the dependencies of each project and build a consolidated report&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; that I&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; can match against the candidates. This would help manage the first&#010;&gt; goal&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; as&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; if a dependency gets added, removed or updated, the global&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; dependencyManagement has to be impacted manually (do we upgrade or&#010;&gt; not,&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; etc).&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; For the second part, it's not easy to force a dependency change in&#010;&gt; &gt; Maven,&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; especially if the version has been specified at the project level.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks for reading that far. If you have any idea or know any&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; organisation&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; that tried to implement that, I'd be interested&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; S.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Anders Hammar &lt;and...@hammar.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: dependency management across projects
contents:- &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; The release of the BOM would be that release of "a single coherent unit"&#010;&gt; &gt; then. It would specify the (marketing) version of the "platform" P.&#010;&gt; &gt; For example, P v1.0.0 will include v1.2.3 of SP1 (sub-product 1), v1.4.3&#010;&gt; of&#010;&gt; &gt; SP2, etc.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Isn't it what I just write in my original post? (without mentioning the&#010;&gt; BOM)&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;I believe so, yes. The key thing in my "solution" is the BOM. And the BOM&#010;will keep the appropriate version of the the sub-products together.&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; The very point I am trying to make here is&#010;&gt; "how do you manage that manual BOM on a daily basis". Each sub-project has&#010;&gt; its own release cycle and we cannot force the versions it has to use for a&#010;&gt; specific branch. For instance, the product might state that the dependency&#010;&gt; D should be 2.2.0 (because that's the latest or the one that people&#010;&gt; generally use) but for backward compatibility reason SP2 has to use 1.8.0.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;There is no automatic solution for this that I know of. I suppose that&#010;tolls could be created, but keep in mind that in the end, "for backward&#010;compatibility reason SP2 has to use 1.8.0" is normally a human decision.&#010;&#010;/Anders&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Creating manually the first BOM for P v1.0.0 isn't a problem: i've created&#010;&gt; a set of tools that I am happy to share once they are fully ready. But&#010;&gt; maintaining that BOM in the long run is more of a challenge (because we&#010;&gt; can't force the sub-projects to use those versions so we have to monitor&#010;&gt; what happens in each sub-project to take the appropriate version at the&#010;&gt; product level).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks again for the feedback!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; S.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; /Anders&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; There is also the possibility of creating a "grouping pom", which&#010;&gt; lists&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; all&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; artifacts as dependencies. You would then declare a dependency to&#010;&gt; that&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; grouping pom and get all deps magically sucked in. However, this is&#010;&gt; not&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; really the "Maven way" in my opinion as you wouldn't specify your&#010;&gt; &gt; direct&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; deps bu sort of relly on transitive deps. There are some fans of this&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; approach though here on this list.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; 2. Build configs that *force* each sub-project to run with the list&#010;&gt; &gt; of&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; dependencies for the project (to ensure all tests pass, etc). This&#010;&gt; is&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; to&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; be&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; used alongside the regular build job for validation purpose&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Maybe some enforcer rule?&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Like I said, this is to be used alongside the regular build job. So my&#010;&gt; &gt; SP4&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; 1.2.0-SNAPSHOT is building with a set of dependencies on its own and I&#010;&gt; &gt; want&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; to validate that with the dependencies of the target release for P, it&#010;&gt; is&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; also working just fine. It may just be the same ideally or slightly&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; different (or not slightly at all which requires an explicit&#010;&gt; validation).&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; So I need to be able to swap those versions for validation purposes and&#010;&gt; &gt; run&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; the build with that.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; S.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; /Anders&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I started to look at this and my first trial was to generate a&#010;&gt; report&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; with&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; all the dependencies of each project and build a consolidated&#010;&gt; report&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; that I&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; can match against the candidates. This would help manage the first&#010;&gt; &gt; goal&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; as&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; if a dependency gets added, removed or updated, the global&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; dependencyManagement has to be impacted manually (do we upgrade or&#010;&gt; &gt; not,&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; etc).&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; For the second part, it's not easy to force a dependency change in&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Maven,&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; especially if the version has been specified at the project level.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks for reading that far. If you have any idea or know any&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; organisation&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; that tried to implement that, I'd be interested&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; S.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Curtis Rueden &lt;ctrue...@wisc.edu&gt;
Subject  :-Re: dependency management across projects
contents:- Hi everyone,&#010;&#010;&gt; &gt; The very point I am trying to make here is&#010;&gt; &gt; "how do you manage that manual BOM on a daily basis".&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; There is no automatic solution for this that I know of.&#010;&#010;Maybe not exactly what you are looking for, but sort of similar:&#010;&#010;My group uses a script [1] to automatically bump the version of our parent&#010;POM [2].&#010;&#010;In that parent POM, we declare many version properties, plugin&#010;configuration in pluginManagement, etc., and we like to keep all our&#010;projects across various Git repositories using the newest available version&#010;of the parent, to minimize version clashes when mixing and matching&#010;libraries.&#010;&#010;We set up a parameterized Jenkins job [3] to run the parent bump for us,&#010;which provides checkboxes for all the downstream projects so the bump can&#010;be controlled individually.&#010;&#010;It's not perfect but it does save a lot of manual maintenance.&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;Curtis&#010;&#010;[1]&#010;https://github.com/scijava/scijava-scripts/blob/a0fc8006741e0216c74c82866fd1bb1a7d364d55/bump-pom-scijava.sh&#010;[2]&#010;https://github.com/scijava/pom-scijava/blob/0de0676f7731b98baa89379dc8b92f8b26a5d086/pom.xml&#010;[3] http://jenkins.imagej.net/view/SciJava/job/Bump-POM-SciJava/&#010;&#010;&#010;On Mon, Feb 3, 2014 at 1:21 AM, Anders Hammar &lt;anders@hammar.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; The release of the BOM would be that release of "a single coherent&#010;&gt; unit"&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; then. It would specify the (marketing) version of the "platform" P.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; For example, P v1.0.0 will include v1.2.3 of SP1 (sub-product 1),&#010;&gt; v1.4.3&#010;&gt; &gt; of&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; SP2, etc.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Isn't it what I just write in my original post? (without mentioning the&#010;&gt; &gt; BOM)&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I believe so, yes. The key thing in my "solution" is the BOM. And the BOM&#010;&gt; will keep the appropriate version of the the sub-products together.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; The very point I am trying to make here is&#010;&gt; &gt; "how do you manage that manual BOM on a daily basis". Each sub-project&#010;&gt; has&#010;&gt; &gt; its own release cycle and we cannot force the versions it has to use for&#010;&gt; a&#010;&gt; &gt; specific branch. For instance, the product might state that the&#010;&gt; dependency&#010;&gt; &gt; D should be 2.2.0 (because that's the latest or the one that people&#010;&gt; &gt; generally use) but for backward compatibility reason SP2 has to use&#010;&gt; 1.8.0.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; There is no automatic solution for this that I know of. I suppose that&#010;&gt; tolls could be created, but keep in mind that in the end, "for backward&#010;&gt; compatibility reason SP2 has to use 1.8.0" is normally a human decision.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; /Anders&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Creating manually the first BOM for P v1.0.0 isn't a problem: i've&#010;&gt; created&#010;&gt; &gt; a set of tools that I am happy to share once they are fully ready. But&#010;&gt; &gt; maintaining that BOM in the long run is more of a challenge (because we&#010;&gt; &gt; can't force the sub-projects to use those versions so we have to monitor&#010;&gt; &gt; what happens in each sub-project to take the appropriate version at the&#010;&gt; &gt; product level).&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Thanks again for the feedback!&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; S.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; /Anders&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; There is also the possibility of creating a "grouping pom", which&#010;&gt; &gt; lists&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; all&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; artifacts as dependencies. You would then declare a dependency to&#010;&gt; &gt; that&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; grouping pom and get all deps magically sucked in. However, this&#010;is&#010;&gt; &gt; not&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; really the "Maven way" in my opinion as you wouldn't specify your&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; direct&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; deps bu sort of relly on transitive deps. There are some fans of&#010;&gt; this&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; approach though here on this list.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; 2. Build configs that *force* each sub-project to run with the&#010;&gt; list&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; of&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; dependencies for the project (to ensure all tests pass, etc).&#010;&gt; This&#010;&gt; &gt; is&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; to&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; be&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; used alongside the regular build job for validation purpose&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Maybe some enforcer rule?&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Like I said, this is to be used alongside the regular build job. So&#010;&gt; my&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; SP4&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; 1.2.0-SNAPSHOT is building with a set of dependencies on its own and&#010;&gt; I&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; want&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; to validate that with the dependencies of the target release for P,&#010;&gt; it&#010;&gt; &gt; is&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; also working just fine. It may just be the same ideally or slightly&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; different (or not slightly at all which requires an explicit&#010;&gt; &gt; validation).&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; So I need to be able to swap those versions for validation purposes&#010;&gt; and&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; run&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the build with that.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; S.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; /Anders&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I started to look at this and my first trial was to generate&#010;a&#010;&gt; &gt; report&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; with&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; all the dependencies of each project and build a consolidated&#010;&gt; &gt; report&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; that I&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; can match against the candidates. This would help manage the&#010;&gt; first&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; goal&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; as&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; if a dependency gets added, removed or updated, the global&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; dependencyManagement has to be impacted manually (do we upgrade&#010;&gt; or&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; not,&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; etc).&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; For the second part, it's not easy to force a dependency change&#010;&gt; in&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Maven,&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; especially if the version has been specified at the project&#010;&gt; level.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks for reading that far. If you have any idea or know any&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; organisation&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; that tried to implement that, I'd be interested&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; S.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;
