Name  :- Jörg Schaible &lt;joerg.schai...@swisspost.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: dependency management across projects
contents:- Curtis Rueden wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi everyone,&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; &gt; The very point I am trying to make here is&#010;&gt;&gt; &gt; "how do you manage that manual BOM on a daily basis".&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; There is no automatic solution for this that I know of.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Maybe not exactly what you are looking for, but sort of similar:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; My group uses a script [1] to automatically bump the version of our parent&#010;&gt; POM [2].&#010;&#010;We use simply "x-SNAPSHOT" for the parent version. That way no unreleased &#010;project has to be touched, it simply uses the "lastest" SNAPSHOT of the &#010;parent. No script required.&#010;&#010;[snip]&#010;&#010;- Jörg&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Curtis Rueden &lt;ctrue...@wisc.edu&gt;
Subject  :-Re: dependency management across projects
contents:- Hi Jörg,&#010;&#010;&gt; We use simply "x-SNAPSHOT" for the parent version. That way no&#010;&gt; unreleased project has to be touched, it simply uses the "lastest"&#010;&gt; SNAPSHOT of the parent. No script required.&#010;&#010;Yeah, that is very convenient, if you are willing to accept the two-edged&#010;sword of irreproducible builds. A breaking change in the parent will break&#010;all builds that consume it... but can be fixed just as easily too without&#010;touching the downstream projects.&#010;&#010;Of course, it's a decision every project has to make for themselves. My&#010;projects opted for build reproducibility by using only release linkages&#010;(for parent POMs, dependencies and plugins). This has many advantages:&#010;e.g., "git bisect" fully works as one might hope, allowing you to resurrect&#010;the state of the code even from years prior and still build successfully.&#010;The downside is that you must make releases in order to be able to pin to&#010;them.&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;Curtis&#010;&#010;&#010;On Tue, Feb 4, 2014 at 4:38 AM, Jörg Schaible&#010;&lt;joerg.schaible@swisspost.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Curtis Rueden wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Hi everyone,&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; The very point I am trying to make here is&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; "how do you manage that manual BOM on a daily basis".&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; There is no automatic solution for this that I know of.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Maybe not exactly what you are looking for, but sort of similar:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; My group uses a script [1] to automatically bump the version of our&#010;&gt; parent&#010;&gt; &gt; POM [2].&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We use simply "x-SNAPSHOT" for the parent version. That way no unreleased&#010;&gt; project has to be touched, it simply uses the "lastest" SNAPSHOT of the&#010;&gt; parent. No script required.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; [snip]&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - Jörg&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Jörg Schaible &lt;joerg.schai...@swisspost.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: dependency management across projects
contents:- Hi Curtis,&#010;&#010;Curtis Rueden wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi Jörg,&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; We use simply "x-SNAPSHOT" for the parent version. That way no&#010;&gt;&gt; unreleased project has to be touched, it simply uses the "lastest"&#010;&gt;&gt; SNAPSHOT of the parent. No script required.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Yeah, that is very convenient, if you are willing to accept the two-edged&#010;&gt; sword of irreproducible builds.&#010;&#010;What do you mean with "irreproducible builds"? Definitely, if you project &#010;relies on a SNAPSHOT parent, it does not matter if you call it 1-SNAPSHOT or &#010;x-SNAPSHOT.&#010;&#010;&gt; A breaking change in the parent will break&#010;&gt; all builds that consume it... but can be fixed just as easily too without&#010;&gt; touching the downstream projects.&#010;&#010;Well, somebody obviously made the choice for the SNAPSHOT parent ... with &#010;all consequences.&#010;&#010;&gt; Of course, it's a decision every project has to make for themselves. My&#010;&gt; projects opted for build reproducibility by using only release linkages&#010;&gt; (for parent POMs, dependencies and plugins). This has many advantages:&#010;&gt; e.g., "git bisect" fully works as one might hope, allowing you to&#010;&gt; resurrect the state of the code even from years prior and still build&#010;&gt; successfully. The downside is that you must make releases in order to be&#010;&gt; able to pin to them.&#010;&#010;Once a project is released, you also have a released parent. No surprises &#010;anymore. And the project can then make its own decision if it creates also a &#010;branch for the parent and rely on e.g. 254.x-SNAPSHOT either for maintenance &#010;releases or further development.&#010;&#010;This scheme works well for us now for several years.&#010;&#010;Cheers,&#010;Jörg&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Curtis Rueden &lt;ctrue...@wisc.edu&gt;
Subject  :-Re: dependency management across projects
contents:- Hi Jörg,&#010;&#010;&gt; What do you mean with "irreproducible builds"?&#010;&#010;I mean that you may build the same source code today, and then again next&#010;week, and the two build results may differ.&#010;&#010;With our projects we wanted the certainty that if you checked out *any*&#010;revision from the SCM history, you would still be able to build it in, say,&#010;5 years... at least as long as you use the same versions of the tooling&#010;(Java version etc.).&#010;&#010;With a SNAPSHOT parent, that is not guaranteed. You may introduce a change&#010;in the parent that causes a build to fail when it used to succeed, which&#010;makes "bisect" style debugging no longer feasible. That is, if old SCM&#010;revisions no longer build properly due to changes in the parent, you will&#010;no longer be able to perform a binary search through the SCM history to&#010;determine the exact commit which introduced a bug.&#010;&#010;&gt; This scheme works well for us now for several years.&#010;&#010;Sure, and I'm not dissing it, just pointing out the pros and cons. We&#010;wanted fully reproducible builds, which meant that even our SNAPSHOT&#010;revisions have only release dependencies, including the parent POM&#010;reference. This indeed has some negative consequences, such as needing that&#010;script to bump things for us, rather than everything "Just Working" with no&#010;changes. And you're right that *release* version builds are still&#010;reproducible either way.&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;Curtis&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Feb 5, 2014 at 1:54 AM, Jörg Schaible&#010;&lt;joerg.schaible@swisspost.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi Curtis,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Curtis Rueden wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Hi Jörg,&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; We use simply "x-SNAPSHOT" for the parent version. That way no&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; unreleased project has to be touched, it simply uses the "lastest"&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; SNAPSHOT of the parent. No script required.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Yeah, that is very convenient, if you are willing to accept the two-edged&#010;&gt; &gt; sword of irreproducible builds.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; What do you mean with "irreproducible builds"? Definitely, if you project&#010;&gt; relies on a SNAPSHOT parent, it does not matter if you call it 1-SNAPSHOT&#010;&gt; or&#010;&gt; x-SNAPSHOT.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; A breaking change in the parent will break&#010;&gt; &gt; all builds that consume it... but can be fixed just as easily too without&#010;&gt; &gt; touching the downstream projects.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Well, somebody obviously made the choice for the SNAPSHOT parent ... with&#010;&gt; all consequences.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Of course, it's a decision every project has to make for themselves. My&#010;&gt; &gt; projects opted for build reproducibility by using only release linkages&#010;&gt; &gt; (for parent POMs, dependencies and plugins). This has many advantages:&#010;&gt; &gt; e.g., "git bisect" fully works as one might hope, allowing you to&#010;&gt; &gt; resurrect the state of the code even from years prior and still build&#010;&gt; &gt; successfully. The downside is that you must make releases in order to be&#010;&gt; &gt; able to pin to them.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Once a project is released, you also have a released parent. No surprises&#010;&gt; anymore. And the project can then make its own decision if it creates also&#010;&gt; a&#010;&gt; branch for the parent and rely on e.g. 254.x-SNAPSHOT either for&#010;&gt; maintenance&#010;&gt; releases or further development.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; This scheme works well for us now for several years.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Cheers,&#010;&gt; Jörg&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Stephane Nicoll &lt;stephane.nic...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: dependency management across projects
contents:- On Mon, Feb 3, 2014 at 8:21 AM, Anders Hammar &lt;anders@hammar.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I believe so, yes. The key thing in my "solution" is the BOM. And the BOM&#010;&gt; will keep the appropriate version of the the sub-products together.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Right!&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; There is no automatic solution for this that I know of. I suppose that&#010;&gt; tolls could be created, but keep in mind that in the end, "for backward&#010;&gt; compatibility reason SP2 has to use 1.8.0" is normally a human decision.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;It is. The tool I aim to create is more report-based. Something that would&#010;gather the dependencies on each sub-projects and report inconsistencies: a&#010;dependency unknown to the product has been added or removed, etc.&#010;&#010;Thanks for brainstorming this with me. It feels that we're indeed lacking&#010;for a standard solution for this in the Maven land. Will look into that and&#010;report here my progress&#010;&#010;S.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; /Anders&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Creating manually the first BOM for P v1.0.0 isn't a problem: i've&#010;&gt; created&#010;&gt; &gt; a set of tools that I am happy to share once they are fully ready. But&#010;&gt; &gt; maintaining that BOM in the long run is more of a challenge (because we&#010;&gt; &gt; can't force the sub-projects to use those versions so we have to monitor&#010;&gt; &gt; what happens in each sub-project to take the appropriate version at the&#010;&gt; &gt; product level).&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Thanks again for the feedback!&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; S.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; /Anders&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; There is also the possibility of creating a "grouping pom", which&#010;&gt; &gt; lists&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; all&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; artifacts as dependencies. You would then declare a dependency to&#010;&gt; &gt; that&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; grouping pom and get all deps magically sucked in. However, this&#010;is&#010;&gt; &gt; not&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; really the "Maven way" in my opinion as you wouldn't specify your&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; direct&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; deps bu sort of relly on transitive deps. There are some fans of&#010;&gt; this&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; approach though here on this list.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; 2. Build configs that *force* each sub-project to run with the&#010;&gt; list&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; of&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; dependencies for the project (to ensure all tests pass, etc).&#010;&gt; This&#010;&gt; &gt; is&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; to&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; be&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; used alongside the regular build job for validation purpose&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Maybe some enforcer rule?&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Like I said, this is to be used alongside the regular build job. So&#010;&gt; my&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; SP4&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; 1.2.0-SNAPSHOT is building with a set of dependencies on its own and&#010;&gt; I&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; want&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; to validate that with the dependencies of the target release for P,&#010;&gt; it&#010;&gt; &gt; is&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; also working just fine. It may just be the same ideally or slightly&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; different (or not slightly at all which requires an explicit&#010;&gt; &gt; validation).&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; So I need to be able to swap those versions for validation purposes&#010;&gt; and&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; run&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the build with that.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; S.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; /Anders&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I started to look at this and my first trial was to generate&#010;a&#010;&gt; &gt; report&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; with&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; all the dependencies of each project and build a consolidated&#010;&gt; &gt; report&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; that I&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; can match against the candidates. This would help manage the&#010;&gt; first&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; goal&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; as&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; if a dependency gets added, removed or updated, the global&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; dependencyManagement has to be impacted manually (do we upgrade&#010;&gt; or&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; not,&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; etc).&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; For the second part, it's not easy to force a dependency change&#010;&gt; in&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Maven,&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; especially if the version has been specified at the project&#010;&gt; level.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks for reading that far. If you have any idea or know any&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; organisation&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; that tried to implement that, I'd be interested&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; S.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

It correlates with a mystery.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Looks like http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MASSEMBLY-671 … basically it happens when&#010;there’s a problem with the assembly descriptor which then triggers a code path that leads&#010;to this cryptic debug message (because something in the code is looking up a resolver with&#010;a non-existent hint). Name  :- Stuart McCulloch &lt;mccu...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Strange log traffic from the assembly plugin
contents:- On 3 Feb 2014, at 14:44, Stuart McCulloch &lt;mcculls@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; On 3 Feb 2014, at 14:34, Benson Margulies &lt;bimargulies@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; Does anyone recognize the following? It correlates with a mystery.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Looks like http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MASSEMBLY-671 … basically it happens when&#010;there’s a problem with the assembly descriptor which then triggers a code path that leads&#010;to this cryptic debug message (because something in the code is looking up a resolver with&#010;a non-existent hint). Typically the assembly plugin still goes on and produces an assembly,&#010;but the contents may not be what you want due to the issue with the descriptor.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Another example: http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/maven-users/201110.mbox/%3CCAHCAor7DcA9UKMpQredEovqkxw2EPZxJkqJ+=peWkUxjjvE-mA@mail.gmail.com%3E&#010;&#010;More details: this debug message appears the first time that something uses the DefaultRepositoryAssembler&#010;from the shared maven-repository-builder component:&#010;&#010;&#009;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/maven/shared/tags/maven-repository-builder-1.0-alpha-2/src/main/java/org/apache/maven/shared/repository/DefaultRepositoryAssembler.java?view=markup#l96&#010;&#009;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/maven/shared/tags/maven-repository-builder-1.0-alpha-2/src/main/java/org/apache/maven/shared/repository/DefaultRepositoryAssembler.java?view=markup#l710&#010;&#010;The DefaultRepositoryAssembler first looks for the 'project-cache-aware’ ArtifactResolver&#010;before falling back to the default - this change was introduced back in the Maven2 days:&#010;&#010;&#009;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;revision=564256&#010;&#010;but I can’t seem to find out where the 'project-cache-aware’ hinted version of ArtifactResolver&#010;was ever implemented… which is why the first lookup fails and it goes on to use the default&#010;implementation.&#010;&#010;Summary: this is a debug log message that is likely unrelated to the actual issue you’re&#010;investigating, it will always happen first time DefaultRepositoryAssembler is used.&#010;&#010;&gt;&gt; Subject  :-maven-release-plugin updates modules with wrong versioning
contents:- Hi all mates,&#010;&#010;in Apache Oltu we have a commons modules set[1] which I am trying to cut a&#010;release, but I am experiencing for the first time a strange issue: when&#010;installing all modules from /trunk, versions respect what it is specified&#010;in project.version field in the POM, but when releasing them, all modules&#010;inherit the version from the parent.&#010;&#010;Can I kindly ask you an extra pair of eyes that would help me detecting why&#010;this is happening?&#010;&#010;Many thanks in advance, all the best!&#010;-Simo&#010;&#010;[1] https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/oltu/trunk/commons/&#010;&#010;http://people.apache.org/~simonetripodi/&#010;http://twitter.com/simonetripodi&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Alexander Kriegisch &lt;Alexan...@Kriegisch.name&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Deep dependency analysis
contents:- You could use Maven Shade plugin with the option minimizeJar and check the resulting Uber-JAR.&#010;&#010;Maybe even better is ProGuard (the shrinker part without the obfuscator). It will even detect&#010;some uses of class.forName if they are not using dynamic strings. By trial and error you can&#010;exclude some essential classes or packages from shrinking and the remaining stuff in your&#010;Uber-JAr again tells you how many and which dependencies your program is actually using.&#010;-- &#010;Alexander Kriegisch&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; Am 03.02.2014 um 21:28 schrieb Benoît Berthonneau &lt;benoit@berthonneau.com&gt;:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I'll try...&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Thx&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; -----Message d'origine-----&#010;&gt; De : bmathus@gmail.com [mailto:bmathus@gmail.com] De la part de Baptiste Mathus&#010;&gt; Envoyé : lundi 3 février 2014 21:13&#010;&gt; À : Maven Users List&#010;&gt; Objet : Re: Deep dependency analysis&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I'd look at the code behind dependency: analyze I guess the improvement by logging the&#010;class level usage might be doable.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; My 2 cents&#010;&gt; Le 3 févr. 2014 20:48, "Benoît Berthonneau" &lt;benoit@berthonneau.com&gt; a écrit&#010;:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; Hi All,&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; Do you know any maven plugin that could say which classes (from&#010;&gt;&gt; dependencies) are used by the maven project (class by class) ?&#010;&gt;&gt; useful or just because of a “little” API (something like StringUtility &#010;&gt;&gt; class) called by only one class…&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; Thanks,&#010;&gt;&gt; Name  :- Hervé Boutemy &lt;hbout...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-[ANN] Apache Maven SCM Publish Plugin 1.0 Released
contents:- The Apache Maven team is pleased to announce the release of the Apache Maven &#010;SCM Publish Plugin, version 1.0&#010;&#010;The maven-scm-publish-plugin is a utility plugin to allow publishing Maven &#010;website to any supported SCM. The primary goal was to have an utility plugin &#010;to allow Apache projects to publish Maven websites via the ASF svnpubsub &#010;system. The plugin has been tested with git scm too and by example can push &#010;content for github pages.&#010;&#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-scm-publish-plugin/&#010;&#010;You should specify the version in your project's plugin configuration:&#010;&#010;&lt;plugin&gt;&#010;  &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;  &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-scm-publish-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;  &lt;version&gt;1.0&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;Release Notes - maven-scm-publish-plugin - Version 1.0&#010;&#010;** Improvement&#010;    * [MSCMPUB-6] - when creating a directory in svn, if checkout fails, wait &#010;a few seconds and retry&#010;    * [MSCMPUB-7] - Add timestamp when commit starts (and ends)&#010;    * [MSCMPUB-10] - Pick up SCM credentials from settings.xml server section&#010;    * [MSCMPUB-11] - display content size (number of directories, files, and &#010;size)&#010;&#010;** Story&#010;    * [MSCMPUB-4] - Need a working example for GitHub/gh-pages, preferably &#010;naturally linked to natural site lifecycle, and multi-module&#010;&#010;** Task&#010;    * [MSCMPUB-3] - Upgrade to SCM-1.9&#010;&#010;Enjoy,&#010;&#010;-The Apache Maven team&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Melvyn de Kort &lt;mel...@mdekort.nl&gt;
Subject  :-Maven multi-module site
contents:- Hi all,&#010;&#010;We have a large multi-module project with over 90 submodules.&#010;When we run a mvn site-deploy command, the build will run out of memory.&#010;This used to work, but I guess we reached a threshold.&#010;&#010;Our idea is to split the site command in groups of modules, or maybe build&#010;every module separately.&#010;However, we still want to have an aggregated site in the end.&#010;&#010;Does anybody have experience in how to configure and run such a setup?&#010;&#010;Kind regards,&#010;&#010;Melvyn de Kort&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Maven multi-module site
contents:- On 05/02/2014 4:22 AM, Melvyn de Kort wrote:&#010;&gt; Hi all,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We have a large multi-module project with over 90 submodules.&#010;&gt; When we run a mvn site-deploy command, the build will run out of memory.&#010;&gt; This used to work, but I guess we reached a threshold.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Our idea is to split the site command in groups of modules, or maybe build&#010;&gt; every module separately.&#010;&gt; However, we still want to have an aggregated site in the end.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Does anybody have experience in how to configure and run such a setup?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Kind regards,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Melvyn de Kort&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Have you increased the memory to the max that your virtual memory can &#010;support?&#010;This does not give you a "better" structure but should solve your &#010;current bottleneck.&#010;Memory is very cheap. Virtual memory is even cheaper.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Release Plugin DOES NOT USE IT.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; We should really have a new release of m-r-p that forces the use of&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; current scm-providers cause I can see this problem only increasing as&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Name  :- TenLeftFingers &lt;jarlathre...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Build is successful but can't run?
contents:- When I build my Maven project with dependencies (using Netbeans but pointing&#010;to a vanilla Maven installation), I get BUILD SUCCESS. Great!&#010;&#010;When I try to /run /it in the form of *java -cp&#010;target/my-app-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar com.mycompany.app.App* I get this:&#010;*java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/slf4j/LoggerFactory*&#010;&#010;How come this dependency fails at this late stage?&#010;&#010;Trying to run the class from NetBeans itself gives a different error:&#010;*Failed to execute goal org.codehaus.mojo:exec-maven-plugin:1.2.1:exec*&#010;&#010;Please enlighten me as to how I can run this thing. It works fine in Eclipse&#010;when I run it as a Java Application - but Eclipse has other problems that&#010;I'm avoiding so I need to do this either from CLI or NetBeans (preferable).&#010;&#010;Thanks,&#010;Ten&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Build-is-successful-but-can-t-run-tp5783294.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Wayne Fay &lt;wayne...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Build is successful but can't run?
contents:- &gt; When I try to /run /it in the form of *java -cp&#010;&gt; target/my-app-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar com.mycompany.app.App* I get this:&#010;&gt; *java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/slf4j/LoggerFactory*&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; How come this dependency fails at this late stage?&#010;&#010;This line says "run Java with the classpath being my-app.jar and use&#010;com.mycompany.app.App as the main/entry class."&#010;&#010;Java says OK and happily tries to run your file. Then immediately&#010;discovers that the classpath you have specified does not include one&#010;or more classes - classes that you have declared as dependencies and&#010;by using Maven to help manage during the compile process you don't&#010;need to worry about the details of your classpath. This is exactly&#010;correct.&#010;&#010;But now you are dealing with run-time, not compile-time. Until now,&#010;Maven has ensured that various dependencies are in the classpath --&#010;but note that you are not running Maven, you are running Java, and&#010;java does not know anything about Maven's pom and the dependencies&#010;etc. So now you need to manually build out that classpath to run your&#010;code with a lot more things in the -cp parameter.&#010;&#010;A far simpler approach is to use the maven-exec-plugin and again let&#010;Maven help with your run-time dependencies. Here is a link to that&#010;documentation - I'm sure you can sort it out by click a few links and&#010;doing 5 minutes of reading:&#010;http://mojo.codehaus.org/exec-maven-plugin/&#010;&#010;Wayne&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Mark Eggers &lt;its_toas...@yahoo.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Build is successful but can't run?
contents:- On 2/5/2014 9:52 AM, TenLeftFingers wrote:&#010;&gt; When I build my Maven project with dependencies (using Netbeans but pointing&#010;&gt; to a vanilla Maven installation), I get BUILD SUCCESS. Great!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; When I try to /run /it in the form of *java -cp&#010;&gt; target/my-app-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar com.mycompany.app.App* I get this:&#010;&gt; *java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/slf4j/LoggerFactory*&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; How come this dependency fails at this late stage?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Trying to run the class from NetBeans itself gives a different error:&#010;&gt; *Failed to execute goal org.codehaus.mojo:exec-maven-plugin:1.2.1:exec*&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Please enlighten me as to how I can run this thing. It works fine in Eclipse&#010;&gt; when I run it as a Java Application - but Eclipse has other problems that&#010;&gt; I'm avoiding so I need to do this either from CLI or NetBeans (preferable).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks,&#010;&gt; Ten&#010;&#010;I normally use NetBeans . . . .&#010;&#010;One way to handle this (and it'll end up looking like a standard &#010;NetBeans project) is the following.&#010;&#010;1. Modify the manifest via the maven-jar-plugin&#010;&#010;&lt;plugin&gt;&#010;   &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;   &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-jar-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;   &lt;version&gt;2.4&lt;/version&gt;&#010;   &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;     &lt;archive&gt;&#010;       &lt;manifest&#010;&lt;addDefaultImplementationEntries&gt;true&lt;/addDefaultImplementationEntries&gt;&#010;         &lt;mainClass&gt;main-class-name&lt;/mainClass&gt;&#010;         &lt;addClasspath&gt;true&lt;/addClasspath&gt;&#010;         &lt;classpathPrefix&gt;lib/&lt;/classpathPrefix&gt;&#010;       &lt;/manifest&gt;&#010;     &lt;/archive&gt;&#010;   &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;2. Use the maven-dependency-plugin to copy over the libraries&#010;&#010;&lt;plugin&gt;&#010;   &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;   &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-dependency-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;   &lt;version&gt;2.8&lt;/version&gt;&#010;   &lt;executions&gt;&#010;     &lt;execution&gt;&#010;       &lt;phase&gt;package&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;       &lt;goals&gt;&#010;         &lt;goal&gt;copy-dependencies&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;       &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;       &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&lt;outputDirectory&gt;${project.build.directory}/lib&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;         &lt;includeScope&gt;compile&lt;/includeScope&gt;&#010;       &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;     &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;   &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;&lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;3. Run from the command line to test&#010;&#010;mvn package&#010;cd target&#010;java -jar jarFileName.jar&#010;&#010;To ship the binaries, use the maven-assembly-plugin and package both the &#010;JAR and the supporting libraries. That way when someone unpacks the zip &#010;(or tar or tar.gz, etc.), the directory structure will be maintained.&#010;&#010;Here's an assembly.xml file. I've left out the xml namespace declarations:&#010;&#010;&lt;?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?&gt;&#010;&lt;assembly&gt;&#010;     &lt;id&gt;bin&lt;/id&gt;&#010;     &lt;formats&gt;&#010;         &lt;format&gt;tar.gz&lt;/format&gt;&#010;         &lt;format&gt;zip&lt;/format&gt;&#010;     &lt;/formats&gt;&#010;     &lt;includeBaseDirectory&gt;false&lt;/includeBaseDirectory&gt;&#010;     &lt;includeSiteDirectory&gt;false&lt;/includeSiteDirectory&gt;&#010;     &lt;fileSets&gt;&#010;         &lt;fileSet&gt;&#010;             &lt;directory&gt;target&lt;/directory&gt;&#010;             &lt;outputDirectory&gt;&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;             &lt;includes&gt;&#010;                 &lt;include&gt;*.jar&lt;/include&gt;&#010;                 &lt;include&gt;lib/&lt;/include&gt;&#010;             &lt;/includes&gt;&#010;         &lt;/fileSet&gt;&#010;     &lt;/fileSets&gt;&#010;&lt;/assembly&gt;&#010;&#010;Other ways include creating an uber-jar.&#010;&#010;. . . . just my two cents.&#010;/mde/&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- TenLeftFingers &lt;jarlathre...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Build is successful but can't run?
contents:- Hi Mark,&#010;&#010;Thanks for that. I changed the pom as you suggested. When I ran with java&#010;-jar myApp.jar I got the output:&#010;*Failed to load Main-Class manifest attribute from target/myApp.jar*&#010;&#010;I opened the manifest and the *Main-Class* attribute was entered as&#010;*mainClass.* So I changed it to the former and that got rid of that error.&#010;But now  I *still *get the original error.&#010;&#010;The only pom change I'm not sure about is&#010;*&lt;classpathPrefix&gt;lib/&lt;/classpathPrefix&gt;*. What classes is that classpath&#010;trying to capture?&#010;&#010;Thanks,&#010;Ten&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Feb 5, 2014 at 7:01 PM, Mark Eggers [via Maven] &lt;&#010;ml-node+s40175n5783298h15@n5.nabble.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; On 2/5/2014 9:52 AM, TenLeftFingers wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; When I build my Maven project with dependencies (using Netbeans but&#010;&gt; pointing&#010;&gt; &gt; to a vanilla Maven installation), I get BUILD SUCCESS. Great!&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; When I try to /run /it in the form of *java -cp&#010;&gt; &gt; target/my-app-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar com.mycompany.app.App* I get this:&#010;&gt; &gt; *java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/slf4j/LoggerFactory*&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; How come this dependency fails at this late stage?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Trying to run the class from NetBeans itself gives a different error:&#010;&gt; &gt; *Failed to execute goal org.codehaus.mojo:exec-maven-plugin:1.2.1:exec*&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Please enlighten me as to how I can run this thing. It works fine in&#010;&gt; Eclipse&#010;&gt; &gt; when I run it as a Java Application - but Eclipse has other problems&#010;&gt; that&#010;&gt; &gt; I'm avoiding so I need to do this either from CLI or NetBeans&#010;&gt; (preferable).&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Thanks,&#010;&gt; &gt; Ten&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I normally use NetBeans . . . .&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; One way to handle this (and it'll end up looking like a standard&#010;&gt; NetBeans project) is the following.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 1. Modify the manifest via the maven-jar-plugin&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;    &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;    &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-jar-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;    &lt;version&gt;2.4&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;    &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;archive&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;manifest&#010;&gt; &lt;addDefaultImplementationEntries&gt;true&lt;/addDefaultImplementationEntries&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;mainClass&gt;main-class-name&lt;/mainClass&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;addClasspath&gt;true&lt;/addClasspath&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;classpathPrefix&gt;lib/&lt;/classpathPrefix&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;/manifest&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/archive&gt;&#010;&gt;    &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 2. Use the maven-dependency-plugin to copy over the libraries&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;    &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;    &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-dependency-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;    &lt;version&gt;2.8&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;    &lt;executions&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;execution&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;phase&gt;package&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;goals&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;goal&gt;copy-dependencies&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;outputDirectory&gt;${project.build.directory}/lib&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;includeScope&gt;compile&lt;/includeScope&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;&gt;    &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 3. Run from the command line to test&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; mvn package&#010;&gt; cd target&#010;&gt; java -jar jarFileName.jar&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; To ship the binaries, use the maven-assembly-plugin and package both the&#010;&gt; JAR and the supporting libraries. That way when someone unpacks the zip&#010;&gt; (or tar or tar.gz, etc.), the directory structure will be maintained.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Here's an assembly.xml file. I've left out the xml namespace declarations:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;assembly&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;id&gt;bin&lt;/id&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;formats&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;format&gt;tar.gz&lt;/format&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;format&gt;zip&lt;/format&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/formats&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;includeBaseDirectory&gt;false&lt;/includeBaseDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;includeSiteDirectory&gt;false&lt;/includeSiteDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;fileSets&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;directory&gt;target&lt;/directory&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;outputDirectory&gt;&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;includes&gt;&#010;&gt;                  &lt;include&gt;*.jar&lt;/include&gt;&#010;&gt;                  &lt;include&gt;lib/&lt;/include&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;/includes&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;/fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/fileSets&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;/assembly&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Other ways include creating an uber-jar.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Name  :- Mark Eggers &lt;its_toas...@yahoo.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Build is successful but can't run?
contents:- On 2/5/2014 11:40 AM, TenLeftFingers wrote:&#010;&gt; Hi Mark,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks for that. I changed the pom as you suggested. When I ran with java&#010;&gt; -jar myApp.jar I got the output:&#010;&gt; *Failed to load Main-Class manifest attribute from target/myApp.jar*&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;A couple of things:&#010;&#010;1. the main-class-name was supposed to be your main class&#010;&#010;&gt; I opened the manifest and the *Main-Class* attribute was entered as&#010;&gt; *mainClass.* So I changed it to the former and that got rid of that error.&#010;&gt; But now  I *still *get the original error.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The only pom change I'm not sure about is&#010;&gt; *&lt;classpathPrefix&gt;lib/&lt;/classpathPrefix&gt;*. What classes is that classpath&#010;&gt; trying to capture?&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;You need to change to the project target directory in order for it to &#010;run and find the supporting jars.&#010;&#010;The classpathPrefix line sets where to look for additional JAR files. It &#010;is relative to where you are.&#010;&#010;Maven compiles and packages your program into a JAR. It copies all of &#010;the supporting JAR files listed in your dependencies into target/lib.&#010;&#010;Before you run, make sure that target/lib exists and has all of the JAR &#010;files you need.&#010;&#010;Now, change to the target directory on the command line, and execute the &#010;program. The keys here are the following:&#010;&#010;1. change to the target directory on the command line&#010;2. execute the program with the following:&#010;&#010;java -jar my-app-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar&#010;&#010;Now the lib directory will be in the correct relative path, and your &#010;dependencies should be found.&#010;&#010;&gt; Thanks,&#010;&gt; Ten&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;The exec plugin (http://mojo.codehaus.org/exec-maven-plugin/) as Wayne &#010;has mentioned is another way to accomplish this. This will help you run &#010;from within an IDE or by using mvn exec:exec, but it won't help you &#010;package and ship your code out for other users.&#010;&#010;You can combine both. I've not used the exec-maven-plugin, so creating &#010;the plugin configuration for that is left as an exercise for the reader. &#010;However, the documentation on the link listed above should get you started.&#010;&#010;/mde/&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Wed, Feb 5, 2014 at 7:01 PM, Mark Eggers [via Maven] &lt;&#010;&gt; ml-node+s40175n5783298h15@n5.nabble.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 2/5/2014 9:52 AM, TenLeftFingers wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; When I build my Maven project with dependencies (using Netbeans but&#010;&gt;&gt; pointing&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; to a vanilla Maven installation), I get BUILD SUCCESS. Great!&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; When I try to /run /it in the form of *java -cp&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; target/my-app-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar com.mycompany.app.App* I get this:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; *java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/slf4j/LoggerFactory*&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; How come this dependency fails at this late stage?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Trying to run the class from NetBeans itself gives a different error:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; *Failed to execute goal org.codehaus.mojo:exec-maven-plugin:1.2.1:exec*&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Please enlighten me as to how I can run this thing. It works fine in&#010;&gt;&gt; Eclipse&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; when I run it as a Java Application - but Eclipse has other problems&#010;&gt;&gt; that&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm avoiding so I need to do this either from CLI or NetBeans&#010;&gt;&gt; (preferable).&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Ten&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I normally use NetBeans . . . .&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; One way to handle this (and it'll end up looking like a standard&#010;&gt;&gt; NetBeans project) is the following.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 1. Modify the manifest via the maven-jar-plugin&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-jar-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     &lt;version&gt;2.4&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;       &lt;archive&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;         &lt;manifest&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;addDefaultImplementationEntries&gt;true&lt;/addDefaultImplementationEntries&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;           &lt;mainClass&gt;main-class-name&lt;/mainClass&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;           &lt;addClasspath&gt;true&lt;/addClasspath&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;           &lt;classpathPrefix&gt;lib/&lt;/classpathPrefix&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;         &lt;/manifest&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;       &lt;/archive&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 2. Use the maven-dependency-plugin to copy over the libraries&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-dependency-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     &lt;version&gt;2.8&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     &lt;executions&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;       &lt;execution&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;         &lt;phase&gt;package&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;         &lt;goals&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;           &lt;goal&gt;copy-dependencies&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;         &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;         &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;outputDirectory&gt;${project.build.directory}/lib&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;           &lt;includeScope&gt;compile&lt;/includeScope&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;         &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;       &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;     &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 3. Run from the command line to test&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; mvn package&#010;&gt;&gt; cd target&#010;&gt;&gt; java -jar jarFileName.jar&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; To ship the binaries, use the maven-assembly-plugin and package both the&#010;&gt;&gt; JAR and the supporting libraries. That way when someone unpacks the zip&#010;&gt;&gt; (or tar or tar.gz, etc.), the directory structure will be maintained.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Here's an assembly.xml file. I've left out the xml namespace declarations:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;assembly&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;       &lt;id&gt;bin&lt;/id&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;       &lt;formats&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;           &lt;format&gt;tar.gz&lt;/format&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;           &lt;format&gt;zip&lt;/format&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;       &lt;/formats&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;       &lt;includeBaseDirectory&gt;false&lt;/includeBaseDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;       &lt;includeSiteDirectory&gt;false&lt;/includeSiteDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;       &lt;fileSets&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;           &lt;fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;               &lt;directory&gt;target&lt;/directory&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;               &lt;outputDirectory&gt;&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;               &lt;includes&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;                   &lt;include&gt;*.jar&lt;/include&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;                   &lt;include&gt;lib/&lt;/include&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;               &lt;/includes&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;           &lt;/fileSet&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;       &lt;/fileSets&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;/assembly&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Other ways include creating an uber-jar.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; . . . . just my two cents.&#010;&gt;&gt; /mde/&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Wayne Fay &lt;wayne...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Build is successful but can't run?
contents:- &gt; *Failed to load Main-Class manifest attribute from target/myApp.jar*&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I opened the manifest and the *Main-Class* attribute was entered as&#010;&gt; *mainClass.* So I changed it to the former and that got rid of that error.&#010;&gt; But now  I *still *get the original error.&#010;&#010;You should specify the fully qualified main class eg:&#010;com.mycompany.app.App&#010;in the mainClass field/parameter to the plugin.&#010;&#010;Wayne&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- TenLeftFingers &lt;jarlathre...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Build is successful but can't run?
contents:- "You should specify the fully qualified main class eg:&#010;com.mycompany.app.App&#010;in the mainClass field/parameter to the plugin."&#010;"1. the main-class-name was supposed to be your main class"&#010;Let me clarify. The entry appears in the manifest as:&#010;mainClass: fully.qualified.path.to.MyApp&#010;instead of&#010;Main-Class: fully.qualified.path.to.MyApp&#010;&#010;I've changed it in the pom (I thought that the tag was a fixed keyword so I&#010;didn't change it there initially).&#010;&#010;"The classpathPrefix line sets where to look for additional JAR files. It&#010;is relative to where you are."&#010;So relative to where I execute my java -jar ... command from. Okay, I have&#010;that. I'm executing from the directory above (..) the target.&#010;&#010;"Maven compiles and packages your program into a JAR. It copies all of&#010;the supporting JAR files listed in your dependencies into target/lib.&#010;Before you run, make sure that target/lib exists and has all of the JAR&#010;files you need."&#010;Yep, they're all there. Including the jar which contains the class it says&#010;it can't load and I can see that that class is present in the jar.&#010;&#010;"The exec plugin (http://mojo.codehaus.org/exec-maven-plugin/) as Wayne&#010;has mentioned is another way to accomplish this. This will help you run&#010;from within an IDE or by using mvn exec:exec, but it won't help you&#010;package and ship your code out for other users."&#010;Once I get this running from the command line, this will be an option that&#010;I want to use. I'm still getting ClassNotFoundException though. I'm&#010;guessing that since I _can_ see the dependencies that this line must be the&#010;culprit:&#010;"&lt;classpathPrefix&gt;target/&lt;/classpathPrefix&gt;"&#010;I'm going to try target/lib now.&#010;&#010;This is a sample client so packaging isn't too important at this point.&#010;Good to know, thank you.&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Feb 5, 2014 at 10:17 PM, Wayne Fay [via Maven] &lt;&#010;ml-node+s40175n5783328h45@n5.nabble.com&gt; contents:- I have just noticed that the dependency it complains about does not exist&#010;in my .m2 folder. I don't know how Eclipse is executing this project but I&#010;would have expected mvn package to pull in that dependency to the local&#010;repository.&#010;&#010;&#010;On Thu, Feb 6, 2014 at 10:02 AM, Jarlath Reidy &lt;jarlathreidy@gmail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; "You should specify the fully qualified main class eg:&#010;&gt; com.mycompany.app.App&#010;&gt; in the mainClass field/parameter to the plugin."&#010;&gt; "1. the main-class-name was supposed to be your main class"&#010;&gt; Let me clarify. The entry appears in the manifest as:&#010;&gt; mainClass: fully.qualified.path.to.MyApp&#010;&gt; instead of&#010;&gt; Main-Class: fully.qualified.path.to.MyApp&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I've changed it in the pom (I thought that the tag was a fixed keyword so&#010;&gt; I didn't change it there initially).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "The classpathPrefix line sets where to look for additional JAR files. It&#010;&gt; is relative to where you are."&#010;&gt; So relative to where I execute my java -jar ... command from. Okay, I have&#010;&gt; that. I'm executing from the directory above (..) the target.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "Maven compiles and packages your program into a JAR. It copies all of&#010;&gt; the supporting JAR files listed in your dependencies into target/lib.&#010;&gt; Before you run, make sure that target/lib exists and has all of the JAR&#010;&gt; files you need."&#010;&gt; Yep, they're all there. Including the jar which contains the class it says&#010;&gt; it can't load and I can see that that class is present in the jar.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "The exec plugin (http://mojo.codehaus.org/exec-maven-plugin/) as Wayne&#010;&gt; has mentioned is another way to accomplish this. This will help you run&#010;&gt; from within an IDE or by using mvn exec:exec, but it won't help you&#010;&gt; package and ship your code out for other users."&#010;&gt; Once I get this running from the command line, this will be an option that&#010;&gt; I want to use. I'm still getting ClassNotFoundException though. ================

Name  :- Wayne Fay &lt;wayne...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Build is successful but can't run?
contents:- &gt; I added the maven-assembly-plugin as described here:&#010;&gt; http://stackoverflow.com/questions/574594/how-can-i-create-an-executable-jar-with-dependencies-using-maven&#010;&gt; and now the dependencies are bundled within the jar. Thanks for your help&#010;&#010;This is a fine approach. I still maintain the exec plugin is a great&#010;option for these types of uses - so long as you (the developer) are&#010;the one who needs to run the app. If you want to deliver it to a&#010;third-party in a single executable jar format, then assembly and other&#010;plugins are generally superior.&#010;&#010;Wayne&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- TenLeftFingers &lt;jarlathre...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Build is successful but can't run?
contents:- Thanks Wayne. As I say, something isn't connecting when I try without the&#010;maven-assembly-plugin. I may figure it out in the future. Thank you Mark&#010;also.&#010;&#010;&#010;On Thu, Feb 6, 2014 at 2:43 PM, Wayne Fay [via Maven] &lt;&#010;ml-node+s40175n5783375h2@n5.nabble.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt;  &gt; I added the maven-assembly-plugin as described here:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; http://stackoverflow.com/questions/574594/how-can-i-create-an-executable-jar-with-dependencies-using-maven&#010;&gt; &gt; and now the dependencies are bundled within the jar. Thanks for your&#010;&gt; help&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; This is a fine approach. I still maintain the exec plugin is a great&#010;&gt; option for these types of uses - so long as you (the developer) are&#010;&gt; the one who needs to run the app. If you want to deliver it to a&#010;&gt; third-party in a single executable jar format, then assembly and other&#010;&gt; plugins are generally superior.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Wayne&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: [hidden email]&lt;http://user/SendEmail.jtp?type=node&amp;node=5783375&amp;i=0&gt;&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: [hidden email]&lt;http://user/SendEmail.jtp?type=node&amp;node=5783375&amp;i=1&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ------------------------------&#010;&gt;  If you reply to this email, your message will be added to the discussion&#010;&gt; below:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Build-is-successful-but-can-t-run-tp5783294p5783375.html&#010;&gt;  To unsubscribe from Build is successful but can't run?, click here&lt;http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/template/NamlServlet.jtp?macro=unsubscribe_by_code&amp;node=5783294&amp;code=amFybGF0aHJlaWR5QGdtYWlsLmNvbXw1NzgzMjk0fDEyMDg3OTQ0MDQ=&gt;&#010;&gt; .&#010;&gt; NAML&lt;http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/template/NamlServlet.jtp?macro=macro_viewer&amp;id=instant_html%21nabble%3Aemail.naml&amp;base=nabble.naml.namespaces.BasicNamespace-nabble.view.web.template.NabbleNamespace-nabble.view.web.template.NodeNamespace&amp;breadcrumbs=notify_subscribers%21nabble%3Aemail.naml-instant_emails%21nabble%3Aemail.naml-send_instant_email%21nabble%3Aemail.naml&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Build-is-successful-but-can-t-run-tp5783294p5783377.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Build is successful but can't run?
contents:- On 06/02/2014 9:42 AM, Wayne Fay wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; I added the maven-assembly-plugin as described here:&#010;&gt;&gt; http://stackoverflow.com/questions/574594/how-can-i-create-an-executable-jar-with-dependencies-using-maven&#010;&gt;&gt; and now the dependencies are bundled within the jar. Thanks for your help&#010;&gt; This is a fine approach. I still maintain the exec plugin is a great&#010;&gt; option for these types of uses - so long as you (the developer) are&#010;&gt; the one who needs to run the app. If you want to deliver it to a&#010;&gt; third-party in a single executable jar format, then assembly and other&#010;&gt; plugins are generally superior.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Wayne&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;It is also a good idea to use an installer to package an app for delivery.&#010;IzPack is a free installer that has a Maven plug-in to help  ease the &#010;setup.&#010;&#010;It allows you to build the code in an OS neutral fashion and make the &#010;installer deal with your OS-dependent bits such as configuration files &#010;and registry entries.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Marko Rantanen &lt;markorantane...@yahoo.fi&gt;
Subject  :-Custom plugin, installation of pom.xml failing
contents:- Hi all,&#010;&#010;We have implemented a custom Maven plugin (build_settings) which is supposed to be used in&#010;the other project (base). The plugin has custom lifecycle. At first, a mojo generates resources.&#010;That phase is working as expected. Second, we want to install pom.xml but this one is failing.&#010;&#010;When trying  - mvn install&#010;&#010;the following error is received:&#010;&#010;org.apache.maven.lifecycle.LifecycleExecutionException: Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-install-plugin:2.3.1:install&#010;(default-install) on project base: The packaging for this project did not assign a file to&#010;the build artifact&#010;&#010;&#010;How should installation of the pom file be handled? We are using Maven 3.0.5.&#010;&#010;The following custom.xml is in plugins/build_settings/src/main/resources/META-INF/plexus:&#010;&#010;&lt;component-set&gt;&#010;    &lt;components&gt;&#010;    &lt;component&gt;&#010;          &lt;role&gt;org.apache.maven.lifecycle.mapping.LifecycleMapping&lt;/role&gt;&#010;         &lt;role-hint&gt;build_settings&lt;/role-hint&gt;&#010;   &lt;component&gt;&#010;&#010;         &lt;role&gt;org.apache.maven.artifact.handler.ArtifactHandler&lt;/role&gt;&#010;         &lt;role-hint&gt;build_settings&lt;/role-hint&gt;&#010;         &lt;implementation&gt;org.apache.maven.artifact.handler.DefaultArtifactHandler&lt;/implementation&gt;&#010;         &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;   &lt;/components&gt;&#010;&#010;&lt;/component-set&gt;&#010;&#010;pom.xml in test/base:&#010;&#010;&lt;project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"&gt;&#010;...&#010;    &lt;parent&gt;&#010;&#010;      &lt;groupId&gt;test&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;      &lt;artifactId&gt;settings&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;      &lt;version&gt;DYNAMIC-SNAPSHOT&lt;/version&gt;&#010;      &lt;relativePath&gt;../settings/pom.xml&lt;/relativePath&gt;&#010;    &lt;/parent&gt;&#010;    &lt;artifactId&gt;base&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&#010;    &lt;packaging&gt;build_settings&lt;/packaging&gt;&#010;&#010;&lt;/project&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;pom.xml in test/settings:&#010;&#010;&lt;project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"&gt;&#010;&#010;...&#010;    &lt;groupId&gt;test&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;    &lt;artifactId&gt;settings&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;    &lt;version&gt;DYNAMIC-SNAPSHOT&lt;/version&gt;&#010;    &lt;packaging&gt;pom&lt;/packaging&gt;&#010;&#010;...&#010;    &lt;build&gt;&#010;&#010;...&#010;      &lt;plugins&gt;&#010;&#010; Subject  :-Dependency to archetype not resolved?
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;I have a website project that I build with the maven-site-plugin. Within &#010;the site, a maven repository is created by using the copy-dependencies &#010;goal of the maven-dependency-plugin and by defining the artifacts as a &#010;project dependency. (If anyone has a better idea, plz let me know.)&#010;&#010;This works for all kind of artifacts (jar, war, ear, sources, zip, pdf, &#010;maven-plugin), EXCEPT a maven-archetype.&#010;The declared dependency looks like this:&#010;&#010;   &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;      &lt;groupId&gt;de.ars.daojones.maven.archetypes&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;      &lt;artifactId&gt;daojones-java-archetype&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;      &lt;version&gt;${daojones.version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;      &lt;type&gt;maven-archetype&lt;/type&gt;&#010;      &lt;!-- make it non-transitive --&gt;&#010;      &lt;optional&gt;true&lt;/optional&gt;&#010;    &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&#010;The artifact is within the local repository. I can find it within the M2E &#010;dialogs (e.g. to add a dependency within the POM editor). But when running &#010;"mvn site" on the project, I get this error:&#010;&#010;[ERROR] Failed to execute goal on project daojones-site: Could not resolve &#010;dependencies for project de.ars.daojones:daojones-site:jar:2.0.0-SNAPSHOT: &#010;Could not find artifact &#010;de.ars.daojones.maven.archetypes:daojones-java-archetype:maven-archetype:2.0.0-SNAPSHOT &#010;-&gt; contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;Is it possible to activate a profile programmatically from a Mojo (or a&#010;plugin lifecycle extension) in Maven 3?  I am trying to understand whether&#010;or not I can add the "build.plugins" from an inherited (but inactive)&#010;profile to the currently executing project during the validate phase. I&#010;know I can do this with a custom ProfileActivator but I'd really like to do&#010;this in a plugin to simplify sharing this functionality. I don't mind if&#010;this involves using some internal APIs but I don't know where to start&#010;looking. Any tips are greatly appreciated.&#010;&#010;Best,&#010;Shahim&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Martin Hoeller &lt;mar...@xss.co.at&gt;
Subject  :-Best practices for Java EE 7 dependencies
contents:- Hi!&#010;&#010;I'm wondering what the best practices are for specifying Java EE 7&#010;dependencies in my modules.&#010;&#010;There is the so called BOM (bill of materials) POM: javax:javaee-api:7.0&#010;which lists all API submodules required for JEE7. Specifying this in my&#010;module as&#010;&#010;  &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;    &lt;groupId&gt;javax&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;    &lt;artifactId&gt;javaee-api&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;    &lt;version&gt;7.0&lt;/version&gt;&#010;  &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&#010;works and is the least work for me. However, this way I got all JEE APIs&#010;on the CLASSPATH even if I just need a few of them. Further on, the&#010;actual dependencies are now transitive which is (IMHO) not fully correct.&#010;Should I better specify the exact dependencies and investigate some more&#010;work in POM maintainance? What would this gain me?&#010;&#010;What do you think?&#010;&#010;- martin&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Samuli Saarinen &lt;samuli.saari...@remion.com&gt;
Subject  :-RE: Best practices for Java EE 7 dependencies
contents:- Hi,&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;You could import the dependencies  in dependencyManagement as described in [1] and only declare&#010;needed dependencies in the project.&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;Cheers &#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;Samuli &#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;[1] http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-dependency-mechanism.html#Importing_Dependencies&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;-----Original Message-----&#013;&#010;From: Martin Hoeller [mailto:martin@xss.co.at] &#013;&#010;Sent: 7. helmikuuta 2014 11:33&#013;&#010;To: Maven Users List&#013;&#010;Subject: Best practices for Java EE 7 dependencies&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;Hi!&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;I'm wondering what the best practices are for specifying Java EE 7&#013;&#010;dependencies in my modules.&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;There is the so called BOM (bill of materials) POM: javax:javaee-api:7.0&#013;&#010;which lists all API submodules required for JEE7. Specifying this in my&#013;&#010;module as&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;  &lt;dependency&gt;&#013;&#010;    &lt;groupId&gt;javax&lt;/groupId&gt;&#013;&#010;    &lt;artifactId&gt;javaee-api&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#013;&#010;    &lt;version&gt;7.0&lt;/version&gt;&#013;&#010;  &lt;/dependency&gt;&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;works and is the least work for me. However, this way I got all JEE APIs&#013;&#010;on the CLASSPATH even if I just need a few of them. Further on, the&#013;&#010;actual dependencies are now transitive which is (IMHO) not fully correct.&#013;&#010;Should I better specify the exact dependencies and investigate some more&#013;&#010;work in POM maintainance? What would this gain me?&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;What do you think?&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;- martin&#013;&#010;

================

Name  :- Thomas Broyer &lt;t.bro...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Best practices for Java EE 7 dependencies
contents:- Because javax:javaee-api:7.0 doesn't use dependencyManagement, but declares&#010;straight dependencies, I don't think &lt;scope&gt;import&lt;/scope&gt; would work (or&#010;be appropriate); however you should be able to declare javax:javaee-api:1.0&#010;as a managed dependency (in &lt;dependencyManagement&gt;, but without any&#010;specific scope, i.e. &lt;scope&gt;compile&lt;/scope&gt; as it's the default) and then&#010;declare needed dependencies; I'm not sure that'd work either though. So I&#010;think the only real choice is to add it as a dependency, with&#010;&lt;scope&gt;provided&lt;/scope&gt;; you'll have all the JARs in the classpath at build&#010;time, but only at build time.&#010;&#010;&#010;On Fri, Feb 7, 2014 at 11:56 AM, Samuli Saarinen &lt;samuli.saarinen@remion.com&#010;&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; You could import the dependencies  in dependencyManagement as described in&#010;&gt; [1] and only declare needed dependencies in the project.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Cheers&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Samuli&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; [1]&#010;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-dependency-mechanism.html#Importing_Dependencies&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -----Original Message-----&#010;&gt; From: Martin Hoeller [mailto:martin@xss.co.at]&#010;&gt; Sent: 7. helmikuuta 2014 11:33&#010;&gt; To: Maven Users List&#010;&gt; Subject: Best practices for Java EE 7 dependencies&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Hi!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'm wondering what the best practices are for specifying Java EE 7&#010;&gt; dependencies in my modules.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; There is the so called BOM (bill of materials) POM: javax:javaee-api:7.0&#010;&gt; which lists all API submodules required for JEE7. Specifying this in my&#010;&gt; module as&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;groupId&gt;javax&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;artifactId&gt;javaee-api&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;version&gt;7.0&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; works and is the least work for me. However, this way I got all JEE APIs&#010;&gt; on the CLASSPATH even if I just need a few of them. Further on, the&#010;&gt; actual dependencies are now transitive which is (IMHO) not fully correct.&#010;&gt; Should I better specify the exact dependencies and investigate some more&#010;&gt; work in POM maintainance? What would this gain me?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; What do you think?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - martin&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Thomas Broyer&#010;/tɔ.ma.bʁwa.je/ &lt;http://xn--nna.ma.xn--bwa-xxb.je/&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Subject  :-Re: Best practices for Java EE 7 dependencies
contents:- Hi!&#010;&#010;Thanks for your answers so far.&#010;&#010;Am Fri, 7 Feb 2014 11:17:22 -0600 schrieb Wayne Fay &lt;waynefay@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; &gt; Should I better specify the exact dependencies and investigate some&#010;&gt; &gt; more work in POM maintainance? What would this gain me?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; You answered your own question, congrats! :)&#010;&#010;Well, if I got you right, you mean it won't gain me anything. Right?&#010;&#010;But I just found out a first problem that arises with the use&#010;javaee-api: "mvn dependency:analyze" reports used undeclared&#010;dependencies :(&#010;&#010;It's totally clear why it reports these: annotation classes like&#010;@Stateless are in the javax.ejb-api JAR and javaee-api declares a&#010;dependency to it but my actual module does not.&#010;&#010;So using javaee-api instead of the finer grained POMs DOES CAUSE&#010;problems. Or am I doing something wrong here?&#010;&#010;many thanks,&#010;- martin&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Wayne Fay &lt;wayne...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Best practices for Java EE 7 dependencies
contents:- &gt;&gt; &gt; Should I better specify the exact dependencies and investigate some&#010;&gt;&gt; &gt; more work in POM maintainance? What would this gain me?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; You answered your own question, congrats! :)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Well, if I got you right, you mean it won't gain me anything. Right?&#010;&#010;I made no such statement. I was simply agreeing that you should&#010;"specify the exact dependencies."&#010;&#010;&gt; So using javaee-api instead of the finer grained POMs DOES CAUSE&#010;&gt; problems. Or am I doing something wrong here?&#010;&#010;Probably you should just use the finer grained POMs. Or better, make a&#010;parent project, use depMgmt, specify versions there, then only&#010;&lt;depend&gt; on the correct things in your various modules. It is not&#010;*that* much more work.&#010;&#010;Wayne&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Reto Hablützel &lt;ret...@rethab.ch&gt;
Subject  :-maven-ear-plugin silently overrides libraries
contents:- Hi there,&#010;&#010;I built an ear using the maven-ear-plugin (version 2.6).&#010;&#010;The ear is configured such that it includes two libraries into the lib&#010;folder, both with the same artifactId as well as the same version, but a&#010;different groupId. Now if I simply call 'mvn package' only the first one is&#010;included, but no warning whatsoever appears. Only once I turn on debugging&#010;(mvn --debug package), I see one subtle message:&#010;[DEBUG] Skipping artifact [jar:com.foo:bar:1.0] as it is already up to date&#010;at [lib/bar-1.0.jar]&#010;&#010;Wouldn't it make sense to either include the groupId in the filename or at&#010;least make a check (that includes the groupId) beforehand if there are any&#010;conflicts?&#010;&#010;Cheers,&#010;Reto&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: maven-ear-plugin silently overrides libraries
contents:- If your IDE supports Maven (Eclipse/STS for example), you will see the &#010;conflict in the dependency hierarchy view and you can fix it with the &#010;right exclusions.&#010;&#010;It is almost always worth a quick look through the dependency hierarchy &#010;view if you use a lot of third party libraries.&#010;Not everyone updates their dependencies when they build a shareable library.&#010;You can sometimes get some pretty old versions of things dragged in with &#010;the latest version of otherwise well-written libraries.&#010;Exclusions need to be added to get what you want in your artifacts.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;On 07/02/2014 9:21 AM, Reto Hablützel wrote:&#010;&gt; Hi there,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I built an ear using the maven-ear-plugin (version 2.6).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The ear is configured such that it includes two libraries into the lib&#010;&gt; folder, both with the same artifactId as well as the same version, but a&#010;&gt; different groupId. Now if I simply call 'mvn package' only the first one is&#010;&gt; included, but no warning whatsoever appears. Only once I turn on debugging&#010;&gt; (mvn --debug package), I see one subtle message:&#010;&gt; [DEBUG] Skipping artifact [jar:com.foo:bar:1.0] as it is already up to date&#010;&gt; at [lib/bar-1.0.jar]&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Wouldn't it make sense to either include the groupId in the filename or at&#010;&gt; least make a check (that includes the groupId) beforehand if there are any&#010;&gt; conflicts?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Cheers,&#010;&gt; Reto&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Reto Hablützel &lt;ret...@rethab.ch&gt;
Subject  :-Re: maven-ear-plugin silently overrides libraries
contents:- Sure, but exclusions don't do the trick if you need both of them, do they?&#010;I am talking about completely independent libraries that happen to have the&#010;same artifactId.&#010;&#010;Those were actually both libraries of mine and I could obviously fix this&#010;issue rather simply, but I was just thinking that it would be helpful to&#010;have at least a warning or something from maven - regardless of the IDE.&#010;&#010;- Reto&#010;&#010;&#010;On Fri, Feb 7, 2014 at 3:33 PM, Ron Wheeler&#010;&lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; If your IDE supports Maven (Eclipse/STS for example), you will see the&#010;&gt; conflict in the dependency hierarchy view and you can fix it with the right&#010;&gt; exclusions.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; It is almost always worth a quick look through the dependency hierarchy&#010;&gt; view if you use a lot of third party libraries.&#010;&gt; Not everyone updates their dependencies when they build a shareable&#010;&gt; library.&#010;&gt; You can sometimes get some pretty old versions of things dragged in with&#010;&gt; the latest version of otherwise well-written libraries.&#010;&gt; Exclusions need to be added to get what you want in your artifacts.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 07/02/2014 9:21 AM, Reto Hablützel wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Hi there,&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I built an ear using the maven-ear-plugin (version 2.6).&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The ear is configured such that it includes two libraries into the lib&#010;&gt;&gt; folder, both with the same artifactId as well as the same version, but a&#010;&gt;&gt; different groupId. Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: maven-ear-plugin silently overrides libraries
contents:- Exclusions will not help in this case.&#010;Looking through the dependency hierarchy will at least get you to see &#010;the problem earlier which I think was the nature of your question.&#010;&#010;It appears from my brief reading and fun with making servlets run in &#010;production that classloaders merge classes by name.&#010;Maven does not.&#010;&#010;I am a bit surprised that groupId does not count.&#010;&#010;If one uses a lot of third -party libraries, it would seem inevitable &#010;that you could need com.artifact-software:utilities:1.0 at the same time &#010;as ch.rethab:utilities:1.0 at the same time.&#010;The classloader is not going to cause any problem but if Maven throws &#010;out one of these as a duplicate, you will be missing classes at run-time.&#010;&#010;It is difficult to force everyone to create unique artifactIds unless &#010;you get rid of the GroupId altogther and make GAV -&gt; &lt;AV&gt; and put the &#010;group name into the artifactID.&#010;&#010;This seems to be a design flaw if it is true.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;On 07/02/2014 9:43 AM, Reto Hablützel wrote:&#010;&gt; Sure, but exclusions don't do the trick if you need both of them, do &#010;&gt; they? I am talking about completely independent libraries that happen &#010;&gt; to have the same artifactId.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Those were actually both libraries of mine and I could obviously fix &#010;&gt; this issue rather simply, but I was just thinking that it would be &#010;&gt; helpful to have at least a warning or something from maven - &#010;&gt; regardless of the IDE.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - Reto&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Fri, Feb 7, 2014 at 3:33 PM, Ron Wheeler &#010;&gt; &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com &#010;&gt; &lt;mailto:rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     If your IDE supports Maven (Eclipse/STS for example), you will see&#010;&gt;     the conflict in the dependency hierarchy view and you can fix it&#010;&gt;     with the right exclusions.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     It is almost always worth a quick look through the dependency&#010;&gt;     hierarchy view if you use a lot of third party libraries.&#010;&gt;     Not everyone updates their dependencies when they build a&#010;&gt;     shareable library.&#010;&gt;     You can sometimes get some pretty old versions of things dragged&#010;&gt;     in with the latest version of otherwise well-written libraries.&#010;&gt;     Exclusions need to be added to get what you want in your artifacts.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     On 07/02/2014 9:21 AM, Reto Hablützel wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;         Hi there,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;         I built an ear using the maven-ear-plugin (version 2.6).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;         The ear is configured such that it includes two libraries into&#010;&gt;         the lib&#010;&gt;         folder, both with the same artifactId as well as the same&#010;&gt;         version, but a&#010;&gt;         different groupId. Now if I simply call 'mvn package' only the&#010;&gt;         first one is&#010;&gt;         included, but no warning whatsoever appears. Only once I turn&#010;&gt;         on debugging&#010;&gt;         (mvn --debug package), I see one subtle message:&#010;&gt;         [DEBUG] Skipping artifact [jar:com.foo:bar:1.0] as it is&#010;&gt;         already up to date&#010;&gt;         at [lib/bar-1.0.jar]&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;         Wouldn't it make sense to either include the groupId in the&#010;&gt;         filename or at&#010;&gt;         least make a check (that includes the groupId) beforehand if&#010;&gt;         there are any&#010;&gt;         conflicts?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;         Cheers,&#010;&gt;         Reto&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     -- &#010;&gt;     Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt;     President&#010;&gt;     Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt;     email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt;     &lt;mailto:rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;&#010;&gt;     skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt;     phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;     To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;     &lt;mailto:users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&gt;&#010;&gt;     For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;     &lt;mailto:users-help@maven.apache.org&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;
