this&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; issue rather simply, but I was just thinking that it would be helpful to&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; have at least a warning or something from maven - regardless of the IDE.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; - Reto&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; On Fri, Feb 7, 2014 at 3:33 PM, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; com &lt;mailto:rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     If your IDE supports Maven (Eclipse/STS for example), you will see&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     the conflict in the dependency hierarchy view and you can fix it&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     with the right exclusions.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     It is almost always worth a quick look through the dependency&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     hierarchy view if you use a lot of third party libraries.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     Not everyone updates their dependencies when they build a&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     shareable library.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     You can sometimes get some pretty old versions of things dragged&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     in with the latest version of otherwise well-written libraries.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     Exclusions need to be added to get what you want in your artifacts.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     Ron&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     On 07/02/2014 9:21 AM, Reto Hablützel wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         Hi there,&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         I built an ear using the maven-ear-plugin (version 2.6).&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         The ear is configured such that it includes two libraries into&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         the lib&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         folder, both with the same artifactId as well as the same&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         version, but a&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         different groupId. Now if I simply call 'mvn package' only the&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         first one is&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         included, but no warning whatsoever appears. Only once I turn&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         on debugging&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         (mvn --debug package), I see one subtle message:&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         [DEBUG] Skipping artifact [jar:com.foo:bar:1.0] as it is&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         already up to date&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         at [lib/bar-1.0.jar]&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         Wouldn't it make sense to either include the groupId in the&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         filename or at&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         least make a check (that includes the groupId) beforehand if&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         there are any&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         conflicts?&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         Cheers,&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;         Reto&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     --     Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     President&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     &lt;mailto:rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     &lt;mailto:users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;     &lt;mailto:users-help@maven.apache.org&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; --&#010;&gt; &gt; Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; &gt; President&#010;&gt; &gt; Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt; &gt; email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; &gt; skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt; &gt; phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Reto Hablützel &lt;ret...@rethab.ch&gt;
Subject  :-Re: maven-ear-plugin silently overrides libraries
contents:- Is JIRA open for public registration / issue creation? I could not find a&#010;link to sign up..&#010;&#010;Anyways, I attached a sample project. Please follow these steps to recreate&#010;the issue (btw. I think the whole naming thing is also a problem if you are&#010;referencing two ejbs with the same artifactId and version):&#010;&#010;Install 'utilities' project in 'collections':&#010;collections/utilities&gt; mvn install&#010;&#010;Install 'utilities' project in 'email':&#010;email/utilities&gt; mvn install&#010;&#010;Package 'ear' project:&#010;ear&gt; mvn package&#010;&#010;Look at contents of ear and notice how only one jar is included:&#010;ear&gt; unzip -v target/ear-1.0.0.ear&#010;&#010;Now use the debug flag to see why only one gets included:&#010;ear&gt; mvn --debug clean package&#010;&#010;Partial output:&#010;  [INFO] Copying artifact [jar:ch.rethab.email:utilities:1.0.0] to&#010;[utilities-1.0.0.jar]&#010;  [DEBUG] Skipping artifact [jar:ch.rethab.collections:utilities:1.0.0], as&#010;it is already up to date at [utilities-1.0.0.jar]&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;On Thu, Feb 13, 2014 at 7:32 PM, Baptiste Mathus &lt;bmathus@batmat.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; That's the way to go. Even more if you're able to attach a test project.&#010;&gt; One report without report is far less likely to be worked on.&#010;&gt; Cheers&#010;&gt; Le 13 févr. 2014 14:06, "Reto Hablützel" &lt;rethab@rethab.ch&gt; a écrit :&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; So what's the status on this? Shall I create a ticket?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; On Fri, Feb 7, 2014 at 5:04 PM, Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; &gt; &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Exclusions will not help in this case.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Looking through the dependency hierarchy will at least get you to see&#010;&gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; problem earlier which I think was the nature of your question.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; It appears from my brief reading and fun with making servlets run in&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; production that classloaders merge classes by name.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Maven does not.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; I am a bit surprised that groupId does not count.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; If one uses a lot of third -party libraries, it would seem inevitable&#010;&gt; &gt; that&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; you could need com.artifact-software:utilities:1.0 at the same time as&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; ch.rethab:utilities:1.0 at the same time.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; The classloader is not going to cause any problem but if Maven throws&#010;&gt; out&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; one of these as a duplicate, you will be missing classes at run-time.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; It is difficult to force everyone to create unique artifactIds unless&#010;&gt; you&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; get rid of the GroupId altogther and make GAV -&gt; &lt;AV&gt; and put the&#010;group&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; name into the artifactID.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; This seems to be a design flaw if it is true.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Ron&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; On 07/02/2014 9:43 AM, Reto Hablützel wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; Sure, but exclusions don't do the trick if you need both of them, do&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; they? I am talking about completely independent libraries that happen&#010;&gt; to&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; have the same artifactId.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; Those were actually both libraries of mine and I could obviously fix&#010;&gt; &gt; this&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; issue rather simply, but I was just thinking that it would be helpful&#010;&gt; to&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; have at least a warning or something from maven - regardless of the&#010;&gt; IDE.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; - Reto&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; On Fri, Feb 7, 2014 at 3:33 PM, Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.&#010;&gt; Subject  :-Re: maven-ear-plugin silently overrides libraries

Even more if you're able to attach a test project.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; One report without report is far less likely to be worked on.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; Cheers&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; Le 13 févr. 2014 14:06, "Reto Hablützel" &lt;rethab@rethab.ch&gt; a écrit&#010;:&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; So what's the status on this? Shall I create a ticket?&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; On Fri, Feb 7, 2014 at 5:04 PM, Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; Exclusions will not help in this case.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; Looking through the dependency hierarchy will at least get you to&#010;&gt; see&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; problem earlier which I think was the nature of your question.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; It appears from my brief reading and fun with making servlets run&#010;in&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; production that classloaders merge classes by name.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; Maven does not.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; I am a bit surprised that groupId does not count.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; If one uses a lot of third -party libraries, it would seem&#010;&gt; inevitable&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; that&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; you could need com.artifact-software:utilities:1.0 at the same time&#010;&gt; as&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; ch.rethab:utilities:1.0 at the same time.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; The classloader is not going to cause any problem but if Maven&#010;&gt; throws&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; out&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; one of these as a duplicate, you will be missing classes at&#010;&gt; run-time.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; It is difficult to force everyone to create unique artifactIds&#010;&gt; unless&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; you&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; get rid of the GroupId altogther and make GAV -&gt; &lt;AV&gt; and&#010;put the&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; group&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; name into the artifactID.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; This seems to be a design flaw if it is true.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; Ron&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; On 07/02/2014 9:43 AM, Reto Hablützel wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; Sure, but exclusions don't do the trick if you need both of them,&#010;&gt; Name  :- &quot;Robert Scholte&quot; &lt;rfscho...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: maven-ear-plugin silently overrides libraries
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;See  &#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-ear-plugin/examples/customize-file-name-mapping.html&#010; &#010;for custom filename mapping.&#010;&#010;Robert&#010;&#010;Op Fri, 07 Feb 2014 15:21:54 +0100 schreef Reto Hablützel  &#010;&lt;rethab@rethab.ch&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi there,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I built an ear using the maven-ear-plugin (version 2.6).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The ear is configured such that it includes two libraries into the lib&#010;&gt; folder, both with the same artifactId as well as the same version, but a&#010;&gt; different groupId. Now if I simply call 'mvn package' only the first one  &#010;&gt; is&#010;&gt; included, but no warning whatsoever appears. Only once I turn on  &#010;&gt; debugging&#010;&gt; (mvn --debug package), I see one subtle message:&#010;&gt; [DEBUG] Skipping artifact [jar:com.foo:bar:1.0] as it is already up to  &#010;&gt; date&#010;&gt; at [lib/bar-1.0.jar]&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Wouldn't it make sense to either include the groupId in the filename or  &#010;&gt; at&#010;&gt; least make a check (that includes the groupId) beforehand if there are  &#010;&gt; any&#010;&gt; conflicts?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Cheers,&#010;&gt; Reto&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-Re: maven-ear-plugin silently overrides libraries
contents:- I confirm that the use case you mention is supposed to work transparently.&#010;This most likely looks like a bug.&#010;&#010;Thanks for reporting this.&#010;&#010;S.&#010;&#010;&#010;On Fri, Feb 7, 2014 at 3:21 PM, Reto Hablützel &lt;rethab@rethab.ch&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi there,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I built an ear using the maven-ear-plugin (version 2.6).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The ear is configured such that it includes two libraries into the lib&#010;&gt; folder, both with the same artifactId as well as the same version, but a&#010;&gt; different groupId. Now if I simply call 'mvn package' only the first one is&#010;&gt; included, but no warning whatsoever appears. Only once I turn on debugging&#010;&gt; (mvn --debug package), I see one subtle message:&#010;&gt; [DEBUG] Skipping artifact [jar:com.foo:bar:1.0] as it is already up to date&#010;&gt; at [lib/bar-1.0.jar]&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Wouldn't it make sense to either include the groupId in the filename or at&#010;&gt; least make a check (that includes the groupId) beforehand if there are any&#010;&gt; conflicts?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Cheers,&#010;&gt; Reto&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Pavlina Temelakieva &lt;pavlina.temelaki...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Maven build hangs forever while running TestNG unit tests.
contents:- Hello everyone,&#010;&#010;I am running maven build on my project and it stuck forever when trying to&#010;run a unit test. I tried disabling the unit test where it used to stuck (by&#010;comment the @Test annotation), but then the build hangs on the Test stage,&#010;without executing a single unit test.&#010;*Output:*&#010;-------------------------------------------------------&#010; T E S T S&#010;-------------------------------------------------------&#010;Running TestSuite&#010;&#010;I am using:&#010;(mvn -version)&#010;*Output:*&#010;ARCH: lin32&#010;JAVA_HOME: /path/to/jdk-1.7.0_45&#010;Apache Maven 3.0.3 (r1075438; 2011-02-28 19:31:09+0200)&#010;Default locale: en_US, platform encoding: UTF-8&#010;OS name: "linux", version: "2.6.38-8-generic", arch: "i386", family: "unix"&#010;Java version: 1.7.0_45, vendor: Oracle Corporation&#010;&#010;For the unit tests I am using TestNG:&#010;  &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;       &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-surefire-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;       &lt;version&gt;2.4.2&lt;/version&gt;&#010;   &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;My current MAVEN_OPTS settings are : -Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize=128m&#010;I read somewhere that changing the MaxPermSize will fix the issue, so I&#010;tried increasing MaxPermGenSize to 256m and the issue is still present.&#010;I rebooted and the issue is still present.&#010;I also tried stopping the process with CTRL+Z, but the output doesn't seem&#010;to give me the PID of the process:&#010;*Output:*&#010;[1]+  Stopped                 mvn clean install -pl ../myProject/&#010;Also, the -e, and the -X options doesn't give any additional information&#010;when the hanging is reached.&#010;Note that when I run mvn clean install -DskipTests, the issue doesn't&#010;appear, and the project is built successfully without the unit tests are&#010;executed.&#010;&#010;I really have no clue what causes this hanging. Can you help?&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Flavio Junqueira &lt;fpjunque...@yahoo.com&gt;
Subject  :-Add Apache License to reduced pom (shade plugin)
contents:- Hi there,&#010;&#010;We are using the shade plugin in the Apache BookKeeper project (BOOKKEEPER-724, BOOKKEEPER-730)&#010;and we originally wanted to the add the Apache license to the reduced pom generated so that&#010;we could ship it with our next release. However, we couldn't find any option that allows us&#010;to add the license automatically. Is it right that there is no option to add it automatically&#010;to the reduced pom? If this is right, then the next question is if we really need to add the&#010;license header to a generated file.&#010;&#010;Has anyone had this problem before? Any suggestion of how to deal with this problem?&#010;&#010;Thanks!&#010;-Flavio &#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Benson Margulies &lt;bimargul...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Add Apache License to reduced pom (shade plugin)
contents:- that JIRA is different. It is asking for _comments_ from the original&#010;pom to flow through, which is pretty nearly impossible. if you ask for&#010;a brand new comment to be inserted based on some configuration&#010;element, and better yet offer a patch, that's doable.&#010;&#010;&#010;On Sun, Feb 9, 2014 at 5:20 PM, Flavio Junqueira &lt;fpjunqueira@yahoo.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Thanks for getting back, but I'm not sure creating a jira is any good in this case. Name  :- Martin Gainty &lt;mgai...@hotmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-RE: Reload MavenProject MavenSession and BuildPluginManager
contents:- &gt; Date: Sat, 8 Feb 2014 09:59:27 -0800&#010;&gt; From: desmond.kirrane@gmail.com&#010;&gt; To: users@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; Subject: Reload MavenProject MavenSession and BuildPluginManager&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; How can my Moo reload/refresh MavenProject MavenSession and&#010;&gt; BuildPluginManager components.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I need to do this after my Mojo switches the a different Git branch.&#010;MG&gt;so you have a "new feature branch"&#010;MG&gt;git hf feature start ##feature name## &#010;&#010;MG&gt;I would set this as a post-create task on a Hudson job  e.g.&#010;MG&gt;and implement 'git hf feature #feature name#' on post-create of Hudson Job&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Reload-MavenProject-MavenSession-and-BuildPluginManager-tp5783698.html&#010;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010; &#009;&#009; &#009;   &#009;&#009;  &#010;

Name  :- Martin Gainty &lt;mgai...@hotmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-RE: Reload MavenProject MavenSession and BuildPluginManager
contents:- you will need to trigger ArtifactResolver.resolveAlways with the artifact, localRepository&#010;properly populated for each of the requested artifacts..Here is an example from maven-netbeans-plugin&#010;&#010; &#010;&#010;private void resolve(Artifact artifact, boolean failOnError, boolean remote) throws MojoExecutionException&#010;{ &#010;&#010;129.        if (!artifact.isResolved() || artifact.isSnapshot()) { &#010;130.            try { &#010;131.                artifactResolver.resolveAlways(artifact, remote ? remoteArtifactRepositories&#010;: Collections.EMPTY_LIST, localRepository); &#010;132.            } catch (AbstractArtifactResolutionException ex) { &#010;133.                if (failOnError) { &#010;134.                    throw new MojoExecutionException("can not resolve " + artifact, ex);&#010;&#010;135.                } &#010;136.            } &#010;137.        } &#010;138.    }&#010;&#010;https://kenai.com/projects/mvn-nb-plugin/sources/subversion/content/src/main/java/com/kenai/maven/netbeans/plugin/NetBeansMojo.java?rev=4&#010;&#010;Martin &#010;______________________________________________ &#010;&#010;  &#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; Date: Sat, 8 Feb 2014 09:59:27 -0800&#010;&gt; From: desmond.kirrane@gmail.com&#010;&gt; To: users@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; Subject: Reload MavenProject MavenSession and BuildPluginManager&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; How can my Moo reload/refresh MavenProject MavenSession and&#010;&gt; BuildPluginManager components.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I need to do this after my Mojo switches the a different Git branch.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Reload-MavenProject-MavenSession-and-BuildPluginManager-tp5783698.html&#010;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010; &#009;&#009; &#009;   &#009;&#009;  &#010;

================

Subject  :-RE: Reload MavenProject MavenSession and BuildPluginManager
contents:- I tried the following but the project version didn't work&#010;&#010;            &#010;            Artifact artifact = project.getArtifact();&#010;            try {&#010;                artifactResolver.resolve(artifact,&#010;remoteArtifactRepositories, localRepository);&#010;                &#010;                System.out.println("project = " + project.getVersion());&#010;                System.out.println("artifact = " + artifact.getVersion());&#010;            } catch (ArtifactResolutionException ex) {&#010;                getLog().error(null, ex);&#010;            } catch (ArtifactNotFoundException ex) {&#010;                getLog().error(null, ex);&#010;            }&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Reload-MavenProject-MavenSession-and-BuildPluginManager-tp5783698p5785012.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- &quot;Zmuda, Matt&quot; &lt;Matt.Zm...@td.com&gt;
Subject  :-wsimport - catalog
contents:- Hi All,&#010;&#010;I am trying to generate some web service client code from a WSDL and schemas that I have.&#010;One issue I am encountering is that one schema file (xsd) I require is in a separate jar that&#010;my client project has a dependency on.&#010;I cannot figure out how to reference that file in my pom. I have been lead down the path of&#010;looking into defining a catalog (and it seems that how it was done in the and build we use&#010;to use) however I can't get this working.&#010;&#010;Below is what I have.. but not sure if I am on right track or not. Any help is appreciated!&#010;&#010;The POM Sample&#010;&#010;&lt;project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"&#010;xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd"&gt;&#010;                &lt;modelVersion&gt;4.0.0&lt;/modelVersion&gt;&#010;                &lt;groupId&gt;com.thegroup&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;                &lt;artifactId&gt;com.theclientcode&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;                &lt;version&gt;0.0.1-SNAPSHOT&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&#010;                &lt;dependencies&gt;&#010;                                &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;                                                &lt;!-- This dependency contains the schema&#010;my wsdl needs --&gt;&#010;                                                &lt;!-- How can I reference it? --&gt;&#010;                                                &lt;groupId&gt;com.mygroup&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;                                                &lt;artifactId&gt;myartifact&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;                                                &lt;version&gt;1.0&lt;/version&gt;&#010;                                &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;                &lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;                &lt;build&gt;&#010;                                &lt;plugins&gt;&#010;                                                &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;                                                                &lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.mojo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;                                                                &lt;executions&gt;&#010;                                                                                &lt;execution&gt;&#010;                                                                                         &#010;      &lt;goals&gt;&#010;                                                                                         &#010;                      &lt;goal&gt;wsimport&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;                                                                                         &#010;      &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;                                                                                &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;                                                                &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;                                                                &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;                                                                                &lt;extension&gt;true&lt;/extension&gt;&#010;                                                                                &lt;!-- Is&#010;this what I should be using? What should be in it??? 0--&gt;&#010;                                                                                &lt;catalog&gt;${basedir}/src/main/resources/META-INF/catalog.xml&lt;/catalog&gt;&#010;                                                                                &lt;wsdlDirectory&gt;${basedir}/src/main/resources&lt;/wsdlDirectory&gt;&#010;                                                                                &lt;sourceDestDir&gt;${project.build.sourceDirectory}&lt;/sourceDestDir&gt;&#010;               xmlns:jxb="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/jaxb"&#010;               xmlns:xjc="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/jaxb/xjc"&#010;               xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"&gt;&#010;&#010;                &lt;jxb:bindings schemaLocation="/com/something/Fault.xsd" node="/xs:schema"&gt;&#010;                    &lt;jxb:schemaBindings&gt;&#010;                      &lt;jxb:package name="com.something.xml"&gt;&#010;                        &lt;jxb:javadoc&gt;&lt;![CDATA[&lt;body&gt;Package level documentation&#010;for generated package&lt;/body&gt;]]&gt;&lt;/jxb:javadoc&gt;&#010;                      &lt;/jxb:package&gt;&#010; Name  :- Michael Osipov &lt;micha...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: wsimport - catalog
contents:- Am 2014-02-10 21:28, schrieb Zmuda, Matt:&#010;&gt; Hi All,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I am trying to generate some web service client code from a WSDL and schemas that I have.&#010;&gt; One issue I am encountering is that one schema file (xsd) I require is in a separate&#010;jar that my client project has a dependency on.&#010;&gt; I cannot figure out how to reference that file in my pom. I have been lead down the path&#010;of looking into defining a catalog (and it seems that how it was done in the and build we&#010;use to use) however I can't get this working.&#010;&#010;That is not a Maven problem but simply a configuration problem with the &#010;JAX-WS Maven Plugin.&#010;&#010;In this case, you should work like this:&#010;&#010;Parent&#010;|- JAR with generated classes from the XSD with generated episode file&#010;|- JAR with SEI and provided episode file, wsimport won't duplicate the &#010;model in that case.&#010;&#010;Generally, the JAX-WS Plugin has a few shortcomings compared to the JAXB &#010;plugin. Search the JAX_WS_COMMONS JIRA and you'll find the tickets.&#010;&#010;Michael&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- geoffh &lt;hartnel...@yahoo.co.uk&gt;
Subject  :-Adding dependency management to parent pom causes errors
contents:- I have a Maven project that has a parent pom and 5 child poms&#010;In the initial version each pom had specific dependencies declared&#010;All the projects completed the 'mvn clean deploy' build with success&#010;&#010;I wanted to change this to use the dependency management features &#010; - where the parent pom declared the dependencies and versions and the child&#010;poms just referenced the dependencies&#010;&#010;I changed the parent and child poms to use dependency management, but then&#010;got compilation errors on one of my child projects&#010;&#010;[ERROR] Failed to execute goal&#010;org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-compiler-plugin:2.3.2:compile&#010;(default-compile) on project clearswift-common-gwt: Compilation failure&#010;[ERROR] Failure executing javac, but could not parse the error:&#010;[ERROR] An exception has occurred in the compiler (1.7.0_25). Please file a&#010;bug at the Java Developer Connection (http://java.sun.com/webapps/bugreport) &#010;after checking the Bug Parade for duplicates. Include your program and the&#010;following diagnostic in your report.  Thank you.&#010;[ERROR] java.lang.AssertionError: typeSig 19&#010;[ERROR] at&#010;com.sun.tools.javac.jvm.ClassWriter.assembleSig(ClassWriter.java:357)&#010;[ERROR] at com.sun.tools.javac.jvm.ClassWriter.typeSig(ClassWriter.java:424)&#010;...&#010;&#010;In attempting to identify the cause, I started by just adding dependency&#010;management to my parent pom&#010;Simply adding  &#010;&lt;dependencyManagement&gt;&#010;&lt;/dependencyManagement&gt;&#010;around the dependencies in my parent pom, causes dependencies not be&#010;resolved&#010;&#010;Does anyone have any idea why using dependency management might cause&#010;compilation errors&#010; - or why just adding dependency management to the parent pom would cause&#010;dependency resolution errors&#010; &#010;Thanks for reading and any help&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Adding-dependency-management-to-parent-pom-causes-errors-tp5784035.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Laird Nelson &lt;ljnel...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Adding dependency management to parent pom causes errors
contents:- On Tue, Feb 11, 2014 at 12:18 AM, geoffh &lt;hartnell_g@yahoo.co.uk&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; In attempting to identify the cause, I started by just adding dependency&#010;&gt;&#010;management to my parent pom&#010;&gt; Simply adding&#010;&gt; &lt;dependencyManagement&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;/dependencyManagement&gt;&#010;&gt; around the dependencies in my parent pom, causes dependencies not be&#010;&gt; resolved&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;I'm not sure why the developers chose the words "dependency management" to&#010;identify the particular XML section in question.  It's very confusing.&#010;&#010;Think of the &lt;dependencyManagement&gt; section as serving two purposes.&#010;&#010;First, and foremost, it is template information.  If a given real&#010;&lt;dependency&gt; somewhere else omits a piece of information, then that piece&#010;of information is taken (if possible) from the &lt;dependencyManagement&gt;&#010;section.&#010;&#010;Second, which is really an outgrowth of the first, it constrains the&#010;versions of transitive dependencies that might be pulled in from somewhere&#010;else.  I say this is an outgrowth of the first concern, because strictly&#010;speaking your project never mentions a transitive dependency, so that&#010;"piece of information" is missing just like, say, a version string.&#010;&#010;Note as well that the stuff in the &lt;dependencyManagement&gt; section can be&#010;made up.  That is, you can put dependency management elements in there that&#010;don't actually pick out any dependencies in the world.  See my earlier&#010;point about this being a template area.&#010;&#010;Putting this all together, it still follows that you have to have *real*&#010;dependencies defined.  If you simply wrap your "real" dependencies with&#010;&lt;dependencyManagement&gt;&lt;/dependencyManagement&gt;, that is clearly not going to&#010;work: you've now specified a template, but nothing that the template will&#010;be merged into.&#010;&#010;The compilation error you're talking about looks like something more&#010;substantial than a bad dependency--you're getting a compiler error from&#010;within javac itself.&#010;&#010;I noticed that "-gwt" showed up in some of your artifact names; perhaps&#010;something with GWT is not playing nice.&#010;&#010;Hope something in here helps.&#010;&#010;Best,&#010;Laird&#010;&#010;-- &#010;http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Adding dependency management to parent pom causes errors
contents:- On 12 February 2014 10:17, Laird Nelson &lt;ljnelson@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; First, and foremost, it is template information.  If a given real&#010;&gt; &lt;dependency&gt; somewhere else omits a piece of information, then that piece&#010;&gt; of information is taken (if possible) from the &lt;dependencyManagement&gt;&#010;&gt; section.&#010;&#010;This is also best practice.&#010;&#010;Appliying DRY principles you pull up all the dependency information&#010;from your child poms into your parent pom's dependencyManagement&#010;section.&#010;Then in your child poms you *always* omit the version information in&#010;your dependency section.&#010;&#010;This way you know that your project is using a consistent version of artifacts.&#010;The last thing you want is for your project to be using a mish-mash of&#010;GWT versions (1.0 in one project, 2.6 in another, etc).&#010;&#010;This gives you one place to define the versions.&#010;And when its time to upgrade then one place to make the change.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Laird Nelson &lt;ljnel...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Adding dependency management to parent pom causes errors
contents:- On Tue, Feb 11, 2014 at 4:48 PM, Barrie Treloar &lt;baerrach@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; This is also best practice.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Agreed wholesale.  I think the original poster was wondering why this&#010;stanza:&#010;&#010;&lt;dependencies&gt;&#010;&lt;!-- ... --&gt;&#010;&lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;...when "wrapped" (replaced, really) thusly:&#010;&#010;*&lt;dependencyManagement&gt;*&#010;  &lt;dependencies&gt;&#010;  &lt;!-- ... --&gt;&#010;  &lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;*&lt;/dependencyManagement&gt;*&#010;&#010;&#010;...suddenly {handwave handwave} made his dependencies stop {handwave}&#010;resolving.  (The answer being of course that there is no longer a&#010;&lt;dependencies&gt; section in this particular case; he replaced it—did not&#010;augment it—with a &lt;dependencyManagement&gt; stanza.)&#010;&#010;While we're on the subject of best practices in this area, we've also found&#010;that dependency managing the versions of even child &lt;modules&gt; pays off in&#010;the end.&#010;&#010;Best,&#010;Laird&#010;&#010;-- &#010;http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Adding dependency management to parent pom causes errors
contents:- On 12 February 2014 11:51, Laird Nelson &lt;ljnelson@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Agreed wholesale.  I think the original poster was wondering why this&#010;&gt; stanza:&#010;[del]&#010;&#010;You did a good job there so I didn't add any value to the response.&#010;&#010;&gt; While we're on the subject of best practices in this area, we've also found&#010;&gt; that dependency managing the versions of even child &lt;modules&gt; pays off in&#010;&gt; the end.&#010;&#010;Be careful here.&#010;People get confused with what a module is.&#010;&#010;A module is not a dependency.&#010;I think of it as a handy shortcut to allow me to run a maven command&#010;at the top and have the same command also run in any module&#010;declaration.&#010;Logically a module is a group of things that tend to get released&#010;together. If that is not the case, then don't use a module.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Adrien Rivard &lt;adrien.riv...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Adding dependency management to parent pom causes errors
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;DependencyManagement is declaring dependencies(mostly for versions) and&#010;dependencies is using them,&#010;So in general you should have only dependencyManagement in the parent poms&#010;and only dependencies in the childs.&#010;&#010;Now there are exceptions, for example junit is generally used in all child&#010;projects , so you can add it in dependencies of the parent pom and it will&#010;be avaible in all childs.&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Feb 12, 2014 at 10:33 AM, geoffh &lt;hartnell_g@yahoo.co.uk&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Laird, Barrie&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks for taking the time with some useful explanations&#010;&gt; I'd like to put more detail into my problem in the hope that you may be&#010;&gt; able&#010;&gt; to spot something I am doing wrong:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I started off with parent and child poms with no dependency management -&#010;&gt; along the lines of:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Parent pom (without dependencyManagement)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;                 &lt;dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;                                 &lt;groupId&gt;log4j&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;                                 &lt;artifactId&gt;log4j&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;                                 &lt;version&gt;${log4j-version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; .&#010;&gt; .&#010;&gt; .&#010;&gt;                 &lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Child pom (without dependencyManagement)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;                                         &lt;groupId&gt;log4j&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;                                         &lt;artifactId&gt;log4j&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;                                         &lt;version&gt;${log4j-version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt; .&#010;&gt; .&#010;&gt; .&#010;&gt;         &lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; As I said, 'mvn clean deploy' completed successfully with no compilation&#010;&gt; errors&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I then changed the parent and child poms to use dependency management -&#010;&gt; along the lines of:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Parent pom (with dependencyManagement)&#010;&gt;         &lt;dependencyManagement&gt;&#010;&gt;                 &lt;dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;                                 &lt;groupId&gt;log4j&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;                                 &lt;artifactId&gt;log4j&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;                                 &lt;version&gt;${log4j-version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; .&#010;&gt; .&#010;&gt; .&#010;&gt;                 &lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;/dependencyManagement&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Child pom (with dependencyManagement)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;                                         &lt;groupId&gt;log4j&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;                                         &lt;artifactId&gt;log4j&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt; .&#010;&gt; .&#010;&gt; .&#010;&gt;         &lt;/dependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I arranged that each child pom only referenced the dependencies it needed&#010;&gt; - with the parent pom having all dependencies required by all children&#010;&gt; After that I got the compilation error&#010;&gt; Interestingly, I got the same error trace when invoking 'mvn&#010;&gt; dependency:analyze'&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;The compilation error you're talking about looks like something more&#010;&gt; &gt;substantial than a bad dependency--you're getting a compiler error from&#010;&gt; &gt;within javac itself.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; However,  the compilation error did not occur in the situation without&#010;&gt; dependencyManagement&#010;&gt; If there is a genuine compilation error, would it be expected to show in&#010;&gt; both cases&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is that the correct way to use dependencyManagement ?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks for reading and any help / suggestions&#010;&gt; Geoff&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context:&#010;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Adding-dependency-management-to-parent-pom-causes-errors-tp5784035p5784252.html&#010;&gt; Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Adding dependency management to parent pom causes errors
contents:- On 12 February 2014 20:12, Adrien Rivard &lt;adrien.rivard@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; DependencyManagement is declaring dependencies(mostly for versions) and&#010;&gt; dependencies is using them,&#010;&gt; So in general you should have only dependencyManagement in the parent poms&#010;&gt; and only dependencies in the childs.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Now there are exceptions, for example junit is generally used in all child&#010;&gt; projects , so you can add it in dependencies of the parent pom and it will&#010;&gt; be avaible in all childs.&#010;&#010;Adding dependencies into the pom with modules is a bad idea,&#010;There will always be an exception that breaks that rule.&#010;Then you will be asking how do I remove a dependency from a child pom&#010;- you can't, dont define it in the first place.&#010;&#010;Typical exceptions would be poms whose sole purpose is to build an&#010;assembly (zip file) for package management, or Ear poms, etc.&#010;&#010;A best practice is to never have any dependencies in a pom that has modules.&#010;If you want to share common dependencies between projects, then you&#010;can look at using the inherit type relationship but that pom would be&#010;a standalone pom with no module declarations.&#010;Your top level project is an Aggregation pom to make running Maven easier.&#010;See https://maven.apache.org/pom.html#Aggregation&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-Why is dependency:analyze lying to me?
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;I’m using Maven 3.1.1 on Mac 10.9.1.  When I ran “mvn dependency:analyze” on&#010;my project, I got results that included:&#010;&#010;&#009;[WARNING] Unused declared dependencies found:&#010;&#009;…&#010;&#009;[WARNING]    junit:junit:jar:4.11:test&#010;&#010;So I commented out the above junit dependency in my pom (declared like so):&#010;&#010;                &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;                        &lt;groupId&gt;junit&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;                        &lt;artifactId&gt;junit&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;                        &lt;version&gt;${version.junit}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;                        &lt;scope&gt;test&lt;/scope&gt;&#010;                &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&#010;However, when I ran “mvm clean install” on my project, I got errors like&#010;&#010;&#009;initializationError0(org.mainco.subco.core.SerializableTest)  Time elapsed:&#010;0 sec  &lt;&lt;&lt; ERROR!&#010;&#009;java.lang.NoSuchFieldError: NULL&#010;&#009;&#009;at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.&lt;init&gt;(ParentRunner.java:48)&#010;&#009;&#009;at&#010;org.junit.runners.BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.&lt;init&gt;(BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.java:58)&#010;&#009;&#009;at&#010;org.springframework.test.context.junit4.SpringJUnit4ClassRunner.&lt;init&gt;(SpringJUnit4ClassRunner.java:104)&#010;&#010;This isn’t the only dependency that the analyze goal lists that wreaks havoc&#010;when I comment it out.  Is there another way to detect what dependencies are&#010;truly not needed by my project?&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Why-is-dependency-analyze-lying-to-me-tp5784108.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Why is dependency:analyze lying to me?
contents:- On 12 February 2014 07:41, laredotornado-3 &lt;laredotornado@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'm using Maven 3.1.1 on Mac 10.9.1.  When I ran "mvn dependency:analyze" on&#010;&gt; my project, I got results that included:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;         [WARNING] Unused declared dependencies found:&#010;&gt;         ...&#010;&gt;         [WARNING]    junit:junit:jar:4.11:test&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; So I commented out the above junit dependency in my pom (declared like so):&#010;[del]&#010;&gt;         java.lang.NoSuchFieldError: NULL&#010;&gt;                 at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.&lt;init&gt;(ParentRunner.java:48)&#010;&gt;                 at&#010;&gt; org.junit.runners.BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.&lt;init&gt;(BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.java:58)&#010;&gt;                 at&#010;&gt; org.springframework.test.context.junit4.SpringJUnit4ClassRunner.&lt;init&gt;(SpringJUnit4ClassRunner.java:104)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; This isn't the only dependency that the analyze goal lists that wreaks havoc&#010;&gt; when I comment it out.  Is there another way to detect what dependencies are&#010;&gt; truly not needed by my project?&#010;&#010;Unfortunately this stuff is not documented well enough in the plugin.&#010;You're welcome to submit a patch!&#010;&#010;Have a look at http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-dependency-plugin/faq.html#unused&#010;&#010;I think Maven is missing a scope, it needs to break up test into two&#010;phases; testCompile and testRuntime instead of having one scope which&#010;means both.&#010;This means that the analyze code can't tell what stuff is needed for&#010;tests at compile time and what is needed at runtime.&#010;&#010;If my memory serves me right, that would mean for your example that&#010;Spring is a compile time dependency but junit would be a runtime&#010;dependency.&#010;Hence the incorrect "Unused declared dependencies found" error.&#010;&#010;I would manually ignore anything found in the test scope from the error list.&#010;I never found the time to go hacking the plugin to work better - i.e.&#010;if it is test scope it really can't tell the difference between unused&#010;dependencies and shouldn't report them.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Paul Benedict &lt;pbened...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Why is dependency:analyze lying to me?
contents:- I am so happy someone brought this up. I actually hit this issue several&#010;times but never got around to mentioning it. Please submit a JIRA issue!&#010;&#010;&#010;On Tue, Feb 11, 2014 at 3:41 PM, Barrie Treloar &lt;baerrach@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; On 12 February 2014 07:41, laredotornado-3 &lt;laredotornado@gmail.com&gt;&#010;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt; Hi,&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I'm using Maven 3.1.1 on Mac 10.9.1.  When I ran "mvn&#010;&gt; dependency:analyze" on&#010;&gt; &gt; my project, I got results that included:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;         [WARNING] Unused declared dependencies found:&#010;&gt; &gt;         ...&#010;&gt; &gt;         [WARNING]    junit:junit:jar:4.11:test&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; So I commented out the above junit dependency in my pom (declared like&#010;&gt; so):&#010;&gt; [del]&#010;&gt; &gt;         java.lang.NoSuchFieldError: NULL&#010;&gt; &gt;                 at&#010;&gt; org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.&lt;init&gt;(ParentRunner.java:48)&#010;&gt; &gt;                 at&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; org.junit.runners.BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.&lt;init&gt;(BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.java:58)&#010;&gt; &gt;                 at&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; org.springframework.test.context.junit4.SpringJUnit4ClassRunner.&lt;init&gt;(SpringJUnit4ClassRunner.java:104)&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; This isn't the only dependency that the analyze goal lists that wreaks&#010;&gt; havoc&#010;&gt; &gt; when I comment it out.  Is there another way to detect what dependencies&#010;&gt; are&#010;&gt; &gt; truly not needed by my project?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Unfortunately this stuff is not documented well enough in the plugin.&#010;&gt; You're welcome to submit a patch!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Have a look at&#010;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-dependency-plugin/faq.html#unused&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I think Maven is missing a scope, it needs to break up test into two&#010;&gt; phases; testCompile and testRuntime instead of having one scope which&#010;&gt; means both.&#010;&gt; This means that the analyze code can't tell what stuff is needed for&#010;&gt; tests at compile time and what is needed at runtime.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; If my memory serves me right, that would mean for your example that&#010;&gt; Spring is a compile time dependency but junit would be a runtime&#010;&gt; dependency.&#010;&gt; Hence the incorrect "Unused declared dependencies found" error.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I would manually ignore anything found in the test scope from the error&#010;&gt; list.&#010;&gt; I never found the time to go hacking the plugin to work better - i.e.&#010;&gt; if it is test scope it really can't tell the difference between unused&#010;&gt; dependencies and shouldn't report them.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Cheers,&#010;Paul&#010;&#010;

Name  :- &quot;Mark H. Wood&quot; &lt;mw...@IUPUI.Edu&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Why is dependency:analyze lying to me?
contents:- On Wed, Feb 12, 2014 at 08:11:29AM +1030, Barrie Treloar wrote:&#010;[snip]&#010;&gt; I think Maven is missing a scope, it needs to break up test into two&#010;&gt; phases; testCompile and testRuntime instead of having one scope which&#010;&gt; means both.&#010;&gt; This means that the analyze code can't tell what stuff is needed for&#010;&gt; tests at compile time and what is needed at runtime.&#010;&#010;Picky terminology tweak:  I went off to check my memory because I was&#010;*sure* that Maven has a full set of test-* phases parallel to what we&#010;might call the "main" phases.  It has.  Then I came back here and saw&#010;that what you want is parallel *scopes* [test]Compile, [test]Runtime.&#010;&#010;Having sorted that (I hope), I think I agree with you.&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Mark H. Wood, Lead System Programmer   mwood@IUPUI.Edu&#010;Machines should not be friendly.  Machines should be obedient.&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Why is dependency:analyze lying to me?
contents:- On 13 February 2014 00:20, Mark H. Wood &lt;mwood@iupui.edu&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; On Wed, Feb 12, 2014 at 08:11:29AM +1030, Barrie Treloar wrote:&#010;&gt; [snip]&#010;&gt;&gt; I think Maven is missing a scope, it needs to break up test into two&#010;&gt;&gt; phases; testCompile and testRuntime instead of having one scope which&#010;&gt;&gt; means both.&#010;[del]&#010;&gt; Picky terminology tweak:&#010;&#010;Yes, my bad.&#010;I meant break that one scope into two scopes (not phases).&#010;Much like there are two scopes for compilation (compile and runtime),&#010;there needs to be two scopes for test (compile and runtime).&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- laredotornado-3 &lt;laredotorn...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Why is dependency:analyze lying to me?
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;This may fall into the “How the hell is Maven supposed to know?” category,&#010;but one of the dependencies that dependency:analyze lists when I run it on&#010;my WAR project is&#010;&#010;[WARNING] Unused declared dependencies found:&#010;…&#010;[WARNING]   &#010;org.springframework.security:spring-security-taglibs:jar:3.1.1.RELEASE:compile&#010;&#010;However, when I comment this out of my pom, a few of my JSPs die with the&#010;error&#010;&#010;&#009;org.apache.jasper.JasperException: The absolute uri:&#010;http://www.springframework.org/security/tags cannot be resolved in either&#010;web.xml or the jar files deployed with this application&#010;&#009;&#010;org.apache.jasper.compiler.DefaultErrorHandler.jspError(DefaultErrorHandler.java:51)&#010;&#009;&#010;org.apache.jasper.compiler.ErrorDispatcher.dispatch(ErrorDispatcher.java:409)&#010;&#009;&#010;org.apache.jasper.compiler.ErrorDispatcher.jspError(ErrorDispatcher.java:116)&#010;&#010;because the JSP includes this&#010;&#010;&#009;&lt;%@ taglib prefix="sec"&#010;uri="http://www.springframework.org/security/tags"%&gt;&#010;&#010;Anyway, not sure if the plugin can be configured to detect these kind of&#010;things, but a guy can dream, can’t he??&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Why-is-dependency-analyze-lying-to-me-tp5784108p5784691.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Paul Benedict &lt;pbened...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Why is dependency:analyze lying to me?
contents:- Especially if you use Spring XML configuration, it's impossible for the&#010;Dependency Plugin to figure out you need this-or-that Spring jar. The best&#010;you can do, actually, is use the new Spring Java Config so that your&#010;configuration is code and thus able to be statically analyzed.&#010;&#010;&#010;On Thu, Feb 13, 2014 at 3:54 PM, laredotornado-3 &lt;laredotornado@gmail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; This may fall into the "How the hell is Maven supposed to know?" category,&#010;&gt; but one of the dependencies that dependency:analyze lists when I run it on&#010;&gt; my WAR project is&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; [WARNING] Unused declared dependencies found:&#010;&gt; ...&#010;&gt; [WARNING]&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; org.springframework.security:spring-security-taglibs:jar:3.1.1.RELEASE:compile&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; However, when I comment this out of my pom, a few of my JSPs die with the&#010;&gt; error&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;         org.apache.jasper.JasperException: The absolute uri:&#010;&gt; http://www.springframework.org/security/tags cannot be resolved in either&#010;&gt; web.xml or the jar files deployed with this application&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; org.apache.jasper.compiler.DefaultErrorHandler.jspError(DefaultErrorHandler.java:51)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; org.apache.jasper.compiler.ErrorDispatcher.dispatch(ErrorDispatcher.java:409)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; org.apache.jasper.compiler.ErrorDispatcher.jspError(ErrorDispatcher.java:116)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; because the JSP includes this&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;%@ taglib prefix="sec"&#010;&gt; uri="http://www.springframework.org/security/tags"%&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Anyway, not sure if the plugin can be configured to detect these kind of&#010;&gt; things, but a guy can dream, can't he??&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context:&#010;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Why-is-dependency-analyze-lying-to-me-tp5784108p5784691.html&#010;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Cheers,&#010;Paul&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Wayne Fay &lt;wayne...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Why is dependency:analyze lying to me?
contents:- &gt; This may fall into the “How the hell is Maven supposed to know?” category,&#010;&#010;Yes, it most certainly does.&#010;&#010;&gt; [WARNING]&#010;&gt; org.springframework.security:spring-security-taglibs:jar:3.1.1.RELEASE:compile&#010;...&#010;&gt; Anyway, not sure if the plugin can be configured to detect these kind of&#010;&gt; things, but a guy can dream, can’t he??&#010;&#010;You would need to write code that performs the following tasks:&#010;1. look in jar files related to dependencies&#010;2. find taglib files and other configuration files [each file type&#010;needs its own parser]&#010;3. store tag uris that are discovered along with the associated jar&#010;4. check those tag uris vs what is in your code (keep in mind some may&#010;be in config files you wrote, so gotta parse those too - more code to&#010;write)&#010;5. output the list of jars (dependencies) which are not actually used&#010;in code or config&#010;&#010;This is nontrivial, so no one has done it. I'm sure we'd take a&#010;contribution if you did the work.&#010;&#010;Wayne&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Mirko Friedenhagen &lt;mfriedenha...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Why is dependency:analyze lying to me?
contents:- Hello,&#010;&#010;you see this a lot with runtime dependencies (which should probably be&#010;ignored during analyze anyway), so I mostly just ignore these in the&#010;output. It would be a cool thing, if you could suppress warnings for gavs&#010;directly in the analyze goal, so you see new stuff coming up more easily.&#010;&#010;Regards&#010;Mirko&#010;-- &#010;Sent from my mobile&#010;On Feb 13, 2014 11:01 PM, "Wayne Fay" &lt;waynefay@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; &gt; This may fall into the “How the hell is Maven supposed to know?”&#010;&gt; category,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Yes, it most certainly does.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; [WARNING]&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; org.springframework.security:spring-security-taglibs:jar:3.1.1.RELEASE:compile&#010;&gt; ...&#010;&gt; &gt; Anyway, not sure if the plugin can be configured to detect these kind of&#010;&gt; &gt; things, but a guy can dream, can’t he??&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; You would need to write code that performs the following tasks:&#010;&gt; 1. look in jar files related to dependencies&#010;&gt; 2. find taglib files and other configuration files [each file type&#010;&gt; needs its own parser]&#010;&gt; 3. store tag uris that are discovered along with the associated jar&#010;&gt; 4. check those tag uris vs what is in your code (keep in mind some may&#010;&gt; be in config files you wrote, so gotta parse those too - more code to&#010;&gt; write)&#010;&gt; 5. output the list of jars (dependencies) which are not actually used&#010;&gt; in code or config&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; This is nontrivial, so no one has done it. I'm sure we'd take a&#010;&gt; contribution if you did the work.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Wayne&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: maven-assembly-plugin:2.4 The following patterns were never triggered in this artifact inclusion filter
contents:- &gt;&gt; &gt;From&#010;&gt;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-assembly-plugin/examples/single/including-and-excluding-artifacts.html&#010;&gt;&gt; I think the shortened form assumes a "jar" classifier.&#010;&gt;&gt; I'm guessing from your assembly name "webapps-tar.xml" that these might be&#010;&gt;&gt; wars?&#010;&gt;&gt; Have you tried using the long form of the dependency conflict id?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I am not sure what you mean by this.&#010;&gt; The dependency specification in the pom has the right type.&#010;&gt; I tried adding the version and type in the assembly file and just got an&#010;&gt; error message with a more specific file name.&#010;&#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-assembly-plugin/examples/single/including-and-excluding-artifacts.html&#010;defines the spec for "dependency conflict id" and it does not include&#010;version.&#010;&#010;It is either&#010;* short form = groupId:artifactId&#010;* long form = groupId:artifactId:type:classifier&#010;&#010;Can you paste in your pom values for the dependency, as well as the&#010;snippet from your assembly file.&#010;&#010;I'm suggesting that you may not be able to use&#010;&lt;include&gt;com.artifact-software.taw:taw-localized-iumessage-ws&lt;/include&gt;&#010;but instead need&#010;&lt;include&gt;com.artifact-software.taw:taw-localized-iumessage-ws:war:&lt;/include&gt;&#010;&#010;&gt; I have not specified a specific phase but I assume that the plug-in is being&#010;&gt; triggered since the error comes from the plug-in.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I did read the docs but there is no example showing including of specific&#010;&gt; dependencies.&#010;&#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-assembly-plugin/examples/multimodule/module-binary-inclusion-simple.html&#010;Has the example you want to look at.&#010;It has the assembly descriptior, the pom that describes the plugin&#010;management, and the actual pom that defines the dependencies and&#010;invokes the assembly plugin.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

&#010;http://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/MojoExecutionException&#010;&#010;&#010;On 12/02/2014 8:56 AM, Barrie Treloar wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; From&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-assembly-plugin/examples/single/including-and-excluding-artifacts.html&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think the shortened form assumes a "jar" classifier.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm guessing from your assembly name "webapps-tar.xml" that these might be&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; wars?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Have you tried using the long form of the dependency conflict id?&#010;&gt;&gt; I am not sure what you mean by this.&#010;&gt;&gt; The dependency specification in the pom has the right type.&#010;&gt;&gt; I tried adding the version and type in the assembly file and just got an&#010;&gt;&gt; error message with a more specific file name.&#010;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-assembly-plugin/examples/single/including-and-excluding-artifacts.html&#010;&gt; defines the spec for "dependency conflict id" and it does not include&#010;&gt; version.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; It is either&#010;&gt; * short form = groupId:artifactId&#010;&gt; * long form = groupId:artifactId:type:classifier&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Can you paste in your pom values for the dependency, as well as the&#010;&gt; snippet from your assembly file.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'm suggesting that you may not be able to use&#010;&gt; &lt;include&gt;com.artifact-software.taw:taw-localized-iumessage-ws&lt;/include&gt;&#010;&gt; but instead need&#010;&gt; &lt;include&gt;com.artifact-software.taw:taw-localized-iumessage-ws:war:&lt;/include&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I have not specified a specific phase but I assume that the plug-in is being&#010;&gt;&gt; triggered since the error comes from the plug-in.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I did read the docs but there is no example showing including of specific&#010;&gt;&gt; dependencies.&#010;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-assembly-plugin/examples/multimodule/module-binary-inclusion-simple.html&#010;&gt; Has the example you want to look at.&#010;&gt; It has the assembly descriptior, the pom that describes the plugin&#010;&gt; management, and the actual pom that defines the dependencies and&#010;&gt; invokes the assembly plugin.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Subject  :-Re: maven-assembly-plugin:2.4 The following patterns were never triggered in this artifact inclusion filter
contents:- On 13 February 2014 02:24, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; I did a debug run and I think that the log shows where the includes get&#010;&gt;     &lt;id&gt;webapps&lt;/id&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;dependencySet&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;outputDirectory&gt;/target&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;useProjectArtifact&gt;false&lt;/useProjectArtifact&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;unpack&gt;false&lt;/unpack&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;scope&gt;runtime&lt;/scope&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;includes&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;include&gt;com.artifact-software.taw:taw-localized-iumessage-ws:war&lt;/include&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;include&gt;com.artifact-software.taw:taw-dataccess-ws:war&lt;/include&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;/includes&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;/dependencySet&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;/dependencySets&gt;&#010;[del]&#010;&gt; [DEBUG] com.artifact_software.taw:taw-localized-uimessage-ws:war:1.0.2 was removed by&#010;one or more filters.&#010;&gt; [DEBUG] com.artifact_software.taw:taw-dataaccess-ws:war:1.0.2 was removed by one or more&#010;filters.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; [WARNING] The following patterns were never triggered in this artifact&#010;&gt; inclusion filter:&#010;&gt; o  'com.artifact-software.taw:taw-localized-iumessage-ws:war'&#010;&gt; o  'com.artifact-software.taw:taw-dataccess-ws:war'&#010;[del]&#010;&gt;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-assembly-plugin/examples/single/including-and-excluding-artifacts.html&#010;&gt;&gt; defines the spec for "dependency conflict id" and it does not include&#010;&gt;&gt; version.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; It is either&#010;&gt;&gt; * short form = groupId:artifactId&#010;&gt;&gt; * long form = groupId:artifactId:type:classifier&#010;&#010;I'm guiding you blind since I've not done this before.&#010;The output is telling us that the pattern&#010;'com.artifact-software.taw:taw-localized-iumessage-ws:war'&#010;does not match the artifact&#010;com.artifact_software.taw:taw-localized-uimessage-ws:war:1.0.2&#010;&#010;And there is your problem.&#010;You have an _ in your groupid for the artifact, but not your include filter.&#010;&#010;I've been looking at maven-common-artifact-filters-1.4&#010;PatternIncludesArtifactFilter.matchAgainst(). since I thought that may&#010;you needed a trailing : on the long id.&#010;&#010;But it does the "right thing" with as much of the pattern you provide&#010;- and wildcards the rest.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

I dont think it is working with files at the point it is doing all the&#010;&gt; checking, especially if the filter has a * in it.&#010;&#010;The message could be clearer about what it was complaining about: "Found &#010;Include in a Dependency Set that is not declared as a dependency"&#010;If the message is triggered by other events, perhaps it might need to be &#010;a bit more general.&#010;&#010;"The following patterns were never triggered in this artifact inclusion filter"&#010;&#010;makes one think that the problem has something to do with the flow &#010;control ("triggered") rather than the artifact itself.&#010;It looks like the message has more to do with the way the plug-in is &#010;structured internally than the way the configuration is specified.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; I guess you could use&#010;&gt; http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/apidocs/org/apache/commons/lang3/StringUtils.html#getLevenshteinDistance%28java.lang.CharSequence,%20java.lang.CharSequence%29&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Name  :- Benoît Berthonneau &lt;ben...@berthonneau.com&gt;
Subject  :-Code coverage with debug logs: 100% branch coverage not possible?...
contents:- Hi all,&#010;&#010; &#010;&#010;I need your opinion/way to tackle the following problem:&#010;&#010;In many projects we use a Logger (doesnt matter which implementation). It&#010;is often recommend to test if the debug level is activated before logging a&#010;debug trace like the following:&#010;&#010;if (logger.isDebugEnabled()) {&#010;&#010;    logger.debug(blah  + i +  in the loop that contains  + max);&#010;&#010;}&#010;&#010; &#010;&#010;Now when you run unit tests on this kind of code you need to make a choice:&#010;run tests with INFO level or run tests with ALL traces activated. I choose&#010;the second option in order to:&#010;&#010;*         Check that debug traces doesnt throw unwanted exception (like&#010;NPE)&#010;&#010;*         Have a better code coverage in term of covered lines&#010;&#010; &#010;&#010;But in term of branches coverage we could never have a 100% :(&#010;&#010; &#010;&#010;To me the only way to cover this is to run the tests suite 2 times: one with&#010;INFO traces configured, and another one with ALL traces activated.&#010;&#010;Did you face this issue and how did you solve it ?&#010;&#010; &#010;&#010;Thanks,&#010;&#010;Benoît.&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Paul Benedict &lt;pbened...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Code coverage with debug logs: 100% branch coverage not possible?...
contents:- IIRC, there should be an option in Emma/Cobertura that allows you to&#010;exclude coverage on certain classes. So if you can exclude your log4j&#010;classes (you don't really want to test your logging, do you?), then you&#010;should be able to raise your percentage.&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Feb 12, 2014 at 2:30 PM, Benoît Berthonneau&#010;&lt;benoit@berthonneau.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi all,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I need your opinion/way to tackle the following problem:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; In many projects we use a Logger (doesn't matter which implementation). It&#010;&gt; is often recommend to test if the debug level is activated before logging a&#010;&gt; debug trace like the following:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; if (logger.isDebugEnabled()) {&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     logger.debug("blah " + i + " in the loop that contains " + max);&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; }&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Now when you run unit tests on this kind of code you need to make a choice:&#010;&gt; run tests with INFO level or run tests with ALL traces activated. I choose&#010;&gt; the second option in order to:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; *         Check that debug traces doesn't throw unwanted exception (like&#010;&gt; NPE)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; *         Have a better code coverage in term of covered lines&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; But in term of branches coverage we could never have a 100% :(&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; To me the only way to cover this is to run the tests suite 2 times: one&#010;&gt; with&#010;&gt; INFO traces configured, and another one with ALL traces activated.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Did you face this issue and how did you solve it ?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Benoît.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Cheers,&#010;Paul&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Reto Hablützel &lt;ret...@rethab.ch&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Code coverage with debug logs: 100% branch coverage not possible?...
contents:- To follow up on Paul's answer, I would go as far as to say that I test my&#010;code in order to feel comfortable that it actually does what it should do.&#010;Thus, I can very well live with 90% coverage if I know what the missing 10%&#010;are rather than testing for the sake of making a good impression with a&#010;100% report.&#010;&#010;- Reto&#010;On Feb 12, 2014 9:37 PM, "Paul Benedict" &lt;pbenedict@apache.org&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; IIRC, there should be an option in Emma/Cobertura that allows you to&#010;&gt; exclude coverage on certain classes. So if you can exclude your log4j&#010;&gt; classes (you don't really want to test your logging, do you?), then you&#010;&gt; should be able to raise your percentage.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Wed, Feb 12, 2014 at 2:30 PM, Benoît Berthonneau&#010;&gt; &lt;benoit@berthonneau.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Hi all,&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I need your opinion/way to tackle the following problem:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; In many projects we use a Logger (doesn't matter which implementation).&#010;&gt; It&#010;&gt; &gt; is often recommend to test if the debug level is activated before&#010;&gt; logging a&#010;&gt; &gt; debug trace like the following:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; if (logger.isDebugEnabled()) {&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;     logger.debug("blah " + i + " in the loop that contains " + max);&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; }&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Now when you run unit tests on this kind of code you need to make a&#010;&gt; choice:&#010;&gt; &gt; run tests with INFO level or run tests with ALL traces activated. I&#010;&gt; choose&#010;&gt; &gt; the second option in order to:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; *         Check that debug traces doesn't throw unwanted exception (like&#010;&gt; &gt; NPE)&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; *         Have a better code coverage in term of covered lines&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; But in term of branches coverage we could never have a 100% :(&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; To me the only way to cover this is to run the tests suite 2 times: one&#010;&gt; &gt; with&#010;&gt; &gt; INFO traces configured, and another one with ALL traces activated.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Did you face this issue and how did you solve it ?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Thanks,&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Benoît.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Cheers,&#010;&gt; Paul&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Subject  :-RE: Code coverage with debug logs: 100% branch coverage not possible?...
contents:- Hi Reto,&#010;&#010;I understood your point of view but to me the problem I'm talking about&#010;could be "easily" solved for a better branch coverage and know what is the&#010;real missed branches report.&#010;&#010;Benoît.&#010;&#010;&#010;-----Message d'origine-----&#010;De : Reto Hablützel [mailto:rethab@rethab.ch] &#010;Envoyé : mercredi 12 février 2014 21:47&#010;À : Maven Users List&#010;Objet : Re: Code coverage with debug logs: 100% branch coverage not&#010;possible?...&#010;&#010;To follow up on Paul's answer, I would go as far as to say that I test my&#010;code in order to feel comfortable that it actually does what it should do.&#010;Thus, I can very well live with 90% coverage if I know what the missing 10%&#010;are rather than testing for the sake of making a good impression with a 100%&#010;report.&#010;&#010;- Reto&#010;On Feb 12, 2014 9:37 PM, "Paul Benedict" &lt;pbenedict@apache.org&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; IIRC, there should be an option in Emma/Cobertura that allows you to &#010;&gt; exclude coverage on certain classes. So if you can exclude your log4j &#010;&gt; classes (you don't really want to test your logging, do you?), then &#010;&gt; you should be able to raise your percentage.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Wed, Feb 12, 2014 at 2:30 PM, Benoît Berthonneau&#010;&gt; &lt;benoit@berthonneau.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Hi all,&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I need your opinion/way to tackle the following problem:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; In many projects we use a Logger (doesn't matter which implementation).&#010;&gt; It&#010;&gt; &gt; is often recommend to test if the debug level is activated before&#010;&gt; logging a&#010;&gt; &gt; debug trace like the following:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; if (logger.isDebugEnabled()) {&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;     logger.debug("blah " + i + " in the loop that contains " + max);&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; }&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Now when you run unit tests on this kind of code you need to make a&#010;&gt; choice:&#010;&gt; &gt; run tests with INFO level or run tests with ALL traces activated. I&#010;&gt; choose&#010;&gt; &gt; the second option in order to:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; *         Check that debug traces doesn't throw unwanted exception (like&#010;&gt; &gt; NPE)&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; *         Have a better code coverage in term of covered lines&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; But in term of branches coverage we could never have a 100% :(&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; To me the only way to cover this is to run the tests suite 2 times: &#010;&gt; &gt; one with INFO traces configured, and another one with ALL traces &#010;&gt; &gt; activated.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Did you face this issue and how did you solve it ?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Thanks,&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Benoît.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Cheers,&#010;&gt; Paul&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;
