Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Why does Maven fail to compile my project occasionally?
contents:- On 20/02/2014 4:38 AM, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt; On 20 February 2014 01:58, LevskiWeng &lt;levskiweng@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Wayne Fay wrote&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven calls out to your system JDK to do the compilation step. With&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; the [ERROR] lines you provided previously, Maven is simply passing&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; along the error that was reported by javac. I bet, if you constructed&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; the proper javac call (which can be seen in Maven's logs if you use -X&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; for debug mode), you would see the same error produced without&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; involving Maven (or Jenkins) at all.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; IIRC you had some "cannot find symbol" errors. What do you expect&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven to do about code defects reported by the Java compiler? Why are&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; you blaming Maven for this?&#010;&gt;&gt; After digging into the dependency tree described in each module's pom.xml&#010;&gt;&gt; for several days, I found that you're right. It's my fault, not Maven's.&#010;&gt;&gt; It's because my code depends some other modules which I didn't put it into&#010;&gt;&gt; pom.xml explicitly. And I'm adding them into the corresponding pom.xml.&#010;&gt;&gt; Thank you for directing me back to the right track!&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; However, I'm curious that I succeed to compile the project after several&#010;&gt;&gt; compilation failure. How does it happen? I've passed the parameter 'clean&#010;&gt;&gt; install -Dmaven.test.skip=true --update-snapshots --batch-mode --fail-fast&#010;&gt;&gt; --debug -Dmaven.compiler.forceJavacCompilerUse=true&#010;&gt;&gt; -Dmaven.compiler.verbose=true' to Maven, but it doesn't get the same error&#010;&gt;&gt; when I compile the project the second time. And it mislead me to blame&#010;&gt;&gt; Maven&#010;&gt;&gt; ;-)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Could anyone explain the somewhat weird behavior of Maven? Thanks.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; Do you happen to have eclipse open while doing your tests?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; If the answer is yes, then eclipse could be doing some background&#010;&gt; compilation and just happen to write the files in place during your second&#010;&gt; time on the cli&#010;Eclipse can resolve missing dependencies by looking at other projects in &#010;your workspace.&#010;It is a good idea to turn this off so you don't make projects that only &#010;work in your workspace.&#010;&#010;You can look at project properties to see where Eclipse is getting your &#010;dependencies&#010;This can help track down the case where it builds in Eclipse or shows no &#010;errors in the imports while editing but will not build outside Eclipse.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; --&#010;&gt;&gt; View this message in context:&#010;&gt;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Why-does-Maven-fail-to-compile-my-project-occasionally-tp5784849p5785441.html&#010;&gt;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-Re: Why does Maven fail to compile my project occasionally?
contents:- Wayne Fay wrote&#010;&gt; I rarely use any parameters as you have done here. Can you try a&#010;&gt; simple "mvn clean install" and see how that goes? Also -U and -X may&#010;&gt; be useful shortcuts for you to know about.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; And I agree with Stephen and Ron - Eclipse sometimes does helpful&#010;&gt; things which produce hard to explain results. I would suggest either&#010;&gt; using Eclipse or Maven CLI but not both simultaneously on the same&#010;&gt; project (close Eclipse &amp; just use Maven CLI, or just use Eclipse).&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Wayne&#010;&#010;Well, Eclipse is not installed on my daily-build server, so I guess it has&#010;nothing to do with Eclipse. ;-)&#010;&#010;I guess when Maven encounters the missing-dependency compilation error, it&#010;doesn't stop compiling immediately, and it tries its best to compile other&#010;unrelated modules. When I compile the whole project again, the missing&#010;dependent modules may appear in the local repository because the unrelated&#010;modules compiled previously have declared them as dependencies.&#010;&#010;Anyway, the long-lasting problem has been solved perfectly. Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Why does Maven fail to compile my project occasionally?
contents:- &gt; Well, Eclipse is not installed on my daily-build server, so I guess it has&#010;&gt; nothing to do with Eclipse. ;-)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I guess when Maven encounters the missing-dependency compilation error, it&#010;&gt; doesn't stop compiling immediately, and it tries its best to compile other&#010;&gt; unrelated modules. When I compile the whole project again, the missing&#010;&gt; dependent modules may appear in the local repository because the unrelated&#010;&gt; modules compiled previously have declared them as dependencies.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Anyway, the long-lasting problem has been solved perfectly. Thank you guys!&#010;&#010;What you have is a http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heisenbug&#010;And you need to understand what the root cause of the problem is.&#010;Otherwise you will suffer this problem again in the future.&#010;&#010;Plus, once you understand the problem you should post back to the list&#010;and explain it.&#010;So that other people can google their similar problems and find the answer.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Why does Maven fail to compile my project occasionally?
contents:- Is it possible that you have more than 1 version of Java installed?&#010;I use Eclipse/STS,  have all the Maven tools that I need to build with &#010;Maven so I may suggest some things that you may not have, with m2 &#010;installed separately.&#010;&#010;1) Look in the project properties and make sure that you have nothing &#010;specified as a library besides Maven dependencies. (libraries might be &#010;configured in Eclipse that you are not setting in other builds)&#010;2) Make sure that you do not allow Eclipse to use other project &#010;workspaces for resolution of dependencies.(Eclipse will look in other &#010;eclipse projects to find dependencies).&#010;3) Make sure that you are using the "right" java compiler from Eclipse. &#010;It is easy to get different compilers in play.&#010;&#010;&#010;If you do all this, you may find that your Eclipse build fails in the &#010;same way that your other builds fail.&#010;You can then fix them both up to be the same.&#010;&#010;I hope that this helps.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;n 16/02/2014 10:15 AM, LevskiWeng wrote:&#010;&gt; Thanks for your suggestion. But I don't think it's the Jenkins fault&#010;&gt; because:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I've written a Windows batch file to invoke Maven to build the project&#010;&gt; before I choose Jenkins as my daily build system. And at that time I got&#010;&gt; the same Maven error as I described in this thread.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'll post some other source code and POM files later. Please help me to&#010;&gt; diagnose my problem then. Thanks.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; P.S:&#010;&gt; I'll diagnose my POM configuration of package dependency, and I'll post the&#010;&gt; result here tomorrow.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Sun, Feb 16, 2014 at 2:59 AM, stephenconnolly [via Maven] &lt;&#010;&gt; ml-node+s40175n5785002h44@n5.nabble.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; http://javaadventure.blogspot.ie/2013/11/jenkins-maven-job-type-considered-evil.html&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Using the evil one makes Maven behave in ways that it doesn't intend to...&#010;&gt;&gt; Please try with a FreeStyle job using a Maven Build step to see if it is&#010;&gt;&gt; the evil job type causing issues for you&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Levski Weng&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Why-does-Maven-fail-to-compile-my-project-occasionally-tp5784849p5785057.html&#010;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

contents:- "My code is correct because I could successfully build the whole project  &#010;in Eclipse again and again."&#010;This is 100% true. Within Eclipse you can manually add libraries.  &#010;Actually, if you create your first JUnit test, Eclipse will ask if the  &#010;JUnit4 library should be added. If you do so, it's added as an Eclipse  &#010;library, but your Maven build won't have junit as a dependency, resulting  &#010;in uncompilable tests.&#010;&#010;&gt; [INFO] -------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; [ERROR] COMPILATION ERROR :&#010;&gt; [INFO] -------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; [ERROR] \Program Files&#010;&gt; (x86)\Jenkins\jobs\CDMS-web-server\workspace\src\com.xxx.system\com.xxx.system.devicecenter\src\main\java\com\centerm\system\devicecenter\network\AgentIdResourceMapIpHandle.java:[36,24]&#010;&gt; Can't find the symbol&#010;&gt; Symbol: Variable TYPE_AGENT_ID&#010;&gt; Location: Class com.xxx.system.common.ResourceTypeDef&#010;&gt; [ERROR] \Program Files&#010;&gt; (x86)\Jenkins\jobs\CDMS-web-server\workspace\src\com.xxx.system\com.xxx.system.devicecenter\src\main\java\com\centerm\system\devicecenter\network\AgentUuidResourceMapIpHandle.java:[38,24]&#010;&gt; Can't find the symbol&#010;&gt; Symbol: Variable TYPE_AGENT_UUID&#010;&gt; Location: Class com.xxx.system.common.ResourceTypeDef&#010;&gt; [ERROR] \Program Files&#010;&gt; (x86)\Jenkins\jobs\CDMS-web-server\workspace\src\com.xxx.system\com.xxx.system.devicecenter\src\main\java\com\centerm\system\devicecenter\network\AgentIdAgentUpdateMapIpHandle.java:[32,24]&#010;&gt; Can't find the symbol&#010;&gt; Symbol: Variable TYPE_COMPUTER_ID_FOR_UPDATE&#010;&gt; Location: Class com.xxx.system.common.ResourceTypeDef&#010;&gt; [INFO] 3 errors&#010;&gt; [INFO] -------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&#010;Did you open this file?&#010;AgentIdResourceMapIpHandle.java:[36,24] refers to line 36, column 24. Name  :- LevskiWeng &lt;levskiw...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Why does Maven fail to compile my project occasionally?
contents:- Robert Scholte-4 wrote&#010;&gt; "My code is correct because I could successfully build the whole project  &#010;&gt; in Eclipse again and again."&#010;&gt; This is 100% true. Within Eclipse you can manually add libraries.  &#010;&gt; Actually, if you create your first JUnit test, Eclipse will ask if the  &#010;&gt; JUnit4 library should be added. If you do so, it's added as an Eclipse  &#010;&gt; library, but your Maven build won't have junit as a dependency, resulting  &#010;&gt; in uncompilable tests.&#010;&#010;I'm add all necessary dependent libraries that I know in pom.xml. It looks&#010;weird and I've no idea about it. Could you help me to diagnose the problem&#010;further?&#010;&#010;&#010;Robert Scholte-4 wrote&#010;&gt; Did you open this file?&#010;&gt; AgentIdResourceMapIpHandle.java:[36,24] refers to line 36, column 24. Just  &#010;&gt; open that file with notepad (copy/paste the fully qualified path to ensure  &#010;&gt; you're picking up the correct file, not some copy)&#010;&gt; Where is that "symbol"/Class coming from? It seems to be on the classpath  &#010;&gt; of your Eclipse, but it is not a dependency for Maven.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Robert&#010;&#010;I guess I've declared all dependent packages in the pom.xml.&#010;The content of AgentIdResourceMapIpHandle.java is: (I omit the unimportant&#010;lines)&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; contents:- &gt; To: users@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; Subject: Re: Why does Maven fail to compile my project occasionally?&#010;&gt; Date: Sat, 15 Feb 2014 11:45:57 +0100&#010;&gt; From: rfscholte@apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; "My code is correct because I could successfully build the whole project &#010;&gt; in Eclipse again and again."&#010;&gt; This is 100% true. Within Eclipse you can manually add libraries. &#010;&gt; Actually, if you create your first JUnit test, Eclipse will ask if the &#010;&gt; JUnit4 library should be added. Actually I can't se how it can help me :(&#010;&#010;Thanks for the help :)&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Apr 30, 2014 at 11:22 PM, Ron Wheeler &lt;&#010;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I don't have time to look at code and projects for free.&#010;&gt; If you need consulting to move forward, there are others here that do&#010;&gt; Maven for a business and can help you better than I can.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Have you tried making the red5 scope "provided".&#010;&gt; What does this do to your build?&#010;&gt; Does it get eliminate the red5 classes from your jar so that it only&#010;&gt; appears in the assembled war as a resource?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; To make life simpler, remove all code from the war project and put it into&#010;&gt; a separate project that makes a jar that the war depends on.&#010;&gt; This will make it clearer when you need red5 to compile your code and when&#010;&gt; you need it to build a deployable war.&#010;&gt; It will have scope "provided" as a dependency in your jar project.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Do you have specific questions about my blog articles on Maven and&#010;&gt; aggregation jars?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 30/04/2014 11:44 AM, Maxim Solodovnik wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I'm afraid I don't understand your advice :(&#010;&gt;&gt; Sorry&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; maybe you have example project available?&#010;&gt;&gt; Or maybe you can take a look at my project&#010;&gt;&gt; parent&#010;&gt;&gt; http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/openmeetings/trunk/&#010;&gt;&gt; singlewebapp/pom.xml?revision=HEAD&amp;view=markup&#010;&gt;&gt; util&#010;&gt;&gt; http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/openmeetings/trunk/&#010;&gt;&gt; singlewebapp/openmeetings-util/pom.xml?revision=HEAD&amp;view=markup&#010;&gt;&gt; web&#010;&gt;&gt; http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/openmeetings/trunk/&#010;&gt;&gt; singlewebapp/openmeetings-web/pom.xml?revision=HEAD&amp;view=markup&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; and tell me what need to be changed.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; working example will help a lot :)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On Wed, Apr 30, 2014 at 11:11 AM, Ron Wheeler &lt;&#010;&gt;&gt; rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  So, as far as Maven is concerned, Red5 is scope "provided".&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; You want it to reference it for compiling but should not put its classes&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; in the jar or war since you are going to sneak it into the package&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; without&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven noticing.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Pretty standard problem. We make a lot of aggregation jars that are used&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; in the same way.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; http://blog.artifact-software.com/tech/?p=121 describes how we handle a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; similar need to produce skinny wars that use libraries in Tomcar/shared&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; or&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; tomcat/lib to avoid copies of the same code in multiple jars. Our LMS&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; project has over 80 Maven projects that produce a variety of jars and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; wars.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Many of these share the use of large libraries such as CXF, Spring and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Apache commons that can be shared through Tomcat's classloader rather&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; than&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; duplicated in each war.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; There are some other notes about Maven on our blog that you might find&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; interesting.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I would prefer an installer to get the shared libraries into tomcat/lib&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; but that is another issue.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 29/04/2014 10:24 PM, Maxim Solodovnik wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;  Here is the structure:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "Openmeetings Util" project has compile time dependency "Red5 server"&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Almost all other projects are dependent on "Openmeetings Util" and "Red5&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; server" (compile time)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; But When I'm creating war file in "Openmeetings Web" project I need to&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; remove "Red5 server" and all it dependencies from the WEB-INF/lib folder&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; since all these jar files will be placed into tomcat/lib folder.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; system&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; admin install all of your components in the "right" places&#010;with the&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; required permissions, initialization, etc. that may be required.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; you need it to build a deployable war.&#010;&gt; It will have scope "provided" as a dependency in your jar project.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Do you have specific questions about my blog articles on Maven and&#010;&gt; working example will help a lot :)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On Wed, Apr 30, 2014 at 11:11 AM, Ron Wheeler &lt;&#010;&gt;&gt; rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  So, as far as Maven is concerned, Red5 is scope "provided".&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; You want it to reference it for compiling but should not put its classes&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; in the jar or war since you are going to sneak it into the package&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; without&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven noticing.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Pretty standard problem. We make a lot of aggregation jars that are used&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; in the same way.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; http://blog.artifact-software.com/tech/?p=121 describes how we handle a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; similar need to produce skinny wars that use libraries in Tomcar/shared&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; or&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; tomcat/lib to avoid copies of the same code in multiple jars. Our LMS&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; project has over 80 Maven projects that produce a variety of jars and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; wars.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Many of these share the use of large libraries such as CXF, Spring and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Apache commons that can be shared through Tomcat's classloader rather&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; than&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; duplicated in each war.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; There are some other notes about Maven on our blog that you might find&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; interesting.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I would prefer an installer to get the shared libraries into tomcat/lib&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; but that is another issue.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 29/04/2014 10:24 PM, Maxim Solodovnik wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;  Here is the structure:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "Openmeetings Util" project has compile time dependency "Red5 server"&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Almost all other projects are dependent on "Openmeetings Util" and "Red5&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; server" (compile time)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Have you tried making the red5 scope "provided".&#010;&gt;&gt; What does this do to your build?&#010;&gt;&gt; Does it get eliminate the red5 classes from your jar so that it only&#010;&gt;&gt; appears in the assembled war as a resource?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; To make life simpler, remove all code from the war project and put it&#010;&gt;&gt; into a separate project that makes a jar that the war depends on.&#010;&gt;&gt; This will make it clearer when you need red5 to compile your code and&#010;&gt;&gt; when you need it to build a deployable war.&#010;&gt;&gt; It will have scope "provided" as a dependency in your jar project.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Do you have specific questions about my blog articles on Maven and&#010;&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;  So, as far as Maven is concerned, Red5 is scope "provided".&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; You want it to reference it for compiling but should not put its classes&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; in the jar or war since you are going to sneak it into the package&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; without&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven noticing.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Pretty standard problem. We make a lot of aggregation jars that are used&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; in the same way.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; http://blog.artifact-software.com/tech/?p=121 describes how we handle a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; similar need to produce skinny wars that use libraries in Tomcar/shared&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; or&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; tomcat/lib to avoid copies of the same code in multiple jars. Our LMS&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; project has over 80 Maven projects that produce a variety of jars and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; wars.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Many of these share the use of large libraries such as CXF, Spring and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Apache commons that can be shared through Tomcat's classloader rather&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; than&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; duplicated in each war.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; There are some other notes about Maven on our blog that you might find&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; interesting.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I would prefer an installer to get the shared libraries into tomcat/lib&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; but that is another issue.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ================

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Help with converting existing ant build to maven is required - forking
contents:- Never used "optional".&#010;What classes were missing when you used "provided"?&#010;http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-dependency-mechanism.html &#010;mentions that the transitive dependencies are not available if you use &#010;provided.&#010;You will have to add any dependencies that your code calls that are not &#010;part of Red5 but are also used by Red5.&#010;&#010;This is a good idea anyway since it documents what libraries your code &#010;actually uses.&#010;You may want to use a more recent version than the one that Red5 does.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;&#010;On 30/04/2014 8:56 PM, Maxim Solodovnik wrote:&#010;&gt; Make the dependency "optional" seems to help :)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Thu, May 1, 2014 at 7:43 AM, Maxim Solodovnik &lt;solomax666@gmail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Thanks for your time&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I have started with making red5 "provided" but the build failed since&#010;&gt;&gt; necessary classes were not found.&#010;&gt;&gt; May be is there any way to provide dependency before build ...&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; If not I will try to create optional dependency and another one&#010;&gt;&gt; subproject, not sure if it will work.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I believe the blog article would be better if you can extend it a little&#010;&gt;&gt; bit and improve the formatting. Actually I can't se how it can help me :(&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Thanks for the help :)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On Wed, Apr 30, 2014 at 11:22 PM, Ron Wheeler &lt;&#010;&gt;&gt; rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I don't have time to look at code and projects for free.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; If you need consulting to move forward, there are others here that do&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven for a business and can help you better than I can.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Have you tried making the red5 scope "provided".&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; What does this do to your build?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Does it get eliminate the red5 classes from your jar so that it only&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; appears in the assembled war as a resource?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; To make life simpler, remove all code from the war project and put it&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; into a separate project that makes a jar that the war depends on.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; This will make it clearer when you need red5 to compile your code and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; when you need it to build a deployable war.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; It will have scope "provided" as a dependency in your jar project.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Do you have specific questions about my blog articles on Maven and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; aggregation jars?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On Wed, Apr 30, 2014 at 11:11 AM, Ron Wheeler &lt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;   So, as far as Maven is concerned, Red5 is scope "provided".&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; You want it to reference it for compiling but should not put its classes&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; in the jar or war since you are going to sneak it into the package&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; without&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven noticing.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Pretty standard problem. We make a lot of aggregation jars that are used&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; in the same way.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; http://blog.artifact-software.com/tech/?p=121 describes how we handle&#010;a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; similar need to produce skinny wars that use libraries in Tomcar/shared&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; or&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; tomcat/lib to avoid copies of the same code in multiple jars. Our LMS&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; project has over 80 Maven projects that produce a variety of jars and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; wars.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Many of these share the use of large libraries such as CXF, Spring and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Apache commons that can be shared through Tomcat's classloader rather&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; than&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; duplicated in each war.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; There are some other notes about Maven on our blog that you might find&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; interesting.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I would prefer an installer to get the shared libraries into tomcat/lib&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; but that is another issue.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 29/04/2014 10:24 PM, Maxim Solodovnik wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;   Here is the structure:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "Openmeetings Util" project has compile time dependency "Red5 server"&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Almost all other projects are dependent on "Openmeetings Util" and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "Red5&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; server" (compile time)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; But When I'm creating war file in "Openmeetings Web" project I need&#010;to&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; remove "Red5 server" and all it dependencies from the WEB-INF/lib&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; folder&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; since all these jar files will be placed into tomcat/lib folder.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; contents:- If there are specific suggestions or questions about the maven blog &#010;articles (from anyone), I would be grateful to have them.&#010;They were written rather quickly to explain a technique that we found &#010;useful. People may have to read more than one of the maven articles to &#010;get the gist of what we do.&#010;&#010;Some of the more experienced and knowledgeable people in this forum have &#010;some reservations about our approach so I would hesitate to propose it &#010;as a "Best practice" but it does address the problem that you are facing &#010;in a way that works in a team environment (small team)&#010;and achieves the objects that we sought&#010;- faster maven build (install,deploy),&#010;- small wars (only our code),&#010;- easy deployment (fewer shared libraries)&#010;- shorter and simpler pom dependency specifications and&#010;- complete management control over versions of third party libraries.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;On 30/04/2014 8:43 PM, Maxim Solodovnik wrote:&#010;&gt; Thanks for your time&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I have started with making red5 "provided" but the build failed since&#010;&gt; necessary classes were not found.&#010;&gt; May be is there any way to provide dependency before build ...&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; If not I will try to create optional dependency and another one subproject,&#010;&gt; not sure if it will work.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I believe the blog article would be better if you can extend it a little&#010;&gt; bit and improve the formatting. Actually I can't se how it can help me :(&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks for the help :)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Wed, Apr 30, 2014 at 11:22 PM, Ron Wheeler &lt;&#010;&gt; rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I don't have time to look at code and projects for free.&#010;&gt;&gt; If you need consulting to move forward, there are others here that do&#010;&gt;&gt; Maven for a business and can help you better than I can.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Have you tried making the red5 scope "provided".&#010;&gt;&gt; What does this do to your build?&#010;&gt;&gt; Does it get eliminate the red5 classes from your jar so that it only&#010;&gt;&gt; appears in the assembled war as a resource?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; To make life simpler, remove all code from the war project and put it into&#010;&gt;&gt; a separate project that makes a jar that the war depends on.&#010;&gt;&gt; This will make it clearer when you need red5 to compile your code and when&#010;&gt;&gt; you need it to build a deployable war.&#010;&gt;&gt; It will have scope "provided" as a dependency in your jar project.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Do you have specific questions about my blog articles on Maven and&#010;&gt;&gt; aggregation jars?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 30/04/2014 11:44 AM, Maxim Solodovnik wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm afraid I don't understand your advice :(&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; singlewebapp/pom.xml?revision=HEAD&amp;view=markup&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; util&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/openmeetings/trunk/&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; singlewebapp/openmeetings-util/pom.xml?revision=HEAD&amp;view=markup&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; working example will help a lot :)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On Wed, Apr 30, 2014 at 11:11 AM, Ron Wheeler &lt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;   So, as far as Maven is concerned, Red5 is scope "provided".&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; You want it to reference it for compiling but should not put its classes&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; in the jar or war since you are going to sneak it into the package&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; without&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven noticing.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Pretty standard problem. We make a lot of aggregation jars that are used&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; in the same way.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; http://blog.artifact-software.com/tech/?p=121 describes how we handle a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; similar need to produce skinny wars that use libraries in Tomcar/shared&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; or&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; tomcat/lib to avoid copies of the same code in multiple jars. Our LMS&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; project has over 80 Maven projects that produce a variety of jars and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; wars.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Many of these share the use of large libraries such as CXF, Spring and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Apache commons that can be shared through Tomcat's classloader rather&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; than&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; duplicated in each war.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; There are some other notes about Maven on our blog that you might find&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; interesting.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I would prefer an installer to get the shared libraries into tomcat/lib&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; but that is another issue.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; during your Maven build (http://izpack.codehaus.org/&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; izpack-maven-plugin/e.g.).&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Name  :- Rickard von Essen &lt;rickard.von.es...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-[ANN] rpm-maven-plugin 2.1-alpha-4 Released
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;The Mojo team is pleased to announce the release of the rpm-maven-plugin&#010;version 2.1-alpha-4.&#010;&#010;The RPM Maven Plugin allows artifacts from one or more projects to be&#010;packaged in an RPM for distribution. In addition to project artifacts, the&#010;RPM can contain other resources to be installed with the artifacts and&#010;scripts to be run while the package is being installed and removed. This&#010;plugin does not support the full range of features available to RPMs. In&#010;particular, source RPMs can not be generated and the spec files which are&#010;used do not do any build process (the plugin collects the files and&#010;"installs" them for packaging).&#010;&#010;http://mojo.codehaus.org/rpm-maven-plugin/&#010;&#010;To get this update, simply specify the version in your project's plugin&#010;configuration:&#010;&#010;&lt;plugin&gt;&#010;        &lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.mojo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;        &lt;artifactId&gt;rpm-maven-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;        &lt;version&gt;2.1-alpha-4&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;Release Notes:&#010;http://jira.codehaus.org/secure/ReleaseNote.jspa?projectId=11970&amp;version=19640&#010;&#010;Enjoy,&#010;&#010;The Mojo team.&#010;&#010;Rickard von Essen&#010;&#010;

                &lt;executions&gt;&#010;&gt;                     &lt;execution&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;phase&gt;validate&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;goals&gt;&#010;&gt;                             &lt;goal&gt;copy&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;outputDirectory&gt;${endorsed.dir}&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt;                             &lt;silent&gt;true&lt;/silent&gt;&#010;&gt;                             &lt;artifactItems&gt;&#010;&gt;                                 &lt;artifactItem&gt;&#010;&gt;                                     &lt;groupId&gt;javax&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;javaee-endorsed-api&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;                                     &lt;version&gt;7.0&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;                                     &lt;type&gt;jar&lt;/type&gt;&#010;&gt;                                 &lt;/artifactItem&gt;&#010;&gt;                             &lt;/artifactItems&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;                     &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;&gt;                 &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;/plugins&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;/build&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;/project&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -----------------------------------&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The ojdbc jar is also colocated with the injection project jar. It is&#010;&gt; included as a runtime dependency in the persistence project and the&#010;&gt; injection project. I have tried to use the following fragment from the&#010;&gt; above POM to include the driver jar in the Class-path attribute in the&#010;&gt; Manifest file but this doesn't seem to do anything:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;                     &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;                     &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-jar-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;                     &lt;version&gt;2.4&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;                     &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;archive&gt;&#010;&gt;                             &lt;manifest&gt;&#010;&gt;                                 &lt;addClasspath&gt;true&lt;/addClasspath&gt;&#010;&gt;                             &lt;/manifest&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;/archive&gt;&#010;&gt;                     &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;                 &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I've set the classpath environment variable to include the driver jar and&#010;&gt; I've tried running appclient with the -classpath option but I cannot seem&#010;&gt; to set the appropriate classpath for appclient no matter what I try. 2&#010;&gt; weeks of misguided hacking in the evenings is enough so  I'm hoping someone&#010;&gt; out there who understands this technology can help (as I clearly don't get&#010;&gt; sufficient understanding from tutorials/blogs/manuals/hacking..)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I am using :&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Netbeans 8&#010;&gt; Glassfish 4&#010;&gt; JDK 1.7 (tried with 1.6 too with no difference)&#010;&gt; Oracle 11.2.0.1&#010;&gt; Oracle driver 'ojdbc6.jar', download from OTN&#010;&gt; ...  on a Windows 7 64-bit laptop&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks in advance for any help&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Kind regards&#010;&gt; Mark&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; Subject  :-Spring snapshots
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;I am trying to understand mavens downloading of snapshots (maven 3.0.4,&#010;vanilla install)&#010;&#010;I use only spring RELEASE (3.1.4.RELEASE) builds in my pom and I have no&#010;repository definitions in the pom.&#010;When I display the dependency tree with mvn dependency:tree I also see that&#010;my project has no dependencies on snapshots.&#010;&#010;Nevertheless, every day, maven pulls in loads of snapshots from the spring&#010;snapshot repository.&#010;&#010;How can I avoid downloading the snapshots?&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Alexander&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Martin Gainty &lt;mgai...@hotmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-RE: Spring snapshots
contents:- &#010;when invoking mvn why not pass the repositoryId of the NON-SNAPSHOT repository you want  e.g.?&#010;&lt;repository&gt;&#010;    &lt;id&gt;jboss&lt;/id&gt;&#010;    &lt;name&gt;JBoss Repository&lt;/name&gt;&#010;    &lt;url&gt;http://repository.jboss.com/maven2&lt;/url&gt;&#010;    &lt;snapshots&gt;&#010;        &lt;enabled&gt;false&lt;/enabled&gt;&#010;    &lt;/snapshots&gt;&#010;&lt;/repository&gt;mvn -DrepositoryId=jboss WhateverTarget&#010;&#010;?&#010;Martin &#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; Date: Thu, 1 May 2014 13:58:33 +0200&#010;&gt; Subject: Spring snapshots&#010;&gt; From: alexander.g.kaiser@gmail.com&#010;&gt; To: users@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I am trying to understand mavens downloading of snapshots (maven 3.0.4,&#010;&gt; vanilla install)&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I use only spring RELEASE (3.1.4.RELEASE) builds in my pom and I have no&#010;&gt; repository definitions in the pom.&#010;&gt; When I display the dependency tree with mvn dependency:tree I also see that&#010;&gt; my project has no dependencies on snapshots.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Nevertheless, every day, maven pulls in loads of snapshots from the spring&#010;&gt; snapshot repository.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; How can I avoid downloading the snapshots?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; -- &#010;&gt; Alexander&#010; &#009;&#009; &#009;   &#009;&#009;  &#010;

Name  :- Kristian Rosenvold &lt;kristian.rosenv...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: dependency plugin fails with &gt;9 threads
contents:- It turns out dependency plugin is using an old version of doxia (version&#010;1.0, latest released is 1.4) that has known thread safety issues. You&#010;*might* be able to work around this by adding the following dependencies to&#010;the dependency-plugin in your pom:&#010;&#010;    &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;      &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.doxia&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;      &lt;artifactId&gt;doxia-sink-api&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;      &lt;version&gt;1.4&lt;/version&gt;&#010;    &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;    &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;      &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.doxia&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;      &lt;artifactId&gt;doxia-site-renderer&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;      &lt;version&gt;1.4&lt;/version&gt;&#010;    &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&#010;See&#010;http://blog.sonatype.com/2008/04/how-to-override-a-plugins-dependency-in-mavenif&#010;you're unfamiliar about how to do this. this might work, but might&#010;also&#010;bug out due to some incompatibility between 1.0 and 1.4 of doxia, I did not&#010;try.&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;Please file an issue under http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MDEP&#010;&#010;&#010;Kristian&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;2014-05-01 16:00 GMT+02:00 Anthony Clark &lt;anthonyclarka2@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi All,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'm trying to improve our build by using parallel threads (i.e. mvn -T #)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Unfortunately I'm running into an error when I try to use more than 9&#010;&gt; threads on this 24 core server:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; [ERROR] Failed to execute goal&#010;&gt; org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-dependency-plugin:2.8:analyze-report&#010;&gt; (analyze-report)&#010;&gt;  on project enterprise-provided: An error has occurred in Dependency&#010;&gt; Analysis report generation. goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-depen&#010;&gt; dency-plugin:2.8:analyze-report (analyze-report) on project&#010;&gt; enterprise-provided: An error has occurred in Dependenc&#010;&gt; y Analysis report generation.&#010;&gt;         at&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; org.apache.maven.lifecycle.internal.MojoExecutor.execute(MojoExecutor.java:216)&#010;&gt;         at&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; org.apache.maven.lifecycle.internal.MojoExecutor.execute(MojoExecutor.java:153)&#010;&gt; Name  :- Kristian Rosenvold &lt;kristian.rosenv...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: dependency plugin fails with &gt;9 threads
contents:- I fixed the problem on trunk in dependency plugin.&#010;&#010;You should be able to modify the deps in your current version to work&#010;around this,&#010;but you need to mimic what I did in the actual fix:&#010;&#010;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;revision=1591759&#010;&#010;Kristian&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;2014-05-01 21:25 GMT+02:00 Kristian Rosenvold &lt;kristian.rosenvold@gmail.com&gt;&#010;:&#010;&#010;&gt; It turns out dependency plugin is using an old version of doxia (version&#010;&gt; 1.0, latest released is 1.4) that has known thread safety issues. You&#010;&gt; *might* be able to work around this by adding the following dependencies to&#010;&gt; the dependency-plugin in your pom:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.doxia&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;artifactId&gt;doxia-sink-api&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;version&gt;1.4&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.doxia&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;artifactId&gt;doxia-site-renderer&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;version&gt;1.4&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; See&#010;&gt; http://blog.sonatype.com/2008/04/how-to-override-a-plugins-dependency-in-mavenif you're&#010;unfamiliar about how to do this. this might work, but might also&#010;&gt; bug out due to some incompatibility between 1.0 and 1.4 of doxia, I did not&#010;&gt; try.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Please file an issue under http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MDEP&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Kristian&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 2014-05-01 16:00 GMT+02:00 Anthony Clark &lt;anthonyclarka2@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Hi All,&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I'm trying to improve our build by using parallel threads (i.e. mvn -T #)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Unfortunately I'm running into an error when I try to use more than 9&#010;&gt;&gt; threads on this 24 core server:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; [ERROR] Failed to execute goal&#010;&gt;&gt; org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-dependency-plugin:2.8:analyze-report&#010;&gt;&gt; (analyze-report)&#010;&gt;&gt;  on project enterprise-provided: An error has occurred in Dependency&#010;&gt;&gt; Analysis report generation. Name  :- Anthony Clark &lt;anthonyclar...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: dependency plugin fails with &gt;9 threads
contents:- Many thanks Kristian!&#010;&#010;I am currently dealing with another emergency but as soon as that is over I&#010;will track down the maven plugins directory and make the change.&#010;&#010;I'll add the bug in JIRA as soon as I am able.&#010;&#010;Thanks again!&#010;&#010;Anthony&#010;&#010;&#010;On Thu, May 1, 2014 at 4:08 PM, Kristian Rosenvold &lt;&#010;kristian.rosenvold@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I fixed the problem on trunk in dependency plugin.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; You should be able to modify the deps in your current version to work&#010;&gt; around this,&#010;&gt; but you need to mimic what I did in the actual fix:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;revision=1591759&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Kristian&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 2014-05-01 21:25 GMT+02:00 Kristian Rosenvold &lt;&#010;&gt; kristian.rosenvold@gmail.com&gt;&#010;&gt; :&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; It turns out dependency plugin is using an old version of doxia (version&#010;&gt; &gt; 1.0, latest released is 1.4) that has known thread safety issues. You&#010;&gt; &gt; *might* be able to work around this by adding the following dependencies&#010;&gt; to&#010;&gt; &gt; the dependency-plugin in your pom:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;     &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.doxia&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;artifactId&gt;doxia-sink-api&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;version&gt;1.4&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;     &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;     &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.doxia&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;artifactId&gt;doxia-site-renderer&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;version&gt;1.4&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;     &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; See&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; http://blog.sonatype.com/2008/04/how-to-override-a-plugins-dependency-in-mavenifyou're&#010;unfamiliar about how to do this. this might work, but might also&#010;&gt; &gt; bug out due to some incompatibility between 1.0 and 1.4 of doxia, I did&#010;&gt; not&#010;&gt; &gt; try.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Please file an issue under http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MDEP&#010;&gt; Name  :- Jörg Hohwiller &lt;jo...@j-hohwiller.de&gt;
Subject  :-[ANN] flatten-maven-plugin 1.0.0-beta-1 Released
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;The Mojo team is pleased to announce the release of the flatten-maven-plugin version 1.0.0-beta-1.&#010;&#010;Flatten Maven Plugin generates a flattened version of your pom.xml and makes maven to install&#010;and deploy this one instead of the original pom.xml.&#010;&#010;http://mojo.codehaus.org/flatten-maven-plugin/&#010;&#010;To get this update, simply specify the version in your project's plugin configuration:&#010;&#010;&lt;plugin&gt;&#010;         &lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.mojo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;         &lt;artifactId&gt;flatten-maven-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;         &lt;version&gt;1.0.0-beta-1&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;All you need to do is add the plugin to the plugins in your build section.&#010;&#010;This is the initial release.&#010;&#010;Enjoy,&#010;&#010;The Mojo team.&#010;  &#010;Jörg&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Eric Kolotyluk &lt;eric.koloty...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: [ANN] flatten-maven-plugin 1.0.0-beta-1 Released
contents:- When I tried using Maven with IBM's Jazz, I had to manually flatten my &#010;projects because Jazz could not deal with nested projects (modules).&#010;&#010;Was the flatten-maven-plugin designed to solve this problem, or some &#010;other problems?&#010;&#010;Cheers, Eric&#010;&#010;On 2014-05-01, 8:55 AM, Jörg Hohwiller wrote:&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The Mojo team is pleased to announce the release of the &#010;&gt; flatten-maven-plugin version 1.0.0-beta-1.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Flatten Maven Plugin generates a flattened version of your pom.xml and &#010;&gt; makes maven to install&#010;&gt; and deploy this one instead of the original pom.xml.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://mojo.codehaus.org/flatten-maven-plugin/&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; To get this update, simply specify the version in your project's &#010;&gt; plugin configuration:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.mojo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;artifactId&gt;flatten-maven-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;version&gt;1.0.0-beta-1&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; All you need to do is add the plugin to the plugins in your build &#010;&gt; section.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; This is the initial release.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Enjoy,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The Mojo team.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Jörg&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Alejandro.E...@miranda.com
Subject  :-Re: [ANN] flatten-maven-plugin 1.0.0-beta-1 Released
contents:- I have a pretty deep hierarchy of poms, ~ 4 or 5 levels where each level &#010;contains certain parameters. Sometimes when I want to change one of the &#010;root parameters and then release I am forced to release 4 or 5 poms, one &#010;at a time, before I can release the artifact we actually ship, otherwise &#010;the m-release-p will complain about snapshots. Can this plugin help with &#010;that? i.e help in releasing a chain of poms in one shot where some of the &#010;parents have SNAPSHOT dependencies. I cannot release from the higher &#010;levels because they aggregate the lower levels so this would release a lot &#010;of artifacts when I am trying to release only one of the leaf ones. To be &#010;clear, when I release only the higher level poms, I have to disable &#010;aggregation to avoid releasing too much&#010;&#010;In other words, I would need this plugin to basically only flatten when &#010;doing a release, but i am not sure if the switcheroo happens only at &#010;deploy time or early on so the snapshot-to-release changes in the pom done &#010;by the release-plugin would happen in the flattened version&#010;&#010;Anyone knows?&#010;&#010;Alejandro Endo | Software Designer/Concepteur de logiciels &#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;From:   Jörg Hohwiller &lt;joerg@j-hohwiller.de&gt;&#010;To:     announce@mojo.codehaus.org, dev@mojo.codehaus.org, &#010;user@mojo.codehaus.org, users@maven.apache.org, &#010;Date:   2014-05-01 11:56 AM&#010;Subject:        [ANN] flatten-maven-plugin 1.0.0-beta-1 Released&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;Hi,&#010;&#010;The Mojo team is pleased to announce the release of the &#010;flatten-maven-plugin version 1.0.0-beta-1.&#010;&#010;Flatten Maven Plugin generates a flattened version of your pom.xml and &#010;makes maven to install&#010;and deploy this one instead of the original pom.xml.&#010;&#010;http://mojo.codehaus.org/flatten-maven-plugin/&#010;&#010;To get this update, simply specify the version in your project's plugin &#010;configuration:&#010;&#010;&lt;plugin&gt;&#010;         &lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.mojo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;         &lt;artifactId&gt;flatten-maven-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;         &lt;version&gt;1.0.0-beta-1&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;All you need to do is add the plugin to the plugins in your build section.&#010;&#010;This is the initial release.&#010;&#010;Enjoy,&#010;&#010;The Mojo team.&#010; &#010;Jörg&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;DISCLAIMER:&#010;Privileged and/or Confidential information may be contained in this&#010;message. contents:- Hi Alejandro,&#010;&#010;I know what you are talking about and was facing the same trouble with &#010;maven.&#010;This is why I wrote flatten-maven-plugin.&#010;You might want to wait for beta-2 to get startet, but you could already &#010;give it a try if you want.&#010;To be warned:&#010;http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MOJO-2030&#010;&#010;Cheers&#010;   Jörg&#010;&#010;Am 01.05.2014 19:43, schrieb Alejandro.Endo@miranda.com:&#010;&gt; I have a pretty deep hierarchy of poms, ~ 4 or 5 levels where each level&#010;&gt; contains certain parameters. Can this plugin help with&#010;&gt; that? i.e help in releasing a chain of poms in one shot where some of the&#010;&gt; parents have SNAPSHOT dependencies. I cannot release from the higher&#010;&gt; levels because they aggregate the lower levels so this would release a lot&#010;&gt; of artifacts when I am trying to release only one of the leaf ones. doing a release, but i am not sure if the switcheroo happens only at&#010;&gt; deploy time or early on so the snapshot-to-release changes in the pom done&#010;&gt; by the release-plugin would happen in the flattened version&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; contents:- I have one archetype A which can be used to generate project B with module C and module D.&#010;I also need capability to generate second, third etc. module C that could be added to existing&#010;project B.&#010;How could I reuse module C definition in both cases? Name  :- Olivier Lamy &lt;ol...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-[ANN] Apache Maven Shade Plugin 2.3 Released
contents:- The Apache Maven team is pleased to announce the release of the Apache&#010;Maven Shade Plugin, version 2.3.&#010;&#010;This plugin provides the capability to package the artifact in an&#010;uber-jar, including its dependencies and to shade - i.e. rename - the&#010;packages of some of the dependencies.&#010;&#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-shade-plugin/&#010;&#010;You should specify the version in your project's plugin configuration:&#010;&#010;&lt;plugin&gt;&#010;  &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;  &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-shade-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;  &lt;version&gt;2.3&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;Release Notes - Maven Shade Plugin - Version 2.3&#010;&#010;** Bug&#010;    * [MSHADE-166] - maven-shade-plugin not compatible with Java 8&#010;&#010;** Improvement&#010;    * [MSHADE-167] - [PATCH] When individual classes are renamed, they&#010;are not debuggable&#010;&#010;&#010;Have Fun!&#010;--&#010;The Apache Maven team&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Baptiste Mathus &lt;bmat...@batmat.net&gt;
Subject  :-[ANN] buildnumber-maven-plugin 1.3 Released
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;The Mojo team is pleased to announce the release of the&#010;buildnumber-maven-plugin version 1.3.&#010;&#010;This mojo is designed to get a unique build number for each time you build&#010;your project. So while your version may remain constant at 1.0-SNAPSHOT for&#010;many iterations until release, you will have a build number that can&#010;uniquely identify each build during that time.&#010;&#010;http://mojo.codehaus.org/buildnumber-maven-plugin/&#010;&#010;To get this update, simply specify the version in your project's plugin&#010;configuration:&#010;&lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.mojo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&lt;artifactId&gt; buildnumber-maven-plugin&lt; /artifactId&gt;&#010;&lt;version&gt;1.3&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;Release Notes&#010;https://jira.codehaus.org/secure/ReleaseNote.jspa?projectId=12124&amp;version=18855&#010;&#010;Enjoy,&#010;&#010;The Mojo team.&#010;&#010;-- Baptiste&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Baptiste Mathus &lt;bmat...@batmat.net&gt;
Subject  :-[ANN] buildnumber-maven-plugin 1.3 Released
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;The Mojo team is pleased to announce the release of the&#010;buildnumber-maven-plugin version 1.3.&#010;&#010;This mojo is designed to get a unique build number for each time you build&#010;your project. So while your version may remain constant at 1.0-SNAPSHOT for&#010;many iterations until release, you will have a build number that can&#010;uniquely identify each build during that time.&#010;&#010;http://mojo.codehaus.org/buildnumber-maven-plugin/&#010;&#010;To get this update, simply specify the version in your project's plugin&#010;configuration:&#010;&lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.mojo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&lt;artifactId&gt; buildnumber-maven-plugin&lt; /artifactId&gt;&#010;&lt;version&gt;1.3&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;Release Notes&#010;https://jira.codehaus.org/secure/ReleaseNote.jspa?projectId=12124&amp;version=18855&#010;&#010;Enjoy,&#010;&#010;The Mojo team.&#010;&#010;-- Baptiste&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Bruce Wen &lt;bruce....@ericsson.com&gt;
Subject  :-RE: [ANN] buildnumber-maven-plugin 1.3 Released
contents:- Hi,&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;How does this work? I tried twice but the build number is still the same. &#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;Bruce Wen&#013;&#010;-----Original Message-----&#013;&#010;From: bmathus@gmail.com [mailto:bmathus@gmail.com] On Behalf Of Baptiste Mathus&#013;&#010;Sent: Friday, May 02, 2014 4:28 PM&#013;&#010;To: announce@mojo.codehaus.org; dev@mojo.codehaus.org; user@mojo.codehaus.org; Maven Users&#010;List&#013;&#010;Subject: [ANN] buildnumber-maven-plugin 1.3 Released&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;Hi,&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;The Mojo team is pleased to announce the release of the buildnumber-maven-plugin version 1.3.&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;This mojo is designed to get a unique build number for each time you build your project. So&#010;while your version may remain constant at 1.0-SNAPSHOT for many iterations until release,&#010;you will have a build number that can uniquely identify each build during that time.&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;http://mojo.codehaus.org/buildnumber-maven-plugin/&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;To get this update, simply specify the version in your project's plugin&#013;&#010;configuration:&#013;&#010;&lt;plugin&gt;&#013;&#010;&lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.mojo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#013;&#010;&lt;artifactId&gt; buildnumber-maven-plugin&lt; /artifactId&gt; &lt;version&gt;1.3&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&lt;/plugin&gt;&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;Release Notes&#013;&#010;https://jira.codehaus.org/secure/ReleaseNote.jspa?projectId=12124&amp;version=18855&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;Enjoy,&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;The Mojo team.&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;-- Baptiste&#013;&#010;

Name  :- Baptiste Mathus &lt;bmat...@batmat.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: [ANN] buildnumber-maven-plugin 1.3 Released
contents:- Just a small guess: if you're using a versioning control system (svn,git it&#010;mercurial supported), the build number won't indeed change if you're&#010;building the same source code many times: it will reflect the current state&#010;of your tree (say revision for svn, or sha-1 for Git).&#010;&#010;HTH&#010;Cheers&#010;Le 3 mai 2014 18:46, "Karl Heinz Marbaise" &lt;khmarbaise@gmx.de&gt; a écrit :&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Hi Bruce,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; How does this work? I tried twice but the build number is still the same.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; What does this mean?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; What did you tried? Can you show the pom file you used? Can you show the&#010;&gt; output you've got?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Kind regards&#010;&gt; Karl-Heinz Marbaise&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-How is version:display-plugin-updates determine the super-pom version (wrongly?)
contents:- Hello,&#010;&#010;when I create a minimal POM* and expand it with maven 3.2.1 then I see&#010;an entry in the resulting effective pom:&#010;&#010;      &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;        &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-surefire-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;        &lt;version&gt;2.12.4&lt;/version&gt;&#010;        &lt;executions&gt;&#010;          &lt;execution&gt;&#010;            &lt;id&gt;default-test&lt;/id&gt;&#010;            &lt;phase&gt;test&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;            &lt;goals&gt;&#010;              &lt;goal&gt;test&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;            &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;          &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;        &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;      &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;(and no plugin management enty). (from super-pom) 2.17&#010;&#010;I have no idea why it tells me that the super-pom defines 2.17, is this the expected behavior?&#010;In the debug output the versions look better.&#010;&#010;Greetings&#010;Bernd&#010;&#010;PS: I tested it with the following pom, settings file, empty local repo and commands:&#010;&#010;pom.xml:&#010;&lt;project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"&#010;  xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"&#010;  xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0&#010;                      http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd"&gt;&#010;  &lt;modelVersion&gt;4.0.0&lt;/modelVersion&gt;&#010;&#010;  &lt;groupId&gt;test&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;  &lt;artifactId&gt;pom-test&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;  &lt;version&gt;0.1-SNAPSHOT&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&#010;&lt;/project&gt;&#010;&#010;empty.xml:&#010;&lt;settings xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/SETTINGS/1.0.0"&#010;  xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"&#010;  xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/SETTINGS/1.0.0&#010;                      http://maven.apache.org/xsd/settings-1.0.0.xsd"&gt;&#010;&#009;&lt;localRepository&gt;C:\Users\USER\.m2\default-repository&lt;/localRepository&gt;&#010;&lt;/settings&gt;&#010;&#010;$ mvn -s empty.xml versions:display-plugin-updates&#010;$ mvn -s empty.xml help:effective-pom &gt; pom-effective.xml&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

contents:- Hi All,&#010;&#010;I'm trying to exclude the .gitignore file from the source package generated&#010;with Maven source plugin while executing mvn release:perform, but it did&#010;not work.&#010;&#010;&lt;plugin&gt;&#010;                    &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;                    &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-source-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;                    &lt;executions&gt;&#010;                        &lt;execution&gt;&#010;                            &lt;id&gt;attach-sources&lt;/id&gt;&#010;                            &lt;phase&gt;verify&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;                            &lt;goals&gt;&#010;                                &lt;goal&gt;jar-no-fork&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;                            &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;                            &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;                                &lt;excludes&gt;&#010;&#010;&lt;exclude&gt;${project.build.directory}/**/*&lt;/exclude&gt;&#010;                                    &lt;exclude&gt;**/.gitignore&lt;/exclude&gt;&#010;                                    &lt;exclude&gt;**/.git/**/*&lt;/exclude&gt;&#010;                                &lt;/excludes&gt;&#010;                            &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;                        &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;                    &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;                &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;The pom.xml file could be found here:&#010;https://github.com/apache/incubator-stratos/blob/4.0.0-incubating/pom.xml&#010;&#010;Really appreciate any thoughts on this.&#010;&#010;Thanks&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Imesh Gunaratne&#010;&#010;Technical Lead, WSO2&#010;Committer &amp; PPMC Member, Apache Stratos&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Mirko Friedenhagen &lt;mfriedenha...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Is it possible to exclude .gitignore file from source package?
contents:- Imesh,&#010;&#010;I wonder why you need this, in my usecases the .git directory and&#010;.gitignore are at the same level as pom.xml, the source plugin will&#010;only pick up stuff from src/main/java (and maybe&#010;target/generated-sources/SOURCE_GENERATOR).&#010;&#010;Regards Mirko&#010;--&#010;http://illegalstateexception.blogspot.com/&#010;https://github.com/mfriedenhagen/ (http://osrc.dfm.io/mfriedenhagen)&#010;https://bitbucket.org/mfriedenhagen/&#010;&#010;&#010;On Sun, May 4, 2014 at 7:44 PM, Imesh Gunaratne &lt;imesh@apache.org&gt;                     &lt;executions&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;execution&gt;&#010;&gt;                             &lt;id&gt;attach-sources&lt;/id&gt;&#010;&gt;                             &lt;phase&gt;verify&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;&gt; Name  :- Martin Hoeller &lt;mar...@xss.co.at&gt;
Subject  :-bug in maven-ear-plugin with skinny war?
contents:- Hi!&#010;&#010;I see strange behavior when using the maven EAR plugin with the&#010;skinnyWar [1] feature, which might be a bug.&#010;&#010;Here is the (simplified) module-structure I have:&#010;&#010;core&#010;  +-- core-shared&#010;&#010;web&#010;  +-- backend&#010;  +-- war&#010;&#010;ee&#010;  +-- ear&#010;&#010;Usually all modules share the same version (let's say 1.0) number. My&#010;"ear" module includes a skinny version of the war module, "core-shared"&#010;and some other 3rd-party dependencies. This works fine.&#010;&#010;However, when I update all modules to version 2.0-SNAPSHOT but keep the&#010;dependency on the "war" in the "ear" to version 1.0, the skinny war is&#010;no longer skinny. Instead the "war" 1.0 in the "ear" contains&#010;"core-shared" 1.0 dependency but the "ear" contains core-shared&#010;2.0-SNAPSHOT. Thus, the dependency is included twice with different&#010;versions.&#010;&#010;IMHO the EAR plugin doesn't respect artifact's version information&#010;when removing JARs from the skinny war, but only removes JARs that&#010;match exactly (including version string). I'd consider this a bug. Or&#010;at least a missing feature in the EAR plugin.&#010;&#010;What do others think? Should I create a JIRA entry?&#010;&#010;thx,&#010;- martin&#010;&#010;[1] http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-ear-plugin/examples/skinny-wars.html&#010;&#010;

contents:- for legal purpose ( btw, please dont drill me here), I would like to use&#010;one mirror as a gate way for all of of my project dependencies,and another&#010;mirror as a gate way for all of my plugins and their dependencies&#010;&#010;&#010;is it possible? Posting a settings.xml config here is very much appreciated&#010;&#010;&#010;Thanks&#010;&#010;-D&#010;&#010;BTW&#010;&#010;as documented, I am currently  able to get both type of artifacts to use&#010;the same mirror to my repo manager&#010;&#010;http://maven.apache.org/guides/mini/guide-mirror-settings.html does not&#010;seem to support what I am looking for&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: use separate mirrors for project dendencies and plugin dependencies ??
contents:- On 6 May 2014 09:21, Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; for legal purpose ( btw, please dont drill me here), I would like to use&#010;&gt; one mirror as a gate way for all of of my project dependencies,and another&#010;&gt; mirror as a gate way for all of my plugins and their dependencies&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; is it possible? Posting a settings.xml config here is very much appreciated&#010;&#010;&#010;Having not done this, here is some more insane advice.&#010;&#010;I'd use three.&#010;One proxy to proxy the other two proxies.&#010;All developers point to the master proxy.&#010;You can then configure the master proxy to refer to the project&#010;dependencies proxy and another for plugins dependencies proxy.&#010;&#010;You might need a more sophisticated maven repository manager that you can&#010;restrict what is allowed in the proxies (i.e. it just doesn't go and grab&#010;stuff for you).&#010;&#010;You're going to have to do a lot of fiddling to get this to work.&#010;I'm not convinced it is going to give you what legal thinks it will...&#010;&#010;If you could write up what you tried and whether it worked it would be&#010;helpful for anyone else attempting the same thing...&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Christian Domsch &lt;m...@landrus.de&gt;
Subject  :-Re: use separate mirrors for project dendencies and plugin dependencies ??
contents:- Hi Dan,&#010;&#010;Did you consider using nexus? There you can setup any kind of strange &#010;repo setup your mind can come up with ;-) For your case, create one repo &#010;for your project stuff and one repo for your plugin stuff. Create a &#010;group for both for easy access and control access by authorization...&#010;&#010;Christian&#010;&#010;On 06.05.2014 06:29, Dan Tran wrote:&#010;&gt; Thanks Barrie,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Will see what I can can do.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Mon, May 5, 2014 at 5:04 PM, Barrie Treloar &lt;baerrach@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 6 May 2014 09:21, Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; for legal purpose ( btw, please dont drill me here), I would like to use&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; one mirror as a gate way for all of of my project dependencies,and&#010;&gt;&gt; another&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; mirror as a gate way for all of my plugins and their dependencies&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; is it possible? There you can setup any kind of strange repo&#010;&gt; setup your mind can come up with ;-) For your case, create one repo for&#010;&gt; your project stuff and one repo for your plugin stuff. Create a group for&#010;&gt; both for easy access and control access by authorization...&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Christian&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 06.05.2014 06:29, Dan Tran wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Thanks Barrie,&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Will see what I can can do.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On Mon, May 5, 2014 at 5:04 PM, Barrie Treloar &lt;baerrach@gmail.com&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  On 6 May 2014 09:21, Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;  for legal purpose ( btw, please dont drill me here), I would like to use&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; one mirror as a gate way for all of of my project dependencies,and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; another&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; mirror as a gate way for all of my plugins and their dependencies&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; is it possible? Posting a settings.xml config here is very much&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; appreciated&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Having not done this, here is some more insane advice.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'd use three.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; One proxy to proxy the other two proxies.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; All developers point to the master proxy.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; You can then configure the master proxy to refer to the project&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; dependencies proxy and another for plugins dependencies proxy.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; You might need a more sophisticated maven repository manager that you can&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; restrict what is allowed in the proxies (i.e. it just doesn't go and grab&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; stuff for you).&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; You're going to have to do a lot of fiddling to get this to work.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm not convinced it is going to give you what legal thinks it will...&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; If you could write up what you tried and whether it worked it would be&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; helpful for anyone else attempting the same thing...&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Bernd Eckenfels &lt;e...@zusammenkunft.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: use separate mirrors for project dendencies and plugin dependencies ??
contents:- Hello,&#010;&#010;It would be good if Proxy requests would actually carry the repository URLs or names the request&#010;is actually proxied for. I havent seen a proxy which allows configuration in this regard (and&#010;therefore I think the protocol does not provide this extra information)&#010;&#010;Bernd&#010;&#010;&gt; Am 06.05.2014 um 09:07 schrieb Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Ofcourse, I do have Maven repo manager ̣ nexus at this time), however still&#010;&gt; struggle on how to get only plugin's artifact goto one proxy and others&#010;&gt; goto to another proxy using mirror settings.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Are you able to do so?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; -Dan&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; On Mon, May 5, 2014 at 11:59 PM, Christian Domsch &lt;mail@landrus.de&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; Hi Dan,&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; Did you consider using nexus? There you can setup any kind of strange repo&#010;&gt;&gt; setup your mind can come up with ;-) For your case, create one repo for&#010;&gt;&gt; your project stuff and one repo for your plugin stuff. Create a group for&#010;&gt;&gt; both for easy access and control access by authorization...&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; Christian&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 06.05.2014 06:29, Dan Tran wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks Barrie,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Will see what I can can do.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On Mon, May 5, 2014 at 5:04 PM, Barrie Treloar &lt;baerrach@gmail.com&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 6 May 2014 09:21, Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; for legal purpose ( btw, please dont drill me here), I would like to use&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; one mirror as a gate way for all of of my project dependencies,and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; another&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; mirror as a gate way for all of my plugins and their dependencies&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; is it possible? Posting a settings.xml config here is very much&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; appreciated&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Having not done this, here is some more insane advice.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'd use three.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; One proxy to proxy the other two proxies.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; All developers point to the master proxy.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; You can then configure the master proxy to refer to the project&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; dependencies proxy and another for plugins dependencies proxy.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; You might need a more sophisticated maven repository manager that you can&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; restrict what is allowed in the proxies (i.e. it just doesn't go and grab&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; stuff for you).&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; You're going to have to do a lot of fiddling to get this to work.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm not convinced it is going to give you what legal thinks it will...&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; If you could write up what you tried and whether it worked it would be&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; helpful for anyone else attempting the same thing...&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;
