Name  :- Wolf Geldmacher &lt;wolf.geldmac...@abacus.ch&gt;
Subject  :-Re: use separate mirrors for project dendencies and plugin dependencies ??
contents:- On 06.05.2014 09:07, Dan Tran wrote:&#010;&gt; Ofcourse, I do have Maven repo manager ̣ nexus at this time), however still&#010;&gt; struggle on how to get only plugin's artifact goto one proxy and others&#010;&gt; goto to another proxy using mirror settings.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Are you able to do so?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -Dan&#010;I'm none to sure that this would even help at all:&#010;&#010;Presumably you are trying to separate artifacts used by plugins during &#010;your build (where you might use e.g. GPL licensed modules) from &#010;artifacts used as dependencies in your project proper (where using that &#010;same GPL licensed modules would make your legal department scream) by &#010;separating the repositories used to provide them.&#010;&#010;As far as I know/understand all artifacts are downloaded to the same &#010;local cache repository (~/.m2/repository), regardless of whether they &#010;were required by some plugin or as a dependency of your project.&#010;&#010;This makes them available for both purposes and thus obliterates all &#010;your efforts of keeping them separate.&#010;&#010;Maven Masters: Please correct me if I'm wrong.&#010;&#010;Cheers,&#010;Wolf&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Mon, May 5, 2014 at 11:59 PM, Christian Domsch &lt;mail@landrus.de&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Hi Dan,&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Did you consider using nexus? There you can setup any kind of strange repo&#010;&gt;&gt; setup your mind can come up with ;-) For your case, create one repo for&#010;&gt;&gt; your project stuff and one repo for your plugin stuff. Create a group for&#010;&gt;&gt; both for easy access and control access by authorization...&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Christian&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 06.05.2014 06:29, Dan Tran wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks Barrie,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Will see what I can can do.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On Mon, May 5, 2014 at 5:04 PM, Barrie Treloar &lt;baerrach@gmail.com&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;   On 6 May 2014 09:21, Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;   for legal purpose ( btw, please dont drill me here), I would like to use&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; one mirror as a gate way for all of of my project dependencies,and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; another&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; mirror as a gate way for all of my plugins and their dependencies&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; is it possible? Posting a settings.xml config here is very much&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; appreciated&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Having not done this, here is some more insane advice.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'd use three.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; One proxy to proxy the other two proxies.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; All developers point to the master proxy.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; You can then configure the master proxy to refer to the project&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; dependencies proxy and another for plugins dependencies proxy.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; You might need a more sophisticated maven repository manager that you can&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; restrict what is allowed in the proxies (i.e. it just doesn't go and grab&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; stuff for you).&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; You're going to have to do a lot of fiddling to get this to work.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm not convinced it is going to give you what legal thinks it will...&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; If you could write up what you tried and whether it worked it would be&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; helpful for anyone else attempting the same thing...&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Anders Hammar &lt;and...@hammar.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: use separate mirrors for project dendencies and plugin dependencies ??
contents:- &gt;&#010;&gt; Presumably you are trying to separate artifacts used by plugins during&#010;&gt; your build (where you might use e.g. GPL licensed modules) from artifacts&#010;&gt; used as dependencies in your project proper (where using that same GPL&#010;&gt; licensed modules would make your legal department scream) by separating the&#010;&gt; repositories used to provide them.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; As far as I know/understand all artifacts are downloaded to the same local&#010;&gt; cache repository (~/.m2/repository), regardless of whether they were&#010;&gt; required by some plugin or as a dependency of your project.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; This makes them available for both purposes and thus obliterates all your&#010;&gt; efforts of keeping them separate.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Maven Masters: Please correct me if I'm wrong.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;I don't think this is correct with Maven 3. Maven 3 uses Aether which AFAIK&#010;keeps the repository id for the artifact to verify from where it was&#010;downloaded. Haven't verified for this use case though.&#010;&#010;So, using Maven 3 it should be possible to specify one repository&#010;declaration for your deps and one pluginRepository declaration (with a&#010;different repo id) for your plugins (incl deps). If you msut use mirror&#010;declarations, I would use this for the deps and add exclusions (using '!')&#010;for any pluginRepository.&#010;&#010;/Anders&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Cheers,&#010;&gt; Wolf&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On Mon, May 5, 2014 at 11:59 PM, Christian Domsch &lt;mail@landrus.de&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  Hi Dan,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Did you consider using nexus? There you can setup any kind of strange&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; repo&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; setup your mind can come up with ;-) For your case, create one repo for&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; your project stuff and one repo for your plugin stuff. Create a group for&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; both for easy access and control access by authorization...&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Christian&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 06.05.2014 06:29, Dan Tran wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;  Thanks Barrie,&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Will see what I can can do.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On Mon, May 5, 2014 at 5:04 PM, Barrie Treloar &lt;baerrach@gmail.com&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;   On 6 May 2014 09:21, Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;   for legal purpose ( btw, please dont drill me here), I would like to&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; use&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; one mirror as a gate way for all of of my project dependencies,and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;  another&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;  mirror as a gate way for all of my plugins and their dependencies&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; is it possible? Posting a settings.xml config here is very much&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;  appreciated&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Having not done this, here is some more insane advice.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'd use three.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; One proxy to proxy the other two proxies.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; All developers point to the master proxy.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; You can then configure the master proxy to refer to the project&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; dependencies proxy and another for plugins dependencies proxy.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; You might need a more sophisticated maven repository manager that you&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; can&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; restrict what is allowed in the proxies (i.e. it just doesn't go and&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; grab&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; stuff for you).&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; You're going to have to do a lot of fiddling to get this to work.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm not convinced it is going to give you what legal thinks it will...&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; If you could write up what you tried and whether it worked it would be&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; helpful for anyone else attempting the same thing...&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: use separate mirrors for project dendencies and plugin dependencies ??
contents:- On 6 May 2014 20:23, Anders Hammar &lt;anders@hammar.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Presumably you are trying to separate artifacts used by plugins during&#010;&gt; &gt; your build (where you might use e.g. GPL licensed modules) from artifacts&#010;&gt; &gt; used as dependencies in your project proper (where using that same GPL&#010;&gt; &gt; licensed modules would make your legal department scream) by separating&#010;&gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; repositories used to provide them.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; As far as I know/understand all artifacts are downloaded to the same&#010;&gt; local&#010;&gt; &gt; cache repository (~/.m2/repository), regardless of whether they were&#010;&gt; &gt; required by some plugin or as a dependency of your project.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; This makes them available for both purposes and thus obliterates all your&#010;&gt; &gt; efforts of keeping them separate.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Maven Masters: Please correct me if I'm wrong.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I don't think this is correct with Maven 3. Maven 3 uses Aether which AFAIK&#010;&gt; keeps the repository id for the artifact to verify from where it was&#010;&gt; downloaded. Haven't verified for this use case though.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; So, using Maven 3 it should be possible to specify one repository&#010;&gt; declaration for your deps and one pluginRepository declaration (with a&#010;&gt; different repo id) for your plugins (incl deps). If you msut use mirror&#010;&gt; declarations, I would use this for the deps and add exclusions (using '!')&#010;&gt; for any pluginRepository.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; /Anders&#010;&#010;&#010;I don't remember what happens for duplicates.&#010;I think it used to complain that the artifact doesn't exist (if the one it&#010;downloaded from is not available, even though its available elsewhere).&#010;&#010;The GPL example isn't a good one, as the output of running GPL is not GPL&#010;itself.&#010;&#010;I think Nexus allows you to restrict things by licence so that you can&#010;curate what is available in your repository manager. You'd have to look at&#010;the docs to find out.&#010;&#010;

================

     &lt;id&gt;central&lt;/id&gt;&#010;      &lt;name&gt;Central Repository&lt;/name&gt;&#010;      &lt;url&gt;http://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2&lt;/url&gt;&#010;      &lt;layout&gt;default&lt;/layout&gt;&#010;      &lt;snapshots&gt;&#010;        &lt;enabled&gt;false&lt;/enabled&gt;&#010;      &lt;/snapshots&gt;&#010;      &lt;releases&gt;&#010;        &lt;updatePolicy&gt;never&lt;/updatePolicy&gt;&#010;      &lt;/releases&gt;&#010;    &lt;/pluginRepository&gt;&#010;  &lt;/pluginRepositories&gt;&#010;&#010;Is there a way to disable/clear out the super pom pluginRepositories?&#010;If I add my own pluginRepositories, will it override the super pom&#010;one?&#010;&#010;&#010;Thanks&#010;&#010;Dan&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;On Tue, May 6, 2014 at 6:20 AM, Barrie Treloar &lt;baerrach@gmail.com&gt; &gt; &gt; your build (where you might use e.g. GPL licensed modules) from&#010;&gt; artifacts&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; used as dependencies in your project proper (where using that same GPL&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; licensed modules would make your legal department scream) by separating&#010;&gt; &gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; repositories used to provide them.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; As far as I know/understand all artifacts are downloaded to the same&#010;&gt; &gt; local&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; cache repository (~/.m2/repository), regardless of whether they were&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; required by some plugin or as a dependency of your project.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; This makes them available for both purposes and thus obliterates all&#010;&gt; your&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; efforts of keeping them separate.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Maven Masters: Please correct me if I'm wrong.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I don't think this is correct with Maven 3. Maven 3 uses Aether which&#010;&gt; AFAIK&#010;&gt; &gt; keeps the repository id for the artifact to verify from where it was&#010;&gt; &gt; downloaded. Haven't verified for this use case though.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; So, using Maven 3 it should be possible to specify one repository&#010;&gt; &gt; declaration for your deps and one pluginRepository declaration (with a&#010;&gt; &gt; different repo id) for your plugins (incl deps). If you msut use mirror&#010;&gt; &gt; declarations, I would use this for the deps and add exclusions (using&#010;&gt; '!')&#010;&gt; &gt; for any pluginRepository.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; /Anders&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I don't remember what happens for duplicates.&#010;&gt; I think it used to complain that the artifact doesn't exist (if the one it&#010;&gt; downloaded from is not available, even though its available elsewhere).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The GPL example isn't a good one, as the output of running GPL is not GPL&#010;&gt; itself.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I think Nexus allows you to restrict things by licence so that you can&#010;&gt; curate what is available in your repository manager. You'd have to look at&#010;&gt; the docs to find out.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

    &lt;/pluginRepository&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;/pluginRepositories&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is there a way to disable/clear out the super pom pluginRepositories?&#010;&gt; If I add my own pluginRepositories, will it override the super pom&#010;&gt; during&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; your build (where you might use e.g. GPL licensed modules) from&#010;&gt; &gt; artifacts&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; used as dependencies in your project proper (where using that same&#010;&gt; GPL&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; licensed modules would make your legal department scream) by&#010;&gt; separating&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; repositories used to provide them.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; required by some plugin or as a dependency of your project.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; This makes them available for both purposes and thus obliterates all&#010;&gt; &gt; your&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; efforts of keeping them separate.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Maven Masters: Please correct me if I'm wrong.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; I don't think this is correct with Maven 3. Maven 3 uses Aether which&#010;&gt; &gt; AFAIK&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; keeps the repository id for the artifact to verify from where it was&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; downloaded. Haven't verified for this use case though.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; So, using Maven 3 it should be possible to specify one repository&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; declaration for your deps and one pluginRepository declaration (with a&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; different repo id) for your plugins (incl deps). If you msut use mirror&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; declarations, I would use this for the deps and add exclusions (using&#010;&gt; &gt; '!')&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; for any pluginRepository.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; /Anders&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I don't remember what happens for duplicates.&#010;&gt; &gt; I think it used to complain that the artifact doesn't exist (if the one&#010;&gt; it&#010;&gt; &gt; downloaded from is not available, even though its available elsewhere).&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; The GPL example isn't a good one, as the output of running GPL is not GPL&#010;&gt; &gt; itself.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I think Nexus allows you to restrict things by licence so that you can&#010;&gt; &gt; curate what is available in your repository manager. You'd have to look&#010;&gt; at&#010;&gt; &gt; the docs to find out.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

contents:- I got some thing working&#010;&#010;1. at my repo manager, create a proxy, called plugin-central, to host&#010;another central.maven.org/maven2&#010;2. reconfigure my global settings.xml with the following contents. &gt; Anders' suggestion sounds very logical&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; however, i found this at super pom&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;   &lt;repositories&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;     &lt;repository&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;id&gt;central&lt;/id&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;name&gt;Central Repository&lt;/name&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;url&gt;http://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2&lt;/url&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;layout&gt;default&lt;/layout&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;snapshots&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;         &lt;enabled&gt;false&lt;/enabled&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;/snapshots&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;     &lt;/repository&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;   &lt;/repositories&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;   &lt;pluginRepositories&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;     &lt;pluginRepository&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;id&gt;central&lt;/id&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;name&gt;Central Repository&lt;/name&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;url&gt;http://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2&lt;/url&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;layout&gt;default&lt;/layout&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;snapshots&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;         &lt;enabled&gt;false&lt;/enabled&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;/snapshots&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;releases&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;         &lt;updatePolicy&gt;never&lt;/updatePolicy&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;       &lt;/releases&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;     &lt;/pluginRepository&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;   &lt;/pluginRepositories&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Is there a way to disable/clear out the super pom pluginRepositories?&#010;&gt; &gt; If I add my own pluginRepositories, will it override the super pom&#010;&gt; &gt; one?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Thanks&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Dan&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; On Tue, May 6, 2014 at 6:20 AM, Barrie Treloar &lt;baerrach@gmail.com&gt;&#010;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; On 6 May 2014 20:23, Anders Hammar &lt;anders@hammar.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Presumably you are trying to separate artifacts used by plugins&#010;&gt; &gt; during&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; your build (where you might use e.g. GPL licensed modules) from&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; artifacts&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; used as dependencies in your project proper (where using that same&#010;&gt; &gt; GPL&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; licensed modules would make your legal department scream) by&#010;&gt; &gt; separating&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; repositories used to provide them.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; As far as I know/understand all artifacts are downloaded to the&#010;&gt; same&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; local&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; cache repository (~/.m2/repository), regardless of whether they&#010;&gt; were&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; required by some plugin or as a dependency of your project.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; This makes them available for both purposes and thus obliterates&#010;&gt; all&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; your&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; efforts of keeping them separate.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Maven Masters: Please correct me if I'm wrong.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I don't think this is correct with Maven 3. Maven 3 uses Aether which&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; AFAIK&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; keeps the repository id for the artifact to verify from where it was&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; downloaded. Haven't verified for this use case though.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; So, using Maven 3 it should be possible to specify one repository&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; declaration for your deps and one pluginRepository declaration (with&#010;&gt; a&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; different repo id) for your plugins (incl deps). If you msut use&#010;&gt; mirror&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; declarations, I would use this for the deps and add exclusions (using&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; '!')&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; for any pluginRepository.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; /Anders&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; I don't remember what happens for duplicates.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; I think it used to complain that the artifact doesn't exist (if the one&#010;&gt; &gt; it&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; downloaded from is not available, even though its available elsewhere).&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; The GPL example isn't a good one, as the output of running GPL is not&#010;&gt; GPL&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; itself.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; I think Nexus allows you to restrict things by licence so that you can&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; curate what is available in your repository manager. You'd have to look&#010;&gt; &gt; at&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; the docs to find out.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

same&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; GPL&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; licensed modules would make your legal department scream) by&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; separating&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; repositories used to provide them.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; As far as I know/understand all artifacts are downloaded to&#010;the&#010;&gt; required by some plugin or as a dependency of your project.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; This makes them available for both purposes and thus obliterates&#010;&gt; &gt; all&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; your&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; efforts of keeping them separate.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Maven Masters: Please correct me if I'm wrong.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I don't think this is correct with Maven 3. Maven 3 uses Aether&#010;&gt; which&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; AFAIK&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; keeps the repository id for the artifact to verify from where it&#010;&gt; was&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; downloaded. Haven't verified for this use case though.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; So, using Maven 3 it should be possible to specify one repository&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; declaration for your deps and one pluginRepository declaration&#010;&gt; (with&#010;&gt; &gt; a&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; different repo id) for your plugins (incl deps). If you msut use&#010;&gt; &gt; mirror&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; declarations, I would use this for the deps and add exclusions&#010;&gt; (using&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; '!')&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; for any pluginRepository.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; /Anders&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I don't remember what happens for duplicates.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I think it used to complain that the artifact doesn't exist (if the&#010;&gt; one&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; it&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; downloaded from is not available, even though its available&#010;&gt; elsewhere).&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The GPL example isn't a good one, as the output of running GPL is not&#010;&gt; &gt; GPL&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; itself.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I think Nexus allows you to restrict things by licence so that you&#010;&gt; can&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; curate what is available in your repository manager. You'd have to&#010;&gt; look&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; at&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the docs to find out.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-Re: use separate mirrors for project dendencies and plugin dependencies ??
contents:- Hi Ander&#010;&#010;that makes sense&#010;&#010;now i only have&#010;&#010; &lt;mirrors&gt;&#010;    &lt;mirror&gt;&#010;      &lt;id&gt;product-repo&lt;/id&gt;&#010;      &lt;mirrorOf&gt;*,!plugin-central&lt;/mirrorOf&gt;&#010;      &lt;name&gt;Internal Maven Repository Manager&lt;/name&gt;&#010;      &lt;url&gt;http://repos.xxx.com:8081/nexus/content/groups/public&lt;/url&gt;&#010;    &lt;/mirror&gt;&#010;  &lt;/mirrors&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;Also, do i need to redefine 'central'  it looks redundant to me&#010;&#010;Thanks&#010;&#010;-D&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;On Mon, May 26, 2014 at 10:34 PM, Anders Hammar &lt;anders@hammar.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; For my solution on this topic I didn't declare a mirror for&#010;&gt; 'plugin-central', i.e. I didn't have the 'plugin-repo' mirror declaration.&#010;&gt; I does not add anything as it is only a mirror for one repo.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; /Anders&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Sun, May 25, 2014 at 3:00 AM, Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I got some thing working&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; 1. at my repo manager, create a proxy, called plugin-central, to host&#010;&gt; &gt; another central.maven.org/maven2&#010;&gt; &gt; 2. reconfigure my global settings.xml with the following contents. &gt; &gt; &gt; one?&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Dan&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; On 6 May 2014 20:23, Anders Hammar &lt;anders@hammar.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Presumably you are trying to separate artifacts used by&#010;plugins&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; during&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; your build (where you might use e.g. GPL licensed modules)&#010;from&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; artifacts&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; used as dependencies in your project proper (where using&#010;that&#010;&gt; &gt; same&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; GPL&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; licensed modules would make your legal department scream)&#010;by&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; separating&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; repositories used to provide them.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; As far as I know/understand all artifacts are downloaded&#010;to the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; same&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; local&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; cache repository (~/.m2/repository), regardless of whether&#010;they&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; were&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; required by some plugin or as a dependency of your project.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; This makes them available for both purposes and thus&#010;&gt; obliterates&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; all&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; your&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; efforts of keeping them separate.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Maven Masters: Please correct me if I'm wrong.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I don't think this is correct with Maven 3. Maven 3 uses Aether&#010;&gt; &gt; which&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; AFAIK&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; keeps the repository id for the artifact to verify from where&#010;it&#010;&gt; &gt; was&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; downloaded. Haven't verified for this use case though.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; So, using Maven 3 it should be possible to specify one repository&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; declaration for your deps and one pluginRepository declaration&#010;&gt; &gt; (with&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; a&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; different repo id) for your plugins (incl deps). If you msut&#010;use&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; mirror&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; declarations, I would use this for the deps and add exclusions&#010;&gt; &gt; (using&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; '!')&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; for any pluginRepository.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; /Anders&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I don't remember what happens for duplicates.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I think it used to complain that the artifact doesn't exist (if the&#010;&gt; &gt; one&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; it&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; downloaded from is not available, even though its available&#010;&gt; &gt; elsewhere).&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The GPL example isn't a good one, as the output of running GPL is&#010;&gt; not&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; GPL&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; itself.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I think Nexus allows you to restrict things by licence so that you&#010;&gt; &gt; can&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; curate what is available in your repository manager. You'd have to&#010;&gt; &gt; look&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; at&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the docs to find out.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Anders Hammar &lt;and...@hammar.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: use separate mirrors for project dendencies and plugin dependencies ??
contents:- &gt;&#010;&gt; Also, do i need to redefine 'central'  it looks redundant to me&#010;&#010;&#010;It's best-practice IMO. It ensures that the central definition declared in&#010;the super-POM is overwritten with a dummy (not working) URL. It will/should&#010;then be handled by the mirror so that it is redirected to the internal&#010;mirror. If, for any reason, the mirror definition is removed or not&#010;correctly declared you will then quickly noticed this as your Maven build&#010;will not work (as the calls to 'central' will fail).&#010;&#010;/Anders&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -D&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Mon, May 26, 2014 at 10:34 PM, Anders Hammar &lt;anders@hammar.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; For my solution on this topic I didn't declare a mirror for&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; one?&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Dan&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; On 6 May 2014 20:23, Anders Hammar &lt;anders@hammar.net&gt;&#010;wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Presumably you are trying to separate artifacts used&#010;by&#010;&gt; plugins&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; during&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; your build (where you might use e.g. GPL licensed&#010;modules)&#010;&gt; from&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; artifacts&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; used as dependencies in your project proper (where&#010;using that&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; same&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; GPL&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; licensed modules would make your legal department&#010;scream) by&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; separating&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; repositories used to provide them.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; As far as I know/understand all artifacts are downloaded&#010;to&#010;&gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; same&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; local&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; cache repository (~/.m2/repository), regardless of&#010;whether&#010;&gt; they&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; were&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; required by some plugin or as a dependency of your&#010;project.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; This makes them available for both purposes and thus&#010;&gt; &gt; obliterates&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; all&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; your&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; efforts of keeping them separate.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Maven Masters: Please correct me if I'm wrong.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I don't think this is correct with Maven 3. Maven 3 uses&#010;Aether&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; which&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; AFAIK&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; keeps the repository id for the artifact to verify from&#010;where&#010;&gt; it&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; was&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; downloaded. Haven't verified for this use case though.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; So, using Maven 3 it should be possible to specify one&#010;&gt; repository&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; declaration for your deps and one pluginRepository declaration&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; (with&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; a&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; different repo id) for your plugins (incl deps). If you&#010;msut&#010;&gt; use&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; mirror&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; declarations, I would use this for the deps and add exclusions&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; (using&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; '!')&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; for any pluginRepository.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; /Anders&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I don't remember what happens for duplicates.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I think it used to complain that the artifact doesn't exist&#010;(if&#010;&gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; one&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; it&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; downloaded from is not available, even though its available&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; elsewhere).&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; The GPL example isn't a good one, as the output of running GPL&#010;is&#010;&gt; &gt; not&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; GPL&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; itself.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; I think Nexus allows you to restrict things by licence so that&#010;&gt; you&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; can&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; curate what is available in your repository manager. You'd have&#010;&gt; to&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; look&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; at&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; the docs to find out.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Cristiano Gavião &lt;cvgav...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-How to resolve and get the right packaging type?
contents:- Hello,&#010;&#010;I'm using maven-bundle-plugin in a project. it generates a jar but its &#010;packaging type is "bundle".&#010;&#010;Maven doesn't complains when I declare a bundle dependency without the &#010;type property (that defaults to "jar").&#010;&#010;In the plugin that I'm developing I need to create some files based on &#010;that packaging type.&#010;I tried to resolve each direct dependency and tried to get its packaging &#010;type (the one fixed in its pom), but it is not working, because I always &#010;get the "jar" value.&#010;&#010;&gt;     for (Artifact artifact : artifacts) {&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;                 getLog().debug("Resolving dependency artifact " +&#010;&gt;     artifact);&#010;&gt;                 ArtifactResolutionRequest request = new&#010;&gt;     ArtifactResolutionRequest()&#010;&gt;                         .setArtifact(artifact)&#010;&gt;                         .setRemoteRepositories(remoteRepositories)&#010;&gt;     .setLocalRepository(localArtifactRepository);&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;                 ArtifactResolutionResult resolutionResult =&#010;&gt;     repositorySystem&#010;&gt;                         .resolve(request);&#010;&gt;                 if (resolutionResult.hasExceptions()) {&#010;&gt;                     throw new MojoExecutionException("Could not&#010;&gt;     resolve artifact: "&#010;&gt;                             + artifact,&#010;&gt;     resolutionResult.getExceptions().get(0));&#010;&gt;                 }&#010;&gt;                 artifact = (Artifact)&#010;&gt;     resolutionResult.getArtifacts().iterator()&#010;&gt;                         .next();&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;                 String type = artifact.getType();&#010;&#010;    I need to know the declared artifact packaging type. How could I&#010;    achieve this?&#010;&#010;    thanks for any tip.&#010;&#010;    Cristiano&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Brendan Miller &lt;catph...@catphive.net&gt;
Subject  :-running integration tests with maven
contents:- I currently have some testng integration tests in a maven project. This is&#010;causing problems because the tests get picked up and run during the test&#010;phase, rather than the integration-test phase.&#010;&#010;How do I cause tests to be run in the integration test phase rather than&#010;test? All of my tests in this particular module should be run during&#010;integration-test.&#010;&#010;I don't really see anything in my pom.xml that specifies phase. This is the&#010;only test specific thing I'm seeing:&#010;&#010;&lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&lt;groupId&gt;org.testng&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&lt;artifactId&gt;testng&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&lt;version&gt;${testng.version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&lt;scope&gt;compile&lt;/scope&gt;&#010;&lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&#010;That by itself seems to be running the  tests in my class BlahTest.java.&#010;I'm guessing it automatically picks up anything matching Test.java?&#010;&#010;Thanks,&#010;Brendan&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Anders Hammar &lt;and...@hammar.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: running integration tests with maven
contents:- You need to add/bind the maven-failsafe-plugin to your build:&#010;http://maven.apache.org/surefire/maven-failsafe-plugin/usage.html&#010;&#010;You also need to adapt the naming of your test files:&#010;http://maven.apache.org/surefire/maven-failsafe-plugin/examples/inclusion-exclusion.html&#010;&#010;/Anders&#010;&#010;&#010;On Thu, May 8, 2014 at 2:45 AM, Brendan Miller &lt;catphive@catphive.net&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I currently have some testng integration tests in a maven project. This is&#010;&gt; causing problems because the tests get picked up and run during the test&#010;&gt; phase, rather than the integration-test phase.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; How do I cause tests to be run in the integration test phase rather than&#010;&gt; test? All of my tests in this particular module should be run during&#010;&gt; integration-test.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I don't really see anything in my pom.xml that specifies phase. This is the&#010;&gt; only test specific thing I'm seeing:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.testng&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;testng&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;version&gt;${testng.version}&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;scope&gt;compile&lt;/scope&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; That by itself seems to be running the  tests in my class BlahTest.java.&#010;&gt; I'm guessing it automatically picks up anything matching Test.java?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks,&#010;&gt; Brendan&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Hervé Boutemy &lt;hbout...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-[ANN] Apache Maven Plugin Tools (including Maven Plugin Plugin) 3.3 Released
contents:- The Apache Maven team is pleased to announce the release of the Apache Maven &#010;Plugin Tools, version 3.3&#010;&#010;The Maven Plugin Tools contains the necessary tools to be able to produce &#010;Maven Plugins in scripting languages and to generate rebarbative content like &#010;descriptor, help and documentation.&#010;&#010;The Maven Plugin Plugin is used to create a Maven plugin descriptor for any &#010;Mojo's found in the source tree, to include in the JAR. It is also used to &#010;generate report files for the Mojos as well as for updating the plugin &#010;registry, the artifact metadata and generating a generic help goal.&#010;&#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugin-tools/&#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugin-tools/maven-plugin-plugin/&#010;&#010;You should specify the version in your project's plugin configuration:&#010;&#010;&lt;plugin&gt;&#010;  &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;  &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-plugin-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;  &lt;version&gt;3.3&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;Release Notes - Maven Plugin Tools - Version 3.3&#010;&#010;** Bug&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-191] - plugin-info.html is not created&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-234] - Extreme amounts of debug logging&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-235] - Doc example incorrectly states that plexus-utils is &#010;needed as a dependency&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-236] - Value for Mojo's 'defaultPhase' parameter is incorrectly &#010;a string in examples&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-239] - Execute goal does not passes from mojos.xml &#010;pluginMetadata&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-242] - NullPointerException in MojoClassVisitor.visit()&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-244] - Help mojo generates Javadoc, which is not accepted by &#010;JDK 8 doclint&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-245] - @Parameter property names are not written to the plugin-&#010;help.xml file&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-248] - XML-Namespace in ITs for ant-based mojos are wrong.&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-255] - Generated HelpMojo doesn't close resource stream&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-258] - IT failures with Jdk 8 (EA) &#010;    * [MPLUGIN-260] - Plugin that uses annotations in Java 8 source can't &#010;generate descriptor&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-262] - Generated HelpMojo doesn't display default values and &#010;user properties.&#010;&#010;** Improvement&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-237] - JavaDoc WARNING on generated HelpMojo class.&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-246] - Clarify that super class must also use annotations&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-264] - Allow other packaging types&#010;&#010;** New Feature&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-259] - @Parameter name="xxx" to set bean property name different &#010;from class' field&#010;&#010;** Task&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-233] - remove InstanciationStrategy enum from annotations&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-265] - remove deprecated API since introduction of &#010;PluginToolsRequest&#010;&#010;** Wish&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-249] - give snippets to show use of expressions to get Maven &#010;objects&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-250] - since element is not in version 1.0.0 of plugin-&#010;metadata: should create a new version of the descriptor&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-257] - deprecate classical Maven objects as components&#010;    * [MPLUGIN-261] - sort goals in generated plugin.xml&#010;&#010;Enjoy,&#010;&#010;-The Apache Maven team&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Niranjan Rao &lt;nhr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-How to override settings for maven module
contents:- I have a master POM file which defines common stuff such as common &#010;dependencies like junit and compiler settings.&#010;&#010;The compiler settings are set to treat warning as error using &#010;maven-compiler-plugin and Werror as compiler argument. I have a new &#010;module which declares the master pom as parent pom, but has generated &#010;code which has lot of warnings. I would like to disable treating &#010;warnings as errors only for this module or if possible only for &#010;generated package or generated source directory.&#010;&#010;I tried adding compiler plugin entry in module's pom file. But it looks &#010;like it overrides from parent. How do I disable warnings for this module &#010;only?&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;&#010;Niranjan&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Niranjan Rao &lt;nhr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: How to override settings for maven module
contents:- Found the answer, you need to use combine.self="override" in the &#010;compiler plugin settings. More details at &#010;http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1771561/maven-is-it-possible-to-override-the-configuration-of-a-plugin-already-defined&#010;&#010;On 05/08/2014 05:59 PM, Niranjan Rao wrote:&#010;&gt; I have a master POM file which defines common stuff such as common &#010;&gt; dependencies like junit and compiler settings.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The compiler settings are set to treat warning as error using &#010;&gt; maven-compiler-plugin and Werror as compiler argument. I have a new &#010;&gt; module which declares the master pom as parent pom, but has generated &#010;&gt; code which has lot of warnings. I would like to disable treating &#010;&gt; warnings as errors only for this module or if possible only for &#010;&gt; generated package or generated source directory.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I tried adding compiler plugin entry in module's pom file. But it &#010;&gt; looks like it overrides from parent. How do I disable warnings for &#010;&gt; this module only?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Regards,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Niranjan&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Karl Heinz Marbaise &lt;khmarba...@gmx.de&gt;
Subject  :-Re: How to override settings for maven module
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;the first thing in such situations is to create a separate module which &#010;contains the generation code part. In this module you can change the &#010;configuration for maven-compiler-plugin via a pluginManagemen block...&#010;&#010;So looks like this:&#010;&#010;   parent (pom.xml)&#010;     +-- mod-generated (pom.xml)&#010;     +-- mod-the-rest (pom.xml)&#010;&#010;If you follow this suggestions you have clear separation of concern for &#010;your modules and you only need to change the configuration for the &#010;mod-generated.&#010;&#010;Kind regards&#010;Karl-Heinz Marbaise&#010;&#010;On 5/9/14 2:59 AM, Niranjan Rao wrote:&#010;&gt; I have a master POM file which defines common stuff such as common&#010;&gt; dependencies like junit and compiler settings.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The compiler settings are set to treat warning as error using&#010;&gt; maven-compiler-plugin and Werror as compiler argument. I have a new&#010;&gt; module which declares the master pom as parent pom, but has generated&#010;&gt; code which has lot of warnings. I would like to disable treating&#010;&gt; warnings as errors only for this module or if possible only for&#010;&gt; generated package or generated source directory.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I tried adding compiler plugin entry in module's pom file. But it looks&#010;&gt; like it overrides from parent. How do I disable warnings for this module&#010;&gt; only?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Regards,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Niranjan&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Niranjan Rao &lt;nhr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: How to override settings for maven module
contents:- Thanks for the answer, but as I said in the email, I already have a &#010;module which consists just generated code. However I could not figure &#010;out how to override settings for the plugin block. Maven by default &#010;merges the arguments from parent pom. Answer was to use &#010;combine.self="override" block in the configuration section of the plugin.&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;&#010;Niranjan&#010;&#010;&#010;On 05/12/2014 09:31 AM, Karl Heinz Marbaise wrote:&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; the first thing in such situations is to create a separate module &#010;&gt; which contains the generation code part. In this module you can change &#010;&gt; the configuration for maven-compiler-plugin via a pluginManagemen &#010;&gt; block...&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; So looks like this:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;   parent (pom.xml)&#010;&gt;     +-- mod-generated (pom.xml)&#010;&gt;     +-- mod-the-rest (pom.xml)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; If you follow this suggestions you have clear separation of concern &#010;&gt; for your modules and you only need to change the configuration for the &#010;&gt; mod-generated.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Kind regards&#010;&gt; Karl-Heinz Marbaise&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 5/9/14 2:59 AM, Niranjan Rao wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; I have a master POM file which defines common stuff such as common&#010;&gt;&gt; dependencies like junit and compiler settings.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The compiler settings are set to treat warning as error using&#010;&gt;&gt; maven-compiler-plugin and Werror as compiler argument. I have a new&#010;&gt;&gt; module which declares the master pom as parent pom, but has generated&#010;&gt;&gt; code which has lot of warnings. I would like to disable treating&#010;&gt;&gt; warnings as errors only for this module or if possible only for&#010;&gt;&gt; generated package or generated source directory.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I tried adding compiler plugin entry in module's pom file. But it looks&#010;&gt;&gt; like it overrides from parent. How do I disable warnings for this module&#010;&gt;&gt; only?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Regards,&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Niranjan&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Thomas Broyer &lt;t.bro...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-M2Eclipse vs. maven-eclipse-plugin: which is preferred?
contents:- Hi all,&#010;&#010;Does the Apache Maven Project/Community has an official stance about&#010;whether M2Eclipse or maven-eclipse-plugin is preferred way of importing&#010;Maven projects into Eclipse?&#010;&#010;I thought M2Eclipse was the blessed way, but I cannot find anything&#010;"official" online.&#010;Only that the maven-eclipse-plugin hasn't been updated for a while, but&#010;that could also be a sign that it has no issue and Eclipse offers backwards&#010;compatibility.&#010;&#010;Note: this is not a poll about what you as a developer prefers, I'm looking&#010;for whether there's an official position and which one it is.&#010;Background: I'm in a argument in a code review for an archetype about&#010;whether to include maven-eclipse-plugin configuration within the POM or&#010;not; and any "official" choice would help us avoid "bikeshedding".&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Thomas Broyer&#010;/tɔ.ma.bʁwa.je/ &lt;http://xn--nna.ma.xn--bwa-xxb.je/&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Jason van Zyl &lt;ja...@takari.io&gt;
Subject  :-Re: M2Eclipse vs. maven-eclipse-plugin: which is preferred?
contents:- There is nothing official from the Maven itself. There used to be competing Maven Eclipse integration&#010;from different people here, and there has always been the command line generation vs IDE integration.&#010;So there is no officially blessed integration from the Maven project proper.&#010;&#010;Also note that M2Eclipse and the maven-eclipse-plugin are not compatible. In M2E it specifically&#010;looks for project files created with the maven-eclipse-plugin and disables them.&#010;&#010;On May 9, 2014, at 2:19 AM, Thomas Broyer &lt;t.broyer@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi all,&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Does the Apache Maven Project/Community has an official stance about&#010;&gt; whether M2Eclipse or maven-eclipse-plugin is preferred way of importing&#010;&gt; Maven projects into Eclipse?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I thought M2Eclipse was the blessed way, but I cannot find anything&#010;&gt; "official" online.&#010;&gt; Only that the maven-eclipse-plugin hasn't been updated for a while, but&#010;&gt; that could also be a sign that it has no issue and Eclipse offers backwards&#010;&gt; compatibility.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Note: this is not a poll about what you as a developer prefers, I'm looking&#010;&gt; for whether there's an official position and which one it is.&#010;&gt; Background: I'm in a argument in a code review for an archetype about&#010;&gt; whether to include maven-eclipse-plugin configuration within the POM or&#010;&gt; not; and any "official" choice would help us avoid "bikeshedding".&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; -- &#010;&gt; Thomas Broyer&#010;&gt; /tɔ.ma.bʁwa.je/ &lt;http://xn--nna.ma.xn--bwa-xxb.je/&gt;&#010;&#010;Thanks,&#010;&#010;Jason&#010;&#010;----------------------------------------------------------&#010;Jason van Zyl&#010;Founder,  Apache Maven&#010;http://twitter.com/jvanzyl&#010;http://twitter.com/takari_io&#010;---------------------------------------------------------&#010;&#010;We all have problems. How we deal with them is a measure of our worth.&#010;&#010; -- Unknown&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: M2Eclipse vs. maven-eclipse-plugin: which is preferred?
contents:- On 9 May 2014 18:49, Thomas Broyer &lt;t.broyer@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi all,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Does the Apache Maven Project/Community has an official stance about&#010;&gt; whether M2Eclipse or maven-eclipse-plugin is preferred way of importing&#010;&gt; Maven projects into Eclipse?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I thought M2Eclipse was the blessed way, but I cannot find anything&#010;&gt; "official" online.&#010;&gt; Only that the maven-eclipse-plugin hasn't been updated for a while, but&#010;&gt; that could also be a sign that it has no issue and Eclipse offers backwards&#010;&gt; compatibility.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Note: this is not a poll about what you as a developer prefers, I'm looking&#010;&gt; for whether there's an official position and which one it is.&#010;&gt; Background: I'm in a argument in a code review for an archetype about&#010;&gt; whether to include maven-eclipse-plugin configuration within the POM or&#010;&gt; not; and any "official" choice would help us avoid "bikeshedding".&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;There isn't anything really official.&#010;&#010;The maven-eclipse-plugin doesn't get much love any more these days, but&#010;still works fine for some people.&#010;&#010;However you will probably find the m2eclipse experience better.&#010;&#010;Other alternatives to consider are other editors.&#010;I've never used NetBeans or IntelliJ but others report good experiences.&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Jens Reimann &lt;ct...@dentrassi.de&gt;
Subject  :-Using plugins from the command line that come not from maven central
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;I want to execute a project-less maven plugin from the command line.&#010;However the plugin is not in maven central and I cannot place the plugin&#010;repository in the settings.xml file.&#010;&#010;Now I can use the dependency:get plugin to fetch the plugin from the&#010;remote repository into my local repository. However I have to use the&#010;command line switch -llr, which triggers a warning. Otherwise maven&#010;complains about the fact that the plugin cannot be found at maven&#010;central (though it really is in the local repository).&#010;&#010;Adding -llr works, and the plugin is found.&#010;&#010;However I would like to have a way were I can run a project-less plugin,&#010;from the command line, using an alternate plugin repository.&#010;&#010;Like:&#010;    mvn mygroup:myartifact:1.2.3:do-my-stuff&#010;-Dmaven.plugin.repository=http://my.own/repository&#010;&#010;I have not found such a property in the documentation.&#010;&#010;Jens&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Anders Hammar &lt;and...@hammar.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Using plugins from the command line that come not from maven central
contents:- Not possible. You should add the plugin repo to your settings.xml.&#010;&#010;If you can't modify your settings.xml (locked by corporate policy or&#010;similar), you can always create your own settings.xml (adding the plugin&#010;repo) and have Maven use that for this execution through the "-s" switch.&#010;&#010;/Anders&#010;&#010;&#010;On Fri, May 9, 2014 at 11:52 AM, Jens Reimann &lt;ctron@dentrassi.de&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I want to execute a project-less maven plugin from the command line.&#010;&gt; However the plugin is not in maven central and I cannot place the plugin&#010;&gt; repository in the settings.xml file.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Now I can use the dependency:get plugin to fetch the plugin from the&#010;&gt; remote repository into my local repository. However I have to use the&#010;&gt; command line switch -llr, which triggers a warning. Otherwise maven&#010;&gt; complains about the fact that the plugin cannot be found at maven&#010;&gt; central (though it really is in the local repository).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Adding -llr works, and the plugin is found.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; However I would like to have a way were I can run a project-less plugin,&#010;&gt; from the command line, using an alternate plugin repository.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Like:&#010;&gt;     mvn mygroup:myartifact:1.2.3:do-my-stuff&#010;&gt; -Dmaven.plugin.repository=http://my.own/repository&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I have not found such a property in the documentation.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Jens&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- James Green &lt;james.mk.gr...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Sharing of values across dependant projects?
contents:- I have two projects - A and B. B depends on A.&#010;&#010;A is built with a number (call it a build number). B needs to which number&#010;is in A at the time B builds.&#010;&#010;Any ideas how to achieve this without any human intervention?&#010;&#010;FWIW the use case here is that A is software distributed by B (a WAR&#010;archive). A queries B for an updated build number, thus implementing&#010;"automatic updates". I'm trying to automate the setting of this number&#010;across the two projects but I've drawn a blank inside Jenkins for the&#010;moment.&#010;&#010;James&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Bernd Eckenfels &lt;e...@zusammenkunft.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Sharing of values across dependant projects?
contents:- Is A released after each built-number change or is it a snapshot? In the snapshot case you&#010;can add a snapshot dependency and then see the number in the classpath. Maven will find the&#010;latest updates. If you make a release I guess it is easier to use a built parameter passed&#010;by Jenkins to both projects in a Pipeline. (Or to actually commit changes to version control,&#010;hard to say without details).&#010;&#010;You could also use the versions-plugin to programmatically bump the dependency version in&#010;project B and then run a second maven invocation to build it.&#010;&#010;Gruss&#010;Bernd&#010;&#010;&gt; Am 09.05.2014 um 16:02 schrieb James Green &lt;james.mk.green@gmail.com&gt;:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I have two projects - A and B. B depends on A.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; A is built with a number (call it a build number). B needs to which number&#010;&gt; is in A at the time B builds.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Any ideas how to achieve this without any human intervention?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; FWIW the use case here is that A is software distributed by B (a WAR&#010;&gt; archive). A queries B for an updated build number, thus implementing&#010;&gt; "automatic updates". I'm trying to automate the setting of this number&#010;&gt; across the two projects but I've drawn a blank inside Jenkins for the&#010;&gt; moment.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; James&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Curtis Rueden &lt;ctrue...@wisc.edu&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Sharing of values across dependant projects?
contents:- Hi James,&#010;&#010;&gt; I have two projects - A and B. B depends on A.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; A is built with a number (call it a build number). B needs to which number&#010;&gt; is in A at the time B builds.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Any ideas how to achieve this without any human intervention?&#010;&#010;For B to query A at *runtime* of B: embed your build numbers in the JAR&#010;manifest.&#010;&#010;With the buildnumber-maven-plugin, it's something like this:&#010;https://github.com/scijava/pom-scijava/blob/69b3520e486b2a3d65636833efe230b00f3ea78f/pom.xml#L680&#010;And this:&#010;https://github.com/scijava/pom-scijava/blob/69b3520e486b2a3d65636833efe230b00f3ea78f/pom.xml#L567&#010;&#010;Then you can extract the version information out the manifest using Java's&#010;built-in API:&#010;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/jar/JarFile.html#getManifest()&#010;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/index.html?java/util/jar/Manifest.html&#010;&#010;To query A at B's *build* time as you request -- i.e., for your Jenkins job&#010;that builds B to query the version of A, to decide whether to even build --&#010;you could use the Jenkins Groovy plugin with the "Poll with a Groovy&#010;script" ScriptTrigger that checks whether the build number changed since&#010;the last build, using the above approach...&#010;&#010;But is there some reason it's not good enough to simply have B's build be a&#010;downstream job of A's build?&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;Curtis&#010;&#010;&#010;On Fri, May 9, 2014 at 9:02 AM, James Green &lt;james.mk.green@gmail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I have two projects - A and B. B depends on A.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; A is built with a number (call it a build number). B needs to which number&#010;&gt; is in A at the time B builds.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Any ideas how to achieve this without any human intervention?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; FWIW the use case here is that A is software distributed by B (a WAR&#010;&gt; archive). A queries B for an updated build number, thus implementing&#010;&gt; "automatic updates". I'm trying to automate the setting of this number&#010;&gt; across the two projects but I've drawn a blank inside Jenkins for the&#010;&gt; moment.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; James&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

contents:- I have small maven project. I'm trying to add generating site by &#010;maven-site-plugin, but it doesn't work. When I'm building this project i &#010;get following error:&#010;&#010;[ERROR] Failed to execute goal &#010;org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-site-plugin:3.3:site (default-site) on &#010;project [MY-PROJECT]: SiteToolException: The site descriptor cannot be &#010;resolved from the repository: ArtifactResolutionException: Unable to &#010;locate site descriptor: Could not transfer artifact &#010;[PARENT-PROJECT]:xml:site_en:1.0 from/to eclipse &#010;(http://maven.eclipse.org/nexus/content/repositories/testing/): &#010;Connection tohttp://maven.eclipse.org &lt;http://maven.eclipse.org/&gt;refused&#010;&#010;My project is extension for other project, so in my pom.xml is set &#010;parent project which isn't mine and I can't add site configuration there.&#010;&#010;So is there any chance to skip checking parent project's site in site &#010;generation?&#010;&#010;My pom.xml looks like this:&#010;&#010;|    &lt;project&gt;&#010; Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: How to avoid checking parent project in maven-site-plugin
contents:- To get it working make a copy of the parent with the stuff that you need.&#010;&#010;This will at least tell you if you are on the right track and perhaps &#010;give you the settings that you need to override in the module pom.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;On 12/05/2014 5:16 AM, Dariusz Jurojc wrote:&#010;&gt; I have small maven project. I'm trying to add generating site by &#010;&gt; maven-site-plugin, but it doesn't work. When I'm building this project &#010;&gt; i get following error:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; [ERROR] Failed to execute goal &#010;&gt; org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-site-plugin:3.3:site (default-site) on &#010;&gt; project [MY-PROJECT]: SiteToolException: The site descriptor cannot be &#010;&gt; resolved from the repository: ArtifactResolutionException: Unable to &#010;&gt; locate site descriptor: Could not transfer artifact &#010;&gt; [PARENT-PROJECT]:xml:site_en:1.0 from/to eclipse &#010;&gt; (http://maven.eclipse.org/nexus/content/repositories/testing/): &#010;&gt; Connection tohttp://maven.eclipse.org &lt;http://maven.eclipse.org/&gt;refused&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My project is extension for other project, so in my pom.xml is set &#010;&gt; parent project which isn't mine and I can't add site configuration there.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; So is there any chance to skip checking parent project's site in site &#010;&gt; generation?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My pom.xml looks like this:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; |    &lt;project&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;parent&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;artifactId&gt;|||[PARENT-PROJECT]|&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;groupId&gt;||[PARENT-PROJECT-GROUP]&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;version&gt;1.0&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;/parent&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;build&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;plugins&gt;&#010;&gt;                 &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-site-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;                    &lt;version&gt;3.3&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;                    &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;                       &lt;reportPlugins&gt;&#010;&gt;                       &lt;/reportPlugins&gt;&#010;&gt;                    &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;                 &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;              &lt;/plugins&gt;&#010;&gt;        &lt;/build&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;/project&gt;&#010;&gt; |&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; And of course i have site.xml file in src/site directory in my project.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: How to avoid checking parent project in maven-site-plugin
contents:- I am not sure what you mean by "can't".&#010;You can make any POM you want.&#010;You could start by having Maven give you the effective pom from your &#010;project.&#010;You could save that and make the changes that you require to get your &#010;site produced to that pom as a standalone project .&#010;&#010;Once you have this working you will know which of the master poms is &#010;giving you the problem so you can get them to change it or figure out &#010;what you need to override when using their poms.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;On 13/05/2014 9:47 AM, Dariusz Jurojć wrote:&#010;&gt; I can't do it - as I said - I'm only writing extension to very big project&#010;&gt; which is not mine. And I have to use pom from that "big project". And that&#010;&gt; pom has it's own parent and so on... I can't copy and modify all of them. Name  :- Paul Benedict &lt;pbened...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: How to avoid checking parent project in maven-site-plugin
contents:- You need to have the parent projects available to you in your remote or&#010;local repository. You can't build with them missing because the parent has&#010;configuration which you project (the child) depends upon.&#010;On May 14, 2014 12:48 AM, "Dariusz Jurojć" &lt;dariusz.jurojc@daprog.pl&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I can't do it - as I said - I'm only writing extension to very big project&#010;&gt; which is not mine. And I have to use pom from that "big project". And that&#010;&gt; pom has it's own parent and so on... I can't copy and modify all of them. I&#010;&gt; just want to create site with some reports for my project regardless of&#010;&gt; parent project.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context:&#010;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/How-to-avoid-checking-parent-project-in-maven-site-plugin-tp5792945p5793019.html&#010;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- William Ferguson &lt;william.fergu...@xandar.com.au&gt;
Subject  :-Wagon extensions not available from AbstractMavenLifecycleParticipant or maven-dependency-tree?
contents:- I have a MavenLifecycleParticipant in my plugin. It uses&#010;maven-dependency-tree to resolve some deps that we need to do extra&#010;processing on. It works fine if the deps are in the local repo.&#010;&#010;But if the s3 Wagon is defined in the project along with a dependency from&#010;the s3 bucket, then the following debug log shows that&#010;DependencyGraphBuilder of maven-dependency-tree can't resolve the s3 wagon,&#010;and the dependency is not resolved now or later in the build, so&#010;compilation fails.&#010;&#010;NB If I remove the MavenLifecycleParticipant then the dep is resolved via&#010;the S3 Wagon.&#010;&#010;Q1) When are the Wagons configured? Shouldn't it be prior to&#010;MavenLifecycleParticipant being called?&#010;Q2) How can I get the DependencyGraphBuilder to resolve the s3 artifact&#010;from within the ================

Name  :- Nick Dimiduk &lt;ndimi...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Shading all modules in a project
contents:- Hello,&#010;&#010;Over in Apache HBase, we have an interesting problem that I'm hoping the&#010;shade plugin can help us solve. It all started with a performance&#010;enhancement to reduce garbage by creating a subclass of a protobuf type&#010;[0]. It works fine for us most of the time. However, when using this code&#010;from a Hadoop mapreduce job, things get strange. Due to the permissions on&#010;the parent object and the way Hadoop uses "fat" jars, we now have&#010;classloader troubles [1]. We were able to work around the issue by&#010;documenting the required classpath constructions. However, this is not&#010;possible for all users. This is where the shade plugin comes in.&#010;&#010;I gave shade a shot [2], though I admit I'm not terribly familiar with it,&#010;nor the inner workings of maven. As far as I can tell, the trouble is the&#010;plugin invocation is limited to the single module in our multi-module&#010;project. I think what's happening is shade is doing what I want for the&#010;hbase-protocol module, but I also need it to do bytecode rewriting for the&#010;modules that consume this module as well. Luckily, this detail is not part&#010;of our public API so it should be transparent to our users.&#010;&#010;My patch is posted on [2]. Any pointers/advice is greatly appreciated.&#010;&#010;Thanks in advance,&#010;Nick&#010;&#010;[0]: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-9867&#010;[1]: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-10304&#010;[2]: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-11118&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Nick Dimiduk &lt;ndimi...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Shading all modules in a project
contents:- Ping. Any advice on this?&#010;&#010;&#010;On Mon, May 12, 2014 at 9:01 AM, Nick Dimiduk &lt;ndimiduk@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hello,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Over in Apache HBase, we have an interesting problem that I'm hoping the&#010;&gt; shade plugin can help us solve. It all started with a performance&#010;&gt; enhancement to reduce garbage by creating a subclass of a protobuf type&#010;&gt; [0]. It works fine for us most of the time. However, when using this code&#010;&gt; from a Hadoop mapreduce job, things get strange. Due to the permissions on&#010;&gt; the parent object and the way Hadoop uses "fat" jars, we now have&#010;&gt; classloader troubles [1]. We were able to work around the issue by&#010;&gt; documenting the required classpath constructions. However, this is not&#010;&gt; possible for all users. This is where the shade plugin comes in.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I gave shade a shot [2], though I admit I'm not terribly familiar with it,&#010;&gt; nor the inner workings of maven. As far as I can tell, the trouble is the&#010;&gt; plugin invocation is limited to the single module in our multi-module&#010;&gt; project. I think what's happening is shade is doing what I want for the&#010;&gt; hbase-protocol module, but I also need it to do bytecode rewriting for the&#010;&gt; modules that consume this module as well. Luckily, this detail is not part&#010;&gt; of our public API so it should be transparent to our users.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My patch is posted on [2]. Any pointers/advice is greatly appreciated.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks in advance,&#010;&gt; Nick&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; [0]: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-9867&#010;&gt; [1]: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-10304&#010;&gt; [2]: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-11118&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- james northrup &lt;northrup.ja...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Shading all modules in a project
contents:- i have had better luck in recent years with maven-dependency-plugin&#010;creating a classpath pointing to the ~/.m2 artifacts versus uberjar, shade,&#010;and assembly.  not every production app can build a maven app in place to&#010;run, but where it can a) startup can be faster using test "target/" to skip&#010;compile on rerun and b) dep version collisions and mismatches are easier to&#010;trace into using said classpath&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, May 21, 2014 at 9:15 AM, Nick Dimiduk &lt;ndimiduk@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Ping. Any advice on this?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Mon, May 12, 2014 at 9:01 AM, Nick Dimiduk &lt;ndimiduk@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Hello,&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Over in Apache HBase, we have an interesting problem that I'm hoping the&#010;&gt; &gt; shade plugin can help us solve. It all started with a performance&#010;&gt; &gt; enhancement to reduce garbage by creating a subclass of a protobuf type&#010;&gt; &gt; [0]. It works fine for us most of the time. However, when using this code&#010;&gt; &gt; from a Hadoop mapreduce job, things get strange. Due to the permissions&#010;&gt; on&#010;&gt; &gt; the parent object and the way Hadoop uses "fat" jars, we now have&#010;&gt; &gt; classloader troubles [1]. We were able to work around the issue by&#010;&gt; &gt; documenting the required classpath constructions. However, this is not&#010;&gt; &gt; possible for all users. This is where the shade plugin comes in.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I gave shade a shot [2], though I admit I'm not terribly familiar with&#010;&gt; it,&#010;&gt; &gt; nor the inner workings of maven. As far as I can tell, the trouble is the&#010;&gt; &gt; plugin invocation is limited to the single module in our multi-module&#010;&gt; &gt; project. I think what's happening is shade is doing what I want for the&#010;&gt; &gt; hbase-protocol module, but I also need it to do bytecode rewriting for&#010;&gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; modules that consume this module as well. Luckily, this detail is not&#010;&gt; part&#010;&gt; &gt; of our public API so it should be transparent to our users.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; My patch is posted on [2]. Any pointers/advice is greatly appreciated.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Thanks in advance,&#010;&gt; &gt; Nick&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; [0]: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-9867&#010;&gt; &gt; [1]: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-10304&#010;&gt; &gt; [2]: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-11118&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Jim Northrup  *  (408) 837-2270 *&#010;&#010;
