Name  :- Nick Dimiduk &lt;ndimi...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Shading all modules in a project
contents:- In general, I agree with you regarding the perils of this "fat jar"&#010;approach. However, due to legacy reasons, this is a feature that we must&#010;support. Give this context, is there any advice regarding how to use the&#010;shade plugin to rewrite all references to the moved class in dependent&#010;submodules? Is this a feature the share plugin supports? Assuming this is a&#010;reasonable use of the shade plugin, we have a willingness to contribute a&#010;patch.&#010;&#010;Thank you for the replies.&#010;Nick&#010;&#010;On Wed, May 21, 2014 at 10:44 AM, Martin Gainty &lt;mgainty@hotmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; From: ndimiduk@gmail.com&#010;&gt; &gt; Date: Wed, 21 May 2014 09:15:51 -0700&#010;&gt; &gt; Subject: Re: Shading all modules in a project&#010;&gt; &gt; To: users@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Ping. Any advice on this?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; On Mon, May 12, 2014 at 9:01 AM, Nick Dimiduk &lt;ndimiduk@gmail.com&gt;&#010;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Hello,&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Over in Apache HBase, we have an interesting problem that I'm hoping&#010;&gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; shade plugin can help us solve. It all started with a performance&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; enhancement to reduce garbage by creating a subclass of a protobuf type&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; [0]. It works fine for us most of the time. However, when using this&#010;&gt; code&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; from a Hadoop mapreduce job, things get strange. Due to the&#010;&gt; permissions on&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; the parent object and the way Hadoop uses "fat" jars&#010;&gt; MG&gt;Uberjar or KitchenSinkJar or FatJar or SealedJar forces the situation of&#010;&gt; MG&gt;whenever any of the dependencies in fatjar change that you are packing&#010;&gt; into fatjar you will need to trigger a repackage of FatJar&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;we now have&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; classloader troubles [1]. We were able to work around the issue by&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; documenting the required classpath constructions. However, this is not&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; possible for all users. This is where the shade plugin comes in.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; I gave shade a shot [2], though I admit I'm not terribly familiar with&#010;&gt; it,&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; nor the inner workings of maven. As far as I can tell, the trouble is&#010;&gt; the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; plugin invocation is limited to the single module in our multi-module&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; project. I think what's happening is shade is doing what I want for the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; hbase-protocol module&#010;&gt; MG&gt;yes but every time the original (non-shaded) project you are shading is&#010;&gt; updated&#010;&gt; MG&gt;then you will need a mechanism to trigger that update to your shaded&#010;&gt; jar (to grab those deltas)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;but I also need it to do bytecode rewriting&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;for the&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; modules that consume this module as well. Luckily, this detail is not&#010;&gt; part&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; of our public API so it should be transparent to our users.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; My patch is posted on [2]. Any pointers/advice is greatly appreciated.&#010;&gt; MG&gt;break the fat jars into discrete individual maven artifacts is what i&#010;&gt; would suggest&#010;&gt; MG&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks in advance,&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Nick&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; [0]: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-9867&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; [1]: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-10304&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; [2]: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-11118&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Martin Gainty &lt;mgai...@hotmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-RE: What's a good plugin to translate markdown content?
contents:- I havent used this so this is speculation on my part but supposedly googles jquery-translate&#010;will translate your HTML body text&#010;&#010;using Bing Translator or Google-api code-key&#010;&#010;there is a quick sanity check with isTranslatable( langCode OR language ) so you can test&#010;langCode availability before attempting the translate&#010; &#010;&#010;http://code.google.com/p/jquery-translate/wiki/General&#010;&#010;&#010;Benson may suggest some tools/strategies that will probably be better suited to this task&#010;&#010;http://www.basistech.com/solutions/search/?__hstc=117837206.490a4e71e67300c4d4cfa0e096ccf97f.1400065515328.1400065515328.1400065515328.1&amp;__hssc=117837206.1.1400065515328&amp;__hsfp=1058780468&#010;&#010;&#010;the challenge I found is translating from SBCS (English ISO 8859-1 ) to DBCS character sets&#010;(such as Hebrew ISO 8859-8)&#010;&#010;HTH&#010;&#010;Martin&#010;  &#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; Date: Mon, 12 May 2014 13:15:10 -0500&#010;&gt; Subject: What's a good plugin to translate markdown content?&#010;&gt; From: pbenedict@apache.org&#010;&gt; To: users@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I am looking for a plugin that can generate HTML from markdown document.&#010;&gt; This is not about using the site goal but static pages for a site. Name  :- Curtis Rueden &lt;ctrue...@wisc.edu&gt;
Subject  :-Re: What's a good plugin to translate markdown content?
contents:- Hi Paul,&#010;&#010;&gt; I am looking for a plugin that can generate HTML from markdown document.&#010;&#010;You could write your own plugin that uses Markdownj. Or easier: a groovy&#010;script that does so with groovy-maven-plugin bound to the desired Maven&#010;goal. [1]&#010;&#010;Otherwise, Doxia already supports Markdown so maven-site-plugin could work,&#010;couldn't it?&#010;&#010;-Curtis&#010;&#010;[1] We use this to code generate sources using velocity:&#010;https://github.com/imagej/imagej-ops/blob/imagej-ops-0.3.0/pom.xml&#010;&#010; On May 16, 2014 3:26 AM, "Paul Benedict" &lt;pbenedict@apache.org&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I am looking for a plugin that can generate HTML from markdown document.&#010;&gt; This is not about using the site goal but static pages for a site. Anyone&#010;&gt; been using something like this?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Cheers,&#010;&gt; Paul&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Paul Benedict &lt;pbened...@apache.org&gt;
Subject  :-Re: What's a good plugin to translate markdown content?
contents:- Curtis, yes, the site plugin contains the support for the markdown content&#010;but only if you're doing a site. There's no straightforward way (or anyway&#010;that I know of) to take advantage of doxia as part of a project's build&#010;(not the site build).&#010;&#010;&#010;Cheers,&#010;Paul&#010;&#010;&#010;On Fri, May 16, 2014 at 7:24 AM, Curtis Rueden &lt;ctrueden@wisc.edu&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi Paul,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I am looking for a plugin that can generate HTML from markdown document.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; You could write your own plugin that uses Markdownj. Or easier: a groovy&#010;&gt; script that does so with groovy-maven-plugin bound to the desired Maven&#010;&gt; goal. [1]&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Otherwise, Doxia already supports Markdown so maven-site-plugin could work,&#010;&gt; couldn't it?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -Curtis&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; [1] We use this to code generate sources using velocity:&#010;&gt; https://github.com/imagej/imagej-ops/blob/imagej-ops-0.3.0/pom.xml&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;  On May 16, 2014 3:26 AM, "Paul Benedict" &lt;pbenedict@apache.org&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I am looking for a plugin that can generate HTML from markdown document.&#010;&gt; &gt; This is not about using the site goal but static pages for a site. Anyone&#010;&gt; &gt; been using something like this?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Cheers,&#010;&gt; &gt; Paul&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- DenisDasKind &lt;blto...@abv.bg&gt;
Subject  :-Version in Mojo
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;i'm new to maven, and now i have the following problem. I have a custom&#010;Mojo, and the Mojo should print the own version stored in the pom.xml of&#010;this mojo. And now i have trouble to get this version. I have tried the&#010;project.version, but this is always the version of the pom, that calls my&#010;Mojo. A easy way, will be when the version is hardcoded, but this is not the&#010;best way, becausae each time when the version is changed (release) i must&#010;change it manually.&#010;Is there a better way to get this version?&#010;&#010;Thank you in advance!&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Version-in-Mojo-tp5793054.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Dan Tran &lt;dant...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Version in Mojo
contents:- Your plugin manifest has that info ( look under your jar/META-INF)&#010;&#010;-D&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, May 14, 2014 at 7:41 AM, DenisDasKind &lt;bltomov@abv.bg&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; i'm new to maven, and now i have the following problem. Subject  :-Re: Version in Mojo
contents:- Store the version of the plugin in a properties file and load it at runtime.. &#010;&#010;DenisDasKind wrote on 14.05.2014 07:41:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; i'm new to maven, and now i have the following problem. I have tried the&#010;&gt; project.version, but this is always the version of the pom, that calls my&#010;&gt; Mojo. A easy way, will be when the version is hardcoded, but this is not the&#010;&gt; best way, becausae each time when the version is changed (release) i must&#010;&gt; change it manually.&#010;&gt; Is there a better way to get this version?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Thank you in advance!&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context:&#010;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Version-in-Mojo-tp5793054.html&#010;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Bernd Eckenfels &lt;e...@zusammenkunft.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Version in Mojo
contents:- Hello,&#010;&#010;this is not really Mojo specific.&#010;&#010;If you build a JAR with maven you can&#010;include the build number or version with filtered resources, filtering&#010;the source code, as a expanded Variable in the Manifest header or by&#010;copy of META-INF/maven/pom.properties. To any of those information you&#010;can then reference to print it out.&#010;&#010;This is an example I use (you need to use a class of your project and&#010;add maven group and artifactID):&#010;&#010;    /** Read program version from Manifest or maven properties. */&#010;    private static String getVersion()&#010;    {&#010;        Class me = MyClass.class;&#010;        Package jarPackage = me.getPackage();&#010;        if (jarPackage != null)&#010;        {&#010;            String version = jarPackage.getImplementationVersion();&#010;            if (version != null)&#010;            {&#010;                return version;&#010;            }&#010;        }&#010;        InputStream in =&#010;        me.getClassLoader().getResourceAsStream("META-INF/maven/groupID/artifactID/pom.properties");&#010;        if (in == null) { return "UNKNOWN";}&#010;        try&#010;        {&#010;            Properties p = new Properties();&#010;            p.load(in);&#010;            return p.getProperty("version", "UNKNOWN");&#010;        }&#010;        catch (Exception ignored)&#010;        {&#010;            return "UNKNOWN";&#010;        }&#010;        finally&#010;        {&#010;            try { in.close(); } catch (Exception ignored) { /* ignored&#010;    */ } }&#010;    }&#010;&#010;Greetings&#010;Bernd&#010;&#010;&#010; Am Wed, 14 May 2014 07:41:27 -0700&#010;(PDT) schrieb DenisDasKind &lt;bltomov@abv.bg&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; i'm new to maven, and now i have the following problem. I have a&#010;&gt; custom Mojo, and the Mojo should print the own version stored in the&#010;&gt; pom.xml of this mojo. And now i have trouble to get this version. I&#010;&gt; have tried the project.version, but this is always the version of the&#010;&gt; pom, that calls my Mojo. A easy way, will be when the version is&#010;&gt; hardcoded, but this is not the best way, becausae each time when the&#010;&gt; version is changed (release) i must change it manually.&#010;&gt; Is there a better way to get this version?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Thank you in advance!&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context:&#010;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Version-in-Mojo-tp5793054.html Sent&#010;&gt; from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Martin Hoeller &lt;mar...@xss.co.at&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Version in Mojo
contents:- Am Wed, 14 May 2014 07:41:27 -0700 (PDT) schrieb DenisDasKind &lt;bltomov@abv.bg&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi,&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; i'm new to maven, and now i have the following problem. I have a&#010;&gt; custom Mojo, and the Mojo should print the own version stored in the&#010;&gt; pom.xml of this mojo. And now i have trouble to get this version. I&#010;&gt; have tried the project.version, but this is always the version of the&#010;&gt; pom, that calls my Mojo. A easy way, will be when the version is&#010;&gt; hardcoded, but this is not the best way, becausae each time when the&#010;&gt; version is changed (release) i must change it manually.&#010;&gt; Is there a better way to get this version?&#010;&#010;There are also some useful hints on StackOverflow:&#010;http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2712970/how-to-get-maven-artifact-version-at-runtime/12571330&#010;&#010;hth,&#010;- martin&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Hervé BOUTEMY &lt;herve.bout...@free.fr&gt;
Subject  :-Re: maven-site-plugin unhappy with jdk 1.8?
contents:- AFAIK, the m-site-p itself doesn't have any problem with jdk 8, since it &#010;doesn't care about jdk&#010;but from the little trace you give, there seem to be a reporting plugin that &#010;is sensitive to jdk 8: yes, some plugins have problems, we track them here [1]&#010;&#010;just look at your error traces and you'll see which report is in cause&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;&#010;Hervé&#010;&#010;&#010;[1] http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MNG-5551&#010;&#010;Le jeudi 15 mai 2014 15:35:31 Andy Abendschein a écrit :&#010;&gt; I have recently udated my jdk from 1.7 to 1.8.&#010;&gt; Now I am having problems with the maven-site-plugin which fails with the&#010;&gt; error:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;      Error during page generation: Error rendering Maven report:&#010;&gt; Unsupported targetJdk value '1.8'.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Is there a way to specify a different targetJdk value to the plugin?&#010;&gt; Is there a plan to update the plugin to accommodate jdk 1.8?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Thanks,&#010;&gt; Andy&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Martin Gainty &lt;mgai...@hotmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-RE: maven-site-plugin unhappy with jdk 1.8?
contents:- &#010;&#010;  &#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; Date: Thu, 15 May 2014 15:35:31 -0600&#010;&gt; From: aabendschein@powertagging.com&#010;&gt; To: users@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; Subject: maven-site-plugin unhappy with jdk 1.8?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I have recently udated my jdk from 1.7 to 1.8.&#010;&gt; Now I am having problems with the maven-site-plugin which fails with the &#010;&gt; error:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Error during page generation: Error rendering Maven report: &#010;&gt; Unsupported targetJdk value '1.8'.&#010;&#010;MG&gt;GIYF: looks like this is targetJdk attribute from maven-pmd-plugin&#010;&#010;The target JDK to analyse based on. Should match the target used in the compiler plugin. Valid&#010;values are currently 1.3, 1.4, 1.5 and 1.6. &#010;Note: support for 1.6 was added in version 2.3 of this plugin. &#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;Parameter:&#010;expression="${targetJdk}&#010;&#010;MG&gt;http://grepcode.com/file/repo1.maven.org/maven2/org.apache.maven.plugins/maven-pmd-plugin/2.3/org/apache/maven/plugin/pmd/PmdReport.java#PmdReport.0targetJdk"&#010;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Is there a way to specify a different targetJdk value to the plugin?&#010;&gt; Is there a plan to update the plugin to accommodate jdk 1.8?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Thanks,&#010;&gt; Andy&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010; &#009;&#009; &#009;   &#009;&#009;  &#010;

Name  :- Curtis Rueden &lt;ctrue...@wisc.edu&gt;
Subject  :-Re: http://central.maven.org/maven2/org/eclipse/m2e gone ??
contents:- Hi Dan,&#010;&#010;&gt; I am looking for org.eclipse.m2e:lifecycle-mapping:1.0.0&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; and it is not at maven central any more.&#010;&#010;My team definitely felt the pain of its absence from Central as well.&#010;&#010;To avoid the problem, we use this workaround:&#010;&#010;    &lt;profile&gt;&#010;      &lt;id&gt;only-eclipse&lt;/id&gt;&#010;      &lt;activation&gt;&#010;        &lt;property&gt;&#010;          &lt;name&gt;m2e.version&lt;/name&gt;&#010;        &lt;/property&gt;&#010;      &lt;/activation&gt;&#010;      &lt;build&gt;&#010;        &lt;pluginManagement&gt;&#010;          &lt;plugins&gt;&#010;            &lt;!-- This plugin's configuration is used to store Eclipse m2e&#010;settings&#010;                 only. It has no influence on the Maven build itself. --&gt;&#010;            &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;              &lt;groupId&gt;org.eclipse.m2e&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;              &lt;artifactId&gt;lifecycle-mapping&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;              &lt;version&gt;1.0.0&lt;/version&gt;&#010;              &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;                ...&#010;              &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;            &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;          &lt;/plugins&gt;&#010;        &lt;/pluginManagement&gt;&#010;      &lt;/build&gt;&#010;    &lt;/profile&gt;&#010;&#010;Beautiful, right? ;-)&#010;&#010;-Curtis&#010;&#010;&#010;On Fri, May 16, 2014 at 2:48 PM, Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; any one?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://central.maven.org/maven2/org/eclipse/m2e&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -D&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Thu, May 15, 2014 at 4:34 PM, Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I am looking for org.eclipse.m2e:lifecycle-mapping:1.0.0&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; and it is not at maven central any more.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; do you see the same thing?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Thanks&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; -D&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Dan Tran &lt;dant...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: http://central.maven.org/maven2/org/eclipse/m2e gone ??
contents:- umm, what worries me why it disappears from maven central which suppose to&#010;be a well guarded place?&#010;&#010;I am going to file a JIRA for this&#010;&#010;Thank you for confirmation&#010;&#010;-D&#010;&#010;&#010;On Fri, May 16, 2014 at 1:29 PM, Curtis Rueden &lt;ctrueden@wisc.edu&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi Dan,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I am looking for org.eclipse.m2e:lifecycle-mapping:1.0.0&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; and it is not at maven central any more.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My team definitely felt the pain of its absence from Central as well.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; To avoid the problem, we use this workaround:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;profile&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;id&gt;only-eclipse&lt;/id&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;activation&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;property&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;name&gt;m2e.version&lt;/name&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;/property&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;/activation&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;build&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;pluginManagement&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;plugins&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;!-- This plugin's configuration is used to store Eclipse m2e&#010;&gt; settings&#010;&gt;                  only. It has no influence on the Maven build itself. --&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;groupId&gt;org.eclipse.m2e&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;artifactId&gt;lifecycle-mapping&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;version&gt;1.0.0&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;                 ...&#010;&gt;               &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;/plugins&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;/pluginManagement&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;/build&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;/profile&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Beautiful, right? ;-)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -Curtis&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Fri, May 16, 2014 at 2:48 PM, Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; any one?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; http://central.maven.org/maven2/org/eclipse/m2e&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Thanks&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; -D&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; On Thu, May 15, 2014 at 4:34 PM, Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; I am looking for org.eclipse.m2e:lifecycle-mapping:1.0.0&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; and it is not at maven central any more.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; do you see the same thing?&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; -D&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Dan Tran &lt;dant...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: http://central.maven.org/maven2/org/eclipse/m2e gone ??
contents:- umm, what worries me why it disappears from maven central which suppose to&#010;be a well guarded place?&#010;&#010;a JIRA case is filed at  https://issues.sonatype.org/browse/CENTRALSRV-74&#010;&#010;-D&#010;&#010;&#010;On Fri, May 16, 2014 at 1:29 PM, Curtis Rueden &lt;ctrueden@wisc.edu&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi Dan,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I am looking for org.eclipse.m2e:lifecycle-mapping:1.0.0&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; and it is not at maven central any more.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My team definitely felt the pain of its absence from Central as well.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; To avoid the problem, we use this workaround:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;profile&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;id&gt;only-eclipse&lt;/id&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;activation&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;property&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;name&gt;m2e.version&lt;/name&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;/property&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;/activation&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;build&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;pluginManagement&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;plugins&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;!-- This plugin's configuration is used to store Eclipse m2e&#010;&gt; settings&#010;&gt;                  only. It has no influence on the Maven build itself. --&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;groupId&gt;org.eclipse.m2e&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;artifactId&gt;lifecycle-mapping&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;version&gt;1.0.0&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;                 ...&#010;&gt;               &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;/plugins&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;/pluginManagement&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;/build&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;/profile&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Beautiful, right? ;-)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -Curtis&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Fri, May 16, 2014 at 2:48 PM, Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; any one?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; http://central.maven.org/maven2/org/eclipse/m2e&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Thanks&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; -D&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; On Thu, May 15, 2014 at 4:34 PM, Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; I am looking for org.eclipse.m2e:lifecycle-mapping:1.0.0&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; and it is not at maven central any more.&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; do you see the same thing?&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; -D&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Stuart McCulloch &lt;mccu...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: http://central.maven.org/maven2/org/eclipse/m2e gone ??
contents:- On 16 May 2014, at 22:59, Dan Tran &lt;dantran@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; umm, what worries me why it disappears from maven central which suppose to&#010;&gt; be a well guarded place?&#010;&#010;It has not disappeared as it was never on central in the first place - it's just a placeholder&#010;GAV that m2e uses for configuration purposes. Name  :- David Delbecq &lt;de...@meteo.be&gt;
Subject  :-How to put inline image in doxia generate doc
contents:- Hello, &#010;&#010;i am trying to transfert documentation for an application, which is written using a .odt file,&#010;to some doxia process, so i can be sure pdf is the lastest version in the build. &#010;&#010;However, i am facing a surprisingly basic problem: i can't find out how to include an inline&#010;image. That is, i can put image before, or after a paragraph, but i can't put it inside a&#010;paragraph. I tried xhtml, apt, confluence, twiki, xdoc and markdown. &#010;&#010;Here are my results: &#010;apt -&gt; there is no way to make an inline image in apt &#010;confluence -&gt; while the language allows it, and the eclipse confluence parser shows it&#010;properly, the image tag is not read by doxia and the wiki code appear as is on the final document.&#010;image is properly recognized when inside a paragraph &#010;twiki -&gt; didn't find a way to make an inline image &#010;markdown -&gt; image tag is recognized inline, but everything after the tag, in same paragraph,&#010;is ignored. &#010;xhtml -&gt; while verbose, this language does allow inline image. Unfortunately, all inline&#010;image are showed above paragraph in the resulting pdf, not inline. &#010;xdoc -&gt; the parser just doesn't kick in, doxia think it's a docbook and messes everything&#010;&#010;&#010;So, my question is simple: how can i put an inline image in a doxia document. Which markup&#010;language must i use, and what is the process? &#010;&#010;Best result i got so far was with xhtml, and it looked like this in pdf, &#010;http://i.imgur.com/82mL281.png &#010;&#010;when it should have looked about like this (original open office document): &#010;http://i.imgur.com/UEDuQf1.png &#010;&#010;&#010;David Delbecq &#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Martin Gainty &lt;mgai...@hotmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-RE: Debugging output only for a subproject in a reactor run
contents:- log4j.properties:&#010;&#010; &#010;&#010;# OpenSymphony Stuff FATAL Error messages only&#010;log4j.logger.com.opensymphony=FATAL&#010;&#010;&#010;#Struts core debug (LOTS of messaging)&#010;&#010;log4j.logger.org.apache.struts2=DEBUG&#010;&#010; &#010;&#010;# Spring Stuff (lighten up to INFO Level)&#010;log4j.logger.org.springframework=INFO&#010;&#010;&#010;https://logging.apache.org/log4j/1.2/manual.html&#010;HTH&#010;Martin &#010;______________________________________________ &#010;&#010;&#010;  &#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; From: christian.domsch@assentis.com&#010;&gt; To: users@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; Subject: Debugging output only for a subproject in a reactor run&#010;&gt; Date: Mon, 31 Mar 2014 09:56:00 +0000&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Hi all,&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I have problems with a very specific plugin in our build and want to &#010;&gt; enable debugging output only for the subproject in our overall build &#010;&gt; setup. The commandline option -X enables debugging for the complete &#010;&gt; execution, and I fear this would create too much output and might fail &#010;&gt; the build due to memory problems... Now, is there a way to change the &#010;&gt; logger during the build to enable debugging just for this one project? &#010;&gt; (plugins running in pre and post phases to enable/disable that?)&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Thanks,&#010;&gt; Christia&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010; &#009;&#009; &#009;   &#009;&#009;  &#010;

contents:- &gt; Hi,&#010;&gt; I have run into a problem when upgrading Archiva 1.3.6 to v2.0.1&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Even though I retained the data/database/users directory, archiva fail to&#010;&gt; validate accounts.&#010;&gt; I have tried this a few times now and the problem is the same.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; It's running on tomcat-7.0.42&#010;&gt; Starts up nicely and performs the upgrade - everything looks fine in the&#010;&gt; logs&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; However when I try to login as admin it fail to authenticate.&#010;&gt; I've tried to reset the password - receive the "password reset" email with&#010;&gt; the link (*actually receives a number of emails each time (up to 4 each time&#010;&gt; I request a reset) )&#010;&gt; Follow the link in the email that takes me to the account password reset&#010;&gt; page where I am prompted for a new password.&#010;&gt; Enter the new password and then brought to /archiva/index.html#search page&#010;&gt; (still not logged on)&#010;&gt; Then try to login using the new password but it's again not recognized.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I downloaded the archiva-2.0.1.war that I installed&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Anyone else experiencing this issue? &#010;&#010;This is not Archiva support! &#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Stefan Ferstl &lt;st.fer...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-DependencyTreeBuilder vs. DependencyGraphBuilder
contents:- I'm using the org.apache.maven.shared:dependency-tree library to&#010;gather dependency information on my projects. In order to get&#010;additional information about version conflicts, I prefer to use&#010;DependencyTreeBuilder instead of DependencyGraphBuilder. However, the&#010;Javadoc of DependencyTreeBuilder says:&#010;&#010;"Notice that it doesn't fail with Maven 3, but when Maven 2 and Maven&#010;3 don't calculate the same transitive dependency result, the tree&#010;calculated with this component is consistent with Maven 2 even if run&#010;with Maven 3 (see MSHARED-167)"&#010;&#010;The issue MSHARED-167 [1] was closed in June 2012. So may&#010;DependencyTreeBuilder still produce different results than&#010;DependencyGraphBuilder or is this not an issue anymore?&#010;&#010;&#010;Cheers,&#010;Stefan&#010;&#010;[1] https://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MSHARED-167&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Hervé BOUTEMY &lt;herve.bout...@free.fr&gt;
Subject  :-Re: DependencyTreeBuilder vs. DependencyGraphBuilder
contents:- the difference still exists, and will never be fixed: that's the reasoning &#010;behind deprecating DependencyTreeBuilder&#010;&#010;I you need additional info about version conflicts, you should use Aether API + &#010;Maven Aether Provider for Maven 3, which will give you everything&#010;&#010;But at this precise level, you don't have any single API working with every &#010;version of Maven&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;&#010;Hervé&#010;&#010;Le mardi 1 avril 2014 08:29:20 Stefan Ferstl a écrit :&#010;&gt; I'm using the org.apache.maven.shared:dependency-tree library to&#010;&gt; gather dependency information on my projects. In order to get&#010;&gt; additional information about version conflicts, I prefer to use&#010;&gt; DependencyTreeBuilder instead of DependencyGraphBuilder. However, the&#010;&gt; Javadoc of DependencyTreeBuilder says:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; "Notice that it doesn't fail with Maven 3, but when Maven 2 and Maven&#010;&gt; 3 don't calculate the same transitive dependency result, the tree&#010;&gt; calculated with this component is consistent with Maven 2 even if run&#010;&gt; with Maven 3 (see MSHARED-167)"&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; The issue MSHARED-167 [1] was closed in June 2012. So may&#010;&gt; DependencyTreeBuilder still produce different results than&#010;&gt; DependencyGraphBuilder or is this not an issue anymore?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Cheers,&#010;&gt; Stefan&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; [1] https://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MSHARED-167&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

In order to get&#010;&gt; additional information about version conflicts, I prefer to use&#010;&gt; DependencyTreeBuilder instead of DependencyGraphBuilder. However, the&#010;&gt; Javadoc of DependencyTreeBuilder says:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; "Notice that it doesn't fail with Maven 3, but when Maven 2 and Maven&#010;&gt; 3 don't calculate the same transitive dependency result, the tree&#010;&gt; calculated with this component is consistent with Maven 2 even if run&#010;&gt; with Maven 3 (see MSHARED-167)"&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; The issue MSHARED-167 [1] was closed in June 2012. So may&#010;&gt; DependencyTreeBuilder still produce different results than&#010;&gt; DependencyGraphBuilder or is this not an issue anymore?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Cheers,&#010;&gt; Stefan&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; [1] https://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MSHARED-167&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010; &#009;&#009; &#009;   &#009;&#009;  &#010;

Name  :- Stefan Ferstl &lt;st.fer...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: DependencyTreeBuilder vs. DependencyGraphBuilder
contents:- I haven't had any problems so far. I was just confused by&#010;DependencyTreeBuilder's Javadoc. It says that (at least I understood&#010;it that way) the dependency graph might differ from the dependency&#010;resolution in Maven 3. The same Javadoc references an Issue&#010;(MSHARED-167) that was solved two years ago. So I was not sure if&#010;differences can still occur or not. According to Hervé's reply,&#010;differences can still occur.&#010;&#010;&#010;Cheers,&#010;Stefan&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Apr 2, 2014 at 2:49 AM, Martin Gainty &lt;mgainty@hotmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Stefan&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; A year ago..Herve says r1469697 maven-dependency-tree  is fixed for M3&#010;&gt; Is this not the case?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Martin&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Date: Tue, 1 Apr 2014 08:29:20 +0200&#010;&gt;&gt; Subject: DependencyTreeBuilder vs. DependencyGraphBuilder&#010;&gt;&gt; From: st.ferstl@gmail.com&#010;&gt;&gt; To: users@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I'm using the org.apache.maven.shared:dependency-tree library to&#010;&gt;&gt; gather dependency information on my projects. In order to get&#010;&gt;&gt; additional information about version conflicts, I prefer to use&#010;&gt;&gt; DependencyTreeBuilder instead of DependencyGraphBuilder. However, the&#010;&gt;&gt; Javadoc of DependencyTreeBuilder says:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; "Notice that it doesn't fail with Maven 3, but when Maven 2 and Maven&#010;&gt;&gt; 3 don't calculate the same transitive dependency result, the tree&#010;&gt;&gt; calculated with this component is consistent with Maven 2 even if run&#010;&gt;&gt; with Maven 3 (see MSHARED-167)"&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The issue MSHARED-167 [1] was closed in June 2012. So may&#010;&gt;&gt; DependencyTreeBuilder still produce different results than&#010;&gt;&gt; DependencyGraphBuilder or is this not an issue anymore?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Cheers,&#010;&gt;&gt; Stefan&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; [1] https://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MSHARED-167&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Tonio Caputo &lt;ton...@exeo.com.ar&gt;
Subject  :-Re: DependencyTreeBuilder vs. DependencyGraphBuilder
contents:- Hi,&#010;&#010;Interesting problem, I've just faced,  using aether and maven 3.1,  I&#010;developed a plugin for&#010;creating a special kind of 'war' file for a plugin infrastructure.&#010;&#010;I was using aether directly,  I faced the problem aether was changed, so&#010;just looking into&#010;maven dependency plugin, and looking at some advice mentioned in the&#010;network I moved&#010;from using aether directly to use maven-dependency-tree library, which&#010;isolates me of the problem&#010;of what Aether provider is used.&#010;&#010;Because of the nature of the plugin, I need to use DependencyTree and not&#010;DependencyGraph (need the repeated/confict info).&#010;&#010;So wondering, should I go back to using Aether directly (because of&#010;DependencyTree) deprecation, or&#010;some replacement for it will be available ?&#010;&#010;thanks in advance&#010;tonio&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Apr 2, 2014 at 10:34 AM, Stefan Ferstl &lt;st.ferstl@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I haven't had any problems so far. I was just confused by&#010;&gt; DependencyTreeBuilder's Javadoc. It says that (at least I understood&#010;&gt; it that way) the dependency graph might differ from the dependency&#010;&gt; resolution in Maven 3. The same Javadoc references an Issue&#010;&gt; (MSHARED-167) that was solved two years ago. So I was not sure if&#010;&gt; differences can still occur or not. According to Hervé's reply,&#010;&gt; differences can still occur.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Cheers,&#010;&gt; Stefan&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Wed, Apr 2, 2014 at 2:49 AM, Martin Gainty &lt;mgainty@hotmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt; Stefan&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; A year ago..Herve says r1469697 maven-dependency-tree  is fixed for M3&#010;&gt; &gt; Is this not the case?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Martin&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; Date: Tue, 1 Apr 2014 08:29:20 +0200&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; Subject: DependencyTreeBuilder vs. DependencyGraphBuilder&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; From: st.ferstl@gmail.com&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; To: users@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; I'm using the org.apache.maven.shared:dependency-tree library to&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; gather dependency information on my projects. In order to get&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; additional information about version conflicts, I prefer to use&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; DependencyTreeBuilder instead of DependencyGraphBuilder. However, the&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; Javadoc of DependencyTreeBuilder says:&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; "Notice that it doesn't fail with Maven 3, but when Maven 2 and Maven&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; 3 don't calculate the same transitive dependency result, the tree&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; calculated with this component is consistent with Maven 2 even if run&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; with Maven 3 (see MSHARED-167)"&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; The issue MSHARED-167 [1] was closed in June 2012. So may&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; DependencyTreeBuilder still produce different results than&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; DependencyGraphBuilder or is this not an issue anymore?&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; Cheers,&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; Stefan&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; [1] https://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MSHARED-167&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Steinar Bang ...@dod.no&gt;
Subject  :-What packaging for Jira excel reports with maven?
contents:- I have access to a Jar-file that contains code that:&#010; - Reads an excel file containing a JQL query, the names of the fields&#010;   from the JQL results to include in excel, as well as the sheets that&#010;   are to be populated&#010; - Talks to Jira, using the Jira REST API, to do the query and extract&#010;   the results&#010; - Exports a new excel file populated with the query results&#010;&#010;The Jar-file resides in a plexus archive, so I thought that having a&#010;small maven project, containing a pom.xml and the template excel&#010;spreadshet in src/main/resources/ would be a good match.&#010;&#010;The idea was that I could:&#010; - set the Jar-file containing the excel export code as a dependency&#010; - use exec-maven-plugin to run the Jar&#010; - have the output of exec-maven-plugin (an excel file) as the build&#010;   artifact &#010;&#010;But the idea stopped on that I don't know what packaging should be used&#010;for the pom: "jar" didn't seem appropriate, so I tried "pom", but that&#010;doesn't do anything (no target directory created).&#010;&#010;Is maven appropriate for what I'm trying to do? Is there an appropriate&#010;packaging to use?&#010;&#010;Thanks!&#010;&#010;&#010;- Steinar&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Anders Hammar &lt;and...@hammar.net&gt;
Subject  :-Re: What packaging for Jira excel reports with maven?
contents:- I categorize different usage of Maven into two categories:&#010;A) As a build tool&#010;B) As a utility tool&#010;&#010;A) would be for example building a Java web application, i.e. using the&#010;full build lifecycle of Maven. B) on the other hand is where you just want&#010;to do one specific "thing", for example generate Java classes from an xml&#010;schema or creating a jar of existing Java classes.&#010;&#010;So the first question is if your usage would fit into A or B? To narrow&#010;things down a little bit, do you want this excel file to be generated as&#010;part of the build of your software and then deployed together with that to&#010;the repository? If so, it would be A. If you're just trying to find a tool&#010;to generate this excel file on demand, we would be in B.&#010;&#010;My point here is that if you're in category A then Maven is absolutely&#010;appropriate. At least if you're building everything else with Maven. But if&#010;you're in category B, then Maven is just one of many options you have. I&#010;would even go as far as saying that there are simpler solutions, one being&#010;a shell script (or Windows batch file) where you just have you Java command&#010;with the jar on the classpath and the options to have the excel file&#010;generated. Using Maven here would just add an additional dependency (to&#010;Maven) which could just complicate things.&#010;&#010;My two cents,&#010;/Anders&#010;&#010;&#010;On Tue, Apr 1, 2014 at 2:05 PM, Steinar Bang &lt;sb@dod.no&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I have access to a Jar-file that contains code that:&#010;&gt;  - Reads an excel file containing a JQL query, the names of the fields&#010;&gt;    from the JQL results to include in excel, as well as the sheets that&#010;&gt;    are to be populated&#010;&gt;  - Talks to Jira, using the Jira REST API, to do the query and extract&#010;&gt;    the results&#010;&gt;  - Exports a new excel file populated with the query results&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The Jar-file resides in a plexus archive, so I thought that having a&#010;&gt; small maven project, containing a pom.xml and the template excel&#010;&gt; spreadshet in src/main/resources/ would be a good match.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The idea was that I could:&#010;&gt;  - set the Jar-file containing the excel export code as a dependency&#010;&gt;  - use exec-maven-plugin to run the Jar&#010;&gt;  - have the output of exec-maven-plugin (an excel file) as the build&#010;&gt;    artifact&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; But the idea stopped on that I don't know what packaging should be used&#010;&gt; for the pom: "jar" didn't seem appropriate, so I tried "pom", but that&#010;&gt; doesn't do anything (no target directory created).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is maven appropriate for what I'm trying to do? Is there an appropriate&#010;&gt; packaging to use?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - Steinar&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

================

Name  :- Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: What packaging for Jira excel reports with maven?
contents:- Looks like something that ANT might be good at.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;On 02/04/2014 6:58 AM, Anders Hammar wrote:&#010;&gt; I categorize different usage of Maven into two categories:&#010;&gt; A) As a build tool&#010;&gt; B) As a utility tool&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; A) would be for example building a Java web application, i.e. using the&#010;&gt; full build lifecycle of Maven. B) on the other hand is where you just want&#010;&gt; to do one specific "thing", for example generate Java classes from an xml&#010;&gt; schema or creating a jar of existing Java classes.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; So the first question is if your usage would fit into A or B? To narrow&#010;&gt; things down a little bit, do you want this excel file to be generated as&#010;&gt; part of the build of your software and then deployed together with that to&#010;&gt; the repository? If so, it would be A. If you're just trying to find a tool&#010;&gt; to generate this excel file on demand, we would be in B.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My point here is that if you're in category A then Maven is absolutely&#010;&gt; appropriate. At least if you're building everything else with Maven. But if&#010;&gt; you're in category B, then Maven is just one of many options you have. I&#010;&gt; would even go as far as saying that there are simpler solutions, one being&#010;&gt; a shell script (or Windows batch file) where you just have you Java command&#010;&gt; with the jar on the classpath and the options to have the excel file&#010;&gt; generated. Using Maven here would just add an additional dependency (to&#010;&gt; Maven) which could just complicate things.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My two cents,&#010;&gt; /Anders&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On Tue, Apr 1, 2014 at 2:05 PM, Steinar Bang &lt;sb@dod.no&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I have access to a Jar-file that contains code that:&#010;&gt;&gt;   - Reads an excel file containing a JQL query, the names of the fields&#010;&gt;&gt;     from the JQL results to include in excel, as well as the sheets that&#010;&gt;&gt;     are to be populated&#010;&gt;&gt;   - Talks to Jira, using the Jira REST API, to do the query and extract&#010;&gt;&gt;     the results&#010;&gt;&gt;   - Exports a new excel file populated with the query results&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The Jar-file resides in a plexus archive, so I thought that having a&#010;&gt;&gt; small maven project, containing a pom.xml and the template excel&#010;&gt;&gt; spreadshet in src/main/resources/ would be a good match.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The idea was that I could:&#010;&gt;&gt;   - set the Jar-file containing the excel export code as a dependency&#010;&gt;&gt;   - use exec-maven-plugin to run the Jar&#010;&gt;&gt;   - have the output of exec-maven-plugin (an excel file) as the build&#010;&gt;&gt;     artifact&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; But the idea stopped on that I don't know what packaging should be used&#010;&gt;&gt; for the pom: "jar" didn't seem appropriate, so I tried "pom", but that&#010;&gt;&gt; doesn't do anything (no target directory created).&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Is maven appropriate for what I'm trying to do? Is there an appropriate&#010;&gt;&gt; packaging to use?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; - Steinar&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-Re: What packaging for Jira excel reports with maven?
contents:- Or ivy if you want dependency resolution&#010;On Apr 2, 2014 7:59 AM, "Ron Wheeler" &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;&#010;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Looks like something that ANT might be good at.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt; On 02/04/2014 6:58 AM, Anders Hammar wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I categorize different usage of Maven into two categories:&#010;&gt;&gt; A) As a build tool&#010;&gt;&gt; B) As a utility tool&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; A) would be for example building a Java web application, i.e. using the&#010;&gt;&gt; full build lifecycle of Maven. B) on the other hand is where you just want&#010;&gt;&gt; to do one specific "thing", for example generate Java classes from an xml&#010;&gt;&gt; schema or creating a jar of existing Java classes.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; So the first question is if your usage would fit into A or B? If so, it would be A. If you're just trying to find a tool&#010;&gt;&gt; to generate this excel file on demand, we would be in B.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; My point here is that if you're in category A then Maven is absolutely&#010;&gt;&gt; appropriate. At least if you're building everything else with Maven. But&#010;&gt;&gt; if&#010;&gt;&gt; you're in category B, then Maven is just one of many options you have. I&#010;&gt;&gt; would even go as far as saying that there are simpler solutions, one being&#010;&gt;&gt; a shell script (or Windows batch file) where you just have you Java&#010;&gt;&gt; command&#010;&gt;&gt; with the jar on the classpath and the options to have the excel file&#010;&gt;&gt; generated. Using Maven here would just add an additional dependency (to&#010;&gt;&gt; Maven) which could just complicate things.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; My two cents,&#010;&gt;&gt; /Anders&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On Tue, Apr 1, 2014 at 2:05 PM, Steinar Bang &lt;sb@dod.no&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  I have access to a Jar-file that contains code that:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;   - Reads an excel file containing a JQL query, the names of the fields&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     from the JQL results to include in excel, as well as the sheets that&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     are to be populated&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;   - Talks to Jira, using the Jira REST API, to do the query and extract&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     the results&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;   - Exports a new excel file populated with the query results&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; The Jar-file resides in a plexus archive, so I thought that having a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; small maven project, containing a pom.xml and the template excel&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; spreadshet in src/main/resources/ would be a good match.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; The idea was that I could:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;   - set the Jar-file containing the excel export code as a dependency&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;   - use exec-maven-plugin to run the Jar&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;   - have the output of exec-maven-plugin (an excel file) as the build&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     artifact&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; But the idea stopped on that I don't know what packaging should be used&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; for the pom: "jar" didn't seem appropriate, so I tried "pom", but that&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; doesn't do anything (no target directory created).&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Is maven appropriate for what I'm trying to do? Is there an appropriate&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; packaging to use?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; - Steinar&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; President&#010;&gt; Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt; email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt; phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-Re: [fixed] Correct way to include aggregated javadocs in subproject assembly?
contents:- On Tue, 1 Apr 2014 19:48:14 +0000&#010;&lt;org.apache.maven.user@io7m.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Noone does this?&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Here's a small example that reproduces the issue:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; https://github.com/io7m/maven-javadoc-bug-20140401&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; $ mvn -C clean package&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; The javadoc:aggregate goal runs as part of the docs project, but no&#010;&gt; javadoc is produced.&#010;&#010;It seems that I actually want the javadoc:javadoc goal, which is the&#010;opposite of what the documentation suggests. Name  :- eugene &lt;eugen.ra...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Scanning for Projects... before
contents:- I want to delete a directory from local repo before building a multi-module&#010;project. &#010;I wrote a plugin for that and the directory get deleted indeed, but it gets&#010;deleted too late.&#010;&#010;What I mean: my project "Project" has a dependency "com.test" that is not&#010;present in local repo. I run mvn clean install. What happens is that maven&#010;is scanning for projects and all the dependencies that it needs, downloading&#010;them (I guess though artifact resolver) to my local repo. Then my plugin is&#010;hooked to the "pre-clean" phase and it removes the directory&#010;".m2/repository/com". Now when "Project" actually needs dependency&#010;"com.test" for the compile, this dependency is not present (my plugin&#010;removed it) and maven fails.&#010;&#010;Why do I have such a weird case? Imagine I have releases artifacts that&#010;actually do not change their version, but do change their contents. Maven&#010;will not update my local repo unless their are snapshots, right? Well&#010;snapshot is not an option right now (due to corporate things).&#010;&#010;That is why I first need to remove "com.test" then kick in the artifact&#010;resolver.&#010;&#010;Thank you,&#010;Eugene.&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Scanning-for-Projects-before-tp5790393p5790400.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Christian Domsch &lt;m...@landrus.de&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Scanning for Projects... before
contents:- Well, I think maven is the wrong thing to solve this here, since you &#010;clearly use maven in a non intended way. In a CI setup, that would be a &#010;build task before the maven task would be called.&#010;Christian&#010;On 02.04.2014 16:09, eugene wrote:&#010;&gt; I want to delete a directory from local repo before building a multi-module&#010;&gt; project.&#010;&gt; I wrote a plugin for that and the directory get deleted indeed, but it gets&#010;&gt; deleted too late.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; What I mean: my project "Project" has a dependency "com.test" that is not&#010;&gt; present in local repo. I run mvn clean install. What happens is that maven&#010;&gt; is scanning for projects and all the dependencies that it needs, downloading&#010;&gt; them (I guess though artifact resolver) to my local repo. Then my plugin is&#010;&gt; hooked to the "pre-clean" phase and it removes the directory&#010;&gt; ".m2/repository/com". Now when "Project" actually needs dependency&#010;&gt; "com.test" for the compile, this dependency is not present (my plugin&#010;&gt; removed it) and maven fails.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Why do I have such a weird case? Imagine I have releases artifacts that&#010;&gt; actually do not change their version, but do change their contents. Maven&#010;&gt; will not update my local repo unless their are snapshots, right? Well&#010;&gt; snapshot is not an option right now (due to corporate things).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; That is why I first need to remove "com.test" then kick in the artifact&#010;&gt; resolver.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thank you,&#010;&gt; Eugene.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Scanning-for-Projects-before-tp5790393p5790400.html&#010;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Christian Domsch &lt;m...@landrus.de&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Scanning for Projects... before
contents:- Have you tried creating a dependency for you rproject, that does that &#010;deleting? If I am not mistaken, dependencies should be downloaded (or &#010;attempted to download) for every project in a reactor run. So lets say &#010;your project is P and the newly introduced project is M then it would &#010;look like:&#010;&#010;/-+-M (deletes com.test in any of its goals...)&#010;   |&#010;   +-P has dependency on com.test and M&#010;&#010;Christian&#010;&#010;&#010;On 02.04.2014 16:14, eugene wrote:&#010;&gt; I could not agree more if only I had a choice :) Thx for the comment&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Scanning-for-Projects-before-tp5790393p5790402.html&#010;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;

My plugin is actually &#010;inside the maven's super pom from maven-model-builder jar&#010;And it gets invoked once per project (even if there are multiple modules)&#010;&#010;I actually wanted a solution that will not trigger any changes in my poms..&#010;&#010;On 4/2/14, 5:20 PM, Christian Domsch [via Maven] wrote:&#010;&gt; Have you tried creating a dependency for you rproject, that does that&#010;&gt; deleting? Name  :- Christian Domsch &lt;m...@landrus.de&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Scanning for Projects... before
contents:- And I think here is the problem. As far as I understand maven, what &#010;happens with your setup is that maven recognizes the dependency to &#010;com.test, then you delete it, after that maven treis to use it e.g. in &#010;the compile step which leads to the error. And the reason is that &#010;through your setup you call it everytime a project is run in the reactor.&#010;&#010;What I meant, is that you create a regular project, through dependency &#010;mechanisms ensure that it is the very first project to be run (probably &#010;multiple ways to achieve that) and so the deletion of com.test is only &#010;attempted once. Every other project afterwards should then try to &#010;download the plugin because it is not found in the local repo.&#010;&#010;Maybe may way is flawed as well, since my idea suggests that each &#010;project scans the repo uncached.&#010;&#010;Christian&#010;&#010;On 02.04.2014 16:25, eugene wrote:&#010;&gt; Well.. there are a lot of projects like this.. My plugin is actually&#010;&gt; inside the maven's super pom from maven-model-builder jar&#010;&gt; And it gets invoked once per project (even if there are multiple modules)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I actually wanted a solution that will not trigger any changes in my poms..&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 4/2/14, 5:20 PM, Christian Domsch [via Maven] wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; Have you tried creating a dependency for you rproject, that does that&#010;&gt;&gt; deleting? If I am not mistaken, dependencies should be downloaded (or&#010;&gt;&gt; attempted to download) for every project in a reactor run. So lets say&#010;&gt;&gt; your project is P and the newly introduced project is M then it would&#010;&gt;&gt; look like:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; /-+-M (deletes com.test in any of its goals...)&#010;&gt;&gt;     |&#010;&gt;&gt;     +-P has dependency on com.test and M&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Christian&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 02.04.2014 16:14, eugene wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I could not agree more if only I had a choice :) Thx for the comment&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; --&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; View this message in context:&#010;&gt;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Scanning-for-Projects-before-tp5790393p5790402.html&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: [hidden email]&#010;&gt;&gt; &lt;/user/SendEmail.jtp?type=node&amp;node=5790403&amp;i=0&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Name  :- Curtis Rueden &lt;ctrue...@wisc.edu&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Scanning for Projects... before
contents:- Hi Eugene,&#010;&#010;&gt; Imagine I have releases artifacts that actually do not change their&#010;&gt; version, but do change their contents. Maven will not update my local&#010;&gt; repo unless their are snapshots, right? Well snapshot is not an option&#010;&gt; right now (due to corporate things).&#010;&#010;It is one of Maven's cardinal assumptions that release versions are&#010;immutable. If you need different contents, use either: A) a different&#010;version string every time something changes; or B) a SNAPSHOT version. This&#010;mutability is the entire purpose of snapshots, and what differentiates them&#010;from release versions.&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;Curtis&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Apr 2, 2014 at 9:09 AM, eugene &lt;eugen.rabii@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I want to delete a directory from local repo before building a multi-module&#010;&gt; project.&#010;&gt; I wrote a plugin for that and the directory get deleted indeed, but it gets&#010;&gt; deleted too late.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; What I mean: my project "Project" has a dependency "com.test" that is not&#010;&gt; present in local repo. I run mvn clean install. What happens is that maven&#010;&gt; is scanning for projects and all the dependencies that it needs,&#010;&gt; downloading&#010;&gt; them (I guess though artifact resolver) to my local repo. Then my plugin is&#010;&gt; hooked to the "pre-clean" phase and it removes the directory&#010;&gt; ".m2/repository/com". Now when "Project" actually needs dependency&#010;&gt; "com.test" for the compile, this dependency is not present (my plugin&#010;&gt; removed it) and maven fails.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Why do I have such a weird case? Imagine I have releases artifacts that&#010;&gt; actually do not change their version, but do change their contents. Maven&#010;&gt; will not update my local repo unless their are snapshots, right? Well&#010;&gt; snapshot is not an option right now (due to corporate things).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; That is why I first need to remove "com.test" then kick in the artifact&#010;&gt; resolver.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thank you,&#010;&gt; Eugene.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context:&#010;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Scanning-for-Projects-before-tp5790393p5790400.html&#010;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Wayne Fay &lt;wayne...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Scanning for Projects... before
contents:- &gt;&gt; repo unless their are snapshots, right? Well snapshot is not an option&#010;&gt;&gt; right now (due to corporate things).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; It is one of Maven's cardinal assumptions that release versions are&#010;&gt; immutable. If you need different contents, use either: A) a different&#010;&#010;As Curtis already mentioned, you are unlikely to find a solution by&#010;continuing to head in this direction. Find another approach - most&#010;likely one that involves a process running outside of Maven before&#010;your build kicks off.&#010;&#010;Wayne&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;
Subject  :-Re: Scanning for Projects... before
contents:- There is a *very* hacky way... I hesitate to suggest it... but as you seem&#010;stuck!&#010;&#010;Your "delete" mojo can take a wander through the dependency tree and record&#010;the details of all dependencies from the tree that will be affected by the&#010;deleting. You will need to do this for the entire set of reactor projects.&#010;You will need to do this only when you are the first reactor project in the&#010;reactor... for all other projects you will just do a no-op and return&#010;immediately.&#010;&#010;Then you do the delete.&#010;&#010;Then you request resolution of all the dependencies that were deleted, and&#010;you tell Maven to force the resolution (i.e. ignore the internal state that&#010;says it downloaded them already) There is a flag you can set that will do&#010;the forcing... but as this is an unrecommended HACK, you shall have to find&#010;that flag yourself.&#010;&#010;Thus when you mojo is finished executing, Maven's internal state that says&#010;it downloaded these dependencies already will be consistent with the&#010;on-disk state (because the files are present) and all will be right with&#010;the world.&#010;&#010;Beware! There be dragons!&#010;&#010;Dragon 1: If any of the dependencies you re-download have a different&#010;dependency list... you will be burned&#010;&#010;Dragon 2: If any of the dependencies you re-download have a dependency&#010;within the reactor... you will be burned&#010;&#010;There are more dragons... and you may find the rug pulled out from under&#010;you if you upgrade Maven...&#010;&#010;Beware!&#010;&#010;&#010;On 4 April 2014 07:55, eugene &lt;eugen.rabii@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I think we have found one...&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We can create a wrapper around MavenCli and replace it in m2.conf...&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 4/2/14, 8:35 PM, Wayne Fay [via Maven] wrote:&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; repo unless their are snapshots, right? Well snapshot is not an option&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; right now (due to corporate things).&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; It is one of Maven's cardinal assumptions that release versions are&#010;&gt; &gt; &gt; immutable. If you need different contents, use either: A) a different&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; As Curtis already mentioned, you are unlikely to find a solution by&#010;&gt; &gt; continuing to head in this direction. Find another approach - most&#010;&gt; &gt; likely one that involves a process running outside of Maven before&#010;&gt; &gt; your build kicks off.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Wayne&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: [hidden email]&#010;&gt; &gt; &lt;/user/SendEmail.jtp?type=node&amp;node=5790420&amp;i=0&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; For additional commands, e-mail: [hidden email]&#010;&gt; &gt; &lt;/user/SendEmail.jtp?type=node&amp;node=5790420&amp;i=1&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt; If you reply to this email, your message will be added to the&#010;&gt; &gt; discussion below:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Scanning-for-Projects-before-tp5790393p5790420.html&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; To unsubscribe from Scanning for Projects... before, click here&#010;&gt; &gt; &lt;&#010;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/template/NamlServlet.jtp?macro=unsubscribe_by_code&amp;node=5790393&amp;code=ZXVnZW4ucmFiaWlAZ21haWwuY29tfDU3OTAzOTN8MTA1NjEzNjg3MA==&#010;&gt; &gt;.&#010;&gt; &gt; NAML&#010;&gt; &gt; &lt;&#010;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/template/NamlServlet.jtp?macro=macro_viewer&amp;id=instant_html%21nabble%3Aemail.naml&amp;base=nabble.naml.namespaces.BasicNamespace-nabble.view.web.template.NabbleNamespace-nabble.view.web.template.NodeNamespace&amp;breadcrumbs=notify_subscribers%21nabble%3Aemail.naml-instant_emails%21nabble%3Aemail.naml-send_instant_email%21nabble%3Aemail.naml&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; View this message in context:&#010;&gt; http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Scanning-for-Projects-before-tp5790393p5790474.html&#010;&gt; Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- Mark Eggers &lt;its_toas...@yahoo.com&gt;
Subject  :-Enforcer plugin
contents:- Folks,&#010;&#010;I've gotten my classifier artifact to build and install in our local &#010;repository. Specifying the classifier gets the appropriate artifact, and &#010;removing the classifier gets the [other] appropriate artifact.&#010;&#010;Now I'm a bit paranoid that the artifact with the classifier will leak &#010;out into other releases, so I thought I would write an enforcer rule.&#010;&#010;I thought that the following would work:&#010;&#010;&lt;bannedDependencies&gt;&#010;     &lt;excludes&gt;&#010;         &lt;exclude&gt;org.mdeggers:*:*:*:*:DEBUG&lt;/exclude&gt;&#010;     &lt;/excludes&gt;&#010;&lt;/bannedDependencies&gt;&#010;&#010;based on:&#010;&#010;http://maven.apache.org/enforcer/enforcer-rules/bannedDependencies.html&#010;&#010;While this certainly blocked the following dependency:&#010;&#010;&lt;dependency&gt;&#010;     &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;     &lt;artifactId&gt;SampleBuild&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;     &lt;version&gt;1.5&lt;/version&gt;&#010;     &lt;type&gt;war&lt;/type&gt;&#010;     &lt;classifier&gt;DEBUG&lt;/classifier&gt;&#010;&lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&#010;with the message:&#010;Found Banned Dependency: org.mdeggers:SampleBuild:war:DEBUG:1.5&#010;&#010;It also blocked the following dependency:&#010;&#010;&lt;dependency&gt;&#010;     &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;     &lt;artifactId&gt;SampleBuild&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;     &lt;version&gt;1.5&lt;/version&gt;&#010;     &lt;type&gt;war&lt;/type&gt;&#010;&lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&#010;with the message:&#010;Found Banned Dependency: org.mdeggers:SampleBuild:war:1.5&#010;&#010;This I did not expect. The messages are also a bit suspect in that they &#010;don't match the pattern given in the documentation.&#010;&#010;I looked on JIRA and found the following (based on another thread):&#010;&#010;http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MENFORCER-74&#010;http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MENFORCER-75&#010;http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MENFORCER-72&#010;&#010;These are all closed with a 'fixed' designation for release 1.3.&#010;&#010;I'm using version 1.3.1&#010;&#010;However, I briefly looked at the code here:&#010;&#010;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/maven/enforcer/tags/enforcer-1.3.1/enforcer-rules/src/main/java/org/apache/maven/plugins/enforcer/BannedDependencies.java?revision=1502671&amp;view=markup&#010;&#010;and classifier does not seem to have made it in.&#010;&#010;Have I walked through this correctly? If so, is there a fix (other than &#010;not using classifiers, or just hoping that a DEBUG classifier doesn't &#010;make it into a release)?&#010;&#010;Thanks,&#010;Mark&#010;&#010;/mde/&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-Re: Enforcer plugin
contents:- On 4/2/2014 5:25 PM, Mark Eggers wrote:&#010;&gt; Folks,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I've gotten my classifier artifact to build and install in our local&#010;&gt; repository. Specifying the classifier gets the appropriate artifact, and&#010;&gt; removing the classifier gets the [other] appropriate artifact.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Now I'm a bit paranoid that the artifact with the classifier will leak&#010;&gt; out into other releases, so I thought I would write an enforcer rule.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I thought that the following would work:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;bannedDependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;excludes&gt;&#010;&gt;          &lt;exclude&gt;org.mdeggers:*:*:*:*:DEBUG&lt;/exclude&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;/excludes&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;/bannedDependencies&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; based on:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/enforcer/enforcer-rules/bannedDependencies.html&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; While this certainly blocked the following dependency:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;artifactId&gt;SampleBuild&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;version&gt;1.5&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;type&gt;war&lt;/type&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;classifier&gt;DEBUG&lt;/classifier&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; with the message:&#010;&gt; Found Banned Dependency: org.mdeggers:SampleBuild:war:DEBUG:1.5&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; It also blocked the following dependency:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;groupId&gt;org.mdeggers&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;artifactId&gt;SampleBuild&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;version&gt;1.5&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;      &lt;type&gt;war&lt;/type&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;/dependency&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; with the message:&#010;&gt; Found Banned Dependency: org.mdeggers:SampleBuild:war:1.5&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; This I did not expect. The messages are also a bit suspect in that they&#010;&gt; don't match the pattern given in the documentation.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I looked on JIRA and found the following (based on another thread):&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MENFORCER-74&#010;&gt; http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MENFORCER-75&#010;&gt; http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MENFORCER-72&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; These are all closed with a 'fixed' designation for release 1.3.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'm using version 1.3.1&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; However, I briefly looked at the code here:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/maven/enforcer/tags/enforcer-1.3.1/enforcer-rules/src/main/java/org/apache/maven/plugins/enforcer/BannedDependencies.java?revision=1502671&amp;view=markup&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; and classifier does not seem to have made it in.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Have I walked through this correctly? If so, is there a fix (other than&#010;&gt; not using classifiers, or just hoping that a DEBUG classifier doesn't&#010;&gt; make it into a release)?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks,&#010;&gt; Mark&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; /mde/&#010;&#010;Works with 2.0-SNAPSHOT of the maven enforcer plugin.&#010;&#010;/mde/&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

contents:- Not sure I understand: did you use a standard rule or did you finally write&#010;&amp; use your own one? If the latter, seing the code somewhere may help.
